fields.headline: Bullish Houllier charged up for win
fields.trailText: As Liverpool continue their bid for a first European trophy since 1984, Gerard Houllier reckons his players have the bit between their teeth for goals after their frustrating but disciplined showing at Nou Camp.
fields.body:
The pre-match promise of goals galore may have rung hollow in the torpor of the first leg, but Liverpool welcome Barcelona to Anfield tonight hoping to justify that night's spoiling tactics by claiming the spoils themselves.

That encounter at Nou Camp had Catalans grumbling themselves to sleep. It is 25 years since Barcelona last visited Merseyside - a 1-1 draw in the Uefa Cup semi-final saw the Reds through 2-1 on aggregate - yet if the Anfield trophy cabinet is to house continental silverware for the first time since 1984, this follow-up must be better than a score draw.

"This is a final to qualify for a final and my team will not let me down," said Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier. With the dust still settling after a raucous Merseyside derby on Monday, few would disagree.

Yet the repercussions of their cagey defensive showing a fortnight ago continue to rile the Spanish media, who grilled Houllier yesterday as if becoming only the third team to keep a clean sheet at Nou Camp this season was something of which to be ashamed. "We need to score goals; we know that," he said. "They were not happy about the way we played, but they should take that as a compliment. The boys were disciplined and kept to the team plan.

"We may not have Barcelona's experience or their record, but we are an exciting team and are progressing all the time. Thanks to the previous generation of players, and there are about 20 commentating every week, the club has acquired a reputation all over the world. But this team has had a good season and they are trying to make a name for themselves.

"We must avoid a repeat of the scenario we had against Derby and Leeds, when we started sloppily. We have big-game players and they couldn't have had a better preparation than at Goodison. That win could be a catalyst."

The unreal nature of the goalless tie has been highlighted by Barca's recent form, relying on last-minute equalisers to salvage 4-4 draws against Villarreal and Real Zaragoza. Their forward line and soft underbelly suggest a repeat of the Nou Camp tedium is unlikely, although only Besiktas have contained the Spaniards on their travels, beating them 2-0 in the first phase of the Champions League.

"Perhaps Anfield can become a Turkish ground," said Houllier, who hopes to include Steven Gerrard after the midfielder underwent a fitness test yesterday. "On their day they can be awesome and they have probably one of the best attacking quartets in Europe. They won't change their philosophy, but I know they are concerned about us. Their officials told me in Barcelona that they felt they needed a 2-0 lead to bring to Anfield."

For their part Barcelona hope to thrive in the extra space as Liverpool loosen the defensive shackles. "They're going to have to take more risks this time," said the defender Carles Puyol. "Losing just doesn't enter into our plans. We're going to Liverpool to win and get through to the final."

That showcase in Dortmund will be played on Rivaldo's birthday. The Brazilian's immediate future appears to be in Catalonia; the Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti had a bid turned down for the 28-year-old after the first leg.

And as if the tie needed any added spice, Houllier provided it by declaring an interest in the Barca captain Josep Guardiola, who will be leaving under the Bosman ruling in the summer. "He is someone I respect and admire," said Liverpool's manager. "He is outstanding. We are interested in every good player who becomes available if they can strengthen our squad."

Yesterday Gazzetto Dello Sport reported that Guardiola has signed a provisional agreement to join Parma on a four-year deal worth £1.4m a season if they qualify for one of Italy's four Champions League berths. However it added that Guardiola can pull out of the agreement if a more lucrative offer arrives from England.

Liverpool (4-4-2 probable): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Murphy, Gerrard, Hamann, Berger; Owen, Heskey.

Barcelona (4-2-3-1 probable): Reina; Gabri, Puyol, De Boer, Sergi; Guardiola, Cocu; Luis Enrique, Rivaldo, Overmars; Kluivert.

webTitle: One lost night and a thousand glittering memories

fields.headline: One lost night and a thousand glittering memories
fields.trailText: The deaths this week of Jim Baxter and Alec Stock were announced in the obits section, but those solemn words told only half the story of these two magnificent men.
fields.body:
The deaths this week of Jim Baxter and Alec Stock - two totally different, but each genuinely immortal, football characters - were announced in the obits section at due deserving length and gravity, but that page's metaphorical black edging prefers the minimum of rainbow colours to intrude.

The Oldie magazine has a regular feature, "I Once Met", in which a reader records the single occasion in a humdrum context on which they encountered a person of undoubted and illustrious celebrity. I always reckon I would, if asked, relate the night I spent with Jim Baxter.

Around 30 years ago, we were of an age and Baxter, portly on over-indulgence even then and on the point of retirement from Rangers and football, was in London for some sponsors' presentation, after which we found ourselves in a cheery pub halfway up Haverstock Hill with a generous, awestruck Scottish landlord and a night to kill.

We killed it for sure - Jim did not really know me from Adam, but he matched my pints with what seemed like ditto lashings of vodka - and we woke up on a bench in Regent's Park, whence we rolled down, arm in arm with a bleary gaiety, through the crisp metropolitan dawn to King's Cross station, where, each of us vowing undying friendship, I waved him off on the Glasgow train.

Never, of course, to see him again. From afar, mind you, I had seen him all right in his beauteous prime. Not at Wembley in 1963 when Slim Jim's two goals beat England, but four years later when his Scots came down seething still at England's World Cup win the year before.

Now Baxter's audacious and brazen natural-born swagger and virtuosity taunted Bobby Moore's home side almost to humiliation. He played them as a show-off uncle might with a six-year-old nephew on the beach. Scotland won 3-2, but they could have had six. Denis Law said: "We could have given them a real good torching, but Jim just wanted to shame and demean them, tip-tap and fanny around them to make them look idiots."

Which he did, outrageously, unforgettably - even to inspire a different sort of rhapsody from the poet Alan Sharp: "If folklore is your thing, it will be clear that what Scotsmen value most is what Baxter had, they value the completely held conviction of their own superiority. On a football field, he just walked about as though encased in the interior certainty that he was better than the whole lot of them ... the hen-toed saunter, the socks crumpled, the florid, gallus expression - and he actually plays keepie-uppie at Wembley and I could feel myself gasp at him, at his sense of theatre, his exact awareness of how we Scots felt about beating the English, beating them bastards 3-2 and tanner ba'ing it, that's perfection."

No footballer's fortunes then. Doing his next best thing, Baxter bought a pub. A dozen years or so ago in Glasgow, a taxi-driver pointed out "our Jim's" pub, an unkempt front just down the road from his Ibrox, but I thought better of popping in even for a dram - "and a large one f'y'self, mine merry host" - and reminding him of our fraternally long (and lost) London night 20 years before.

It was already enough for me to hoard the soaring panegyric from the writer Richard Brentnall: "To see Jim now as he pulled pints for customers, his ruddy complexion and the way his flesh sagged over his belt ... Living proof we're all mere mortals, and if we bestow saintliness upon others then that's not their fault." Mind you, in that litany of football saints, Jim Baxter will forever remain an archangel.

Just a month before Baxter's 1967 defining resplendence, at that same London stadium another miner's son - this one from the Somerset coalfield who became a wartime tank commander - had marched his Third Division Queens Park Rangers to win, outrageously, the League Cup at Wembley.

Eight years later, Alec Stock had also taken (then) little Fulham to the 1975 FA Cup final. I got to relish and savour his convivial courtesies in that period. He had first made his name in 1949 by inventing the idea of a daunting "slope" at Southern Leaguers Yeovil Town - and had himself photographed by the Daily Graphic lying on the centre circle squinting at a tilting spirit-level - and frightening Bury and mighty Sunderland into still legendary defeats.

Alec was manager to such maestros as Bobby Moore, Malcolm Macdonald, Alan Mullery and Rodney Marsh - and, briefly, George Best. They all remained fondly devoted to him.

In Yeovil last year, at Alec's 83rd birthday dinner, Marsh was guest of honour. He told how he had once asked Alec's advice on being offered the lead story by the People to complain that he should be playing for England. "Don't you dare, Rodders," warned Stock. "If you do, Alf Ramsey will never even consider you."

The following Sunday, Rodney grinned as he read the People's screaming banner headline: "Marsh must play for England demands Stock".

fields.headline: Shortages pump up fuel costs
fields.standfirst:
Motorists face a summer of discontent as filling stations around the country raise their prices

Special report:Petrol
fields.trailText: Motorists face a summer of discontent as filling stations around the country raise their prices
fields.body:
Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, which operates Q8 stations, was among those following Shell's lead yesterday by slapping 1p on the price of petrol. By the weekend, most, if not all, are expected to react to the steep jump in crude oil prices from $25 (£17.5) a barrel on average late last week to $29 yesterday.

"Over the next couple of days, prices will go up by 1p or 2p a litre and, in the face of an election, the government can do nothing about it," said Jonathan Akerman of the Petroleum Retailers Association. "Prices will do what they want between now and early June."

The motoring lobby is clamouring for government action while some of September's fuel protesters are limbering up for a re-run. Garry Russell, of the Dump the Pump campaign, blames the government for a "horrendous" situation. Taxes on fuel are the highest in Europe but cuts made by the chancellor in his March budget have all but been wiped out by the latest fuel price rises.

The latest trouble has been triggered from outside these shores, most notably through a round of production cuts imposed by oil cartrel Opec on April 1. The US, faced with shortages, is hoovering up surpluses from elsewhere in the world.

The prevailing view among experts yesterday was that the fire and subsequent two to three week shutdown at the Conoco refinery on Humberside would have a negligible effect on prices.

"The central issue is the lack of product," said Leo Drollas, chief economist of the Saudi-backed Centre for Global Energy Studies. "Killingholme produced some 230,000 barrels a day, half of it is exported - mainly to the US, which takes 80,000 in gasoline."

The Conoco refinery accounts for 8% of Britain's supplies, but it was due for an annual shutdown for maintenance checks.

In the US, where the "driving season" (holidays) takes place in June, insatiable and growing demand for gas has bumped up imports and, with them, global prices.

According to Mr Drollas, the US now has just 23 days cover for petrol on average and 19 days for crude; a systemic failure would leave the world's biggest economy dangerously short. The US has not built a new refinery for 25 years despite rising demand.

He expects prices for Brent crude to stay at about $25 this summer before rising to $28 on average in the fourth quarter - if Opec retains its cuts.

"Because of the tightening in the US the Americans are siphoning any surplus supplies and bidding up prices. The arbitrageurs move in and this pushes up prices in Europe," Mr Drollas said. US imports amount to the same as at least three Killingholme-style refineries.

Drivers in Britain could expect an extra 1p or 2p a litre but the rise will be temporary. Unless, of course, the Middle East crisis blows up into a full scale war.

That would propel prices at the pump way beyond the peak national average of 82.15p (for unleaded) seen last June, and certainly far above the present 74.3p or the 72.4p seen immediately after the chancellor's Budget cut in excise duties.

Government action

Global explanations for higher prices cut little ice with the British motoring organisations. And the Conservatives were quick to make political capital out of the situation. Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo said figures out this week showed the poorest families were being hardest hit under Labour, after Gordon Brown increased taxes like petrol duty paid by everyone.

"It is Labour's stealth taxes that have given Britain's motorists the highest petrol prices in Europe. Conservatives will cut petrol tax and offer some relief to the hard-working families who have to pay too much to the Government every time they fill their tank," he explained.

The RAC and AA renewed their calls for government action to reduce taxation, which makes British car owners pay more for fuel than anyone else in Europe.

Edmund King, executive director of the RAC, said he was seeking a meeting with the government to call for stable fuel prices through the introduction of a sliding scale of duty, which would fluctuate with world prices.

"The last thing the UK needs is more fuel protests on top of the foot and mouth crisis. Our economic model shows that the government could stabilise fuel prices without losing revenue. Some motorists may be tempted to vote with their wheels."

The Road Haulage Association (RHA) had the same message for Downing Street. RHA spokeswoman Kate Hill said foot and mouth was already hitting the business of its 9,500 trucking company members. "Someone seems determined to drive the haulage industry out of business," she said. But a Treasury spokesman said the government had made considerable concessions, and he ruled out any other short-term fix. "Tax decisions are set at the Budget, taking account of the government's economic and social objectives, and environmental commitments. "The 2001 Budget provided a package of £1.5bn for the motorist, including a duty freeze, reductions in ultra-low sulphur petrol and diesel, aimed at promoting cheaper, cleaner motoring."

There is no doubt that prices will rise further. Exxon Mobil's British arm Esso, which increased its prices on April 6 along with BP and others, would not rule out further upwards movements on the forecourt.

A spokeswoman said: "Our retail price strategy is governed by Pricewatch, where we monitor fuel prices at supermarkets within three miles and other service stations within a mile of participating Esso stations.

"What we say is that prices will usually be among the lowest of those monitored."

TotalFinaElf, which operates 1,300 garages, said that it was not implementing an across-the-board wholesale price increase.

But a company spokesman said some retail outlets would put up prices in response to competitors' actions.

Kuwait Petroleum said it had raised petrol prices by around one pence per litre at some of its Q8 branded forecourts in response to local price hikes introduced by its competitors.

"Where it's possible for us to remain competitive, we have put prices up in some areas," a Kuwait Petroleum spokesman said.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the supermarket chain Tesco said: "We moved our prices the week before last as a result of rises in world fuel prices - we had held them down for some time but could not sustain that. At the moment we are monitoring the situation."

BP said it had no further plans to increase at the current time. And there was some relief in the oil markets yesterday as prices fell after a series of data undermined their strength.

Prices lost almost half a dollar yesterday. Sentiment improved as crude stocks in the US were shown to have swollen by 7m barrels to the highest levels in 20 months.

Gasoline also took hefty losses of more than 1.5 cents a gallon, bringing prices down from Tuesday's nine-month peak. This followed a smaller than forecast reduction in inventories giving relief to concerns of a supply crunch in the summer.

London's Brent crude slipped 43 cents in early dealings to $27.20 a barrel, while the US benchmark light crude for May fell 79 cents to $27.45. This brought prices down in the last two days to over one dollar.

Industry body, the American Petroleum Institute, reported a 7.3m barrel increase in US crude stocks to 315.2m barrels.

Gasoline inventories remain more than 8m barrels below last year's thin levels when pump prices hit record highs.

Petrol production at Conoco's refinery on the Humber estuary is likely to be delayed for longer than expected because of the scale of damage to the plant, writes Martin Wainwright .

All production at the 480 acre site in South Killingholme, part of the Immingham port complex, has stopped, although some of the usual 200 tankers a day are still taking stockpiled fuel to filling stations. Conoco said that initial investigations had shown the apparent source of the explosion to be the saturate gas unit.

London's Brent crude slipped 43 cents in early dealings to $27.20 a barrel, while the US benchmark light crude for May fell 79 cents to $27.45. This brought prices down in the last two days to over one dollar. Industry body, the American Petroleum Institute, reported a 7.3m barrel increase in US crude stocks to 315.2m barrels. Gasoline inventories remain more than 8m barrels below last year's thin levels when pump prices hit record highs. Petrol production at Conoco's refinery on the Humber estuary is likely to be delayed for longer than expected because of the scale of damage to the plant, writes Martin Wainwright . All production at the 480 acre site in South Killingholme, part of the Immingham port complex, has stopped, although some of the usual 200 tankers a day are still taking stockpiled fuel to filling stations. Conoco said that initial investigations had shown the apparent source of the explosion to be the saturate gas unit.

fields.headline: Nationwide rejects conversion move
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Nationwide building society yesterday threw out a rebel member's conversion resolution, which means there will be no vote this year on whether it should turn itself into a bank and pay windfalls.
fields.body:
Nationwide building society yesterday threw out a rebel member's conversion resolution, which means there will be no vote this year on whether it should turn itself into a bank and pay windfalls.

Carpetbagger Andrew Muir had wanted Britain's biggest building society to convert and make payments he claimed could average between £700 and £1,000 to its 10m savers and borrowers.

The society said his resolution was legally invalid because it demanded changes to its system of forcing all new members to sign away their right to a windfall to charity.

But members will still indirectly be able to make their views heard on conversion as Nationwide has accepted Mr Muir's application to be allowed to stand for election to the board of directors at the annual meeting on July 19.

Nationwide said the board had taken legal advice on Mr Muir's conversion resolution and had decided it was "in conflict with the society's existing rules".

Mr Muir, 36, who runs a Berkshire recruitment firm, had told members via a website he set up that "this may be your only chance to claim a windfall that is rightfully yours".

Chairman Charles Nunneley said: "Mr Muir's resolution calls for the assignment of windfall gains to the Nationwide Foundation to be altered, and this cannot legally be done. Clearly we cannot ask our members to vote on resolutions which cannot be enacted were they to be passed."

fields.headline: How to beat the hackers
fields.standfirst: Although the internet serves as an excellent resource for investors, it is also a great tool for fraudsters. Marianne Curphey looks at how to use the web wisely
fields.trailText: Although the internet serves as an excellent resource for investors, it is also a great tool for fraudsters. Marianne Curphey looks at how to use the web wisely
fields.body:
One of the most common reasons people cite for not opening a bank account or share dealing account on the internet has to do with concerns for security. The launch yesterday of a hi-tech national police unit to tackle cyber-crime proves the police are taking such internet fraud seriously. Computer hackers have attacked at least four large internet banks in Britain, although, so far, no customer is known to have lost money. Banks are reluctant to report the thefts because of the fear of bad publicity.

While organised fraud is something only the police can tackle, there are steps that consumers can take to ensure their internet banking or share dealing is as secure as possible.

When you sign up with an online dealer they should tell you, under the Data Protection Act, whether they intend to pass your details on to a third party, and give you the option to deny the request to do so. They may or may not give you the option of being removed from mailing lists for information about their products and services.

Once signed up, you will be sent a confirmation of your username, which is the first bit of information you give when you log in. You also need to remember your password. Don't use the same password for several sites, and don't write it down. Try to construct a password that is not a recognisable word, and instead choose a list of letters and numbers that hold special significance for you.

When you go to a site and log in to a secure area, the location address at the top of the site should change.

The beginning of the address, which usually reads "http://" should change to "https://" to indicate you have switched into a protected zone.

If you are using Microsoft Internet Explorer or Netscape Navigator on a PC or Mac, a small padlock icon should appear in the bottom right-hand corner of your screen.

You have to use whatever internet defences there are, and ask companies about their compensation policy if thieves worm their way into secure areas.

Other measures you can take to help the banks and brokers:

 Change your password frequently. This is a difficult habit to get into but it is a good security measure.

 Log out when you have finished your session. Don't leave your computer terminal unattended while you are still logged on.

 Try not to let people look over your shoulder when you are conducting a transaction.

 Treat e-commerce as you would credit card transactions - don't hand out personal information and be sure you know whom you are dealing with.

 Keep a record of transactions. Most sites give you confirmation of this onscreen and you can print out the details. Others send you confirmation in the post.

 Beware of spelling mistakes when inputting the address of the website. Hackers can register common misspellings of well-known companies as domain names.

Marianne Curphey is the editor of Money and the author of E-cash, the complete guide to managing your money online. Find out how to control your own finances, search for a mortgage online, move bank accounts, submit your tax form online, invest in shares and find the best websites for financial information. webTitle: Share surge after US interest rate cut

fields.headline: Share surge after US interest rate cut
fields.standfirst: Share surge after US interest rate cut
fields.trailText: America's central bank, the Federal Reserve, last night surprised financial markets with its second emergency cut in interest rates this year as it sought to fend off the risk of a full-blown recession in the world's biggest economy.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
America's central bank, the Federal Reserve, last night surprised financial markets with its second emergency cut in interest rates this year as it sought to fend off the risk of a full-blown recession in the world's biggest economy.

Shares on Wall Street rose dramatically, with the Dow Jones index climbing more than 400 points. The technology-dominated Nasdaq index rose by almost 10% in the wake of the announcement that borrowing costs were being cut by 0.5 percentage points to 4.5% - the fourth cut this year.

Coming amid a wave of corporate profit warnings and layoffs, the move prompted speculation that the Bank of England would spearhead a reduction in European interest rates as early as next month, as part of an attempt to head off a global recession. The European Central Bank has so far resisted calls for it to boost growth by cutting rates in the euro zone.

Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry welcomed the US interest rate cut, saying: "This is a bold move and one that British business will welcome. With Japan in the doldrums and the ECB apparently not prepared to play its part, this action will ease fears of a prolonged slowdown in global growth and hopefully head off the storm clouds gathering over the US."

The news came within half an hour of the close of business in London, but the FTSE 100 staged a late surge to close up 129.1 points at 5890.2.

In a statement explaining the decision, the Fed said its move was prompted by lower investment, a weaker global outlook and falling share values. It said there was a risk that the economy would remain "unnacceptably weak".

However, recent economic figures suggesting that the US economy might be bottoming out after a pronounced slowdown had appeared to lengthen the odds on a cut in rates before the central bank's next scheduled meeting on the issue in late May.

This week the manufacturing sector reported higher-than-expected growth and the housing and employment data is still strong.

However, some analysts feared that the decision presaged as-yet unknown economic difficulties such as liquidity problems or over-exposure to bad debts.

Ian Shepherdson, the chief US economist at High Frequency Economics, said the cut "must also prompt the question of whether the Fed knows something we don't".

The chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, who presided over the economic boom of the 1990s, has come under fire for the sharpness of the economic slowdown over the past six months. Economists have criticised his failure to cut rates last year.

Art Hogan, the chief market analyst for Jefferies and Co, the US brokerage, said: "This cut should certainly improve his popularity. As for his reputation, it will go down in history as pretty untarnished."

The US economy grew at an annual rate of just 1% in the last quarter of 2000, the weakest performance in more than five years. Declines in the first three months of this year mean that the Fed is expected by many economists cut rates to as low as 4% this year.

In a cheerful note to investors, Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, the Wall Street bank, wrote: "We think the outlook for the market is pretty good."

fields.headline: Bond and Westlife create special effects
fields.trailText: James Bond and Changing Rooms have helped to push up the profits of Soho-based post film production company VTR, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
James Bond favourites like Live and Let Die and The Spy Who Loved Me, and popular television series such as Changing Rooms have helped to push up the profits of Soho-based post film production company VTR.

The firm, which adapted the Bond films for DVD and edited the video for the Westlife video My Love (above), handles post-production, editing and special effects for film-makers, television companies, record companies and the advertising industry.

"The demand we are seeing is for post-production services because of the enormous growth in the number of TV channels requiring content. The DVD market is also growing explosively," said John Banks, VTR's co-founder and chief executive.

VTR announced pre-tax profits for the six months to the end of February of £1.4m, up 21% from £1.15m for the same period last year. Turnover was £11.7m, up from £11m for the previous six months.

"All trading areas in the group have started the second half encouragingly and the board continues to view the future with considerable confidence," said Philip Lovegrove, VTR's chairman.

Clipstream, the group's encoding division, will be a big growth area for the company over the next three years. "We look at it as being another delivery medium," Mr Banks said.

VTR, whose customers include Lego, AOL and Disney, saw its shares rise 9p to 166.5p. The board is recommending an increased dividend of 2p.

webTitle: Internet users play it safe at work

fields.headline: Internet users play it safe at work
fields.trailText: Fewer than half of UK employees are using their office internet connections for personal use, but those that do spend an average of three hours a week surfing for non work-related sites, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
Fewer than half of UK employees are using their office internet connections for personal use, but those that do spend an average of three hours a week surfing for non work-related sites, according to a survey published today.

The survey should put employers at ease as researchers found most workers used the internet to book holidays, research their hobbies, shop or watch sporting events. Just 7% of workers had used an office connection to access adult-oriented material.

About two thirds of UK employees have internet access at work, and employers have been concerned about both time wasting and the potential for accessing pornography or race-hate material. Employees, on the other hand, are largely still dependent on office computers for their internet use.

Geoff Haggart, the vice president of Websense, the company that commissioned the survey, said: "The survey shows that the internet is clearly a valuable business tool for employees, but at the same time it can be a distraction. It also shows that companies need to strike a balance and be aware that employees do not object to having their internet access at work managed."

Researchers questioned 800 employees in France, Germany, Italy and the UK, and found that UK companies are the most aggressive when it comes to reprimanding staff for inappropriate use.

But internet analyst Graham Fisher, of Bloor Research, warns that monitoring and restricting online activity can alienate employees. The key, he said, is trust, and managers need to decide if the survey results justify intrusive measures to maintain control of employee web use.

Websense produces software that can report an employee's every online move back to a central database, which can then be scanned for "inappropriate" use by a network manager or by management. It is also used to block sites deemed unnecessary for corporate use, either for the whole day or just during working hours.

Mr Fisher said: "It's fair enough to have a degree of control, but UK management still has a control freak mentality. It's the same reason that working at home has not taken off, this mentality that a manager has to see bums on seats in front of desks.

"Three hours a week is 36 minutes a day. Some employees spend more time than smoking, and that is seen as acceptable," he added.

Websense commented that 71% of employees indicated they did not object to some form of management control of their surfing.

Mr Fisher said, "I would accept monitoring as long it was on the understanding that I will look at Amazon and my online bank account and that I am not going to be beaten over the head for that. But the majority of the companies I have seen have internet policies that simply ban surfing."

fields.headline: Tracy Moffat
fields.standfirst: Fruitmarket Gallery, Edinburgh ***
fields.trailText: Fruitmarket Gallery, Edinburgh ***
fields.body:
This is an exhibition of two halves: one thrilling, the other less so. On the ground floor, we see one of Tracy Moffatt's best-known works, the film Night Cries, alongside a recent series of large-scale photographic silk screens, Invocations. This juxtaposition works well, showing continuing concerns in the artist's work - the reality and the imaginative dimension of women's lives, filmic dreamworlds as backdrops to politically charged narratives, the interplay between gender, race and culture - and how her practice has changed.

The silk screens are formally more ambitious, almost tacky in their glossy richness of colour, and both melodramatic and terrifying in their iconography. The new work is playful in a way Night Cries is not, with its suffocating narrative of an Aboriginal woman forced to care for the aged white woman who adopted her as a child. Moving from the silk screens to the film and back again, you notice the deeply symbolic and intertextual nature of both works, as well as Moffatt's use of saturated colour and painterly composition.

In the upper gallery, there's no such revealing relationship, largely because of the rather lacklustre arrangement of the work. Two photographic series - Laudanum and Scarred for Life II - need a more intimate space; here they are arranged along two connecting walls, unproductively clashing with each other. Laudanum is a disturbing story, shot in a colonial mansion in Australia, of an Asian servant girl and her Victorian mistress. Shot like a Kate Bush video based on 19th-century photographs, it narrates a tale of submission, sexual violence, domination and finally murder in images that are at once melodramatic and politically charged.

Scarred for Life couldn't be more different: a series of reports from the frontline of suburban life as experienced by Moffatt and her friends growing up in Brisbane. In the style of those Time/Life books from the 1960s, the captions speak of dysfunction, brutality and comic misunderstandings below photographs exuding 1970s bad taste. But this upper gallery lacks atmosphere compared with the dimly lit evocative ground-floor space. Moffatt relies heavily on mood as well as polemic in her work; without it, it's a bit like trying to watch a film in a cinema with the lights up.

 Until May 19. Details: 0131-225 2383.

fields.headline: Investors hit at £5m bonus
fields.standfirst:
Schroders payout 'deserved'

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Peter Sedgwick, chairman of the Schroders financial group, was unrepentant yesterday about a £5m bonus for his predecessor even though shareholders registered an humiliating 40% protest vote against the controversial payment.
fields.body:
Peter Sedgwick, chairman of the Schroders financial group, was unrepentant yesterday about a £5m bonus for his predecessor even though shareholders registered an humiliating 40% protest vote against the controversial payment.

The £5m paid to Sir Win Bischoff prompted concern from shareholder groups but Mr Sedgwick insisted Sir Win deserved the bonus for his "highly delicate, skillful" negotiation of Schroders' sale of its investment banking business to Citigroup of the US last year.

Some 10% of shareholders registered votes against the payment to Sir Win - the largest dissenting vote of any of the resolutions before yesterday's annual general meeting which was attended by just a handful of shareholders.

However, the size of the opposition to the bonus reached 40% if the 45% of the votes controlled by the founding Schroder family are discounted. Resolutions at AGMs more usually attract large majority votes in support.

The chairman of Schroders' remuneration committee, William Turner, earlier told the meeting that Sir Win had presided over an "extraordinary" performance in the shares over the past decade, when they rose 1,000% against a 190% rise in the FTSE 100.

"I don't think we have any apologies for what we did," Mr Turner said at the brief meeting, where journalists almost outnumbered shareholders.

The £5m bonus for Sir Win, who has joined Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney investment banking division, prompted the Association of British Insurers to write in protest at the lack of justification for the payment.

It follows the controversy surrounding the £2.5m special bonuses paid to four executives of the Royal Bank of Scotland for their role in taking over NatWest last year.

Lord Hollick, chief executive of United News & Media, is also facing protests about a bonus for the sale of the group's television assets.

The ABI and the National Association of Pension Funds, whose members between them control 50% of the stock market, have been concerned about payments to reward senior executives for completing takeovers or mergers.

Mr Sedgwick said Schroders had listened to the views of shareholder groups and that the circumstances surrounding the payment to Sir Win were different to those which had prompted concern elsewhere.

He said the £5m was "not a payment for an acquisition or one that yet to be proven".

The sale of the investment banking business to Citigroup had already involved giving shareholders in Schroders some £900m, Mr Sedgwick said.

Lord Hollick, chief executive of United News & Media, is also facing protests about a bonus for the sale of the group's television assets. The ABI and the National Association of Pension Funds, whose members between them control 50% of the stock market, have been concerned about payments to reward senior executives for completing takeovers or mergers. Mr Sedgwick said Schroders had listened to the views of shareholder groups and that the circumstances surrounding the payment to Sir Win were different to those which had prompted concern elsewhere. He said the £5m was "not a payment for an acquisition or one that yet to be proven". The sale of the investment banking business to Citigroup had already involved giving shareholders in Schroders some £900m, Mr Sedgwick said.

fields.headline: US puts pressure on Europe
fields.standfirst:
Bank of England doves shown to be already pushing for a bigger interest rate cut

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Bank of England and the European Central Bank were coming under increasing pressure to cut borrowing costs yesterday, after the US federal reserve surprised the markets with its fourth cut in interest rates this year.
fields.body:
The Bank of England and the European Central Bank were coming under increasing pressure to cut borrowing costs yesterday, after the US federal reserve surprised the markets with its fourth cut in interest rates this year.

With evidence emerging yesterday that three members of the Bank's key rate setting committee were already pressing for a more aggressive stance from Threadneedle Street, dealers believe that the chances of monetary easing in Europe have increased after the US action.

The Federal Reserve's decision to cut borrowing costs by 0.5% to 4.5% came a month ahead of its next scheduled meeting. In its accompanying statement the Fed, chaired by Alan Greenspan, said it was responding to factors "threatening to keep the pace of economic activity unacceptably weak".

Fears that the US slowdown will spread across the Atlantic have already prompted the Bank of England to cut interest rates twice since January, but the ECB has yet to cut borrowing costs.

Minutes of this month's meeting of the Bank's monetary policy committee which cut rates to 5%, showed that all nine members supported lower borrowing costs. However Ian Plenderleith, the Bank's head of foreign exchange dealing joined Thread needle Street's resident doves, Sushil Wadhwani and DeAnne Julius in voting for a 0.5-point cut, rather than the 0.25 reduction favoured by the rest of the committee.

"This certainly increases the chance of a further rate cut," said Jeremy Hawkins, economist at Bank of America in London. "In fact, with the Fed now cutting rates again, it is probably enough to tilt the balance towards a cut next month."

A June move is thought unlikely because the Bank's monthly meeting coincides with the expected date for the general election. While Threadneedle Street has declared itself to be unaffected by the political calendar, few analysts think it would risk a changing rates in such a charged political environment.

The minutes reveal that all nine members of the MPC believe the prospects for the world economy had become gloomier since its last meeting and that there were clear signs that the US slowdown is beginning to affect the UK economy.

"Taken together with the short run effects on demand and supply from foot and mouth disease, the downside risks to UK growth this year had increased," the minutes noted.

Ross Walker, UK economist at RBS Financial Markets, said there had been a "significant mood shift" since last month's meeting. "Where in March the emphasis was on the resilience of demand and confidence, in April the MPC was far more exercised by the downside risks to the UK economy from the deteriorating global outlook and from foot and mouth disease," he said.

The Bank has plenty of room for maneouvre in its quest to insulate Britain from the stormy outlook for the global economy; inflation has been short of the government's target of 2.5% for nearly two years.

Yesterday's minutes underlined the risks posed to the British economy by the global slowdown.

webTitle: Corporate America takes a turn for the worse

fields.headline: Corporate America takes a turn for the worse
fields.trailText: A host of America's largest companies underlined the extent of the economic downturn yesterday when they reported earnings that were sharply down on a year ago and warned of difficult market conditions.
fields.body:
A host of America's largest companies underlined the extent of the economic downturn yesterday when they reported earnings that were sharply down on a year ago and warned of difficult market conditions.

Big consumer groups such as General Motors and Coca-Cola and financial firms JP Morgan Chase and Merrill Lynch were among those announcing sharp declines in profits in the last quarter. Their warnings came hours before the Federal Reserve cited the slowdown in corporate profits for its decision to cut rates for the fourth time this year.

The wave of disappointing earnings has also prompted many Wall Street analysts to downgrade their own fore casts for future growth in US stock markets. Abby Joseph Cohen, one of the equity market's most stalwart cheerleaders, finally cut her year-end price targets for two leading indices yesterday as part of an "annual spring clean-up".

Ms Cohen, the chief investment strategist at Goldman Sachs, admitted that her estimates for corporate earnings and stock market performance - promoted during a torrid year for both - were too high.

She downgraded her year-end price targets for the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 to 12,500 points and 1,550 points respectively. Even after yesterday's strong Fed-inspired rally, both indices are trading well below these levels. After the Fed's last rate cut less than a month ago, Ms Cohen penned an ode to the "mighty Alan" Greenspan in an attempt to cheer nervous investors.

Ms Cohen continues to believe that US shares are undervalued, however. "We do not expect an intractable recession, and expect profit growth to reaccelerate in the second half of 2001," she said.

Coca-Cola, however, lowered growth targets for this year and beyond. General Motors posted an 88% drop in first-quarter earnings, while first-quarter profits at the newly merged JP Morgan Chase fell 28% to $1.4bn from a year ago. It also said it intended to cut more than the 5,000 jobs it announced this year.

At the same time, Merrill Lynch, the Wall Street brokerage and investment bank, reported a 21% decline in first-quarter profits as a result of the stock market decline.

webTitle: Oil and motor groups all look beyond petroleum

fields.headline: Oil and motor groups all look beyond petroleum
fields.standfirst:
Oil companies are criticised for increasing petrol prices and even for producing fossil fuels

Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: Oil companies are criticised for increasing petrol prices and even for producing fossil fuels
fields.body:
If experiments under way in the US and Europe are successful, petrol will no longer be at the centre of debate because it will have been replaced by a completely different fuel.

It is the same oil group "pariahs" who are at the forefront of the alternative fuel developments.

Exxon Mobil (which trades as Esso in Britain) and BP are blazing a trail in the development of hydrogen and fuel cells technology. Exxon claims to be spending $100m a year on research with General Motors and Toyota. BP, whose chief executive, Sir John Browne, controversially claimed last year that the company's name should come to mean "beyond petroleum", is working with General Motors on a fuel cell programme and last month announced plans to introduce hydrogen fuel cell buses in five European cities in collaboration with DaimlerChrysler.

Car manufacturers are working with the oil groups on "green" power solutions as well as producing ever more fuel efficient, high performance, and low emission diesel engines.

About a third of new cars bought in Europe over the last 12 months were diesel compared with 15% a decade ago as drivers switch from more expensive petrol.

Pressure for change is not coming from fringe groups but from government, with California moving toward "zero emission vehicle" mandates and curbs on carbon emissions in Europe.

Alternative energy sources such as hydrogen - an apparently limitless and non-pollutant fuel - were previously thought of only in connection with nuclear or rocket technology.

At an extraordinarily eerie filling station in Germany, behind the cargo area at the Bavarian capital's airport, you can fill up a top of the range BMW 7 series with the fuel of the future: liquid hydrogen.

A robotic arm, triggered by electronic messages from the dashboard and a smart payment card, glides out and fills the 750HL with up to 140 litres of liquid hydrogen, enough to travel 400km.

BMW executives are tremendously excited but there are significant obstacles to overcome. Fuel cells have been around for 150 years and finding ways of making them efficient and commercial has proved tough. They are liked by environmentalists because they combine hydrogen and oxygen to produce electricity. They avoid combustion and emit little worse than water and heat.

Building a hydrogen network capable of keeping all US motorists on the road could cost $100bn, according to estimates in the Economist magazine.

fields.headline: Salonen's magnificent Mahler
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/ Salonen
Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.body:
We see too little of the Finnish conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen in London nowadays. His two concerts with the Philharmonia at the Festival Hall this week - the second, next Sunday, will include the premiere of Colin Matthews's Horn Concerto - are a measly season's ration.

Salonen's account of Mahler's First Symphony on Tuesday night was a vivid reminder of what we have been missing. This was a performance of wonderful flexibility and sweep, which managed to encompass all the extremes of this teeming work. Though the tempi were on the fast side - the main "Wayfaring" theme of the first movement strutted proudly, the scherzo had a perfect fleetness - there was never a sense of unnecessary haste. The wide-spaced textures of the introduction had all the air they needed, and the macabre inventions of the funeral march were never allowed to be merely grotesque. The space Salonen found for the slow episode in the finale, and the purified tone the Philharmonia produced for it, were heart-stopping, while the symphony's ultimate entrance into D major was genuinely triumphant.

The first half, Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto, had been less convincing. The programme notes described the piece as one of the finest of the 20th century, "alongside the Berg, Elgar and Walton" (even allowing for a bit of British bias, the Sibelius and the Bartok might have got a mention too). But it is fundamentally an introspective and unyielding work, and Viktoria Mullova's performance needed much more commitment and vitality to make it truly engaging.

There were some serenely beautiful things, especially in the opening Nocturne, but too often she substituted solemnity for seriousness. The performance really only caught fire when Salonen took the music by the scruff of its neck in the second movement. The occasional twinge of sour tuning apart, it was technically first rate - but that one takes for granted with Mullova. What was absent was her usual fire, and her usual insights.

 A version of this review ran in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: AOL bolsters Time Warner
fields.trailText: AOL Time Warner has bucked the recent trend by revealing a 20% increase in profits in the last quarter, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
AOL Time Warner bucked the recent trend for negative news yesterday when it revealed a 20% increase in profits in the last quarter.

Shares in the world's largest media and internet group rose 8% soon after it released its first-quarter results as analysts welcomed the better than expected earnings and revenue growth during an economic downturn.

Gerry Levin, the company's chief executive, said: "The real strength of AOL Time Warner is magnified by our ability to deliver strong results in this kind of market."

The company said that its wide range of assets - ranging from Time magazine to Warner Brothers film studio to the internet service provider - was the key to offsetting the impact of an economic slowdown and slowing advertising revenue. "This enables us ... to generate sustained and consistent growth and to mitigate volatility," he said.

Shares in AOL Time Warner have fallen since the beginning of the year amid doubts that the company could achieve the aggressive growth targets promised when the internet and media companies merged last year.

Mr Levin reiterated his belief that the company was on course to meet those targets. He said that analysts would see "not only good double-digit growth for our company in advertising, but even in more traditional markets" going forward.

Many of the company's rivals, including Walt Disney, Viacom and News Corp, have warned of declining revenues from advertising sales.

Subscriptions from both internet and cable users spurred AOL's growth in the quarter. Mr Levin called AOL the company's "jewel in the crown" yesterday and suggested that the internet would be "the world's largest mass-market medium ever seen".

Total subscriptions increased 16% to 133m in the quarter with the flagship internet service adding 2m members in the period for a total of almost 29m. About 6m of those subscribers were outside the US.

Steve Case, company chairman, has promised strong growth for AOL's international business, forecasting an increase from a current 17% to half of all revenues within 10 years. Last year's merger, valued at $124bn (£86.7bn), was the largest ever recorded. Yesterday's results mark the first time the two companies have presented consolidated quarterly results.

After merger-related costs and investment write-downs were taken into account, the company managed to lose $1.4bn in the quarter, slightly better than $1.5bn last year. The amortisation of goodwill cost the company $1.8bn in the period.

Still, Wall Street analysts welcomed earnings before exceptionals of 23 cents a share, or $2.1bn, three cents better than expected.

In a note to investors, Henry Blodget and Jessica Reif Cohen, company analysts at Merrill Lynch, said: "We view the company's results as impressive, particularly in light of a very difficult operating environment and industrywide advertising weakness."

Revenues of $9.1bn, up 9% in the year, also exceeded expectations after a strong performance from subscriptions and the company's film business. Mr Levin also forecast a strong performance for the first film to be based on the Harry Porter novels, due out later this year.

Company insiders have described their ability to withstand the downturn in advertising expenditure which has hurt so many competitors as a "flight to quality".

With diminishing budgets, they hope companies are choosing AOL Time Warner's mixed bag of distribution outlets over smaller rivals.

Advertising and commerce revenues rose 37% at AOL and 17% at Time Warner.

webTitle: Hewlett-Packard warns on profits and fires 3,000

fields.headline: Hewlett-Packard warns on profits and fires 3,000
fields.trailText: Hewlett-Packard, America's second-largest computer manufacturer, announced 3,000 job cuts yesterday and warned that its earnings would not meet expectations.
fields.body:
Hewlett-Packard, America's second-largest computer manufacturer, announced 3,000 job cuts yesterday and warned that its earnings would not meet expectations.

The warning is the latest to emerge from the beleaguered computer manufacturing sector. Cisco, the internet equipment group, issued a profits warning and a round of job cuts earlier this week.

In a statement, Carly Fiorina, HP's chairman and chief executive, said that the domestic problems which caused the company to issue an earlier warning had spread to the rest of the world.

"It is quite clear that the US downturn in the consumer market is now spreading to other regions, notably Europe," she warned. The company blamed a slowdown in consumer spending for its woes.

Hewlett-Packard expects profits for the three months to the end of April to be 13-17 cents a share because of weaker demand and a $150m (£105m) inventory write-down. Analysts on average had expected earnings of 35 cents a share.

Ms Fiorina did help to ease concerns about the extent of the economic downturn, however, when she indicated that the quarter would mark a low point in the company's fortunes. "We're clearly talking about the second quarter being a bottom, and I say that with great caution," she said.

Shares in the Palo Alto-based company rose 7% in early trading, before yesterday's surprise interest rate cut lifted the entire market. They have almost halved in the last 12 months, however, as the economic downturn hit confidence.

Some 3,000 of the company's 14,000 managers are to be sacked within the next two months. The company's total workforce of about 88,500 employees has already suffered the cull of 1,700 marketing jobs earlier this year.

Employees are also to be required to take some days off, but Hewlett-Packard said that it would not defer salary increases beyond the 90-day delay that began in the first quarter.

The company said that revenues were expected to fall by up to 4% in the second quarter compared with the previous three months. It forecast little change to third-quarter sales from the year-earlier $11.8bn.

Few Wall Street analysts were surprised by yesterday's announcement because of the wave of bad news from the hi-tech sector in recent weeks. However, there was some disappointment over the need for inventory write-downs at both Hewlett-Packard and Cisco, which announced its decision to write off $2.5bn of unwanted stock on Monday.

Merrill Lynch has maintained a "conservative" stance on the company going forward.26

fields.headline: The inequality of finances
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Women are equal to men in the world of finance, according to a new survey. Unless, that is, they are single and bringing up children or approaching retirement after being widowed.
fields.body:
Women are equal to men in the world of finance, according to a new survey. Unless, that is, they are single and bringing up children or approaching retirement after being widowed.

Women are also likely to suffer inequality to men with regards to pensions, where 29% of men, compared with 18% of women have occupational pensions.

A detailed survey published by the financial services authority yesterday found that while men and women in similar social positions and roles owned a similar number of financial products, there were wide variations between different groups of women.

More than 30% of Bangladeshi women have no financial products, compared with 14% of Bangladeshi men or 5% of white women.

Similar differences where also found in other groups such as Pakistani and black men and women.

The biggest discrepancies between men and women were established by looking at different age groups, with the gap widening against women the older the age group analysed - particularly with regards to pensions.

For instance, men in the age group 55-64 are twice as likely to own a pension than women while at the age group of 16-20 the gap is just 2%.

"The report highlights the importance to women of planning their finances from an early age, in order to cope with developments such as career breaks for raising families that fall disproportionately on women," Christine Farnish, consumer relations director at the FSA, said.

The report was drawn up by a working group which included representatives from the treasury and the cabinet office.

Men and women in similar social positions and roles were found to be equal. For example, women in full-time employment own seven financial products against 7.2 for men.

More than 30% of Bangladeshi women have no financial products, compared with 14% of Bangladeshi men or 5% of white women. Similar differences where also found in other groups such as Pakistani and black men and women. The biggest discrepancies between men and women were established by looking at different age groups, with the gap widening against women the older the age group analysed - particularly with regards to pensions. For instance, men in the age group 55-64 are twice as likely to own a pension than women while at the age group of 16-20 the gap is just 2%. "The report highlights the importance to women of planning their finances from an early age, in order to cope with developments such as career breaks for raising families that fall disproportionately on women," Christine Farnish, consumer relations director at the FSA, said. The report was drawn up by a working group which included representatives from the treasury and the cabinet office. Men and women in similar social positions and roles were found to be equal. For example, women in full-time employment own seven financial products against 7.2 for men.

fields.headline: Low-brain banter with the lads on the sofa
fields.standfirst:
Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned
Shaftesbury Theatre, London **
fields.trailText:
Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned

Shaftesbury Theatre, London **
fields.body:
David Baddiel's pre-show pronouncements don't fill one with enthusiasm. "It's a bigger laugh to do on stage," he says, "where we can swear and talk as much as we like about Frank's toilet habits. That's why I'm doing it." Ho hum.

Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned was touted as trailblazing telly when it premiered on ITV, after Skinner's multimillion-pound transfer from the Beeb last year. It featured the comic duo extemporising from a sofa: Beavis and Butthead for thirtysomethings. Now it's in the West End for a month, and the supposedly pioneering is revealed as lazy and inadequate.

The concept isn't the problem. There's a lot to be said for establishing an honest, spontaneous relationship between audience and performers - fellow improvisers Improbable Theatre, who also have a comedy background, have been fruitfully exploring this territory for years. There are rousing moments here, too, as when Skinner and Baddiel have an entire West End audience singing along to Robbie Williams's Angels (the choice of song is characteristic).

What lets Unplanned down - and threatens to derail it altogether - is its lack of ambition. Within the opening minutes of their hour-long gig, the pair are calling punters "gay" and talking about willies. Having cracked a joke about Abraham Lincoln, they apologise for overestimating the audience's intelligence. They don't make the mistake twice: "Who remembers the firemen's names on Trumpton?" asks Baddiel.

Understandably, a rowdy crowd interprets this comic barrel-scraping as a licence to join in, and duly does so. A man whose birthday it is plonks himself on the boys' leather couch and announces he works for Railtrack. Everyone boos; the volunteer "secretary", Caz from Essex, scribbles "wanker" on a blackboard. As the evening slides into office-party raucousness, Skinner and Baddiel - the latter's eyes flash with panic - seem quite incapable of reining it back.

It falls to Skinner to partly redeem an event that without him would be as appetising as the dregs of someone else's pint. His persona is twinkling and jolly. He seems positively interested in people and in the world. And he can be suddenly, effortlessly funny, piercing the fug of pub-bound blether with tangential shafts of wit. On their first night, the pair's opposing responses to foot and mouth spoke volumes. Skinner indicated the absurdity of the government's response: "Earache? Get on the bonfire!" Baddiel was sneeringly cynical: "Let's face it, those of us in London, we don't fucking care anyway." Baddiel's crime isn't that he's a lad; it's that he's desperate to be one. Swearing is his primary comic strategy (and sex, a topic he snatches at like a drowning man thrown a rope).

It all amounts to a waste of a format that might be developed in interesting directions, and of a dynamic live atmosphere. Unplanned needn't mean unimaginative or unfulfilling. But unless, like Skinner and Baddiel, you're content with ever-decreasing circles of low-brain banter, I'd unbook those tickets immediately.

 Until May 12. Box office: 020-7420 0120.

webTitle: Bayern Munich v Manchester United preview

fields.headline: United have a Bavarian Alp to climb
fields.trailText: As Alex Ferguson noted, United have got to score tonight. David Lacey tries to work out how they will go about getting a result without the services of David Beckham.
fields.body:
So often does the average footballer consider such-and-such the icing on the cake it is tempting to believe that behind the bland pleasantries there is a pastry chef struggling to get out. For Manchester United the Champions League is the cake, and everything else so much marzipan.

On Saturday United became only the fourth English team to complete a championship hat-trick and they have now won the Premiership in seven seasons out of nine. Yet their manager Sir Alex Ferguson has no doubt about the effect on Old Trafford's season should his side fail to overturn Bayern Munich's first-leg lead here this evening.

"It will definitely create a hell of a flatness," Ferguson said. "Of course winning the Premier League is always important but if we are to progress Europe is the place to do it. That is why losing now would be a big disappointment."

Ferguson is convinced United will score against Bayern this time. "If we can get a goal it will be very interesting," he mused. "In fact there's nothing else for it: we've got to score."

A one-match suspension following his booking when Bayern won at Old Trafford will deprive United of David Beckham's superior services tonight. In his absence Ferguson is expected to persist with Paul Scholes on the right, though tucking in to allow Gary Neville to overlap and provide the crosses.

Bayern have lost their two wing-backs, Hasan Salihamidzic and Bixente Lizarazu, to suspensions. Ferguson feels Ottmar Hitzfeld's likely replacements, Willy Sagnol and Michael Tarnat, "are both experienced but without the energy and the quickness of the other two". Ryan Giggs, on whom so much depends, will hope this is true.

As much will rest on Roy Keane and Nicky Butt preventing Stefan Effenberg and Jens Jeremies gaining the sort of control of the second leg that they did in the first. Effenberg's was the long pass nodded square by Thomas Linke for a substitute, Paulo Sergio, to appear from nowhere and win that game in the 86th minute.

"Losing was very disappointing," Ferguson said. "Nil-nil would have been a fantastic result for us but the situation is not insurmountable and the players have done it before. We want the type of performances of two years ago."

Of that there can be little doubt. On the way to winning the 1999 European Cup United came from two goals down to eliminate Juventus in Turin and in the final Bayern, needing only to hold their 1-0 lead for three minutes of stoppage time, were beaten 2-1. Then again United led 2-1 the last time they were in Munich only to be held to a 2-2 draw in the closing minute. They also have to contend with the tiresome statistic that in Europe Bayern have yet to lose a second leg at home after winning the first.

Ferguson believes the opposition will waste little time seeking to put a semi-final place further beyond his reach. "I think they'll try to beat us in the first 20 minutes," he said. "I don't think we'll just be going for it. First of all we've got to make sure they don't score. Patience will be important."

On arrival here yesterday the United party had to walk across disinfected mats, doing their bit to keep foot and mouth out of Bavaria. They will hope Bayern have feet of clay tonight ... but you wouldn't Effen bet on it.

Bayern Munich (probable, 3-4-1-2): Kahn; Linke, Kuffour, Andersson; Sagnol, Jeremies, Effenberg, Tarnat; Scholl; Elber, Jancker.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre; Scholes, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Yorke, Cole.

fields.headline: Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Manchester United (agg: 3 - 1)
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Bayern Munich: Kahn, Kuffour, Andersson, Linke, Sagnol, Tarnat, Jeremies, Effenberg, Scholl, Jancker, Elber. Subs: Dreher, Weisinger, Sergio, Zickler, Hargreaves, Santa Cruz, Kling.

Man Utd: Barthez, Gary Neville, Brown, Stam, Silvestre, Scholes, Keane, Butt, Giggs, Yorke, Cole. Subs: Van Der Gouw, Johnsen, Sheringham, Phil Neville, Solskjaer, Wallwork, Chadwick.

Referee: V M Pereira (Portugal)

1 This is United's biggest test of the season and should they fail to come good then the customary achievement that was this year's Premiership title will truly ring hollow and haunt the club for months. United kick-off with the not so customary pass back to the penalty area as Bayern press from the off.
5 GOAL: Bayern Munich 1 - 0 Manchester United Tame start sees both teams knocking the ball about to try and suss each other out. And then, from nothing, Tarnat gets away on the left and crosses for Elber to fire Bayern into the lead with a header at the far post. Disastrous start for United
8 Jancker cracks it against the crossbar from ten yards. Bayern win a corner, Effenberg takes but United clear. United defence all over the place at the moment. Jancker's miss could end up being a good omen (yeah, right) after he did the same in the later stages of the 1999 final, and guess what happened then?
11 United still not looking like they have any hope of pulling this back.
12 Effenberg gets into gear when he sprays the ball across the pitch to Jancker up on the right, but Silvestre gets in front of him to clear the threat.
13 Kuffour almost blows it when he sells Kahn short with a back-pass and gives Yorke a sniff of a chance.
16 United win a corner - Giggs takes and Jeremies boots into touch. Gary Neville hurls the throw towards Stam on the edge of the six-yard box, Scholes has a go, but Bayern clear.
17 Bayern break and Barthez is almost caught out by Jancker on the edge of the area when Silvestre fluffs things in front of him - Bayern have had chances to wrap this up already and may, just possibly, live to regret that they didn't
20 United free-kick - Giggs takes and Kahn goes down under pressure from Brown at the far post. Goal-kick.
22 Scholl charges away on the left to light the fuse on another Bayern attack - this time it doesn't end in a chance on goal.
23 United break and Butt wins a corner off Andersson - Giggs again takes and Jeremies again gets his foot to it first.
25 United win another corner after Keane slides into Effenberg on the by-line. The two players check each other as their egos comes critically close to colliding. Giggs takes and Cole prods a shot from six yards... cleared off the line. Undoubtedly United's best chance yet.
29 United enjoying good possession in the Bayern half. They may need two goals but they are having the best of the play at the moment.
32 Scholes burgles Linke after pushing him back towards the by-line but there is no one in the area to meet the cross.
33 Yet another corner to United - comes out to Scholes, goes out to the United left and comes back for Scholes to blast a volley well wide of the post.
35 Substitution Zickler on for Jancker.
40 GOAL: Bayern Munich 2 - 0 Manchester United Jeremies races away on the right, looks up and finds Elber in the area; he knocks it on to Zickler, who knocks it on for Scholl to beat Barthez at the far post.
45 Bayern now have 10 men behind the ball as United make a last push this half. Giggs wins a corner after Kahn deflects Cole's shot on to the roof of the net. Bayern break in response with Barthez way out of his goal - nothing doing. Half-time. What to say about this, then? Expect changes by Sir Alex Ferguson

46 Barthez called out to the edge of his area from the off as Elber races clear. No changes so far by United.
47 Silvestre does well to turn Zickler near on the edge of the Bayern area; the ball goes out to the United right for Neville to head down and miss all three United players on the edge of the six-yard box.
49 GOAL: Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Manchester United United break; Scholes lifts the ball over the top to Giggs who in turn lobs Kahn from 15 yards to get one back for United.
51 United corner; Kahn flaps it clear.
53 United have come out fighting this half as Butt battles free of Jeremies to the right of the Bayern area' - too many Bayern bodies waiting for the cross.
56 Bayern free-kick after Stam checks Zickler just outside the United area; Andersson blasts it but the United wall does its job.
58 Yorke does well on the left but his cross into the box is easy for Andersson.
59 Almost a second for United when Giggs volleys it from 20 yards and Kahn is forced to palm away for a corner. Bayern break from the corner kick as United are caught short at the back. Giggs has come alive this half as United up the pace.
63 Yorke and Andersson go down on the after a clash of heads - Andersson streaming with blood.
64 Substitution Santa Cruz on for Elber.
66 Substitution Sheringham on for Yorke.
68 United free-kick 35 yards out; Giggs takes but it is going nowhere. Bayern break from the clearance and Giggs tracks Santa Cruz all the way back to run him out near the by-line.
71 After good early United pressure Bayern have done well to stem the flow and knock the visitors out of their rhythm.
73 United corner after a free-for-all in the Bayern area; Giggs takes, Jeremies away as far as Neville, back in and appeals for a penalty as Kuffour appears to fall into the back of Cole three yards out after Sheringham knocks it down.
76 Bayern free-kick out near the corner flag; Effenberg takes and Brown glances it away.
78 Substitution Solskjaer on for Butt.
79 Effenberg finds Zickler in acres of space 30 yards out but his shot flies over. Followed up by a break and a blinding cross from Sheringham that Cole can't convert.
81 Great snap shot from Scholes 20 yards out - knocked over by Kahn for a corner. Giggs takes but Sheringham can't get to it. Sheringham gets another chance but puts it wide.
83 Effenberg sprays the ball out to the left for Scholl to get past Brown and fire a shot across the face of Barthez's goal.
84 Substitution Chadwick on.
85 Zickler away in the United half, Silvestre chases him back and Zickler goes down just inside the area - no penalty. Barthez dribbles to the halfway line to clear.
87 United all up now. Chadwick beats three players on the right of the Bayern area, but opts for a pass to Kerane when he maybe should have had a crack at the near post.
89 Substitution Sergio on for Scholl.
90 Barthez comes out and ends up passing straight to Kahn. Giggs finds Sheringham at the far post but Sheringham blasts it into the ground. Four minutes left to play. More of the same as United continue to pummel the box. Plenty of half-chances and then a late corner. Giggs takes, easily cleared. Full-time. All over for United.
Bayern Munich 2 - 1 Manchester United Bayern go on to face Real Madrid in the second semi-final.

fields.headline: Phil Neal: King of Europe?
fields.standfirst: Email your questions tothe.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to help
fields.trailText: PHIL NEAL - RECORD HOLDER?
fields.body:
PHIL NEAL - RECORD HOLDER?

"Has Phil Neal won the most European Cup medals in football?" asks madhouse.36

No he hasn't, but he comes surprisingly close. It's easily forgotten - especially as these days Neal has become a figure of fun after his disastrous spells as manager of Coventry and Manchester City and his constant twittering of "yes, boss" to Graham Taylor - that he was a decent player. During his time at Liverpool, Neal won four European Cup medals (76-7, 77-8, 80-1, 83-4) and one Uefa Cup (75-6), as well as eight League Championship medals and 20 England caps.

But Neal's achievements are blown away by Real Madrid legend Francisco Gento, who won six European Cup winners' medals (55-6, 56-77, 57-8, 58-9, 59-60, 65-6) and two runners-up medals (61-2, 63-4) in a 800-game career. He was also awarded 43 Spanish caps, playing in both the 1962 and 1966 World Cups.

ENGLISH TEAMS WITH AN ALL FOREIGN XI

"What is the greatest number of Scots to turn out for a single English club match, either league or cup? Has an English club, in any match ever come close to fielding an all-Scottish eleven?" asks Alan Sheridan.

Yes they have, Alan. Liverpool fielded an all-Scottish eleven in their first-ever match in 1892 (after forming when Everton quit Anfield for Goodison Park earlier that year).

According to the official Liverpool FC website: "It was virtually unheard of at the time for a city to have more than one professional football team, and people naturally wondered where on earth Liverpool's players would come from. John McKenna, the club's first manager, provided the answer: Scotland. All eleven players of the Liverpool team that played its first-ever competitive match, against Higher Walton on September 3 1892, were Scottish."

More recently, Liverpool famously fielded a non-English XI for the 1986 FA Cup final against Everton: Grobbelaar, Lawrenson, Beglin, Nicol, Whelan, Hansen, Dalglish, Johnston, Rush, Mølby and MacDonald came from behind to win 3-1.

And if you want any further evidence that foreign can be fantastic, look at Chelsea. On December 26 1999, they played Southampton with 11 overseas players - the first time an English league side had fielded a starting line-up without a single British player.

With Graeme Le Saux injured, Chris Sutton suffering from flu, and Dennis Wise's wife due to give birth, Gianluca Vialli started with De Goey, Ferrar, Babayaro, Thome, Leboeuf, Petrescu, Poyet, Deschamps, Di Matteo, Flo and Ambrosetti. And the players did Vialli proud, with two first-half goals from Flo helping Chelsea to victory.

ANOTHER PUB TALE PROVED WRONG

"Is it true that Notts County don't have to wear an away kit if they choose not to as they were the first football league team," asks Joe Coffey. "I heard that they didn't on some TV programme once."

According to Notts County, the story is hokum. Club secretary Tony Cuthbert told Guardian Unlimited: "I've never heard of that before. And there's nothing in the football league regulations about it either."

HOOP NIGHTMARES

"Why do football teams tend to play in stripes whereas rugby teams play in hoops? Why do Celtic, then, play in hoops? What other teams break this trend?" asks Richard Tonkin.

Hoops make players look bigger. Stripes make players look taller. Being squat and bulky is a distinct advantage in rugby, a sport where having a neck wider than your head is de rigueur. But footballers like to look tall and slim, so stripes it is.

Why Celtic chose green-and-white hoops as opposed to stripes nobody seems sure. They started life playing in all-white shirts, then changed to a vertical green-and-white-striped affair before "evolving" into the famous hoops in time for the 1903-4 season. Perhaps the team was just too tall and wispy for their own good.

Of course, this is the final season the famous hoops will be seen at Celtic Park. The club's new strip has two white panels under each arm, breaking both hoop and supporters' hearts. A "Hands off the Hoops" campaign hopes to put a stop to this heresy, although as the new strip has already achieved "higher sales than any other shirt", this seems unlikely.

But you'll still be able to see hoops elsewhere. Morton, Queen's Park Rangers and Reading play in blue-and-white hoops, Darlington and Queen's Park play in black-and-white hoops, while the Hamilton Accies play in red-and-white hoops. Sadly, if you still desire that Celtic aesthetic, you'll have to go to watch Rapid Vienna, Shamrock Rovers or Sporting Lisbon play.

BBC SPORT: ALL MANCHESTER UNITED SUPPORTERS?

"Are all the BBC's radio sports correspondents Manchester United fans? I know that Mark Chapman is on Radio 1 as is Fergus Sweeney on Radio 5, however as these are the only radio stations I listen to. I am at a loss as to whether the rest could be the same. Nonetheless with Greg Dyke in charge is there some sinister plot to redden the BBC or simply shared interests that guarantee promotion to top sports jobs?" asks Andy Peacock.

"Does the man not pay attention?" asks Steve Edgington. "Adrian Chiles, a fantastic correspondent who covers the 606 programme amongst other BBC programmes, is a fan of the greatest club in the world. That's West Bromwich Albion, of course."

CAN YOU HELP?

"Who was the first footballer ever to be sent off with the red card?" asks R Richards.

"Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has a record at Manchester United of 76 goals in 202 appearances or one goal every 2.66 matches. Not bad at all, I think we can all agree. However, what I want to know is, bearing in mind how often he has been used as a substitute, how many goals does he score for every 90 minutes he is on the pitch? Does anyone else have a better ratio of goals per 90 minutes? And who has the best goals per 90 international minutes ratio? I am guessing it is Gerd Muller with 68 goals in 62 caps. His club record should also beat Solskjaer, I think, standing at 447 goals in 490 games. Can anyone else help?" asks Benjamin Hardy.

Email the.boss@theguardian.com if you know the answers.
