webTitle: Week 20: North Island to South Island

fields.headline: Ice queen
fields.standfirst: Taking the decision to slow down and spend  more time on the South Island means Sue has time to fit in some new experiences - including her first helicopter flight and a hike over Franz Josef glacier
fields.trailText: Week 20: North Island to South Island Taking the decision to slow down and spend more time on the South Island means Sue has time to fit in some new experiences - including her first helicopter flight and a hike over Franz Josef glacier
fields.body:
New Zealand has been a revelation. It had never been particularly high on my wish-list of places to go, but I have been captivated by its beauty and diversity. Since arriving on South Island I've scarcely been able to draw breath between the new vistas that I've met round every corner.

I crossed uneventfully and relatively smoothly between the Islands on Friday evening, despite having to reverse over a bridge and onto the ferry in order to squeeze car number three between two huge lorries. After spending the night in Picton, I set off next day to the Nelson area, via the scenic coast road which gave stunning views over the forested islands in Marlborough Sound.

I arrived in Richmond, near Nelson, to stay with a cousin of friends from home. I'd somehow caught a terrible cold during the previous 24 hours, and it was rather embarrassing to arrive at a stranger's house with a continually dripping nose, and halfway through my stock of Malaysian loo roll. The cold was also giving me ear- and toothache, which meant I wasn't the brightest company. Margaret, whom I was staying with, was a treasure - feeding me up and administering Lemsip and TLC. One of the big delights of this trip has been the kindness and generosity of the people I have stayed with. When I get back I'll have to think of a way to repay all the friends who have 'lent' me their contacts abroad.

On Sunday, Margaret and her sister Cynthia took me on a 'tiki tour' of the area - which basically means going where your fancy takes you. A picnic on the cliff above Kaiteriteri beach overlooking the Abel Tasman coast made me excited about going there the next day. Abel Tasman National Park is a stretch of the most beautiful coastline imaginable: lush forest, cliff-tops, golden sandy bays and a deep turquoise sea. The first afternoon I just walked along the trail for a couple of hours and back, glad to be giving my legs a stretch. I'm not sure whether it was my cold or the fact of sitting in a car for too long, but I was soon tired. Time to take the fortune teller's advice (see Sue's report, week 11) and eat some more fruit and vegetables - it's too easy to stop at a cafe and just snack on coffee and the delicious cakes they have in New Zealand. Mike from Wellington also gave me some chocolate from Whittakers, where he now works, and I'm addicted - it's really thick and chunky, and stuffed with nuts... mmm.

The next day I caught a water taxi up the coast and walked about 10km to a different pick-up point. It was a lovely day - crashing through the waves in the boat was hard on the backside but great fun. I felt sorry for the kayakers who were caught in the wash. The walk in the bright sun shine was lovely, with occasional stops on the beach to read a couple of chapters of my book. A perfect day. In my usual panic about seeing as much as possible, I headed off that evening to the Nelson Lakes area. Taking a left earlier than I should, I travelled for miles down a pitch black road that every so often turned into a gravel track - I was very relieved to finally reach the hostel and fall into my bunk. A quick zoom round the beautiful Rototoui Lake the next day, and it was off to the west coast.

I was driving through the mountainous Buller Gorge when I suddenly thought, "what on earth am I doing rushing around like a blue-arsed fly?" My original plan had been to go back to Auckland and then on to the North Islands, highly recommended by Susie in an email. I had already forgone the lovely Lakes area, so I decided at that moment that since I was here in the South Island I would take my time and do more 'tiki tours', even though that meant foregoing the North. It felt like a weight had been lifted from my shoulders and I immediately began stopping at all the lookout spots that took my fancy - and there were plenty of those. Sorry Susie - I'll have to come again to go to all the bits I will miss out.

The west coast left me flabbergasted once again by the magnificence of the scenery. Huge rollers crashed against enormous craggy mountains. It has been impossible to take photographs of everything I've seen over the last couple of days - it's all too vast. I ended up deleting the ones that I did take because they couldn't do justice to what was before my eyes.

Eventually, I reached the Pancake Rocks at Punakaiki. A process known as stylobedding - my geological knowledge is increasing - has layered these rocks into what look like stacks of pancakes. The sea has punched holes into them through which the waves crash and spumes of water shoot up - I spent a happy hour wandering around and watching the spectacle. I stopped at Hokitika for local fish and chips and a hostel bed before setting off for the Franz Josef glacier.

After the lovely weather of the last week, the mist descended and the rain fell just when some sunshine was needed for the sights. I did a short walk to a glacier viewpoint but could see very little in the pouring rain. The hostel was a nightmare of smelly, wet clothing, with a bad-tempered queue for the washing machines and dryers. Yet despite all this, I managed to get up the following day and spend the most amazing morning on a helihike to the glacier in glorious sunshine. I am seriously beginning to think that someone is looking down on me, because my good fortune continues - the very helpful Guiding Company at the Alpine Adventure Centre squeezed me in on the morning trip. It was my first ever helicopter flight, and what a debut it was - being whisked up around Franz Josef glacier and then actually dropped off onto it. I'd been very nervous about hiking over the ice, but with the special boots and the guide making steps for us it was easier than I expected. Poor Bruce found it a bit of a struggle, as there weren't any boots to fit him. The ice has a blue tinge - here my geology fails - bright blue in the ice caves and crevasses. It was awesome on the glacier, and crawling through ice caves was yet again something I could never have imagined doing. The list of unforgettable experiences continues to grow. I am now feeling elated and tired - time to go for a late lunch before heading even further south. Happy Easter to everyone.

fields.headline: Lake placid
fields.standfirst: Despite briefly contracting what may have been malaria (or perhaps yellow fever, or possibly typhoid), Sam makes a miraculous recovery and spends the rest of the week soaking up sun and beer on the shores of Lake Malawi
fields.trailText: Week 19: Liwonde to Nkhata Bay Despite briefly contracting what may have been malaria (or perhaps yellow fever, or possibly typhoid), Sam makes a miraculous recovery and spends the rest of the week soaking up sun and beer on the shores of Lake Malawi
fields.body:
We caught the bus south to Zomba. This was the old colonial capital of Malawi and was completely different from the other towns we had been through. It was perched on the edge of a plateau surrounded by wooded hills, and there were wide paved streets lined with trees, and buildings more than two storeys high - the first we had seen outside Lilongwe.

In the middle of town there was a small, quiet graveyard for the European settlers who had lived and died here in the early part of the 20th century. Each of the gravestones told a story: farmers from Devon dying of malaria, children taken by fevers, soldiers of the East Africa Regiment killed in world war one. Next to this there was another more recent graveyard for the local inhabitants. These gravestones told a very different tale. Life in Africa is still hard, but now the killer is more likely to be Aids. It's been forecast that across the continent over 30m people will die from the disease by 2020. In Malawi, HIV is horrifyingly prevalent. Some statistics say that over 50% of pregnant women are infected. The government is trying to tackle the problem - we saw plenty of posters advocating the use of condoms - but there is a long, long way to go.

Leaving Zomba we headed north, back to the Lake.

Lake Malawi forms part of the Great Rift Valley that splits east Africa. It's the third largest lake on the continent, 580km long and up to 700m deep. At it's southern end sits the small port of Monkey Bay.

The journey had taken a few hours and we clambered out of the minibus, stretching our cramped muscles. We were immediately jumped on by 14-year-old Mark who offered to show us around - for a small fee, of course. Mark was very cheerful and, as we walked, kept up a running commentary about the town, pausing occasionally to shoo away other boys also keen to escort us.

After dropping our rucksacks at the only resthouse, we took Mark to a local bar to have some food. We all had chambo (a fish found in the lake) and nsima (a sort of dumpling made from maize flour). Mark told us about school and his favourite subjects (business studies and history - he asked me when the great fire of London was, I'm ashamed to say I didn't know). Exams were coming up soon and he was a bit worried about how he was going to pass maths. As an orphan living with his older sister, he paid his way by escorting mzungus - chichewa for foreigners - like us. When I was 14, I spent most of my time watching TV.

The next morning Mark was there to escort us down to the port (this one was on him). The Ilala is a large old steamship which was commissioned into service on the lake in 1951. She can carry up to 350 passengers and travels up and down the lake once a week stopping at about a dozen towns with exotic names like Chipoka, Usisya and Likoma Island.

On board there were three classes: cabin, first class (you sleep on the deck) and economy (you're in the hold with two hundred other people and lots of chickens). As we were going to be on the boat for two days we had booked one of the cabins for about £30 each. The cabins were certainly not the luxury option they had been once, but they were still in a reasonable condition and comfortable enough.

We were due to sail at 08:00 but in fact didn't get going until nearly 11:00. This, apparently, was pretty punctual and there was a jolly mood amongst the passengers as we crowded onto the boat. Up on deck we met our fellow first class passengers - all mzungus who were too soft to travel economy. There was a sprinkling of Americans, a couple of Aussies and a Dutch girl. The Americans, Rusty, Russell and Jill, had their own boua board (a Malawian game that is an excellent way of passing time) so we immediately made friends with them. The skipper was also there and he introduced himself: Captain Adonis.

Not long into the voyage, I began to feel ill. I had a fever, sore throat, pounding head and aching limbs. I stupidly hadn't brought a thermometer with me so I couldn't check my temperature, but clearly I had malaria, or perhaps yellow fever, or maybe typhoid. I spent most of the next two days asleep in the cabin feeling very sorry for myself.

In spite of this, the Ilala made its stately way around the lake. At each stop there was great excitement, both on the ship and on shore where crowds lined the beaches. Fisherman paddled out in their canoes to sell the day's catch. The lifeboats were lowered and people precariously clambered aboard to be ferried ashore. Everyone else watched from the decks in the faint hope that someone might fall in.

The Aussies and the Dutch contingent had opted for the deck and this proved to be a mistake. During one stop in the night, they woke to find themselves surrounded by interested local villagers who had been allowed on board to sightsee. The next night, a sudden squall left the deck rainswept and sent them scurrying to the shelter of our rooms. They gave up after that and paid the extra for a cabin.

Late in the evening of the second day we arrived at our destination (Nkhata Bay, as recommended by Charlotte in her email) to find a power cut had blacked out the town. Pushing through the crowds on the jetty we grabbed a pick-up to take us to where we were staying. Njaya Lodge was also in darkness so we went straight to bed. I was still feeling ill and woke in the middle of the night, drenched in sweat. My hair was soaked, the sheets were damp but the next morning I felt absolutely fine. Not malaria then.

Njaya is a lovely, relaxed place perched on a hillside sloping down to a quiet beach. The days have slipped by without us really seeming to do anything. Our $3-a-night reed hut overlooks the lake and in the morning we get up late and wander down to the beach for a dip. Our American friends from the Ilala, Rusty, Russell and Jill, are also staying here, and our evenings are spent playing pool and watching the fisherman paddle back in their dugout canoes as the sun set. We drink and eat lots.

Occasionally, for a change of scenery we walk into town to have a drink and share a joke with the market traders who are much friendlier than the ones in Cape Maclear. There are some nice pieces on sale here and Rusty has bought so much that I am beginning to suspect he is planning an African theme park on his return to Michigan.

He had the brilliant idea of bringing lots of old tee-shirts and trainers out with him to use as swaps. The traders are very keen on anything with a recognisable logo such as Nike or Addidas and will bring down their prices substantially. Rusty's negotiations resemble a bring-and-buy sale with him laying out his wares in front of the traders while they pore over them with a critical eye.

My cheap Australian mirrored sunglasses also came in for a lot of attention and I have been offered numerous wood carvings and chieftain's chairs for them. Helen's expensive Diesel sunglasses, however, are bluntly ignored.

Writing this report has been the most exhausting thing I've done all week - I'm going back to sleep on the beach now.

On board there were three classes: cabin, first class (you sleep on the deck) and economy (you're in the hold with two hundred other people and lots of chickens). As we were going to be on the boat for two days we had booked one of the cabins for about £30 each. The cabins were certainly not the luxury option they had been once, but they were still in a reasonable condition and comfortable enough. We were due to sail at 08:00 but in fact didn't get going until nearly 11:00. This, apparently, was pretty punctual and there was a jolly mood amongst the passengers as we crowded onto the boat. Up on deck we met our fellow first class passengers - all mzungus who were too soft to travel economy. There was a sprinkling of Americans, a couple of Aussies and a Dutch girl. The Americans, Rusty, Russell and Jill, had their own boua board (a Malawian game that is an excellent way of passing time) so we immediately made friends with them. The skipper was also there and he introduced himself: Captain Adonis. Not long into the voyage, I began to feel ill. I had a fever, sore throat, pounding head and aching limbs. I stupidly hadn't brought a thermometer with me so I couldn't check my temperature, but clearly I had malaria, or perhaps yellow fever, or maybe typhoid. I spent most of the next two days asleep in the cabin feeling very sorry for myself. In spite of this, the Ilala made its stately way around the lake. At each stop there was great excitement, both on the ship and on shore where crowds lined the beaches. Fisherman paddled out in their canoes to sell the day's catch. The lifeboats were lowered and people precariously clambered aboard to be ferried ashore. Everyone else watched from the decks in the faint hope that someone might fall in. The Aussies and the Dutch contingent had opted for the deck and this proved to be a mistake. During one stop in the night, they woke to find themselves surrounded by interested local villagers who had been allowed on board to sightsee. The next night, a sudden squall left the deck rainswept and sent them scurrying to the shelter of our rooms. They gave up after that and paid the extra for a cabin. Late in the evening of the second day we arrived at our destination (Nkhata Bay, as recommended by Charlotte in her email) to find a power cut had blacked out the town. Pushing through the crowds on the jetty we grabbed a pick-up to take us to where we were staying. Njaya Lodge was also in darkness so we went straight to bed. I was still feeling ill and woke in the middle of the night, drenched in sweat. My hair was soaked, the sheets were damp but the next morning I felt absolutely fine. Not malaria then. Njaya is a lovely, relaxed place perched on a hillside sloping down to a quiet beach. The days have slipped by without us really seeming to do anything. Our $3-a-night reed hut overlooks the lake and in the morning we get up late and wander down to the beach for a dip. Our American friends from the Ilala, Rusty, Russell and Jill, are also staying here, and our evenings are spent playing pool and watching the fisherman paddle back in their dugout canoes as the sun set. We drink and eat lots. Occasionally, for a change of scenery we walk into town to have a drink and share a joke with the market traders who are much friendlier than the ones in Cape Maclear. There are some nice pieces on sale here and Rusty has bought so much that I am beginning to suspect he is planning an African theme park on his return to Michigan. He had the brilliant idea of bringing lots of old tee-shirts and trainers out with him to use as swaps. The traders are very keen on anything with a recognisable logo such as Nike or Addidas and will bring down their prices substantially. Rusty's negotiations resemble a bring-and-buy sale with him laying out his wares in front of the traders while they pore over them with a critical eye. My cheap Australian mirrored sunglasses also came in for a lot of attention and I have been offered numerous wood carvings and chieftain's chairs for them. Helen's expensive Diesel sunglasses, however, are bluntly ignored. Writing this report has been the most exhausting thing I've done all week - I'm going back to sleep on the beach now.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Qian Xi
fields.trailText: If you want to see the 'real' Singapore, take a bus into any HDB (Housing Development Board) estate at about 6pm when everyone's going home and you'll get a look into where and how most of the population lives.
fields.body:
Hello Milly,

I'm Qian Xi - 18, Singaporean, female. I'm so envious of your round-the-world trip! Of course that's not my reason for emailing - just wanted to tell you that if you want to see the 'real' Singapore, take a bus into any HDB (Housing Development Board) estate at about 6pm when everyone's going home and you'll get a look into where and how most of the population lives. HDB estates are completely un-touristy. Of course, don't forget to go to Chinatown and Little India; Orchard Road is essential (focal point of our consumerist culture, sadly) but not quite so interesting. Actually I probably can think of more but these are the basic must-sees. Do email me if there's anything you need to know. Can't wait till my A levels are over and I get to do my own travelling!

fields.headline: More pupils hit By TB
fields.trailText: Another 18 pupils of a school at the centre of a TB outbreak have the disease, it has been confirmed.
fields.body:
Another 18 pupils of a school at the centre of a TB outbreak have the disease, it has been confirmed.

It brings to 50 the number of cases now detected with connections to Crown Hills Community College in the Evington area of Leicester.

Some 40 students have also shown early signs of TB and have been put on antibiotics, Leicestershire Health Authority said.

Public health officials revealed today that one infectious pupil could have been the source for the outbreak, which is believed to be the worst in Britain for 20 years. There are now 50 people diagnosed with TB who have a connection with the school - 44 are students, four are family members and two are teachers.

None of the cases confirmed today needed hospital treatment but relatives of the 18 will now be screened to detect whether they have caught the illness. Dr Philip Monk, consultant in communicable diseases at the health authority, told a press conference tonight: "We don't believe there is an ongoing risk. We are detecting these cases at the very early stage of the disease which are not infectious." "This is a source that has been very infectious in the school but we are sure we now have this outbreak under control," he said.

A six-year-old girl at a Leicester school died of the TB last year and three children at other schools have also been diagnosed with the disease.

The health authority stressed there was no connection between these cases and the outbreak at Crown Hills.

fields.headline: Hit 'em with the handbag
fields.standfirst: A decade on since Mrs Thatcher ruled the Conservative party with an iron fist, party supporters still call for her to sort out internal rows. But why do the Tories still turn to Lady Thatcher to sort out the mess? Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate, Jim Boyd, explains
fields.trailText: A decade on since Mrs Thatcher ruled the Conservative party with an iron fist, party supporters still call for her to sort out internal rows. But why do the Tories still turn to Lady Thatcher to sort out the mess? Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate, Jim Boyd, explains.
fields.body:
In the iconography of the Conservative party few images come higher than Lady Thatcher, as a symbol of determination, resolution and straight talking.

She has taken on her own separate mythology; in foreign policy ascribed with the "mouth of Calligula" by President Mitterand and in domestic affairs an "Iron Lady".

She also ruled during a Conservative "golden age" when an ascendant party was seen by its supporters to be governing for Britain's best interests in a tough, uncompromising way.

But for many of the party faithful Lady Thatcher is much more than a comfort blanket. Many Tories see her as a modern day Bodacea who - unlike her historical counterpart - defeated the twin foes of militancy and the stranglehold of the trade unions following the winter of discontent.

For more than 10 years following this, her political style was renowned for its aggression and discipline in equal measure.

Clearly when we come to fictitious "leadership" challenges some Conservatives will hanker for tough talking from Lady Thatcher to spring clean a muddled situation.

Part of this response is buried in the recognition that Lady Thatcher can still influence perception. The perception of power, whether Lady Thatcher can really influence how senior politicians react to the threat of her disapprobation or how she can influence the perception of the party faithful - is power indeed. This in part must be one of the drivers of this response.

However, this is of little interest to the voters in Sunderland South. To tell you the truth, very little of what the political elite - the London based thought leaders, journalists and opinion formers - believe to be relevant or important, is genuinely important in the north east.

I don't know what amazes me more, the fact that so little time and attention is spent on the substantive issues which have a profound effect on how people live their lives outside of the capital - employment, law and order, housing, health; or the look of undisguised disbelief by spin doctors and "cheeky" political journalists when told that their ruminations are self-serving and rather boring.

Why should someone in Sunderland find speculation in Conservative central office more interesting than the prosecution "metric man," our local market trader who dared to sell apples and pears in pounds and ounces?

Worse still, for the hard working prospective parliamentary candidate on the street any leaked factionalism or spun activity promoting political fragmentation, is distracting and deeply frustrating.

In Sunderland, I am fighting a serious campaign to address the issues that are important for the people of the area. I want to take the fight to New Labour. I want to ask them why the average wage in this region is £6,000 less than other areas. I want New Labour to focus on health, to find solutions to the 20% increase in heroin usage in Wearside in the last year, or the 50% increase in robbery in the town centre.

Why should the policies of New Labour be let off the hook just because it suits the interests of a satisfy selfish interests.

Every time there is an instance of internal spin, it removes the need for New Labour to take responsibility for the looming educational crisis, the crisis facing the manufacturing and farming industries, and rock bottom moral among doctors.

When this occurs, I too would welcome Lady Thatcher visiting Conservative central office. I hope she comes armed with her heaviest and most painful handbag!

 Jim Boyd is the Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate for Sunderland South

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Sarah
fields.trailText: I've just read about you and the other Netjetters, and thought I would just send a quick email as I have recently been to Buenos Aires. It's a vibrant city combining modern day living with buckets of history. The weather was fabulous (though it did become very humid at night) and everyone we came across seemed friendly.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

Wow - you must have really seen and experienced more than most in a lifetime - well done!!

I've just read about you and the other Netjetters, and thought I would just send a quick email as I have recently been to Buenos Aires (I won the National Lottery Jet Set programme and went to Buenos Aires, Rio de Janeiro and New York) and wanted to let you know how I found it - fantastic! Buenos Aires was such a vibrant city combining modern day living with buckets of history. The weather was fabulous (though it did become very humid at night) and everyone we came across seemed friendly.

One thing you must try is the steak. The Argentines are famed for how well they cook steak - and other meat, for that matter - and we never had a meal that we didn't enjoy. The best meal we had was when we spent a day on a polo ranch and the gauchos cooked a meal for us on a huge open barbeque. The meat literally melted in the mouth and was washed down very well with a nice bottle of red wine! One restaurant we found which we really enjoyed was "El Parrillon De Recoleta" in the Recoleta area - if you go please say hi to Franklin from me!! Another thing I would recommend is a visit to a Tango Club - the singing may be a bit dodgy but the dancers really are fantastic. We had a tango lesson but enough said about that! We never managed to get to Eva Peron's grave which was one thing I do regret though as it's one of the first things everyone asks!

I know Rio de Janeiro isn't on your list for places to visit but I would fully recommend that also. The weather we had was fabulous - into the 40s most days. If you get a chance, go, especially during the Carnival season - so maybe next year!

I hope you continue to enjoy your travels.

fields.headline: US cannot stay aloof
fields.standfirst:
Recent Israeli belligerence proves that George Bush may find his policy of detachment in Middle East affairs more difficult than he thinks, says Mark Tran

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Recent Israeli belligerence proves that George Bush may find his policy of detachment in Middle East affairs more difficult than he thinks, says Mark Tran.
fields.body:
The Bush administration can hardly be blamed for wanting to stay well clear of the Middle East mess. It only has to see how Bill Clinton tied himself in knots trying to win a settlement in the last days of his administration. There were high points, like when Yasser Arafat clasped hands with Yitzhak Rabin on the White House lawn. But at the end of it all, a peace settlement eluded Mr Clinton despite frantic peacemaking at the end of his presidency.

George Bush made it clear from the outset that he would take a hands-off attitude to Israel and the Palestinians. But the administration reckoned without the aggressive polices of Ariel Sharon, the new Israeli prime minister. Mr Sharon's instinct is to hit hard and then harder when struck. Nicknamed "the bulldozer", he masterminded Israel's disastrous intervention in Lebanon in 1982 and he played a key role in triggering the present intifada with a provocative visit to a disputed holy site over six months ago.

But Mr Sharon overstepped the bounds of US tolerance when he authorised Israeli troops to occupy a sliver of Palestinian-controlled territory in the Gaza strip, in violation of the 1995 Oslo peace accord. The US usually likes to strike an evenhanded pose, but there was no mistaking the unusually sharp rebuke delivered by Colin Powell, the US secretary of state. He called Israel's move into Gaza "excessive and disproportionate" and demanded that the government keep its promise to vacate the territory.

Mr Powell had to intervene because the US cannot afford to see Israel's conflict with the Palestinians boil over. The country's attack against a Syrian radar station in Lebanon on Sunday was a dangerous escalation. There is no question of a full-scale war between Israel and its neighbours; backed with an arsenal of hi-tech weapons from the US, Israel still remains more than a match for its Arab neighbours.

The danger for the US is more insidious. One of the cornerstones of US foreign policy in the Middle East is keep Iraq quarantined. That policy is already under enormous stress, as few support the embargo against Iraq apart from Britain and Kuwait. The US already has enough trouble keeping Arab countries in line.

If Washington is seen to be an acquiescent partner or even idly standing by while Israel keeps on squeezing the Palestinians, American policy on Iraq would become untenable. Saddam Hussein can be counted on to exploit the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians for his maximum benefit, rallying the Arab world behind him. Beyond Iraq is the deep-seated fear among US policy makers of popular unrest in the oil-producing states such as Saudi Arabia, where the Palestinian cause still resonates among ordinary Arabs.

Because of these wider strategic interests, the US cannot let Ariel Sharon run amok and sooner or later, American foreign policy makers will have to get down to the hard graft of cobbling together a settlement, whether they like it or not. But it will have to be a genuinely measured approach. The US will have to tell Israel that it could be more magnanimous to the Palestinians in terms of territory and in compensation for displaced Palestinians. And Israel listens when the US talks - it can hardly ignore such an important benefactor.

In Washington, Mr Powell has emerged with his reputation enhanced from the latest crisis. It was left to the secretary of state to tell Israel to back off, just as his conciliatory words helped to resolve the recent standoff with China over an American spy plane. Not so long ago, reports were circulating in Washington of Mr Powell was being elbowed out by hardliners such as Dick Cheney, the vice president, and Donald Rumsfeld, the defence secretary. President Bush may want him to stick around as the foreign crises pile up.

fields.headline: Academics protest against Chinese arrests
fields.trailText: Academics from around the world have responded angrily to the detentions without trial of three of their colleagues in China.
fields.body:
Academics from around the world yesterday responded angrily to the detention of three of their colleagues in China.

Chinese officials arrested the three academics in February under allegations of spying. They have since been held without legal representation and in solitary confinement.

In an open letter to the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, almost 400 professors from 14 countries called the detentions a gross violation of China's criminal law and of international human rights law.

Professor Li Shaomin, from the City University of Hong Kong; Dr Gao Zhan, based at the American University in Washington DC and Dr Xu, from Oxford University, were arrested separately, but are all being held in solitary confinement, without outside visits that would reassure their international counterparts.

"What unites all of the signatories is a common hope our detained colleagues will be allowed home to the safety of their families and back to their offices to pursue their legitimate scholarly work as we ourselves are free to do," said Robin Munro, a research fellow at the University of London and one of the scholars who signed the letter.

In the letter, the scholars expressed their concern at the vague reasons for the detention of their colleagues, and called on President Jiang to demonstrate China's commitment to human rights and academic freedom by either immediately releasing the scholars or promptly giving them the chance to defend themselves in court with international standards of due process.

webTitle: Aids charity has drug makers on the run

fields.headline: Aids charity has drug makers on the run
fields.standfirst:
Climax near in South African case for cheaper medicines

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The world's big drug companies return to court in Pretoria today knowing that they have lost the first round of their battle to defend their profits at the expense of lives in the developing world.
fields.body:
The world's big drug companies return to court in Pretoria today knowing that they have lost the first round of their battle to defend their profits at the expense of lives in the developing world.

Last night some of them were scrambling to negotiate a settlement after being cowed not by the South African government but by a small militant aids rights group, the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC).

The companies went to court to challenge a South African law allowing the government to produce or import generic versions of patented drugs in certain circumstances. But the companies' case has been coming apart ever since they arrived in court.

A series of rulings by the judge questioned their right even to pursue the action. There has also been a barrage of international criticism about the moral and legal basis of the case.

They may come to regret bringing the case, not only because of the damage to their industry's reputation but also because it may result in the severe weakening of the patent rights they are trying to protect.

The court adjourned the trial six weeks ago after letting TAC make a submission which threatened to force the companies to reveal long-held secrets about their business practices.

Initially, neither of the other parties wanted TAC in court with them. But the government came to realise that it had a valuable if unconventional ally.

TAC is led by Zackie Achmat, a charismatic homosexual of 38 who attends court wearing a T-shirt with the slogan "I am HIV Positive".

He does not know when he contracted the virus. Perhaps it was during one of his stints in prison agitating against apartheid; by his own description, he had a vigorous sex life there. Or he may have picked it up as a male prostitute.

Either way, he refuses to take anti-retroviral drugs while they are not readily available to the rest of South Africa's people.

"Those of us who are privileged enough to have access to health care should use it to ensure that everyone gets treatment," he has said.

TAC was born a little more than two years ago in protest at the government's Aids policies. A number of hospitals, including the largest biggest in the southern hemisphere, Chris Hani Baragwanath hospital in Soweto, were giving anti-Aids drugs to HIV-positive pregnant women to reduce the number of children born with the virus.

For political reasons, mainly because President Thabo Mbeki's government refused to acknowledge the link between HIV and Aids, the programme was dressed up as research, but the drugs were available to all in the designated hospitals. Then the health department put a stop to the programme.

"That led to a lot of anger and was a direct reason for the formation of TAC," said Mr Achmat, who was head of the Gay and Lesbian Coalition at the time.

"But at the same time we realised that while we always condemned the government, the non-governmental organisations were spending millions of rands in Aids prevention, and it was equally limited.

"So we looked at where all this money was going, and we realised it was to the drug companies. We launched a campaign that would bring in everybody - the churches, the unions - to change the whole approach."

TAC was a driving force behind the legislation now being challenged in the high court. It publicised the drug companies' tactics, and found like minds in the South African department of health. But the government was divided.

Some officials opposed the legislation permitting the import of generic and other cheaper drugs, fearing that it would harm the confidence of investors, particularly after the US put South Africa on a "watch list" of patent pirates.

TAC's greatest victory may come in the next few days. Before the adjournment, the judge let it make a comprehensive submission as a friend of the court. When the drug companies insisted on time to prepare a response, Judge Bernard Ngoepe called their bluff. Fine, he said, but they must respond to TAC's submission point by point; any they failed to address would be taken as proved.

TAC's submission includes detailed affidavits challenging the drug companies' claim that medicines are priced to reflect the costs of research. TAC argued that the research and development bills for all five of the main anti-Aids drugs were met by American universities or the US National Institutes for Health, not the pharmaceutical producers.

"AZT was discovered 30 years before, at the Michigan Cancer Institute," Mr Achmat said.

"It was a cancer drug and the institute did all the initial research. It's the same with STC. The cancer institute met the major costs of discovery but Glaxo claims it is recovering costs. It's the same with all of them."

The companies answered this claim with their own figures. TAC's scientists argue that those numbers include a lot of spending not directly attached to the discoveries, such as marketing costs.

The TAC submission also alleges that the companies have engaged in price fixing and argues that in South Africa the constitutional right to health has greater legal weight than the constitutional right to protection of patents.

The companies have already submitted their response to the judge.

But they do not reveal the details of research funding, the profitability of individual drugs and other issues required by the court. Instead, they revive their previous argument that the new law is unconstitutional because it gives cabinet ministers too much power to decide what constitutes an "unaffordable" drug.

They also say that the government turned down an offer of cheaper medicines which would have obviated the need for generic imports.

TAC hopes the judge will focus on the companies' failure to comply fully with his order and deliver the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association another legal blow.

fields.headline: Solar flares a potential risk
fields.trailText: One of the governmemt's leading scientist warns that solar flares in space pose a potential risk as Britain becomes increasingly reliant on satellites.
fields.body:
Scientist Keith Ryden believes that solar flares in space could affect lives as Britain becomes increasingly reliant on satellites, and that British research is not keeping up with work to prevent that happening, because we have not yet grasped the risk.

The end may be nigh, but not because of a comet crashing to earth as doomsayers of old used to say, according to Mr Ryden, principal scientist in the Space Department of the government's Defence Evaluation and Research Agency, who will be spreading his message to The Royal Aeronautical Society this evening.

Sun flares create massive electromagnetic disruptions that flow outwards in waves across space, said Mr Ryden. Our understanding of the impact of these waves on satellites was largely theoretical, and based on work from the 60's, until a new series of European and American satellites were launched.

"Nasa and others have been positioning satellites four times further out than the moon, balanced in the gravity between the sun and the earth, and so relatively stable. We have seen clearly how disrupted they can be by solar flares," said Mr Ryden.

And there is a potential impact on people's lives. In the past, only ship's navigational systems and surveillance depended on satellite reliability. Now, as guidance systems are brought into cars and general technology, the effect of a possible satellite glitch is magnified.

Research into this area is advanced in Scandinavia, where the impact of solar disturbances are much more direct than in the UK. Magnetic disruption from space has actually affected the area's lengthy power grids.

The United States has also taken solar flares very seriously. "The US is well ahead of the UK. That's particularly because the US air force has seen how important it is for their defence plans," said Mr Ryden.

Useful link
Spaceweather

fields.headline: Hospitals ignoring DNA regulations
fields.trailText: Some UK hospitals are failing to meet ethical requirements when collecting people's DNA, says a leading international expert in genetic ethics.
fields.body:
Some hospitals in the UK are failing to meet ethical requirements when collecting people's DNA, according to a leading international expert in genetic ethics.

The collection of massive samples of DNA in "gene banks" is essential for academic researchers seeking to unravel the impact of particular sets of genes, identified in the human genome project, on individual's lives.

There is a firm legal and ethical requirement on hospitals that keep genetic material, which can be any body sample, even cheek swabs, to get the informed consent of patients involved. Most are sticking to that practice.

However, according Professor Bartha Maria Knopper, Chair of the Human Genome Organisation's (HUGO) Ethics Committee and today's Caledonian Research Foundation speaker at HUGO's Edinburgh conference, not everyone is playing by the rules. "Informed consent is not being done everywhere with the uniformity that this requires," she said.

For Professor Knopper, though, the greatest concern is not that gene banks are being created unethically, but that the potential benefits of genetic research are being stymied by a negative public attitude engendered by poor publicity.

"We have got to normalise genetics as being another risk factor that people face. If we can't have a normal conversation about it, then we risk stigmatising people who have genetic disorders or face increased risks. Genetics is not deterministic, it's probablistic," said Professor Knopper.

She does not believe the greatest danger is the one highlighted by recent news stories, that employers could discriminate against potential employees on a genetic basis. That individuals could face pain, suffering or disease because they are not aware of their biological propensities strikes her as a much more serious consideration.

fields.headline: Drug price wars
fields.standfirst:
Helping the poor will help the industry

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The biggest of the 39 international pharmaceutical companies trying to prevent the South African government from importing cheaper drugs to fight HIV/Aids and other diseases, privately confessed that it was sorry it had brought the law suit.
fields.body:
Last month the biggest of the 39 international pharmaceutical companies trying to prevent the South African government from importing cheaper generic drugs to fight HIV/Aids and other diseases, privately confessed to our health correspondent that it was sorry it had brought the law suit. Today, when the South African high court reconvenes after a six-week adjournment, GlaxoSmithKline (along with the other 38 companies in the suit) have an opportunity to begin repairing the damage they have wreaked in South Africa. The controversial case was adjourned by the judge to give the drug giants time to answer detailed and highly embarrassing questions on the industry's pricing policies. Here is an opportunity for the drug bosses to help the developing world - and themselves. If they withdrew from the suit today, they could signal their support for cheaper drugs for developing states - and save the notoriously secretive industry from divulging sensitive commercial information.

Rarely in the history of commerce has there been such a badly misjudged law suit. Even the industry now recognises what a PR disaster it has been. On the opening day of the civil trial there were protests and demonstrations against the drug companies round the world. Even before then, a succession of powerful international institutions had signalled their support for South Africa: the UN, World Health Organisation and the European Union. True, Tony Blair in a shameful and pusillanimous move sided with the drug giants three weeks ago, but GW Bush showed far more spunk than either Blair or Clinton. Initially, the US placed South Africa on its "watch list" of patent pirates, but Clinton relented and removed them. GW has gone much further. Even though the drug industry was one of his biggest backers, Mr Bush signalled he was not opposed to the new South African law that the drug companies are resisting.

The trial began with the drug industry arguing that "the case is nothing to do with blocking access to medicines, or price fixing. It's about patents. Patents do not block medicines. They stimulate research and development." Developments since that bold assertion have shown just how wrong it was. To select just one. Protests by students and academic staff at Yale, where a key ingredient of two Aids drugs sold by Bristol-Myers Squibb was invented (and earned the university $40m a year in royalties), prompted the company to drop its price from $20 to $2 for a daily dose. Better still, the company dropped its patent protection rights in South Africa. If Bristol-Myers can do this, why can the other 38 not follow? As the company noted: "This is not about profits and patents it's about poverty and a devastating disease."

We do not suggest cheaper drugs - or even free drugs - would solve the African HIV/Aids dilemma. Public health campaigns are much more complicated than that. As well as new clinics and staff, they need epidemiological surveillance, community education, training and distribution chains. But Africa faces a crisis. Cheaper drugs would be an enormous help as Brazil has demonstrated. There are 4.7m people infected in South Africa and 25m in sub-Saharan Africa. Drug prices have belatedly been cut and new partnerships begun. The long-term solution is a vaccine, which new international bodies are pursuing. Meanwhile, in the short-term, an industry which rightly sees the need to improve its image, has to demonstrate it is not just shareholder driven but recognises the public interest too.

webTitle: Robot with living brain created in US

fields.headline: Robot with living brain created in US
fields.trailText: Researchers in Chicago have built a cyborg, a half-living, half-robot creature which connects the brain of an eel-like fish to a computer and is capable of moving towards lights.
fields.body:
Researchers in Chicago have built a cyborg, a half-living, half-robot creature which connects the brain of an eel-like fish to a computer and is capable of moving towards lights.

The device, developed at a research centre owned by Evanston's Northwestern University, consists of the brain stem from the larva of a lamprey, a bloodsucking fish, attached by electrodes to an off-the-shelf Swiss robot.

In an arrangement reminiscent of the genesis of the Daleks, the living brain floats in a container of cool, oxygenated salt fluid.

Placed in the middle of a ring of lights, the robot's sensors detect when a light is switched on. It sends signals to the lamprey brain, which returns impulses instructing the robot to move on its wheels towards the light.

When all the lights are off, the robot stays still. When one of the robot's eyes is masked, the disembodied brain is temporarily confused, but learns to compensate.

One of the researchers, Sandro Mussa-Ivaldi, said the work was a step forward in neural engineering. "There's an element of uniqueness in what we've done, particularly in the fact we've created a closed loop system, where the lamprey brain and the robot are exchanging information," he told the Guardian.

Scientists are exploiting the immature lamprey's instinct to keep itself oriented the right way up in the water. In a cyborg arrangement, that translates into seeking light.

The marriage of baby bloodsucker and Swiss engineering has little chance of conquering the universe as yet. Scientists can only keep the brains alive for a few days and are unable to stabilise them long enough to see whether they can remember anything.

But they hope their work will ultimately lead to the creation of advanced, brain-controlled prostheses for people whose normal ability to control their limbs has been disrupted by a stroke or Parkinson's disease.

"The focus of our work is not so much to create a cyborg as to create a tool for investigating the organisation of the brain," said Dr Mussa-Ivaldi.

Other scientists are already moving towards the practical application of microelectronics to help the disabled.

In Atlanta, scientists have implanted a tiny glass electrode in the cerebral cortex of a quadriplegic patient and coaxed neurons to grow inside. By attaching a transmitter, the patient was able to move a cursor on a computer screen by thought alone.

The creation of the cyborg brings closer the advent of machines with animal parts. Advances in miniaturised electronics have inspired other scientists to try to develop devices with living biological components.

The Washington Post reported that an Iowan entomologist, Tom Baker, has attached moth antennae, capable of detecting the smell of high explosives, to an electronic device which reads variations in the nerve signals sent out by the antennae when they pick something up.

But the electronics are not sophisticated enough to distinguish one smell from another - so as yet the half-moth, half-chip machine isn't much use for its intended purpose, sniffing out land mines.

Dr Mussa-Ivaldi said cyborgs were, in a sense, already all around us. "People wearing prostheses could be considered cyborgs," he said. "Some think that when we're attached to our internet connections, we're cyborgs."

webTitle: Firms split over deal in cheap drugs lawsuit

fields.headline: Firms split over deal in cheap drugs lawsuit
fields.standfirst:
Big companies break ranks in bid to reach South African settlement

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: A split emerged last night between the world's big pharmaceutical companies over whether to proceed today with a patent rights lawsuit against the South African government that has turned into an international public relations disaster.
fields.body:
A split emerged last night between the world's big pharmaceutical companies over whether to proceed today with a patent rights lawsuit against the South African government that has turned into an international public relations disaster.

Three of the world's largest pharmaceutical firms - Britain's GlaxoSmithKline, and Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb in the US - broke ranks with 36 other companies who are party to the attempt to overturn a South African law that permits the government to import generic and other cheaper drugs to deal with health emergencies or where patented medicines are too expensive.

Last night the firms were negotiating with the South African government to reach a settlement before the Pretoria high court hearing resumes today after a six-week adjournment.

At the weekend, Nelson Mandela joined widespread international condemnation of the pharmaceutical companies' lawsuit by denouncing it as "a gross error".

"They are exploiting the situation in the developing world, because they charge exorbitant prices," he said. "This is completely wrong and must be condemned."

But Mr Mandela also said that the case could be settled through negotiation and said the South African government must "take responsibility for not doing sufficient work".

Sources close to the case said the breakaway drug companies were keen to withdraw from the lawsuit but were unable to see a way out without making concessions they are concerned could influence other countries following South Africa's lead.

The firms are particularly worried that a legal precedent might be established, allowing governments to declare individual drugs as too expensive and patents to be overridden worldwide.

If an agreement can be reached between South Africa and the three drugs manufacturers, it would exert enormous pressure on the other firms to pull out of the lawsuit and prove an important moral and legal victory for campaigners for wider access to anti-Aids drugs.

But the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (PMA), in whose name the legal challenge was filed, said it would continue the action even if only a handful of drug companies wanted to do so.

None of the parties was willing to discuss the talks publicly, but an industry source said that Merck in particular had been deeply uncomfortable about the legal action for some time and was urgently looking for a way out. Last month, amid rising international criticism of the lawsuit against South Africa, the company said it would sell two anti-Aids drugs in the developing world without profit.

GlaxoSmithKline distanced itself by using its South African subsidiary as a representative in the lawsuit and has also offered cheaper life-saving drugs to the developing world. Bristol-Myers Squib said it would not oppose generic production of its drugs in Africa, and offered to sell its anti-retrovirals for $1 each.

Last night, the head of the PMA, Mirryena Deeb, said she could not discuss the legal case. The South African government is divided on the issue. While Thabo Mbeki and some of his ministers have portrayed the case as a legal crusade by the developing world against the exploitation of multinationals, there has been concern within the administration that it will deter foreign investors.

But a health department spokeswoman, Jo-Anne Collinge, said the government would not abandon its central claim to the right to import generic and other cheaper drugs to deal with health emergencies or where prices are defined as unaffordable. "Whatever the outcome, we expect to be able to implement this legislation," she said.

If an agreement can be reached between South Africa and the three drugs manufacturers, it would exert enormous pressure on the other firms to pull out of the lawsuit and prove an important moral and legal victory for campaigners for wider access to anti-Aids drugs. But the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (PMA), in whose name the legal challenge was filed, said it would continue the action even if only a handful of drug companies wanted to do so. None of the parties was willing to discuss the talks publicly, but an industry source said that Merck in particular had been deeply uncomfortable about the legal action for some time and was urgently looking for a way out. Last month, amid rising international criticism of the lawsuit against South Africa, the company said it would sell two anti-Aids drugs in the developing world without profit. GlaxoSmithKline distanced itself by using its South African subsidiary as a representative in the lawsuit and has also offered cheaper life-saving drugs to the developing world. Bristol-Myers Squib said it would not oppose generic production of its drugs in Africa, and offered to sell its anti-retrovirals for $1 each. Last night, the head of the PMA, Mirryena Deeb, said she could not discuss the legal case. The South African government is divided on the issue. While Thabo Mbeki and some of his ministers have portrayed the case as a legal crusade by the developing world against the exploitation of multinationals, there has been concern within the administration that it will deter foreign investors. But a health department spokeswoman, Jo-Anne Collinge, said the government would not abandon its central claim to the right to import generic and other cheaper drugs to deal with health emergencies or where prices are defined as unaffordable. "Whatever the outcome, we expect to be able to implement this legislation," she said.

fields.headline: Davina gets primetime game show
fields.trailText: 6pm Davina McCall has just been signed up to front a major new "Truman Show" style entertainment show for ITV.
fields.body:
Davina McCall is to front a major new "Truman Show" style entertainment show for ITV.

It is the first new primetime role she has accepted since fronting Big Brother for Channel 4 and clinches her position as one of ITV's A-league stars.

Every week members of the studio audience of Oblivious will "discover" they have been unwitting participants in the show.

The show's makers will employ secret filming techniques to follow audience members in their everyday life during the weeks running up to transmission of each programme.

Close friends and family may collude with the programme-makers and actors will also be employed to help create certain situations.

The unwitting participants can win money without even knowing it by answering questions correctly or behaving in a certain way while they are being filmed.

Once they get to the Oblivious studio and the secret filming is revealed by McCall, contestants get the chance to gamble the money they have already won and increase it.

Oblivious is being made as a co-production between Mast Media and Tiger Aspect Productions, the company responsible for shows ranging from Gimme, Gimme, Gimme to Streetmate and Playing the Field.

IT will be executive produced by Tiger Aspect head of entertainment Mark Linsey and produced by Barbara Lee.

The Oblivious concept was created by Mast Media co-founders Mark Baker and Steve Havers, who will be acting as consultants to the show.

ITV controller of entertainment Claudia Rosencrantz has ordered six episodes of the 60-minute show.

webTitle: Bard barred for being too boring

fields.headline: Bard barred for being too boring
fields.trailText: Generations of schoolchildren have been saying it for years but finally it is official: Shakespeare is boring, unlikely and ridiculous.
fields.body:
Generations of schoolchildren have been saying it for years but finally it is official: Shakespeare is boring, unlikely and ridiculous.

At least that is the view of a committee of teachers appointed by the education department of South Africa's most important province, Gauteng, which wants to ban some of the Bard's works from state school reading lists because they have unhappy endings, lack cultural diversity and fail to promote the South African constitution's rejection of racism and sexism.

Julius Caesar never had a chance of making it past the sexism criteria, with the committee condemning the work because it "elevates men". Antony and Cleopatra and the Taming of the Shrew fared little better, both being described as undemocratic and racist.

Hamlet was declared persona non grata on the grounds that the play is "not optimistic or uplifting". But it was the "too despairing" King Lear that fared the worst. "The play lacks the power to excite readers and is full of violence and despair. The plot is rather unlikely and ridiculous," the committee concluded.

Those that slipped through included Romeo and Juliet (presumably not for its happy ending), The Merchant of Venice, (anti-semitism not being considered racism?) and Macbeth.

Shakespeare was not alone. Gulliver's Travels is to be pulled because its humour is deemed foreign to South Africans. Even the country's Nobel laureate and Booker prize winner, Nadine Gordimer, is to be removed from school libraries as her writing is allegedly "deeply racist," even though three of her books were also banned by the apartheid regime.

The Gauteng education department, which includes Johannesburg and Pretoria, is ready to ban Mrs Gordimer's July's People, which has been set reading in schools for seven years, because it is "deeply racist, superior and patronising. The novel seems one-sided and outdated".

"To be called a racist as a white South African and as someone who stayed here through all of the worst time and as someone who identified closely with the struggle - that is just very insulting," Mrs Gordimer said.

Some of South Africa's most prominent writers and artists plan to send a letter of protest to the ruling African National Congress accusing it of "political correctness gone mad".

Not the thing

Hamlet Not optimistic or uplifting. Characters not appealing to modern pupils as royalty is no longer fashionable

King Lear Not exciting. Full of violence and despair. Ridiculous and unlikely plot

Julius Caesar Sexist because it elevates men

Antony and Cleopatra Racist and undemocratic

Othello Racist and sexist. A bleak and pessimistic tone

fields.headline: Beryl Gilroy
fields.standfirst: An innovative Caribbean writer, novelist of the black diaspora and London's first black head teacher
fields.trailText: An innovative Caribbean writer, novelist of the black diaspora and London's first black head teacher.
fields.body:
Beryl Gilroy, who has died of a heart attack aged 76, was a novelist, writer, London's first black head teacher and one of Britain's most significant post-war Caribbean migrants.

Born in Springlands, Berbice, Guyana (then British Guiana), she grew up in a family with a commitment to learning - rather than the current rigid system of schooling. The interplay between valuing curiosity and the thorough acquisition of skills helped foster a mind of great creativity. She was also growing up at a time when anti-colonial radicalism and pro-worker politics inspired hope.

From 1943 to 1945, Beryl attended Georgetown's teachers' training college, leaving with a first-class diploma. After graduation, she taught and lectured for the Unicef's nutrition programme.

She always maintained that her decision to go for further study in England, rather than the United States, was decided by exchange rates rather than visions of Britain. Arriving in 1951, after initially facing problems in finding employment as a teacher, she taught from 1953-56 in Inner London Education Authority schools. It was a period recounted in her autobiographical Black Teacher (1976).

The publisher softened her book, fearing for its sales, but it was a harsher account of the conditions of her mainly white, working-class pupils, and of the obstacles facing black teachers, than that of ER Braithwaite's To Sir With Love (1959). Braithwaite was one of the first post-war West Indian writers resident in London whom Beryl got to know.

She also retained a special affection for the writer and editor Andrew Salkey. For a key period in the 1950s, Salkey was the writer-in-residence and main presenter in the BBC World Service's Caribbean section, and he was generous in his support of young, especially women, writers. Taking women seriously as writers - unless they were dead - was unusual among that group. At a conference to honour Salkey, held a few years before his death in 1995, she forcibly stressed that point.

Her own creative writing for adults would be delayed for decades. She continued to add to her academic qualifications - and found people who shared her radical politics. The broad progressive alliances that she knew from Guyana she met again in England.

Most importantly, in a personal sense, she found her English husband Patrick. With their loving marriage to support her, from 1959 to 1968 - when she rejoined the ILEA - she devoted her energies to bringing up her family, but managed to fit in writing textbooks and books for children.

As the parent of "mixed-race" children - a curious term seeming to question the humanity of one parent - she encountered as much nonsense from the supposedly better-educated as she had in her working-class schools. Her own good sense and Patrick's support helped her remain unscathed.

In 1968, she became deputy head and then head of Beckford primary school. Some of her experiences are in Black Teacher, but a sequel never appeared. In 1982, she joined London University's Institute of Education and the Ilea's Centre for Multicultural Education. This ended her direct involvement in schools but opened a new phase in her career, in which she applied her psychological knowledge to her teaching experience. Later, she got a doctorate in counselling psychology.

The death of her husband in 1975 affected her and her children deeply, but she learnt from it. All this contributed to her understanding of children, which she passed on to friends and teachers, both in Britain and the US. The hideous politics of Guyana stopped her doing that work there. She was also a founder member of Camden Black Sisters.

The mid-1980s marked a return to her abiding interest of writing. She showed herself once more an innovator. Her first novel, Frangipani House (1986), set in Guyana, explored issues of ageing, hitherto absent in West Indian novels.

She began to explore the history of the Caribbean and African diaspora in the period of slavery. Steadman And Joanna (1996) was the first of these; her most recent, the as-yet unpublished She Wore Silk, has as its central character a black woman involved in the Gordon Riots of 1780. Her qualities as a writer were more slowly appreciated by critics than readers.

For her work in education and her writing, the Institute of Education made her a fellow, and the University of North London conferred an honorary doctorate. She is survived by her son Paul, her daughter Darla, and two grandchildren.

Jessica and Eric Huntley write: Years after she left her birthplace of Springlands, on the banks of the Corantyne River, and sharing a border with Dutch-speaking Suriname, Beryl Gilroy transformed its oral history into prose and poetry.

The young Beryl, at a time when most children were at school, spent time with her grandparents and many aunts, immersing herself in the folklore, sayings, knowledge of medicinal plants, and stories of the Ndjukas, across the river in Suriname.

There was no learning by rote for her, and her fantastic memory stored those days to become the subject matter for her stories.

In Georgetown, after graduation, the authorities provided early recognition that she was an especially gifted teacher. Unicef aside, she became head of the infant section of Broad Street government school - a premier institution in its day - teaching by activity, as her extended family had in Springlands.

In a sense, that 1951 arrival in England meant that she had come home, for, like many of her generation, she was a colonial at heart, even if those early years in the "mother country" tested her resilience.

But there were those other expats to relieve the gloom: people such as Andrew Salkey, George Lamming from Barbados (whose The Emigrants was published in 1954), and Samuel Selvon (The Lonely Londoners, 1956).

We had the pleasure of working with Beryl on the Bogle-L'Ouverture reprint of Black Teacher (1994). She was the best publicist of her work, always full of confidence - even in the last few months when her work was obviously inhibited by illness, she was planning an American lecture tour.

For the past 26 years, Beryl was a widow, much like those aunts of her childhood. "It is not easy being a widow, or a widower for that matter, although lonely widows always buzz around a man on his own," she wrote to us last December. She had written a story on the subject, based on a friend's experience of how he had made his choice between four women. "They all had to cook," she went on. "Three made elaborate meals and one gave him 'Welsh Rabbit', his favourite: he had cooked it for himself since his wife died and eating it was one way of being with her, in loving intimacy."

 Beryl Gilroy, teacher and writer, born August 30 1924; died April 4 2001

fields.headline: I think we should do...
fields.standfirst:
The problem with thinktanks is their futility. But a 'do-tank' is the one actually redesigning schools

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The problem with thinktanks is their futility. But a 'do-tank' is the one actually redesigning schools.
fields.body:
We have one day to save humanity. That's what the words say, printed on ultra-glossy paper in fetching shades of grey, pink and orange. Quite a claim. Apparently we have just "one day to meet people's real needs, physical and emotional". There are only "nine hours to restore the population's faith".

What is this doomsday warning? What latter-day Book of Revelation have I stumbled across? It's a leaflet promoting a one-day conference on design and the creative industries, that's what. Talk about hyperbole. What will doubtless be a useful conference of academics, designers and business people has been oversold as an exercise in global redemption. They are calling it Superhumanism.

Perhaps we shouldn't pick on this one event, organised by the Foreign Policy Centre. For the centre is only one of nearly a dozen London-based thinktanks which are equally culpable. Day in, day out, these factories of thought churn out ever-brighter, ever-glossier documents - despatched with a great thud on to desks in newsrooms, universities and parliamentary offices. At a Stakhanovite rate, they produce leaflets and pamphlets, position papers and modest proposals, mini-books and printed-up lectures until there is an engulfing avalanche of words, words, words.

The thinktankers' industry is admirable. But in order to be heard above the cacophony of their own, competing voices they are forced to make ever-more overblown, even ludicrous claims. "One day to save humanity" probably takes the biscuit, but Demos - the mid-90s darling of the New Labour set, now supplanted by the hotter Institute for Public Policy Research - came a pretty close second with its release this winter of a document billed as the "reinvention of politics".

It's hard to blame them. The researchers beavering away have only one index of success: press coverage. A pamphlet is deemed to have done well if it gets written about in the papers and to have flopped if it is ignored. No wonder they resort to hyperbolic promotion; they want to get noticed.

But this is a sorry waste of energy. All that combined brainpower just to produce shiny-covered papers which might make a small story on page 9, before being tossed into the newsroom recycling bin. It's not that the authors are not energetic or brilliant: many of the sharpest minds advising the current government are graduates of the thinktank. But their efforts do seem horribly futile. Their best ideas could be just as easily expressed in a newspaper or magazine article, where they would have the added bonus of reaching more people.

Now, however, there is an alternative. At last there is another outlet for all that cerebral talent. Forget the thinktank; make way for the "do tank".

The model of the form is School Works, a group committed to transforming education by rethinking the buildings in which education happens. School Works believe that if schools change physically, they will begin to change culturally, too. Start with the basics: the toilets. Right now, too many kids go home rather than use the dirty, vandalised facilities in their rundown school. They go - and they don't come back. Or take lockers. Many comprehensives got rid of them years ago, leaving pupils with nowhere to put their coats. They go to classes, even eat lunch, feeling as if they have never quite arrived at school because they spend all day with their coats on. They don't bring the right books to class, because they don't want to lug them round all day. Lack of lockers means a lack of learning.

What are School Works doing with this information? Are they publishing it in a neat, 20-page pamphlet with a cover in shocking pink? Are they organising a one-day conference, with big-name speakers? No. They are using this knowledge to turn around a school. An actual school.

They have lighted upon Kingsdale in Southwark, south London. It is what Alastair Campbell would call a "bog-standard comprehensive", only recently taken off Ofsted's special measures. School Works spent three months listening to the people who use Kingsdale - teachers, parents and, above all, pupils - to hear what they needed and now they have won more than £9m from the Department of Education to refurbish it in a radically different way. Instead of the old Victorian model, with classrooms arranged like assembly lines with pupils in serried rows, the school will acquire a new shape. The endless corridors will go; rooms will be in clusters not long lines. Kingsdale will slowly start looking like the real world, where people do not move around at once, in masses, but are able to move freely and at different times. The school will no longer be preparing children for the factory floor past, but equipping them for the modern, hi-tech present and future. The crucial innovation is that in Kingsdale architecture and education, long regarded as separate by local and central government, are joining up.

"What we realised is that the built environment has a clear effect on the way any institution works," says School Works' founder and creator, Hilary Cottam. A former aid worker who cut her teeth in Mozambique and Zambia, Cottam is convinced that the best policy comes from the ground up. You have to speak to the people who use any service to find out what they really need: that's what she did with villagers in Africa and that's what she's doing here. Next she aims to do for prisons what she is doing for schools, and she's already got a £40,000 grant from the Design Council to make it happen. That, too, will come under the new body she has created: the Do Tank.

Even if you disagree with Cottam's specific schemes, you can't help but feel her approach makes sense: policy informed by on-the-ground experience, grass-roots work designed to inform policymaking. (School Works hope Kingsdale will eventually become a model repeated nationwide.) So many of the ideas dreamed up by thinktanks sound wonderful on paper, but fall at the hurdle of practicality: they could never be implemented. Equally, there are countless good, local innovations which are never replicated. Do-tankery might be a way to solve both problems at once.

And, who knows, perhaps this brand of thoughtful, practical work will appeal to all those bright young things who leave college eager to change the world - and end up writing papers for the Fabian Society. Perhaps they might decide to become social entrepreneurs instead, giving up a year or two to work in a real-life project on the ground. There is a precedent. One of Bill Clinton's most popular initiatives was Americorps, his domestic version of John F Kennedy's peace corps, which enabled college leavers to give a year or two of "national service" - teaching in the inner city, helping the old or cleaning up the environment. It was a vote-winner for Clinton; maybe Tony Blair will want to propose a peace corps for Britain. Now that's an idea for the second term! Perhaps I should issue it as a pamphlet - on fabulously glossy paper.
