No. They are using this knowledge to turn around a school. An actual school. They have lighted upon Kingsdale in Southwark, south London. It is what Alastair Campbell would call a "bog-standard comprehensive", only recently taken off Ofsted's special measures. School Works spent three months listening to the people who use Kingsdale - teachers, parents and, above all, pupils - to hear what they needed and now they have won more than £9m from the Department of Education to refurbish it in a radically different way. Instead of the old Victorian model, with classrooms arranged like assembly lines with pupils in serried rows, the school will acquire a new shape. The endless corridors will go; rooms will be in clusters not long lines. Kingsdale will slowly start looking like the real world, where people do not move around at once, in masses, but are able to move freely and at different times. The school will no longer be preparing children for the factory floor past, but equipping them for the modern, hi-tech present and future. The crucial innovation is that in Kingsdale architecture and education, long regarded as separate by local and central government, are joining up. "What we realised is that the built environment has a clear effect on the way any institution works," says School Works' founder and creator, Hilary Cottam. A former aid worker who cut her teeth in Mozambique and Zambia, Cottam is convinced that the best policy comes from the ground up. You have to speak to the people who use any service to find out what they really need: that's what she did with villagers in Africa and that's what she's doing here. Next she aims to do for prisons what she is doing for schools, and she's already got a £40,000 grant from the Design Council to make it happen. That, too, will come under the new body she has created: the Do Tank. Even if you disagree with Cottam's specific schemes, you can't help but feel her approach makes sense: policy informed by on-the-ground experience, grass-roots work designed to inform policymaking. (School Works hope Kingsdale will eventually become a model repeated nationwide.) So many of the ideas dreamed up by thinktanks sound wonderful on paper, but fall at the hurdle of practicality: they could never be implemented. Equally, there are countless good, local innovations which are never replicated. Do-tankery might be a way to solve both problems at once. And, who knows, perhaps this brand of thoughtful, practical work will appeal to all those bright young things who leave college eager to change the world - and end up writing papers for the Fabian Society. Perhaps they might decide to become social entrepreneurs instead, giving up a year or two to work in a real-life project on the ground. There is a precedent. One of Bill Clinton's most popular initiatives was Americorps, his domestic version of John F Kennedy's peace corps, which enabled college leavers to give a year or two of "national service" - teaching in the inner city, helping the old or cleaning up the environment. It was a vote-winner for Clinton; maybe Tony Blair will want to propose a peace corps for Britain. Now that's an idea for the second term! Perhaps I should issue it as a pamphlet - on fabulously glossy paper. jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Kewell: Bring on Valencia
fields.trailText: Leeds United's players today looked forward to their Champions League semi-final against Valencia after surviving a battering from Deportivo La Coruna.
fields.body:
Leeds United's players today looked forward to their Champions League semi-final against Valencia after surviving a battering from Deportivo La Coruna.

Harry Kewell admitted the outcome could have been so different as Leeds desperately clung on for a 3-2 aggregate victory, but said that thoughts must now turn to the future. "The dream keeps going, although it was very nearly derailed," he conceded. "We went across with the intention of winning the game, but from the start they pinned us back.

"They showed us how to play football, while we were very sluggish and in the end we got away with it," he added. "It feels very strange to be celebrating a 2-0 defeat.

"But we're through and that's all that counts and we can look forward to playing Valencia. I just hope we can play a lot better than we did last night and make it through to the final, and we've a good chance of getting there now."

Kewell has targeted the final itself as the match to show he is finally back to his best, after a season frustratingly marred by injury. By his own admission he is still struggling to complete games, and last night he was substituted with 15 minutes remaining.

"The aim would be to peak and be fully fit for that game because I reckon I'm only 80 to 85% at the moment, although I am getting stronger and stronger.

"It's just a matter of getting that last 10 minutes' worth of energy. But after all the problems this season, I'm just happy to be playing again and getting a run in the side.

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale meanwhile played down his team's chances of lifting the greatest prize in European club football.

He said: "I still don't think we believe we can win it because if you look at the teams that are going to get through - Real Madrid or Galatasaray, Bayern Munich or Manchester United - they are big names in European football.

"We are probably the least experienced side going through and that will be the case in the last four, but who knows?"

fields.headline: Cyborgs
fields.standfirst: Scientists have managed to graft a lamprey's brain to a Swiss robot. Here's our guide to the best cyborg sites around
fields.trailText: Scientists have managed to graft a lamprey's brain to a Swiss robot. Here's our guide to the best cyborg sites around.
fields.body:
1. What will they think of next? Researchers in Chicago have created a unique cyborg - in this case a robot with a living brain.

2. Researchers connected the brain of a lamprey, an eel-like fish, to a Swiss robot in a bid to create brain-controlled prostheses.

3. At the moment these fishy Frankensteins can do little more than move towards light and the disembodied brain can only survive a few days.

4. A cyborg can be defined as any kind of a biological being aided or melded with electronics; for example, someone wearing a hearing aid could qualify.

5. Most of the cyborg experimentation going on right now is intended to have real world medical uses, for example with Parkinson's disease or paralysis.

6. Some folks just won't stop, though. Kevin Warwick, the media loving head of the Cybernetics Department at the University of Reading, has plans to install a chip in his brain that will allow computer control of his left arm. However many others in the field of cybernetics have condemned this scheme as "irresponsible".

7. Try as he might, the cyborg academic will never be better, faster, or stronger than the Six Million Dollar Man.

8. Since Lee Majors' debut, books and movies have dealt with cyborg angst, cyborg violence and even cyborg feminism.

9. And of course the sex industry has detailed plans for cybernetics. It can all get so realistic that some people may need to seek help.

10. So although the fishbot might not look like much, humans should be aware that one day a cyborg could rule the universe.

fields.headline: Tomb raiding's no game
fields.standfirst: The return of a classical bust from a US museum heralds the first triumph in Italy's war on cultural plundering, reports Rory Carroll in Palestrina
fields.trailText: The return of a classical bust from a US museum heralds the first triumph in Italy's war on cultural plundering, reports Rory Carroll in Palestrina.
fields.body:
Italy has scored a victory in its battle to prise looted treasures from American and European museums. A 2nd century marble sculpture has been returned after a 45-year odyssey through the underworld art market.

Police traced the bust of a victorious athlete, a copy of a 5th century BC original by the Greek sculptor Polykleitos, to the J Paul Getty museum in Malibu, California. Archaeologists hailed it as the vanguard of hundreds of stolen artifacts which would be reclaimed from public and private collections outside Italy.

"This is a beautiful piece of work and the best news we have had in years. We are very happy it has come home. Now we can pursue items in Paris, London and Munich," said Maria-Luisa Nava, of the culture ministry's archaeological department.

Moves by Britain, Switzerland and the US to ban trade in looted antiquities have coincided with an Italian crackdown on tomb robbers. A multi-million pound black market in ransacking history is feeling the squeeze.

The 10.2kg bust was copied from a Greek bronze statue of a young athlete fresh from triumph, possibly in the Olympics. It was unveiled last week in the former Roman colony of Venosa, deep in southern Italy, from which it disappeared in 1956 soon after excavation.

The Getty, one of America's richest and most aggressive collectors, acquired it in 1996. The museum declined to tell Guardian Unlimited who was the seller.

A brief statement said a decision was made to hand over the display after being alerted to its provenance by a specialist in Polykleitan sculpture. The museum's website made no reference to the bust or the handover.

Sources from the police unit dedicated to protecting Italy's heritage claimed it took hard bargaining to persuade the Getty. The head of the unit, General Roberto Conforti, attended the unveiling.

Archaeologists welcomed the transfer as the first major success of a January bilateral agreement between Italy and the US to make restitution quicker and easier.

"We know of hundreds of artifacts in the Louvre, in the British Museum, in Germany, Denmark and America, that we want back. It is rather delicate and will require lots of diplomacy but we're confident," said Dr Nava.

Britain opened the door last month when Alan Howarth, the arts minister, said the government would sign a United Nations convention banning illicit trade in cultural property.

Interpol implicated Britain's art market, the second largest in the world, in trafficking stolen antiquities. Switzerland is drafting legislation which could end its status as Europe's key transit point for smugglers later this year.

"These initiatives could put a real dampener on the trade. Take out America, Britain and Switzerland and the market is squeezed. Nobody will be able to buy the stuff," said Neil Brodie, head of the McDonald Institute's illicit antiquities' research centre.

A new front against tomb robbers has been established in Palestrina, south of Rome, with Italy's first exhibition of recovered stolen artifacts, titled Wounded Archaeology. The aim was to convince the public that so-called tombaroli were not amateur archaeologists but criminals who destroyed heritage for profit, said organiser Sandra Gatti.

Items secretly excavated were stripped of context and could no longer tell a story, said Dr Gatti. Tourists and schoolchildren yesterday gaped at fragments of Etruscan, Sabine and Roman civilisation displayed in the archaeological museum, adorned with statistics of rising police seizures.

Recovered artifacts from a 3rd century BC necropolis in Colombella revealed a ruling elite which flaunted wealth by stashing their tombs with bronze mirrors, vases and necklaces. Inscriptions and designs showed some princes were freed slaves who became merchants, suggesting an upwardly mobile, relatively democratic society.

Pride of place went to a 460BC ceramic cup adorned with a satyr warrior. Stolen in 1994, a German Mercedes executive bought it the following year for £32,000 at a Sotheby's auction.

webTitle: Comment: English is taking over in Europe

fields.headline: English is taking over in Europe
fields.standfirst: In Brussels some languages are more equal than others
fields.trailText: In Brussels some languages are more equal than others.
fields.body:
The 11 official languages of the 15 members of the EU have equal rights. These are Danish, Dutch, English, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish and Swedish. These are official and working languages of the European parliament and the commission in Brussels.

Since there has never been a close fit between language and state in Europe, three of Belgium's languages are in use - Dutch, French and German - and two of Finland's - Finnish and Swedish. The only language from Spain, however, is Spanish, even though there are more speakers of Catalan than of Danish or Finnish. Many languages in Europe have no EU rights.

Language is a sensitive political issue. As some languages are more "international" than others, the equality of the 11 languages has, in fact, always been a myth. The existing rights to translation are essential, because documents emanating from Brussels have the force of law in member states. But the right to an interpreter is often restricted, except for senior politicians and members of the European parliament. Working documents are seldom available in all 11 languages.

In 1970, 60% of texts in the commission were initially drafted in French and 40% in German. In 1989 the figures were: French 50%, German 9%, and English 30%. By 1997 the figures were: French 40% and English 45%, leaving only a sprinkling in other languages. In external communication, English is generally used.

These figures reveal the de facto hierarchy of languages in Brussels and Strasbourg. English has gradually eroded the monopoly of French. Ironically enough this has happened during a period when successive British governments have kept "Europe" at arm's length. The advance of English reflects American commercial, political and military might, and the impact of Hollywood, CNN and McDonald's. The British, however, have always been keen to capitalise on English as a strategic and commercial asset. English is the most widely learnt foreign language in Europe because Britain's partners recognise it as a necessary tool.

In reality English is no longer a foreign language in several member states. It is widely used internally, and increasingly as the corporate language of big business. It is a fact of working and social life for many EU citizens.

The market forces that are propelling English forward impact on the vitality and viability of other languages. English is capturing some of their territory, despite EU treaties and summit meetings proclaiming a commitment to diversity.

In several member states there are voices protesting against Americanisation and cultural and linguistic homogenisation. Ulrich Ammon has recently written a book exploring whether German, the leading language of the natural sciences a century ago, can still be considered a language of science. Norway's transport minister has protested about the website of the Scandinavian airline SAS being exclusively in English.

The Swedish government recently commissioned a major survey which documents how English is taking over. Work is now under way to ensure that Swedish remains a "complete" language. Investigations of domain loss to English in all the Nordic languages are currently being commissioned.

Several countries are thus following in the steps of the French in registering that the advance of English is a problem. Policy should ensure that people learn and use English in addition to other languages rather than at their expense.

Big business is likely to be taking language policy seriously. A recent US doctoral study in international law concluded that French language-protection measures conflict with the principle of a common market with free movement of goods, services, labour and capital. Such an interpretation could soon lead corporate lawyers to challenge national language legislation, and demand an English-only market throughout the EU.

Countries applying for EU membership have probably assumed that their languages will have the same rights as other official languages. This is most unlikely, since the present interpretation and translation services are ineffective and will be even more unworkable when new states join the EU.

Attitudes need to be rethought. Scoffing at French efforts to shore up their language is myopic. And if native speakers of French and English can use their mother tongues, how can one ensure equivalent rights for others? English can be appropriated without other languages being marginalised.

 The author is research professor at the Department of English, Copenhagen Business School.

 Guardian Weekly is holding a debate today on Global English: the European Lessons. Details from Guardian Weekly.

fields.headline: Stansted hijack jury dismissed
fields.trailText: The jury in the trial of 11 Afghan men accused of hijacking an aircraft and holding passengers hostage at Stansted airport was discharged today after failing to reach verdicts.
fields.body:
The jury in the trial of 11 Afghan men accused of hijacking an aircraft and holding passengers hostage at Stansted airport was discharged today after failing to reach verdicts.

Following a three month trial, the six women and five men reached verdicts in relation to two of the men but could not agree on the remaining 49 charges.

Bruce Houlder, QC, prosecuting, told the Old Bailey the crown would be seeking a retrial in relation to the outstanding charges.

The 11 had denied hijack, possessing firearms, possessing explosives, false imprisonment of passengers and false imprisonment of the cabin crew.

The Ariana Boeing 727, carrying 164 passengers and crew, was forced to fly from Afghanistan to the Essex airport in February last year.

A three-day siege followed which ended peacefully with the alleged hijackers surrendering to armed police.

The defendants at the Old Bailey were: Ali Safi, 35, Abdul Shohab, 21, Taimur Shah, 29, Kazim Mohammed, 28, Waheed Lutfi, 23, Reshad Ahmadi, 19, Nazamuddin Mohammidy, 28, Abdul Ghayur, 25, Mohammed Showaib, 26, Aminullah Mohamedi, 42, and Mohammed Safi, 33.

Aminullah Mohamedi was cleared of hijacking and one charge of false imprisonment on the directions of the judge. The jury found him not guilty of the remaining charges.

Waheed Lutfi, 23, was cleared by the jury of hijack but faces retrial on the other charges. Bail was renewed until next Tuesday when the date of the new trial will be fixed.

The defendants, many of them members of an intellectual group, claimed they had been forced to flee Afghanistan because they were due to be executed by the ruling Taliban group.

Lord Thomas QC, defending Mr Mohamedi, told the jury during the trial that the lack of political freedom in Afghanistan would not be tolerated in Britain. He said: "The Taliban are vicious and dangerous nutters."

Mr Mohamedi had told police he was employed by one of the other defendants and did not know anything about the hijack until he got on to the plane.

webTitle: Robert Altman starts shooting British murder mystery

fields.headline: Robert Altman starts shooting British murder mystery
fields.standfirst: Plus: Pesci to play real-life mobster; Sylvester Stallone aims for big web presence
fields.trailText: Plus: Pesci to play real-life mobster; Sylvester Stallone aims for big web presence
fields.body:
Production has begun on veteran director Robert Altman's new all British film Gosford Park according to Ananova. The murder mystery will be shot entirely on location in the UK and among those appearing are Stephen Fry, Derek Jacobi, Helen Mirren, Maggie Smith and Kristin Scott Thomas. Set in November 1932, the film revolves around an elegant hunting party weekend at a country estate. It brings together an aristocratic family and their friends, including a famous Hollywood actor and producer and, possibly, a number of killers. It is expected to be released sometime next year.

Variety reports that Joe Pesci, who won an Academy Award for his supporting role in mob drama GoodFellas is in talks to star in a new film about real-life Mafia hitman Sammy "the Bull" Gravano. Pesci's involvement in the film, titled "Sammy the Bull", is conditional upon the project being developed as a theatrical release, whereas at the moment it is scheduled as a TV movie.

Sylvester Stallone is boosting his presence on the web by launching what is described as the "biggest Sly multimedia site in the world". The Rambo star's new website, whose unveiling has been scheduled to coincide with the American cinema release of his new movie Driven on 27 April, will feature sound clips as well as interviews with the man himself. webTitle: Where there's a Wiltord there's no way

fields.headline: Where there's a Wiltord there's no way
fields.standfirst: Paul MacInnes picks over Arsenal's Champions League failure and finds some striking problems
fields.trailText: Maybe it's ironic, or perhaps just apposite, that Arsenal were knocked out of the Champions League last night by a typically English goal. A deep cross onto the edge of the six-yard box, a sharp header tucked away by a striker who wouldn't look out of place chasing small thieving children down beanstalks.
fields.body:
Maybe it's ironic, or perhaps just apposite, that Arsenal were knocked out of the Champions League last night by a typically English goal. A deep cross onto the edge of the six-yard box, a sharp header tucked away by a striker who wouldn't look out of place chasing small thieving children down beanstalks.

Arsenal used to have a striker like that, although Malcolm McDonald's time at Highbury is now just a memory. But how the Gunners could have done with a barnstorming centre-forward last night, and to be honest, the past two seasons. It's an inability to finish chances that has sent the Gunners out of Europe, and left them way off Manchester United in the Premiership. And if Arsene Wenger doesn't sort out the problem this summer, they won't win anything next season either.

As has been observed many times by the nation's foremost pundits (John Beresford, Barry Venison etc.), the Gunners never get enough players into the box. This may have something to do with the fact that they don't actually have a decent striker at the club.

That's not intended as a criticism of M Thierry Henry of course. The man is a world-class talent, and scoring 21 goals when your natural inclination is to drift in from the left wing is testament to that. But as often as not, and it happened again with Arsenal's best chance last night, it is Henry who provides the final ball for his team-mates, not the other way round.

Which brings us nicely onto Sylvain Wiltord. If the Euro 2000-winning Frenchman is only £2m less of a striker than Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink then I'm also a Dutchman. For a start, his finishing isn't anything to write home about - only against QPR could you get away with scoring a hat-trick of scuffs. But more worrying is that, for someone who's supposed to be the new Ian Wright, Wiltord is never in the right place at the right time. The goalscoring instinct may not be something you can teach, but when you spend £13m you might hope to get a bit of it.

What makes things worse is that of the four strikers you supposedly have to have if you are to compete at the top level, Arsenal have two who don't even give the pretence of scoring goals. Dennis Bergkamp has never been a 20 goal-a-season striker, and is barely playing 20 games a season nowadays. Kanu, meanwhile, is what the Italians might call a fantasista and is a firm favourite of the Highbury crowd. But the Nigerian has no interest in playing at the cutting edge of a team, as is shown by his record of only 28 goals in two-and-a-half seasons.

Patrick Vieira has today gone on record to confirm what everyone already thought - that Arsenal should never have sold Emmanuel Petit. The absence of his defensive cover, combined with the ever-increasing age and fragility of the Arsenal backline (Tony Adams and Martin Keown have managed only 20 games together this season), means that the Gunners can no longer cling to narrow victories like they used to. But if they scored half as many goals as they ought, then that wouldn't be a problem.

So what should the Gunners do to turn things around? See if they can sell off Sylvian Wiltord for a reasonable fee for a start (chances are that they won't have that opportunity by the end of next season when the transfer changes kick in), and cash in on Bergkamp too if possible. That would leave enough money to pick up somebody who plies their trade in the six yard box: perhaps Francis Jeffers from Everton, Celtic's Henrik Larsson, or maybe even a certain disgruntled young striker in Paris.

webTitle: The chase for European places explained

fields.headline: The chase for European places explained
fields.trailText: With Manchester United finally wrapping up the title on Saturday, the only matter of interest at the top of the table is the hunt for European places.
fields.body:
With Manchester United finally wrapping up the title on Saturday, the only matter of interest at the top of the table is the hunt for European places.

The top three in the Premiership will qualify for the Champions League. But while only fourth spot is technically guaranteed a place in the Uefa Cup, the reality is that teams finishing as low as seventh could book a place in Europe's second competition.

Thanks to Liverpool and Arsenal's exploits in the domestic cups, the sixth-placed team is guaranteed Uefa Cup football - providing Liverpool and Arsenal both finish in the top six. And if Leeds win the Champions League but finish outside the top three, seventh spot will become an additional European place, offering hope to the likes of Aston Villa and Sunderland.

Below we gaze into our crystal ball and outline the prospects for the teams in the European hunt.

ARSENAL

Remaining fixtures:
Everton (H)
Derby (A)
Leeds (H)
Newcastle (A)
Southampton (A)

Arsenal are in pole position in the mini-league behind United. They can afford to lose a game and still not be caught by any of the chasing pack. With current European distractions removed following defeat to Valencia, Arsenal's destiny is very much in their own hands, and they remain favourites to secure another crack at the Champions League.

IPSWICH

Remaining fixtures:
Coventry (H)
Charlton (A)
Man City (H)
Derby (A)

Ipswich have the easiest run-in, playing three of the bottom five sides. Coventry and Man City, scrapping for their Premiership lives, are potentially troublesome opponents, but Ipswich have home advantage against both. Leeds and Liverpool can draw level with Ipswich if they win their games in hand, but both teams have trickier run-ins. The Tractor Boys may never have a better chance than this to secure a massive monetary windfall and regular fixtures against Europe's elite.

LEEDS

Remaining fixtures:
West Ham (A)
Chelsea (H)
Arsenal (A)
Bradford (H)
Leicester (H)

Other than an away match against Arsenal, Leeds should feel confident of winning their remaining fixtures. A two-legged semi-final against Valencia will prove a draining distraction, but Leeds have shown themselves more than capable of competing on the elevated European stage, and their best chance of doing so again remains a top-three league finish. Along with Ipswich, they rank as favourites to claim third spot.

LIVERPOOL

Remaining fixtures:
Tottenham (H)
Coventry (A)
Bradford (A)
Newcastle (H)
Chelsea (H)
Charlton (A)

Liverpool have games in hand but, at this stage, points on the board are a far greater source of confidence. Given their rivals' fixture lists, Liverpool must realistically win at least five of the remaining six matches to stand a chance of a Champions League berth. Their league form remains inconsistent and a resurgent Coventry, as well as a Chelsea side suddenly cured of their travel sickness, constitute considerable obstacles. Add in a FA Cup and, potentially, Uefa Cup final to focus on, and many Liverpool fans may already be resigned to another season in Europe's secondary cup competition.

CHELSEA

Remaining fixtures:
Charlton (H)
Leeds (A)
Everton (H)
Liverpool (A)
Man City (A)

A scintillating surge of form by Chelsea has thrown them firmly into the Champions League equation. They have to keep accumulating wins while relying on teams above them to drop points. At the very least, Chelsea must defeat both Leeds and Liverpool away from home. Even allowing for their fine recent results on the road, this is an extremely tall order. Fifth or sixth place remains the more likely league finish.

ASTON VILLA

Remaining fixtures:
Southampton (H)
Tottenham (A)
Coventry (H)
Newcastle (A)

To finish in the top six, Villa have to acquire at least 10 out of the remaining 12 points available to them and pray that a truly drastic fate befalls one of the teams above them. Failing the occurrence of this improbable scenario, Villa can desperately cling to the remote prospect of Leeds winning the Champions League while coming fourth in the Premier League, thereby opening up seventh place to Uefa qualification. Otherwise, a straight scrap with Sunderland for the Intertoto Cup spot looks like the most likely scenario.

SUNDERLAND

Newcastle (H)
Southampton (A)
Charlton (H)
Everton (A)

The Black Cats find themselves in an identical situation to Villa - same points, similar goal difference, equally difficult fixture list. The Stadium of Light in Portugal looks more likely to witness European football next year than its namesake in the north-east of England. In the highly unlikely event that seventh spot in the Premier League secures Uefa Cup football, Villa and Sunderland will find themselves challenged by Charlton, Tottenham, Leicester, Southampton and Newcastle.

fields.headline: Therapeutic hideaway for wayward priests
fields.trailText: Our Lady of Victory near Stroud, Gloucestershire, is one institution where errant Roman Catholic priests have long been sent for rehabilitation. Built on a terrace in a picturesque valley with lawns sloping down to woods, it has the appearance more of a Cotswold manor house than a clinic.
fields.body:
Our Lady of Victory near Stroud, Gloucestershire, is one institution where errant Roman Catholic priests have long been sent for rehabilitation. Built on a terrace in a picturesque valley with lawns sloping down to woods, it has the appearance more of a Cotswold manor house than a clinic.

But in the lecture hall and consulting rooms, alcoholic, gay and paedophile clergymen are offered counselling and support.

These are issues acknowledged quietly by some Catholic priests to be exacerbated by the solitary, often lonely, and celibate life of the priesthood.

Celibacy is a discipline imposed by the church, rather than by a theological imperative, and therefore one that might one day be changed, if the shortage of priests becomes sufficiently pressing.

In Britain the church accepted more than 100 married Anglican priests for ordination some years ago when they fell out with the Church of England over its decision to ordain women.

Of more concern to some in the Catholic church is the fear that increasing numbers of priests are gay. A book by an American theologian last year estimated that as many as 50% of young US ordinands were homosexual.

Being gay is still viewed as a scandal and a sin and hence a suitable reason for treatment and rehabilitation at centres such as Stroud.

But when it comes to child abuse, the church has for many years been in denial - that the problem exists and is intractable in sufferers, and that it is something that requires firm action. This has inhibited the church from tackling it, rather than just reacting to individual cases and occasionally buying off complainants.

Even though it has had guidelines in place since 1994, some clergy have been slow to acknowledge or accept them. In a deeply hierarchical church, there is a limit to what outside agencies can do.

When Archbishop John Ward of Cardiff was found last year to have ignored the guidelines - and even a warning from a fellow bishop - in ordaining a priest subsequently convicted of child abuse, there was nothing the church could do to censure him, other than calling him in for a carpeting by the papal nuncio in London.

The recommendations of the Nolan review will at least focus the hierarchy's attention on the principle that the needs of children are paramount, rather than protecting the good name of the church. But there are still unanswered questions about how priests can be disciplined - or protected from bogus allegations.

The clinic, often referred to as Stroud, is run by an American order, the Servants of the Paraclete, established in New Mexico in the 1940s. The order opened Our Lady of Victory, its only British centre, in the 1960s. The clinic offers "therapy in a spiritual context".

It is believed that up to 30 residents stay there, usually for a year to 18 months. They tend to be referred by their bishops or other senior clergy.

Michael Hill, the priest jailed for five years in 1997 for indecent assaults on children, was once there but left after three months. He was appointed chaplain at Gatwick in the 1980s by Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, now Archbishop of Westminster but then bishop of Arundel and Brighton, despite complaints that he had been a risk to children.

The centre has attracted criticism. An assistant priest who spent a week there after it was discovered that he was a practising homosexual compared it to "purgatory" complaining of the "gross invasion of privacy, the lack of freedom of movement and the oppressive, claustrophobic atmosphere".

It hit the headlines in 1993 when Father Sean Seddon, 38, was sent there after a six-year affair with a teacher. On learning his lover had lost their baby, he threw himself under a train.

Institutions such as Our Lady of Victory are apparently becoming less popular. The tendency is for priests to be treated in secular organisations.

Yesterday nobody at the centre was available for comment.

Sex attacks

Between 1995 and 1999, 21 Catholic priests were convicted of sexual offences against children. Reported sex cases include:

 1996: Durham priest Adrian McLeish jailed for six years after admitting 12 charges of child abuse

 1997: Michael Hill, a former Gatwick chaplain, jailed for five years for indecent assault and gross indecency over a 19-year period

 1998: Eric Taylor jailed for seven years for abusing boys in his care at the Father Hudson Society's home in Warwickshire, between 1957 and 1965

 1998: John Lloyd , press officer to the Archbishop of Cardiff, jailed for eight years for indecent assaults against children

 2000: Joe Jordan , a Cardiff priest, jailed for eight years for sexually abusing boys

 2000: Investigation at a leading Catholic school, the London Oratory . Pupils alleged they were abused by David Martin , a priest who died of a suspected Aids-related illness in 1998

 2000: Robert Deadman , a Cistercian monk who offered spiritual healing to women, convicted of indecently assaulting four women. The jury heard he carried out attacks in the confessional

 2001: Allegations of torture, beatings and sexual molestation at St Ninian's school in Stirlingshire

fields.headline: Crackdown on abuse by priests
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church was told yesterday that it must appoint child protection representatives in every parish in England and Wales to head off the wave of criticism that has broken over the church after a series of high-profile abuse cases involving clergy.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church was told yesterday that it must appoint child protection representatives in every parish in England and Wales to head off the wave of criticism that has broken over the church after a series of high-profile abuse cases involving clergy.

Even closed religious orders will be required to select protection coordinators as part of a 50-point strategy recommended by an independent committee headed by Lord Nolan, the man who laid down standards for parliament. Everyone working in the church - staff, volunteers and clergy - will be subject to police checks and all applicants will be asked to disclose details of any criminal offences against children and young people.

The 35-page report represents an all but unprecedented, wide-ranging secular assault on the practices of a church where bishops and clergy have traditionally had unquestioned authority.

Lord Nolan told a press conference in London: "The care of children is at the forefront of the teachings of Christ. We believe that the Catholic church in England and Wales should become an example of best practice in the prevention of child abuse and in responding to it.

"Our overriding aim has been to create a secure environment for children. We also want to ensure a consistent and effective approach across the church to allegations of child abuse."

The review is intended to supersede guidelines in place since 1994, which proved ineffective. They were brought into question last year when Archbishop John Ward of Cardiff was seen to have ignored warnings from a fellow bishop in ordaining a priest, Father Joe Jordan, who was subsequently jailed for eight years for indecent assaults against children.

It remained unclear how far the new recommendations would be accepted, although Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, leader of the church in England and Wales, has pledged that they will be adopted when bishops meet in London next week.

Yesterday he said cautiously that the "extremely constructive and helpful" report would form a main item for discussion. "We are committed to ensuring that the Catholic church becomes the safest of places for children and I am sure this report ... will help us to achieve this."

The cardinal came under attack last year for his action as bishop of Arundel and Brighton in the 1980s in moving Father Michael Hill, a priest accused of sexual abuse, from one parish to another and eventually to a chaplaincy at Gatwick airport, where he assaulted a child with learning disabilities. Hill was jailed for five years in 1997 after being convicted of assaults over a 19-year period. He is now free.

The review was set up last autumn to head off criticisms that the church had tolerated abuse by priests and had too often appeared more concerned to protect its clergy than those they were abusing.

Between 1995 and 1999, 21 Catholic priests were convicted of sexual offences against children, two were tried but acquitted, 10 charged but subsequently had the charges dropped, 63 investigated but never charged and six given a police caution.

The review recommends that a national database be set up on all candidates for ordination, that allegations be responded to swiftly, and that cautioned or convicted abusers should not hold any position bringing them into contact with children. It also proposes more pastoral provision to help victims and support parishes.

The report says priests must not give away confidences heard at confession. All new confessionals will have to be constructed so that both priest and parishioner remain visible, if not audible, to those outside.

In extreme cases - where sentences of more than 12 months have been passed on offenders - the review recommends that priests be laicised, effectively dismissed.

Although the review was broadly welcomed by children's charities, some former victims remained unconvinced of the effectiveness of the recommendations.

One, abused at a Catholic children's home in Warwickshire by Father Eric Taylor, an 80-year-old priest who is serving a seven-year prison sentence, said: "The proposals are wishy-washy. A voluntary code by itself will never work. It is going to be pretty difficult to weed out these people."

Lord Nolan said: "I think the accusations have done great harm to the church. Whatever reluctance it has shown in the past to grapple wholeheartedly with child abuse, the church is now fully committed to setting a lead in the matter."
fields.bodyText: The Roman Catholic church was told yesterday that it must appoint child protection representatives in every parish in England and Wales to head off the wave of criticism that has broken over the church after a series of high-profile abuse cases involving clergy. Even closed religious orders will be required to select protection coordinators as part of a 50-point strategy recommended by an independent committee headed by Lord Nolan, the man who laid down standards for parliament. Everyone working in the church - staff, volunteers and clergy - will be subject to police checks and all applicants will be asked to disclose details of any criminal offences against children and young people. The 35-page report represents an all but unprecedented, wide-ranging secular assault on the practices of a church where bishops and clergy have traditionally had unquestioned authority. Lord Nolan told a press conference in London: "The care of children is at the forefront of the teachings of Christ. We believe that the Catholic church in England and Wales should become an example of best practice in the prevention of child abuse and in responding to it. "Our overriding aim has been to create a secure environment for children. We also want to ensure a consistent and effective approach across the church to allegations of child abuse." The review is intended to supersede guidelines in place since 1994, which proved ineffective. They were brought into question last year when Archbishop John Ward of Cardiff was seen to have ignored warnings from a fellow bishop in ordaining a priest, Father Joe Jordan, who was subsequently jailed for eight years for indecent assaults against children. It remained unclear how far the new recommendations would be accepted, although Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, leader of the church in England and Wales, has pledged that they will be adopted when bishops meet in London next week. Yesterday he said cautiously that the "extremely constructive and helpful" report would form a main item for discussion. "We are committed to ensuring that the Catholic church becomes the safest of places for children and I am sure this report ... will help us to achieve this." The cardinal came under attack last year for his action as bishop of Arundel and Brighton in the 1980s in moving Father Michael Hill, a priest accused of sexual abuse, from one parish to another and eventually to a chaplaincy at Gatwick airport, where he assaulted a child with learning disabilities. Hill was jailed for five years in 1997 after being convicted of assaults over a 19-year period. He is now free. The review was set up last autumn to head off criticisms that the church had tolerated abuse by priests and had too often appeared more concerned to protect its clergy than those they were abusing. Between 1995 and 1999, 21 Catholic priests were convicted of sexual offences against children, two were tried but acquitted, 10 charged but subsequently had the charges dropped, 63 investigated but never charged and six given a police caution. The review recommends that a national database be set up on all candidates for ordination, that allegations be responded to swiftly, and that cautioned or convicted abusers should not hold any position bringing them into contact with children. It also proposes more pastoral provision to help victims and support parishes. The report says priests must not give away confidences heard at confession. All new confessionals will have to be constructed so that both priest and parishioner remain visible, if not audible, to those outside. In extreme cases - where sentences of more than 12 months have been passed on offenders - the review recommends that priests be laicised, effectively dismissed. Although the review was broadly welcomed by children's charities, some former victims remained unconvinced of the effectiveness of the recommendations. One, abused at a Catholic children's home in Warwickshire by Father Eric Taylor, an 80-year-old priest who is serving a seven-year prison sentence, said: "The proposals are wishy-washy. A voluntary code by itself will never work. It is going to be pretty difficult to weed out these people." Lord Nolan said: "I think the accusations have done great harm to the church. Whatever reluctance it has shown in the past to grapple wholeheartedly with child abuse, the church is now fully committed to setting a lead in the matter."

webTitle: Suspended officer accuses Met of race bias

fields.headline: Suspended officer accuses Met of race bias
fields.standfirst:
New twist to bitter battle which prompted £1m investigation

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: One of Britain's highest ranking ethnic minority police officers yesterday launched a claim of racial discrimination against the Metropolitan police.
fields.body:
One of Britain's highest ranking ethnic minority police officers yesterday launched a claim of racial discrimination against the Metropolitan police.

Superintendent Ali Dizaei, 39, has been suspended since January over allegations of wrongdoing brought by the force, including sex with prostitutes and corruption.

The discrimination claim is the latest development in an increasingly bitter battle between the Iranian-born officer and the Met, which has been under fire for its record on race after the Stephen Lawrence inquiry branded it "institutionally racist".

The Guardian has learned details of two new allegations served by the Met last week against the officer. They allege Mr Dizaei received a gratuity of two tickets to a social event at a London hotel, and that after an Iranian music concert Mr Dizaei drafted a letter for the organisers praising his role in policing the event which was sent to the Met commissioner.

Supporters of the officer expect him to be questioned under caution about the allegations this month, following a massive investigation believed to have cost £1m and involved phone taps and covert surveillance.

He is yet to be charged with any criminal or disciplinary offences.

In his employment tribunal claim, Mr Dizaei says the Met discriminated against and victimised him because of his race and because of his work for the black police association for which he was the legal adviser.

Sadiq Khan, solicitor for the suspended officer, said Mr Dizaei had been recommended by Sir Paul Condon, the former Met commissioner and by a national selection board to be fit to be promoted to chief officer level.

But a Met selection board rejected him for interview for a lesser job of chief superintendent.

According to his application lodged with the employment tribunal, Mr Dizaei claims the decision to investigate and then suspend him was linked to his previous complaints to superior officers that he had been racially discriminated against: "The respondent's officers decided to victimise the applicant for his considering that the treatment that he had received was on the grounds of his race by 'throwing the book at him' by seeking to dig up any possible complaint that might be made and to investigate it."

Ravi Chand, chair of the national black police association, said: "It is becoming increasingly evident that black and Asian members of the police service do not have any trust or confidence in internal complaints procedures.

"There is overwhelming evidence of the unfair treatment of Supt Dizaei. Taking the Metropolitan police to tribunal is the only way [he] can seek justice from a service riddled with senior officers who have become 'the untouchables' when it comes to accountability."

Senior officers at Scotland Yard have rubbished claims that they are conducting a racist witch hunt against Mr Dizaei, describing his conduct before suspension as "absolutely horrendous".

It was a ruling by an employment tribunal that came to the rescue of Sgt Gurpal Virdi, who was found guilty by a Met disciplinary panel of sending racist hatemail to himself and others.

The force agreed to pay compensation after an employment tribunal found that the force had racially discriminated against Mr Virdi.

webTitle: Police close in on Bradford riot suspects

fields.headline: Police close in on Bradford riot suspects
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Police in Bradford are closing in on a racially mixed group of drinkers whose insults to a party of Hindus during the bank holiday triggered serious violence in the city.
fields.body:
Police in Bradford are closing in on a racially mixed group of drinkers whose insults to a party of Hindus during the bank holiday triggered serious violence in the city.

At least one of three men bailed in connection with violent disorder is understood to have been with the young men whose behaviour started a pub fight which spilled out into the street and led to an attack on an Asian takeaway.

But detectives have found no evidence yet to back claims that the group - mostly white but including Afro-Caribbeans and Asians - had pre-planned an incident in the Lidget Green area to cause the sort of violent "revenge reaction" by Asian youths which saw eight cars torched and three pubs severely damaged.

Detective Superintendent Phil Sedgwick, head of the investigation, said: "Racist behaviour does play a part in this investigation, but several separate things went on. We are looking at the behaviour of all groups, not just one."

Further arrests are expected after a thorough study of video film taken by officers during the incident - a tactic not used during the £1m Manningham violence in Bradford in 1995. On this occasion damage amounting to several hundred thousand pounds was done to businesses owned by whites, Muslims and Hindus.

Most of the burnt out cars belonged to guests at the Hindu engagement party. Indian and white guests of Jyoti Narbheran and her fiance, Gareth Williams, had to crouch inside the Coach House pub when fighting started in the bar and windows were smashed.

A woman motorist was yesterday still in Bradford royal infirmary with a serious eye injury after a stone smashed through her car windscreen as she drove past. Like other victims of the clash, including the party guests from London and Leicester, she was not from Bradford.

Seven other people are recovering from cuts, bruises and shock, and two pubs, the Coach House and the Second West, where 60 customers huddled in an upstairs room as the building was showered with stones and set on fire, will be closed for months.

The Lidget Green area returned to its usual calm overnight, although extra police were prominent and five fire engines were kept on standby.

The three bailed men, a 32-year-old white, a 19-year-old Asian and a "dark European" aged 42, are expected to face further questioning.

Civic leaders in Bradford called for a thorough investigation of the rapid train of events that saw the fight escalate. Several warned of increasing "ghettoisation" in the city.

The development of ghettos was the theme of an interim report three months ago by the Bradford district race review panel. Led by Sir Herman Ouseley, former head of the commission for racial equality, it warned that the city was becoming split on racial and religious lines.

Although Bradford has a generally good reputation for community relations, and plenty of ethnic minority business leaders and councillors, the panel warned that young people from all groups were mixing less.

One of the city's most prominent Hindu businessmen, Hasmukh Shah, was a victim of the Lidget Green violence. His chemist shop in Horton Grane Road was looted by Asian youths. Mr Shah said a neighbour described the mob as "Muslim thugs". He said: "I challenge any statement by police that this was not caused by inter-religious problems."

The local Labour MP, Gerry Sutcliffe, said: " We have got to get to the bottom of this and bring people to justice quickly." Public confidence over violence had been shaken, he said, after a failure to prosecute anyone over bonfire night violence in 1999.

fields.headline: Plc, Pep, and Pat
fields.trailText: MIND THE JAAP
fields.body:
MIND THE JAAP

It's the Big Cup game all Europe is talking about. But enough about Real Madrid v Galatasaray already - let's divert our Saxon-centric blue eyes towards Bayern Munich v Manchester United instead. Today, both teams went into their over-hyped clash (what's the betting it scores at least seven on the Liverpool-away-from-home-dull-o-meter?) making strangely unconfident noises. Jaap Stam expressed doubts for chrissakes, while - even more bizarrely - it was all quiet on the Giovane Elber front! In fact the only startling news was that Peter Schmeichel - on today of all days! - decided to make a pitch for the Imperial Lord Ferg's job.

"I would like to have that job," Schmeichel monotoned, before pulling out an Uzi and blasting John Connor to kingdom come. "I would like to go into management at a later stage in my life and obviously I have always set myself targets. That is the biggest job in football so that is the one I am going to go after." But the good news for United fans - and anyone else really - is that Schmeichel doesn't want the position just yet. "I wouldn't like to be anywhere near that job for the first 10 or 15 years," he added, unveiling a distinctly long-term management masterplan.

Meanwhile, back in Bavaria, the news is that Elber has recovered from injury and will play for Bayern, while United are expected to replace the suspended David Beckham with Nicky Butt, moving Paul Scholes out to the right. But Jaap Stam is sounding more uncertain by the minute. "I can tell you that since we arrived in Munich, confidence is running high inside the United camp," he confessed. But then the St John's Wort wore off, and the doubts crept back in. "But to be honest, if we go out to Bayern our title party won't be as big as it could have been. We can't contemplate going out now. It would be so sad to do so." Indeed it would, Jaap. Indeed it would.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PEP PLC

Welcome to Pep Guardiola Inc. A recently formed start-up, this small company hopes to head into profit within the next six months and then, within six months of that, wind the company up and buy half of the South Pacific. The business plan is not over-complicated and, as far as we can see, has two distinct points. (1) To arrange Pep a loads-a-money transfer from Barcelona to a Serie A side; and (2) Before that deal is completed, shove it under the noses of a few Premiership clubs, and get them to fork out even more.

A masterstroke, we're sure you'll agree. The initiative was announced this morning by the Gazzetta dello Sport (like Teamtalk in Italian, and occasionally truer). They claimed that pretty-boy Pep has signed a pre-contract agreement on a four-year deal with Parma, currently fourth in Serie A. However, according to the report, Pep has insisted on two conditions. Firstly that Pep would only join if they qualify for one of Italy's four Big Cup places. Secondly, Pep would be able to reject the deal at any point if a more lucrative offer arrived from a Premiership team.

Which may suggest that foreign players don't just come to England out of love for the food, weather and transport infrastructure. But it may also be a warning to Premiership managers who can't keep their hands out of other people's pockets. Managers like Gerard Houllier, maybe, who revealed his love for Pep today. "Guardiola is a player I respect and admire," said the bonkers Frenchman, visibly excited at the prospect of signing his 14th defensive midfielder. "We are interested in any good player if they can strengthen our squad, and you can write that," he went on, to the disappointment of the town criers in the audience.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'm disappointed I won't be facing Patrick in the semi-final. So to make up for it, I will give him some tickets to watch us against Valencia - but then I have to be careful what I say now because whenever I make a joke it doesn't come across very well!" - Are you trying to be funny, Olivier Dacourt?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ARSE END OF THE SEASON

It can't be an easy day to be an Arsenal player. Having been knocked out of Big Cup by that nasty bully John Carew, there's nothing left to do until August. Well, there's some exhibition match towards the end of the season but what's the point in that? So it's no surprise to see the likes of Arsene Wenger holding his head in his hands, Lee Dixon stomping around with a gob on, and Tony Adams going out on a 16-novel bender. Luckily, one of the more sensible lads is keeping his head: step forward level-headed Patrick Vieira, and tell us where it all went wrong.

"I feel very disappointed to have gone out to Valencia because I believe we have looked a better team than them," Pat told French newspaper Le Parisien. "But we do need more players in the squad. I feel it was a mistake at the club not to keep [He Was He Is] Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars to their contracts when they went to Barcelona in the summer." The tall French midfielder then fell to his knees, beat the ground with his fists and caterwauled: "We miss them!"

Still, better out than in, and Vieira was soon up on his feet stating calmly and rationally, in that slightly irritating way modern professional footballers do, that he won't be much fussed if the Arse go on to win the FA Cup and finish second in the league. "That is the minimum when you wear the Arsenal shirt," he said with an insouciant shrug of one eyebrow. "But I have to be honest, even if we manage to reach these two objectives, I would qualify our season as average. In the championship we are 15 or 20 points adrift of Manchester United, so for me it's really a season to be forgotten!" Fair enough, Pat. So if you do win the Cup, we can assume you won't be skipping about on the pitch for hours with the lid on your head, then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri could move for Benito Carbone if Gianluca Zola leaves Stamford Bridge at the end of the season. Speaking on Italian TV, Ranieri admitted: "Zola is a fantastic player. However if he does decide to go, then I must have a replacement ready to come in. We already have some players in mind, and Carbone certainly would be a player we would consider."

Blackburn Rovers winger Damien Duff is being targeted by Liverpool.

Leicester midfielder Robbie Savage has been approached by Real Betis about joining them in the summer if they get promoted to the Primera Division.

Coventry, Ipswich and Sunderland are all interested in Brighton's 28-goal striker Bobby Zamora.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

David Buchler, Tottenham's new chief executive, has told fans money will be spent "wisely" on new acquisitions and that Spurs must follow the route taken by their north London rivals Arsenal if they are to succeed. "There is money available but we need to spend this money wisely and attract players to this club wisely," he said. "We must recognise that our north London rivals, who have spent nearly half the money this club has over the last five years [netto, netto], have developed a squad and a team undoubtedly superior to our side when we lost the FA Cup semi-final."

Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe has distanced the club from reports linking Brighton manager Micky Adams with the vacant post at the Dell. A newspaper report suggested Adams was Saints' "top target", but Lowe said: "I don't know who put it there, but it has no truth in it. Whether it's an agent or representative I don't know. [Adams] has done very well at Brighton, but we are concentrating on the last six games. We rule nobody in and nobody out."

Nolberto Solano will play for Newcastle in this weekend's Tyne-Wear derby, despite being under orders to report for Peru's World Cup qualifier against Brazil. "Saturday is a game we must win for the fans and that is why I want to stay and play for Newcastle before I go off with Peru," Solano said. "Don't forget, this will be my last game for United before my two-match suspension and I want to make it a good one."

Dundee's chief executive Peter Marr has met with Claudio Caniggia and his agent today to try to end the speculation that the Argentine is set for a summer move to Rangers. A Dundee spokesman said: "It's an opportunity to discuss where the speculation is coming from with the player during the last couple of weeks and establish what substance, if any, there is to what we keep hearing."

The Football League have asked all member clubs to observe a minute's silence before this weekend's matches in memory of referee Mike North, who collapsed and died during Monday's Third Division match between Southend and Mansfield. All officials will wear green shirts with black armbands.

Crystal Palace midfelder Jamie Pollock has extended his loan spell at Birmingham to a second month.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Bayern Munich v Manchester United (7.30pm) Yesterday we witnessed Sideshow Bob Wilson's life fall to pieces. And things aren't getting any better, because here he is, pressing his nose up against the studio window while Des is inside in the warm, having a great time with all his great mates.

The Big Match (11.45pm) Brr, it's cold outside. And they're even letting Gabby Yorath and Barry bloody Venison in! Bah.

Football Extra (3.35am) Bob hangs around for ages in the hope that someone will take pity on him, invite him inside, and let him do a continuity link. But no.

Sky Sports 1: The Last Word (6.30pm, 10pm SS3) Bob wakes up with a start. Hooray! It must all have been a dream!

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am) But Bob has woken up in a wheelie bin. Sob! Is he destined to walk the streets for eternity, never to anchor a major footballing event on terrestrial television ever again?

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (9.30pm, 11pm SS1) "There's a voice that keeps on calling Bob."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) "Down the road, that's where he'll always be."

Midweek 6-0-6 with David Mellor (10pm) "Every stop he makes, he makes a new friend."

talkspOrt: Football First Champions League Special (7pm) "Can't stay for long, just turn around, and he's gone again."

The tall French midfielder then fell to his knees, beat the ground with his fists and caterwauled: "We miss them!" Still, better out than in, and Vieira was soon up on his feet stating calmly and rationally, in that slightly irritating way modern professional footballers do, that he won't be much fussed if the Arse go on to win the FA Cup and finish second in the league. "That is the minimum when you wear the Arsenal shirt," he said with an insouciant shrug of one eyebrow. "But I have to be honest, even if we manage to reach these two objectives, I would qualify our season as average. In the championship we are 15 or 20 points adrift of Manchester United, so for me it's really a season to be forgotten!" Fair enough, Pat. So if you do win the Cup, we can assume you won't be skipping about on the pitch for hours with the lid on your head, then. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri could move for Benito Carbone if Gianluca Zola leaves Stamford Bridge at the end of the season. Speaking on Italian TV, Ranieri admitted: "Zola is a fantastic player. However if he does decide to go, then I must have a replacement ready to come in. We already have some players in mind, and Carbone certainly would be a player we would consider." Blackburn Rovers winger Damien Duff is being targeted by Liverpool. Leicester midfielder Robbie Savage has been approached by Real Betis about joining them in the summer if they get promoted to the Primera Division. Coventry, Ipswich and Sunderland are all interested in Brighton's 28-goal striker Bobby Zamora. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF David Buchler, Tottenham's new chief executive, has told fans money will be spent "wisely" on new acquisitions and that Spurs must follow the route taken by their north London rivals Arsenal if they are to succeed. "There is money available but we need to spend this money wisely and attract players to this club wisely," he said. "We must recognise that our north London rivals, who have spent nearly half the money this club has over the last five years [netto, netto], have developed a squad and a team undoubtedly superior to our side when we lost the FA Cup semi-final." Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe has distanced the club from reports linking Brighton manager Micky Adams with the vacant post at the Dell. A newspaper report suggested Adams was Saints' "top target", but Lowe said: "I don't know who put it there, but it has no truth in it. Whether it's an agent or representative I don't know. [Adams] has done very well at Brighton, but we are concentrating on the last six games. We rule nobody in and nobody out." Nolberto Solano will play for Newcastle in this weekend's Tyne-Wear derby, despite being under orders to report for Peru's World Cup qualifier against Brazil. "Saturday is a game we must win for the fans and that is why I want to stay and play for Newcastle before I go off with Peru," Solano said. "Don't forget, this will be my last game for United before my two-match suspension and I want to make it a good one." Dundee's chief executive Peter Marr has met with Claudio Caniggia and his agent today to try to end the speculation that the Argentine is set for a summer move to Rangers. A Dundee spokesman said: "It's an opportunity to discuss where the speculation is coming from with the player during the last couple of weeks and establish what substance, if any, there is to what we keep hearing." The Football League have asked all member clubs to observe a minute's silence before this weekend's matches in memory of referee Mike North, who collapsed and died during Monday's Third Division match between Southend and Mansfield. All officials will wear green shirts with black armbands. Crystal Palace midfelder Jamie Pollock has extended his loan spell at Birmingham to a second month. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: The Big Match - Bayern Munich v Manchester United (7.30pm) Yesterday we witnessed Sideshow Bob Wilson's life fall to pieces. And things aren't getting any better, because here he is, pressing his nose up against the studio window while Des is inside in the warm, having a great time with all his great mates. The Big Match (11.45pm) Brr, it's cold outside. And they're even letting Gabby Yorath and Barry bloody Venison in! Bah. Football Extra (3.35am) Bob hangs around for ages in the hope that someone will take pity on him, invite him inside, and let him do a continuity link. But no. Sky Sports 1: The Last Word (6.30pm, 10pm SS3) Bob wakes up with a start. Hooray! It must all have been a dream! You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am) But Bob has woken up in a wheelie bin. Sob! Is he destined to walk the streets for eternity, never to anchor a major footballing event on terrestrial television ever again? Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (9.30pm, 11pm SS1) "There's a voice that keeps on calling Bob." Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) "Down the road, that's where he'll always be." Midweek 6-0-6 with David Mellor (10pm) "Every stop he makes, he makes a new friend." talkspOrt: Football First Champions League Special (7pm) "Can't stay for long, just turn around, and he's gone again."

webTitle: Answers to the Waterstone's/Guardian World Book Day Competition

fields.headline: Answers to the Waterstone's/Guardian World Book Day Competition
fields.standfirst: The competition
fields.trailText: Question 1: Which Doctor?
fields.body:
Question 1: Which Doctor?

Then the Doctor was very happy; for all the lions and the leopards and the antelopes and the giraffes and the zebras - all the animals of the forests and the mountains and the plains - came to help him in his work.

Answer: Doctor Doolittle

Question 2: Name the heroine we are introduced to with the following words: handsome, clever, and rich, with a comfortable home and happy disposition

Answer: Emma Woodhouse in Emma

Question 3: From which Dickens novel does the following reflection come?

It touches me nearly now, although I tell it lightly, to recollect how eager I was to leave my happy home; to think how little I suspected what I did leave for ever.

Answer: David Copperfield

Question 4: Name the imaginary country referred to in the following passage and the novel in which it appears:

I should have lived happy enough in that country, if my littleness had not exposed me to several ridiculous and troublesome accidents; some of which I shall venture to relate.

Answer: Brobdingnag in Gulliver's Travels

Question 5: Name the surprise guest

What is the matter, Uncle Jack? Do look happy! You look as if you had toothache, and I have got such a surprise for you. Who do you think is in the dining-room? Your brother!

Answer: Ernest - The Importance of Being Ernest

Question 6: Which Shakespearean monarch proclaimed: We few, we happy few, we band of brothers

Answer: Henry V

Question 7: Whose childhood?

And how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.

Answer: Alice In Wonderland

Question 8: What was the turning point, and in whose life?

It was the turning point in my life. Of course it wouldn't seem so important to you. I've been here for a year and I've been so happy. Of course, I've had my troubles, but one can live down troubles

Answer: Anne of Green Gables; coming to Green Gables

Question 9:

Where think'st thou he is now? Stands he, or sits he?
Or does he walk? Or is he on his horse?
O happy horse, to bear the weight of ******!
Do bravely, horse! For wot'st thou whom thou movest?
The demi-Atlas of this earth, the arm
And burgonet of men.

Which is the lover speaking here, and who is the object of her affections?

Answer: Cleopatra speaking about Antony, in Antony and Cleopatra

Question 10: Identify the James Joyce novel in which the following passage appears?

He was alone. He was unheeded, happy and near to the wild heart of life. He was alone and young and wilful and wildhearted, alone amid a waste of wild air and brackish waters and the sea-harvest of shells and tangle and veiled grey sunlight and gayclad lightclad figures of children and girls and voices childish and girlish in the air.

Answer: Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man

Question 11: Name the collection of autographical pieces by the author of the Salterton Trilogy, Robertson Davies?

Answer: Happy Alchemy

Question 12: What was the sequel to John Sutherland's collection of literary puzzles, Is Heathcliff a Murderer?

Answer: Can Jane Eyre be Happy?

Question 13: What is the title of the collection of fairy tales Oscar Wilde originally wrote for his children?

Answer: The Happy Prince and Other Stories

Question 14: Which Samuel Beckett play features a character buried to the waist in a mound?

Answer: Happy Days

Question 15: Which co-creator of The Fast Show and would-be 1980s popstar is also author of psychological thriller Happy Now?

Answer: Charlie Higson

Question 16: Which Paul Theroux travelogue details his excursions in the South Pacific?

Answer: The Happy Isles of Oceania

Question 17: Name Albert Camus' posthumously published novel that can be seen as the basis for The Outsider

Answer: Happy Death

Question 18: Name the first collection of stories, published over 30 years ago, by the teller of tales of life in small town Ontario, Alice Munro.

Answer: Dance of the Happy Shades

Question 19: Name Dawn Powell's satire on Greenwich Village caf* society

Answer: Happy Island

Question 20: Name the author of Happy Mouseday, whose book The Sheep Pig formed the basis of the hit film Babe?

Answer: Dick King Smith

fields.headline: Guru-Murthy is C4's Number One
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: Channel 4 News anchor Krishnan Guru-Murthy is to host a new gameshow for the broadcaster, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Channel 4 News anchor, Krishnan Guru-Murthy, is to present a new gameshow for the broadcaster.

In an unexpected move for the TV newsman, Guru-Murthy will front the afternoon show, Number One, when it starts this summer.

The show features 10 contestants battling each other in a game of strategy and general knowledge for a cash prize of up to £2,500.

Contestants move around podiums in the studio, which are ranked one to 10, according to how successful they are at answering questions.

The person on the lowest ranking podium is eliminated at regular intervals.

"Intelligent and accessible quiz formats have long been a successful hallmark of Channel 4 daytime," said Jo McGrath, commissioning editor for daytime at Channel 4.

"Number One is an exciting addition to our afternoon line-up."

The show is being made by Initial Midlands, a subsidiary of Big Brother's producer, Endemol Entertainment UK.

Ms McGrath has ordered 46 half-hour episodes, which will go out in the 4pm afternoon slot later this year when 15-to-1 takes its regular summer break.

Number One is a first daytime commission for Initial, whose TV credits include the Bafta Film Awards and Miss World.

The gameshow is being series produced by Richard Hague, with Richard Osman and Initial managing director Tim Hincks executive producing.

fields.headline: Srebrenica officer pleads not guilty
fields.standfirst: Special report: Yugoslavia war crimes
fields.trailText: A Bosnian Serb brigade commander accused of unleashing a weeklong rampage in Srebrenica that killed thousands of Muslims pleaded not guilty today to charges of complicity in genocide and war crimes.
fields.body:
A Bosnian Serb brigade commander accused of unleashing a weeklong rampage in Srebrenica that killed thousands of Muslims pleaded not guilty today to charges of complicity in genocide and war crimes.

Colonel Dragan Obrenovic is also accused of trying to cover up the largest massacre in Europe since the second world war by exhuming the bodies of victims and reburying them in mass graves.

Col Obrenovic, 38, made his first appearance before the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia since his arrest in Zvornik, Bosnia, on Sunday by Nato-led peacekeeping forces.

He could face a maximum sentence of life imprisonment if found guilty of one of five counts of complicity in genocide and crimes against humanity for the extermination, murder and persecution of Muslims.

"Your honour, I am not guilty," Col Obrenovic told the presiding Australian judge, David Hunt. Dressed in a black suit, crisp white shirt and tie, he stood nervously with his hands clasped before him as he entered a separate plea to each of the five charges he faces.

The court has already heard evidence on the Srebrenica massacre from a witness in the trial of General Radislav Krstic, Col Obenovic's commander.

In the summer of 1995, Serb troops bombarded Srebrenica for five days and gunned down columns of refugees fleeing the town.

At least 7,500 Muslim men and boys were reported dead or missing. Some victims killed themselves to escape capture, and many who surrendered were summarily executed.

According to the indictment, Col Obrenovic was the acting commander of the Zvornik brigade that played a major role in the assault. Eyewitnesses said the bodies of the executed were transported in truckloads to common graves.

Some were dug up later and relocated to try to keep the killings secret. The UN had designated Srebrenica as a "safe haven", where militants were to be barred and civilians protected, and posted 150 Dutch troops there to protect the town of 60,000 residents in eastern Bosnia.

But Serb forces, who alleged that Muslim militants were using the safe haven as cover, easily overran the town. The UN acknowledged in 1999 its error in expecting 150 Dutch troops to deter thousands of Serb fighters.

Also facing war crimes charges for their actions in Srebrenica are two of the most wanted fugitives of the 1992-95 Bosnian war, the wartime Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his highest ranking general, Ratko Mladic.

webTitle: Cath Taylor wins Big Brother account

fields.headline: Cath Taylor scoops Big Brother PR account
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: The PR firm has been appointed to handle online and commercial PR for the new series, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
PR firm Cath Taylor Associates has been appointed to handle the online and commercial PR for the new series of Channel 4's Big Brother.

The agency will liaise with the licensing and commercial partners being lined up to take part in the next phase of the Big Brother phenomenon.

These partners are likely to include mobile phone and PDA companies, which will launch interactive Big Brother services such as text messaging.

The PR agency will also look after Endemol's side of the Big Brother website, which is likely to be hosted jointly with Channel 4.

Cath Taylor, head of the agency, already understands the intensity of the job as her husband - PR maestro James Herring - masterminded the PR operation for last summer's Big Brother.

Channel 4 will appoint a separate PR agency to handle publicity surrounding Big Brother's storyline and characters.

Cath Taylor Associates has also clinched a deal with independent TV production company Talkback.

Under the deal, the agency will handle PR for the BBC shows They Think it's all Over and Nick Hancock's chat show, You Only Live Once.

The agency will also handle an international campaign for Rapture TV's Ibiza coverage this summer.

webTitle: Tutsis toppled from power in Burundi

fields.headline: Tutsis toppled from power in Burundi
fields.trailText: The Burundi government, which has waged an eight year war on ethnic Hutu rebels, has been overthrown, state radio said today.
fields.body:
The Burundi government, which has waged an eight year war on ethnic Hutu rebels, has been overthrown, state radio said today.

Information is sketchy but Reuters report that gunfire was heard in the streets around the radio station before the announcement.

A group calling itself the Young Patriots has claimed to be behind the coup.

"The government which is killing people is over and the government of Buyoya is over now," state radio said.

President Pierre Buyoya, an ethnic Tutsi soldier who has led the country since 1996, is currently attending peace talks with the Hutu rebel leader, Jean-Bosco Ndayikengurukiye, in neighbouring Gabon.

Since 1993, more than 200,000 people have been killed in the civil war.

Mr Buyoya himself took power in a coup in July 1996, promising to end the civil war.

He signed a power-sharing agreement last August with Hutu opposition leaders. But the talks, mediated by the former South African president, Nelson Mandela, did not include the Hutu rebels.

There are 17 political parties participating in the current negotiations, 10 Tutsi and 7 Hutu.

Tutsi hardliners have opposed any talks with the rebels and rumours of a coup have been rampant since Mr Buyoya signed the power-sharing agreement last August in Arusha,Tanzania.

Tutsis have controlled Burundi's army and economy since independence from Belgium in 1962. They have also controlled the government for all but four months of the country's history.
