webTitle: Leah Wild concludes her IVF diary

fields.headline: Leah Wild
fields.standfirst: The final IVF diary entry sees the twins surrounded by people in white coats
fields.trailText: The final IVF diary entry sees the twins surrounded by people in white coats.
fields.body:
It took 10 people to make my babies. The Professor of the Assisted Conception Unit, the Pre-implantation Genetic Diagnosis (PGD) coordinator, the embryologist, two cytogeneticists, the team of four doctors who specialised in reproductive medicine, the consultant obstetrician, and my boyfriend who provided the basic material. Just as the NHS advertising campaign says, everybody's life depends upon more than a couple of responsible parents.

My children, born a few weeks ago, were the product of PGD, a procedure which identifies embryos inheriting my fatal genetic disorder while still little more than a promise of life in a petri-dish. Nine months ago, two unaffected embryos were re-implanted in my womb. Both took, and now I have a brand new boy and girl for aunties to buy blue and pink babygros for. Without the aid of new scientific research, popularly targeted as unfeeling and unethical, I would never have had these children. Needless to say, I'm a great fan of science.

The people who carried out my PGD are not only scientific but also, unwittingly, social pioneers. It is precisely because scientific advance provokes social change that we are often so anxious about it. And it is certainly at the cutting edge of reproductive technology that the greatest challenges are being made to the much-overrated and over-promoted nuclear family.

My boyfriend and I are the babies' parents - we are bringing them up, waking (frequently) with them in the night, changing their nappies, feeding them, and slowly getting to know them. We also happen to be their biological parents. Although we'd still be their mum and dad even if we weren't.

But our babies have another set of adults responsible for producing them - the PGD medical team. Even I was surprised, and ridiculously delighted, to see how these scientists, so often maligned as Frankenstein-like experimenters with sentient life, celebrated the twins' arrival. You should have seen the cytogeneticist holding my baby boy. They are medical wonders, if not miracles; the girl is number five and the boy (arriving five minutes later) number six in the whole country born after PGD for a chromosome disorder like mine. But to this man, my children were not number five and six; they were a joy. They were, in a sense, his creation, too.

The two cytogeneticists were the first to coo over the see-through plastic hospital cot, taking it in turns to hold the babies. As a gift, they had brought photos of them taken in the lab when they were each no more than a pinprick of grey cells, to kick off the album. Next came the PGD co-ordinator, bringing a big box of cakes and a card signed by the PGD team. Then the genetic counsellor arrived, wanting to know their names. The consultant obstetrician popped by every day I was there, just to see how we were all getting on. While other only hours-old mothers were surrounded by relatives, I had a crowd of no less gooey-eyed and grinning scientists around my hospital bed.

Other women in the ward were curious about my stream of visitors. Uncles and aunties perhaps? Or cousins? But this wasn't about the bonds of blood, in which we have no choice. How could I explain that this was the man who, when these children were just a cluster of eight cells, used probes to determine whether they had the condition that would inevitably have led to an early death; that this was the woman who first told us that there was a new procedure called PGD which would make it possible for me to have more children; that this was the man who removed my eggs after I had been injecting myself for weeks. Of course, there is another story beginning now. I also hope that, just as other adults were so intimately involved in the creating of my children, there will be an equally unexpected and wide circle around them as they grow. It's surprising who else may show concern for them if we only let them.

webTitle: Stephen Foster on supporting Stoke City

fields.headline: Forgive me father for I have sinned
fields.standfirst: Of all the wonderful things  Stephen Foster would have wanted to pass on to his son ... supporting Stoke City was not one of them
fields.trailText: Of all the wonderful things Stephen Foster would have wanted to pass on to his son ... supporting Stoke City was not one of them.
fields.body:
In the premier league of parental fears - activities you hope your child won't get involved in - there's the top-of-the-table stuff: crack-dealing, for example, or forming an internet relationship with someone called Danny from California. Next come the first division dreads: finding them buying Hear'Say records (what is that apostrophe for?), or dressing like H from Steps. Bookable offences, both. And then there is the second division: supporting a second division football team. Especially a second division football team whose home ground is 200 miles from your son's home ground in Norwich. Especially if this second (old third) division team is Stoke City.

It's possible that there's a worse professional football team to support, but I doubt there is. At Stoke, they excel in the art of underachievement. One of the founding members of the football league, they've won a major title (if you can call the League Cup major) once in their entire history.

I've carefully monitored Jack's drug habits (an addiction to Ribena and a strange, new, Italian-sounding supersweet) and his internet usage (exclusively skateboarding sites), and, to his credit, he laughed his head off at Popstars, but I was completely unprepared for the red-card offence which he was about to commit - and ashamed that it happened with help from his dad.

I own up: I started it. I took him to Stoke's new Britannia Stadium for the Worthington Cup game against Liverpool. It was the first match we went to this season, just making the kick off after the 200 miles, racing from the new Britannia wasteland car park to the new ground past the new municipal incinerator. We watched (Jack watched; I cried into my shirt) the worst home defeat Stoke has suffered in 137 years.

It might have put some boys off. Not Jack. While I was sulking in the club shop at the end of the game, Jack made an astonishing request: "I want the away strip, dad, it's lush, isn't it?"

"Well," I said, drying my eyes, "It's an unusual shade of purple, I suppose."

What logic might he be employing here, I was thinking - that they must play better when they play away?

Perhaps it was the effect of the dye they put in the mushy peas; or the way the scoreboard refused to give up (even though the Stoke players clearly had), displaying 9-0, when everyone in the crowd knew it should have been only eight. (Liverpool just walked the goals in, and they didn't even bother playing Heskey or Owen.) Whatever effect the Britannia Stadium had on Jack, it was the exact opposite to the effect it had on me.

A long time ago, when we played at the old Victoria Ground, we used to be good. I lived my first 18 years in Stoke: my blood runs in red and white stripes; I support Stoke City despite everything they haven't managed to achieve since I was less than Jack's age, despite the disappointments and the interminable prayers to St Jude to get them in the play-offs. Not automatic promotion, you understand, just the play-offs. Never in my wildest dreams (the ones where I score the winner in the FA Cup Final, for Stoke) did I think it would happen to my own son. I pleaded.

"Jack, you're young. You've got your whole life ahead of you. Think about your future. Think about your children's future. Oh, if only that one had been put to me. Don't do it, my son. Just don't do it."

In fact, this isn't the worst of it: Jack's mate, Other Jack, has been to a game with us (1-1 vs Port Vale) and now he is a supporter, too. I've corrupted a complete innocent who doesn't even belong to me. It's all my fault. Well, mine and Tom Jones's. Delilah is the song we Stoke fans sing to cheer ourselves up, and to celebrate goals (so it's more or less exclusively used for cheering ourselves up): "She stood there laughing ..." It's either that or crying, isn't it? Which is something I do plenty of.

I tried discouraging them, believe me, with my head in my hands, weeping. But it's too late, they've gone public - owned up to it in the playground back in Norwich, and they're unmoved by the taunting. Their decision is irreversible (for the time being, anyway). At least they can't be accused of "glory hunting", the insult they throw back at the Norwich- born Man U- or Arsenal-following taunters. That they're the new anti-glory hunters, that they've got their own cult, is the only comfort I can find in this unfortunate situation.

"Listen, don't do it for me. I can manage on my own, honest," I said. But they started discussing how they were now true Stoke supporters as we drove away. How Stoke was their team.

"It's a lifetime's misery you're looking at here. You do understand that, don't you?"

"Yeah, dad, but Norwich are crap."

"Well, yes, son - but Stoke are worse."

Yeah, Steve, but Stoke have a great crowd, said Other Jack. They never stop singing, do they?

"They?" I said.

"We, we mean we ," they replied.

And they sat in the back of the car, wearing their purple away shirts, trailing their new scarves from the windows, chorusing, "Why why why Delilah, da-dah da-dah da-dah da-da-da ... "

"And they have the best peas and chips, dad."

The best peas and chips, I knew it. Our players live on them. It could be worse: it could turn out that Danny from California is a Stoke City fan, too. But somehow, I doubt it.

 Stephen Foster's first novel, Strides, is published by Faber next month.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: Jane Fonda's new-found faith is said to have wrecked her marriage. Can partnerships survive incompatible beliefs?
fields.trailText: The question: Jane Fonda's new-found faith is said to have wrecked her marriage. Can partnerships survive incompatible beliefs?
fields.body:
Denis Cobell
President of the National Secular Society

When there are differing religious beliefs between two partners, they need to be tolerant of each other and enjoy companionship through mutual tasks and pleasures. Love and respect for one another are very important. When there are children in the family, there needs to be recognition of their right to seek out their own beliefs. As the poet Khalil Gibran said about marriage: "Stand together, yet not too near. The oak tree and the cypress grow not in each other's shadow."
Verdict: Yes

Karen Garvin
Public relations consultant

When I started going out with Simon, my parents were a bit disappointed that he wasn't Jewish like me. Although he is Church of England, I had actually thought he was Jewish at first. We got together quite young and my parents got used to him and liked him. The reason I think our relationship works is because neither of us is very religious. As far as bringing up children goes, it's a matter of wanting them to enjoy both cultures. We have picked the best out of both religions and try to show them that there are things to be enjoyed in both.
Verdict: Yes

Binal Varsani
Land surveyor

Aileen and I have brought our children up to have knowledge of and respect for all religions. I am Hindu and Aileen is Catholic, and we celebrate the main Hindu holy days as well as Christmas and Easter. The children have a good knowledge of both our religions and don't consider one to be superior of the other. Both sets of our parents brought us up to show respect for other religions. When we first started going out with each other, the fact that we have different religions was never an issue.
Verdict: Yes

Matthew Smith
Member of the Unitarian General Assembly

I'm a Unitarian, which is a non-conformist denomination with Christian roots, but also diverse pluralist roots. My wife is a reform Jew. The issue for us is to try to affirm both faiths in a family context. I'm sure we don't do it perfectly, but there is a kind of fluidity about it all. I would like our children to grow up comfortable with and knowledgeable about both faiths, so that they can make their own decisions about their religious beliefs or lack of them. I'm sure that having the two halves of a couple following different faiths can present dilemmas.
Verdict: Yes

Julia Cole
Spokeswoman for Relate

Relationships can thrive where there are religious differences and many people do make a success of them, but it does take a great degree of tolerance from both parties, even if they don't agree with the tenets of the other person's faith. Problems develop where one person isn't really willing to do that and the other person perceives that lack of willingness as an attack. When there are children in the family and there are different views about how to bring the children up in terms of religion, it can also cause problems.
Verdict: Yes

Zia Ramzan
Spokesman for the Muslim Directory

The stress and strain of modern life is difficult to handle at the best of times, coupled with a relentless onslaught against the institution of marriage and a disregard for the valid role of religious beliefs in this institution. Ted Turner and Jane Fonda are unfortunately a sign of the times: they show that it can be difficult to sustain a long-term relationship without common religious values. Although Islam encourages inter-racial marriages and, in certain cases, accepts inter-religious marriages, the latter is discouraged to avoid the same problems experienced by Turner and Fonda.
Verdict: No

fields.headline: 'If I could talk to my mum again I'd tell her I had a daughter - and I wrote some books and guess what happened?'
fields.standfirst: Matt Seaton meets JK Rowling
fields.trailText: Matt Seaton meets JK Rowling.
fields.body:
"There was a point where I really felt I had 'penniless divorcee lone parent' tattooed on my head," remarks JK Rowling sardonically. "You couldn't read about Harry Potter without seeing that somewhere in the piece.

"So I thought, 'Fine, let's take that and use it.' "

"Using it" meant sacrificing the relative anonymity that Jo Rowling still enjoyed before she decided last year to lend her support to the National Council for One-Parent Families. The origin of "JK" goes back to the advice from her publisher Bloomsbury that the adventures of an 11-year-old boy who goes to wizard school would not appeal to 11-year-old boys if written too identifiably by a woman.

Ironically, the initials provided a kind of anonymity and mystique, behind which Rowling was able to guard her privacy. Beyond the fact that she was a young-ish single mother who had written parts of the first book sitting in a cafe in Edinburgh because her flat was unheated, relatively little was known. Only when the third book (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban) was published did the media's curiosity force her hand: "So I decided that I would give interviews - when I had something to say."

She has plenty to say about the way single parents get blamed for everything from falling morals to rising crime: "It's this universal human desire we have through history: if we demonise them, we don't have to help them. It's much easier for certain sections of society to say, 'You've brought this on yourself by your fecklessness; you sort it out,' than to say, 'You've been a victim of circumstances,' or 'Hey, marriages break up ... but how are we going to help you help yourself?'

"I never set out to be a lone parent - and there I was," she says. "It's undeniable: there's a stigma attached. But I was the most unashamed lone parent you were ever going to meet. I was, like, 'And what is your problem? I'm doing a great job.' I'm very impatient with the idea that any of us should be ashamed about it."

Rowling became a single parent when her marriage to Portuguese television journalist Jorge Arantes fell apart shortly after the birth of her daughter Jessica. "It was my Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee moment," she jokes. "It is the most humiliating thing, actually: you're supposed to have your relationship disaster in your teens, aren't you - and then wise up?"

Rowling left Portugal in early 1994 and came to Edinburgh, planning to stay with her sister Di for a few weeks until she found her feet. She never left. "Edinburgh is beautiful," she explains, "has good public transport and did have, then, free museums, and I thought, 'I'll have a much better life here on a low income with my daughter.' I could just see that broke single-parenthood here would be easier."

"Poverty is the issue," she continues. "I do say that partly out of my own experience, but I am acutely aware when I talk about single parents being poor that, for me, it was a temporary state and it was always likely to be. We were never going to be rich if I had been a teacher, but we were never going to be dirt poor. And I had middle-class friends who could lend me a tenner."

Rowling's success as an author - the four Harry Potter books to date have sold more than 90m copies worldwide and been translated into 42 languages - has clearly removed that problem. The days of sitting in a cafe, snatching a few hours to write while Jessica slept in her pushchair, are long gone. Jessica, now seven, goes to school, and has a nanny who picks her up two days a week, while Rowling looks after her the other three.

"She's embarrassingly precocious and gloats about the places she's been," she says. "I heard her saying: 'I went to the Space Needle in Seattle, but Mummy couldn't go; Mummy was in a bookshop.' I'm like: 'Yeah, cheers, I know.' "

So does money solve all the problems of being a single parent? "No, but it sure as hell helps. The worst of being a single parent is constantly thinking, 'I can't give you what I want to give you.' "

Rowling named her daughter after Jessica Mitford, sister of Nancy, author and avowed communist, whose autobiography Rowling read as a teenager. "Basically, [Mitford] had every single possible component you could want as a 13-year-old leftwinger."

Rowling looks an unlikely rebel. She was head girl of her comprehensive school in Chepstow - but she was the sort, she says, who got "caught smoking at bus stops with boys in leather jackets". Now 35, she is slim and chic in fitted black rollneck and charcoal hipster pants that flare from the knee. She shakes her head now and then to clear the blonde fringe from her vision - a mannerism that gives her an air of diffidence. But when she fixes you with her blue-grey eyes, you don't doubt that here is a person with some steel.

"It's a funny thing," she muses, "but I doubt very much there would have been a Jessie if mum hadn't died when she did. I only went abroad nine months after she died: I really needed to get away. A lot of bad stuff had happened, and I needed to sort myself out a bit. And obviously, I met my ex-husband and Jessica was the result, so life does go on.

"It was doing a big rebound job, really," she adds. "That's when you're most vulnerable."

Her mother Anne had died in 1990 from multiple sclerosis at the age of 45. With just 20 years between them, Jo and her mother had been very close. "Because I was the older child, to me she was almost like an older sister. I was never in any doubt that she was my mum, but that kind of relationship was there. I could talk to her a lot more freely than some of my friends spoke to their mothers."

Anne Rowling had been 35 when first diagnosed with the illness - "the same age as me now, which is a bit of a facer, isn't it?" Because of the experience of losing her mother, Rowling has recently embraced the MS Society in Scotland and will be helping to publicise MS awareness week shortly. Anne had been a wheelchair user since Jo graduated from Exeter University, but the end, when it came, still seemed sudden.

"The last time I saw her before she died, I went back for Christmas," she recalls, haltingly. "I can't believe in retrospect that I didn't really realise what was about to happen because she was so ill. Her mobility was very limited; she looked ill, very ill - which I'd never really seen before. She was absolutely exhausted.

"She died at home, of respiratory failure. Dad went upstairs and found her dead."

Part of the appeal of the Harry Potter stories is the way Rowling's fiction engages with the dark stuff. Rowling began work on the first book just six months before her mother died. It is one of those well-known facts that the idea of Harry's world first came to Rowling on a train journey to King's Cross; but it was also on a train from that station that her mother and father first met. "That's obviously why it looms large in my psyche," she comments wryly.

Her mother's death, she says, made the fact that Harry is an orphan and the theme of death and loss "immeasurably more important", and she alludes to the now famous episode in chapter 12 of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, when Harry sees his dead parents in the Mirror of Erised (Desire backwards). What, I wonder, would Rowling see in the mirror?

"It would be my mother," she says without hesitation. "You'd want five minutes to say, 'I have a daughter, and she's called Jessica, and she looks like this and she likes this, and I wrote some books - and Mum, guess what happened?'

"I'd gabble on and at the end of five minutes I'd realise I hadn't asked what it's like to be dead. It's the selfishness of the child, isn't it? - at least I'm aware of that. But it couldn't be long enough. That was all in that mirror episode, I think: recognising that it's just not healthy, not good for you to dwell and dwell and dwell.

"It's not about forgetting, but you have got to move on."

 This is an edited version of an article that appears in the May issue of In Style, on sale from Friday.

The origin of "JK" goes back to the advice from her publisher Bloomsbury that the adventures of an 11-year-old boy who goes to wizard school would not appeal to 11-year-old boys if written too identifiably by a woman. Ironically, the initials provided a kind of anonymity and mystique, behind which Rowling was able to guard her privacy. Beyond the fact that she was a young-ish single mother who had written parts of the first book sitting in a cafe in Edinburgh because her flat was unheated, relatively little was known. Only when the third book (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban) was published did the media's curiosity force her hand: "So I decided that I would give interviews - when I had something to say." She has plenty to say about the way single parents get blamed for everything from falling morals to rising crime: "It's this universal human desire we have through history: if we demonise them, we don't have to help them. It's much easier for certain sections of society to say, 'You've brought this on yourself by your fecklessness; you sort it out,' than to say, 'You've been a victim of circumstances,' or 'Hey, marriages break up ... but how are we going to help you help yourself?' "I never set out to be a lone parent - and there I was," she says. "It's undeniable: there's a stigma attached. But I was the most unashamed lone parent you were ever going to meet. I was, like, 'And what is your problem? I'm doing a great job.' I'm very impatient with the idea that any of us should be ashamed about it." Rowling became a single parent when her marriage to Portuguese television journalist Jorge Arantes fell apart shortly after the birth of her daughter Jessica. "It was my Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee moment," she jokes. "It is the most humiliating thing, actually: you're supposed to have your relationship disaster in your teens, aren't you - and then wise up?" Rowling left Portugal in early 1994 and came to Edinburgh, planning to stay with her sister Di for a few weeks until she found her feet. She never left. "Edinburgh is beautiful," she explains, "has good public transport and did have, then, free museums, and I thought, 'I'll have a much better life here on a low income with my daughter.' I could just see that broke single-parenthood here would be easier." "Poverty is the issue," she continues. "I do say that partly out of my own experience, but I am acutely aware when I talk about single parents being poor that, for me, it was a temporary state and it was always likely to be. We were never going to be rich if I had been a teacher, but we were never going to be dirt poor. And I had middle-class friends who could lend me a tenner." Rowling's success as an author - the four Harry Potter books to date have sold more than 90m copies worldwide and been translated into 42 languages - has clearly removed that problem. The days of sitting in a cafe, snatching a few hours to write while Jessica slept in her pushchair, are long gone. Jessica, now seven, goes to school, and has a nanny who picks her up two days a week, while Rowling looks after her the other three. "She's embarrassingly precocious and gloats about the places she's been," she says. "I heard her saying: 'I went to the Space Needle in Seattle, but Mummy couldn't go; Mummy was in a bookshop.' I'm like: 'Yeah, cheers, I know.' " So does money solve all the problems of being a single parent? "No, but it sure as hell helps. The worst of being a single parent is constantly thinking, 'I can't give you what I want to give you.' " Rowling named her daughter after Jessica Mitford, sister of Nancy, author and avowed communist, whose autobiography Rowling read as a teenager. "Basically, [Mitford] had every single possible component you could want as a 13-year-old leftwinger." Rowling looks an unlikely rebel. She was head girl of her comprehensive school in Chepstow - but she was the sort, she says, who got "caught smoking at bus stops with boys in leather jackets". Now 35, she is slim and chic in fitted black rollneck and charcoal hipster pants that flare from the knee. She shakes her head now and then to clear the blonde fringe from her vision - a mannerism that gives her an air of diffidence. But when she fixes you with her blue-grey eyes, you don't doubt that here is a person with some steel. "It's a funny thing," she muses, "but I doubt very much there would have been a Jessie if mum hadn't died when she did. I only went abroad nine months after she died: I really needed to get away. A lot of bad stuff had happened, and I needed to sort myself out a bit. And obviously, I met my ex-husband and Jessica was the result, so life does go on. "It was doing a big rebound job, really," she adds. "That's when you're most vulnerable." Her mother Anne had died in 1990 from multiple sclerosis at the age of 45. With just 20 years between them, Jo and her mother had been very close. "Because I was the older child, to me she was almost like an older sister. I was never in any doubt that she was my mum, but that kind of relationship was there. I could talk to her a lot more freely than some of my friends spoke to their mothers." Anne Rowling had been 35 when first diagnosed with the illness - "the same age as me now, which is a bit of a facer, isn't it?" Because of the experience of losing her mother, Rowling has recently embraced the MS Society in Scotland and will be helping to publicise MS awareness week shortly. Anne had been a wheelchair user since Jo graduated from Exeter University, but the end, when it came, still seemed sudden. "The last time I saw her before she died, I went back for Christmas," she recalls, haltingly. "I can't believe in retrospect that I didn't really realise what was about to happen because she was so ill. Her mobility was very limited; she looked ill, very ill - which I'd never really seen before. She was absolutely exhausted. "She died at home, of respiratory failure. Dad went upstairs and found her dead." Part of the appeal of the Harry Potter stories is the way Rowling's fiction engages with the dark stuff. Rowling began work on the first book just six months before her mother died. It is one of those well-known facts that the idea of Harry's world first came to Rowling on a train journey to King's Cross; but it was also on a train from that station that her mother and father first met. "That's obviously why it looms large in my psyche," she comments wryly. Her mother's death, she says, made the fact that Harry is an orphan and the theme of death and loss "immeasurably more important", and she alludes to the now famous episode in chapter 12 of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, when Harry sees his dead parents in the Mirror of Erised (Desire backwards). What, I wonder, would Rowling see in the mirror? "It would be my mother," she says without hesitation. "You'd want five minutes to say, 'I have a daughter, and she's called Jessica, and she looks like this and she likes this, and I wrote some books - and Mum, guess what happened?' "I'd gabble on and at the end of five minutes I'd realise I hadn't asked what it's like to be dead. It's the selfishness of the child, isn't it? - at least I'm aware of that. But it couldn't be long enough. That was all in that mirror episode, I think: recognising that it's just not healthy, not good for you to dwell and dwell and dwell. "It's not about forgetting, but you have got to move on."  This is an edited version of an article that appears in the May issue of In Style, on sale from Friday.

webTitle: Julie Myerson on revealing a family feud

fields.headline: 'Mum, why do you hate auntie?'
fields.standfirst: Julie Myerson on revealing a family feud
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson on revealing a family feud.
fields.body:
He's off school ill, but he says he'll come with me to the cafe if I like. I tell him to get a jumper. He sighs loudly, obeys.

We order a Brie baguette, salad, chips to share. And a Coke. He looks happier. I tell him when I was in the sixth form at school, we used to go down to the pub at lunchtime and have chip butties. He shows polite interest. Then, a child's classic non sequitur: "Why exactly did you fall out with auntie Debbie?"

The chip in my mouth is hot but inside I freeze. Our kids know little of the tedious stuff of my family past. It's not secret so much as that the time has never seemed right. Why indulge yourself by telling them stuff that will at best be adult and at worst depressing and incomprehensible? But he's 12 now.

"What the hell are you doing?" I ask him as he opens his sandwich and peers inside.

"Just checking for green bits."

"I'm not sure you're old enough to hear about Debbie, if you're frightened of a bit of lettuce ... "

"I want to know. Please."

"All right," I say, "You remember how my father wasn't very kind at all to me? How he took it out on me after my mother left him?" He nods wearily. Yes, yes, he's heard that bit.

"Well, when I was 15, he told my school I was leaving. And since he had already agreed to pay our school fees, I had to write a letter that was read out in court ..."

"And he had to pay?"

"He was furious, and later he wrote to say he didn't want to see me any more."

"And did you see him again?"

"Well, we took you to visit him when you were a baby. But he wasn't very interested."

"Why?"

I sigh. "Well, he didn't know how to behave or love people, I suppose."

"But why did Debbie start seeing him again and not you?" he asks quickly.

I hesitate. "She hadn't had to fight the battles. I mean, it was only because of me that she ended up staying at school and doing A-levels as well. So although she gained, I was the one who got punished."

I search his face as he munches his baguette with unconcerned relish. What am I hoping for? Approval, pity, to see him moved by this? To hear him say it's not fair? Do I want him to realise that at his age I had few of his certainties?

"So," I say, "when he died, he left all his money to Debbie." He puts down his baguette, looks at me. I'm through to him. "No!" he yells.

"Yup."

I eat another chip, lick salt off my fingers.

"How much?" he says steadily.

"About £350,000," I say, "Enough to buy a lot of Warhammer."

"Bloody hell," he says.

"Hey. We don't say that."

"But what? She didn't share it out?"

"To justify keeping it, she had to say a lot of things that weren't true, had to reinvent the past. Like I'd been a Bad Daughter and she was a Good Daughter."

"So did you start to hate her?" he asks, a touch too excitedly.

I flush. "It's more complicated than that. In the end, I felt bad that money was splitting us up, so even though she was keeping it, I asked her round ... "

He finishes his drink, sucking noisily on the straw. "I remember it!" he says.

"You couldn't. You were only three."

"But, I do - I remember being very low down."

"Sweetie, you were always low down in those days. Anyway, she came round and we talked for a while and then she said to me again that I had treated him so badly and something snapped in me and I grabbed her hair ... "

"Mummy!" he says.

"It was sort of big, sticky-out hair - and I threw her out by it. Out the door and down the path."

"That was pretty violent."

"I agree, I behaved very badly. Sometimes grown-ups do. Maybe you're to young to hear all this."

"No! Please, I like it."

I can't stop either. "I wasn't just cross with her, you see.

"It was years of anger at my father."

"Because he didn't like you?"

"Or love me."

"So what about the money? Did she give you some in the end?"

"Goodness, no," I tell him. "And I haven't seen her since. It's sad and awful, isn't it?"

He stares thoughtfully at the table. I think of how I've always wondered how I would tell him all of this. And now the moment has slid up on me, unasked for. Then, with all the controlled, forensic braininess we've taught him: "You must realise, mummy," he says, "what you've just told me is a very biased view."

But it's not what I want right now: I feel the colour rise in my cheeks again. "But darling, it's never right for a parent to cut children off like that, never. Whatever any of you did, Daddy and I would never ... "

"Even if I committed murder?"

"Even that. We think a parent's relationship with their child is the parent's responsibility - however old or bad the child is."

"But even if I wrote in the paper that you were a terrible novelist?"

"Ah well, then of course I would cut you off." He grins.

"Are you surprised by all of this?" I ask him gently.

"I don't know. Not really."

"So what are you thinking?"

"If we go past Apollo, can we rent Gladiator again?"

fields.headline: Phillips cleared of plugging charities for cash
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: GMTV presenter Fiona Phillips has been cleared of allegations made by the Sunday People, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
GMTV presenter Fiona Phillips has been cleared by the Independent Television Commission of allegations she promoted charities on air in return for money.

The TV watchdog came to its conclusion after examining hours of tapes of the show over the past year.

Its investigation followed the Sunday People's "Sofagate" stories, published in January, which alleged Ms Phillips wanted £10,000 to promote the NSPCC's cause on her show.

Ms Phillip's agent, Nicola Ibison, allegedly told the newspaper's undercover reporter Ms Phillips "always tries to sneak in a mention" on the live breakfast programme for the charities that pay her.

The ITC investigated the claims because of the strict guidelines preventing presenters from promoting products or organisations on air.

GMTV provided the TV watchdog with a random selection of programme tapes.

On examining the footage, the ITC failed to find any references to the charities mentioned in the newspaper articles.

The broadcaster also reviewed tapes and found no plugs of the type referred to in the Sunday People and also confirmed Ms Phillips had not authorised her agent to speak as she was reported to have done.

fields.headline: Revolution
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 18
fields.trailText: April 18: Lucozade is to launch a standalone site to bolster its 'Larazade' promotion targeting young adults.
fields.body:
GlaxoSmithKline energy drink brand Lucozade is to launch a standalone site to bolster its "Larazade" promotion targeting young adults.

UK company Prism Leisure, a wholesaler and distributor of budget CDs, computer games and DVDs, is to launch a consumer-facing arm during the next few weeks under the name of Amazing DVDs.

Jobline International is to shed staff at its UK office as it cuts 150 jobs across Europe.

Channel Health is talking to Pharmacy2U about giving pharmacists access to the public via iTV in surgeries and health centres.

Online games retailer Gameplay has cancelled its contract with digital television provider Open.

News International is piloting a new service that will see it sell customised versions of copyrighted photos from its picture library via Page3.com and the Sun's web site.

fields.headline: Campbell to sign for Burnley?
fields.trailText: Burnley FC, the first division play-off hopefuls and adopted home team of Downing Street uber-spinner Alastair Campbell, have got a vacancy - for a press officer.
fields.body:
Burnley FC, the first division play-off hopefuls and adopted home team of Downing Street uber-spinner Alastair Campbell, have got a vacancy - for a press officer.

The three-strong PR team are looking for "an experienced journalist" to update their website and write some programme notes.

And the salary? Undisclosed, but possibly less than the prime minister's official spokesman's current £99,000 pay packet.

Chief press officer Danny Ruben explains: "If Alastair's interested in the vacancy, I'd have him on board any time.

"He's one of our most celebrated supporters and a true friend to the club. He comes to most home games and as many away ones as he can manage.

"Indeed, he already writes some programme notes for us."

webTitle: Curbing our right to online freedom

fields.headline: Curbing our right to online freedom
fields.standfirst: Like the draconian 'RIP' laws introduced last year, the new cyber-crime unit may restrict freedom of speech, writes Neil McIntosh, deputy editor of Guardian Online
fields.trailText: Like the draconian 'RIP' laws introduced last year, the new cyber-crime unit may restrict freedom of speech, writes Neil McIntosh, deputy editor of Guardian Online.
fields.body:
Today's unveiling of a £25m cyber crime-busting unit, the national hi-tech crime unit (NHTCU), looks to be good news. The UK police forces have, until now, had only an ad hoc approach to the problems of crime on the internet. This new initiative means, for the first time, that there is a coordinated effort against major internet crime, including child pornography and cyber-terrorism.

Breakthroughs against the supposed new class of "cyber-criminals" have, until now, been as the result of old-fashioned detective work - or just plain good luck - rather than because of any great technical awareness on the part of the police. Raids on one paedophile's home would uncover images and details which would lead to others in a ring; this is how the Wonderland Club, a worldwide internet paedophile ring, was smashed earlier this year.

Within the new unit, for the first time, resources will be concentrated on understanding how these crimes are committed. Police might manage to get beyond simple reaction to online crimes which surface in the offline world by chance, and move to hunt them down in their native habitat, where online criminals believe that the internet gives them anonymity they cannot enjoy away from their computer terminals.

But there are dangers in all this. The Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) act, which came into force last year, was written on the basis that Britain's security forces, including the police and MI5, needed some special help with the net. It assumed they would not have the ability to work out what crimes were being committed online without extra powers - powers they would not enjoy in the physical world, and powers which US authorities apparently do not need.

The RIP act is a draconian piece of legislation, as regular readers of Guardian Online will know. Now, nothing you write in an email, or attach to an email, or do on the internet, can ever be assumed to be private.

Furthermore, those unfortunates charged under it - the RIP victims - must, for a start, prove themselves and their online communications innocent, reversing the burden of proof and forcing the accused to prove what they were doing is above board.

The way they are to prove this innocence is to hand over the keys to any encrypted information that they have sent or stored. Should they forget the key, they could go to jail for two years - opening up the possibility that, eventually, drug barons and porn peddlers will routinely encrypt anything incriminating. That way, they can choose to "forget" the key and take two years in jail, rather than open up the files and face far longer in the clink.

The list of horrors included in the RIP bill goes on and on: a sledgehammer law designed to support security services at the expense of civil liberties which are taken for granted in most of the western world. Tim Berners-Lee, the British inventor of the world-wide web, has said the RIP bill would have been rejected "in a second" in the US. Britain does not join the best company with its RIP bill - other places to have similar laws include Russia and Malaysia.

Most countries, however, see that protecting encryption from government demands might pay dividends in increased e-commerce, and that attempting to clamp down on its use would be pointless. Ireland has passed a law making it illegal for the government to access encryption keys, while France and Germany have both rejected controls on citizen's use of encryption technology.

Of course one supports the work of the police. Online crime erodes confidence in the medium and, even more importantly than that, causes real pain, suffering and loss in the physical world. And it should, really, be good news that the police is doing more to protect us online.

But, because of RIP, forgive me if my reaction to this morning's trumpeting is a little muted: I've never been a victim of online crime, don't know anyone who has been, yet we are all victims of those new laws.

fields.headline: Boot Camp kicks off well for Sky One
fields.trailText:
3.45pm TV overnights: The latest US reality format to invade these shores pulled in 0.85m viewers, writes Jason Deans.
06.04.2001: Sky One to shoot 18 hours of Temptation Island for UK
28.03.2001: Boot Camp marches to Sky One
fields.body:
The latest US reality format to invade these shores, Fox's Boot Camp, made a promising start on Sky One last night.

Boot Camp, in which eight men and eight women are put through their paces by drill instructors in order to win a cash prize, had 0.85m viewers and a 7.7% share of multichannel viewing, according to unofficial overnights.

These are good figures by Sky One's standards - in the week ending April 8, the channel's top-rated show was the Dervla Kirwan drama the Bombmaker with 0.86m viewers, according to official Barb audience figures.

Boot Camp, which is broadcast between 8pm and 9pm, will almost certainly overtake this rating when video viewing is added to the official Barb statistics.

The Boot Camp format was created in this country by Granada Media's Greenhouse Project, before being sold to Fox and developed for the US market.

Temptation Island, another US reality show bought from Fox, opened with 0.56m viewers, according to overnights, and averaged more than 0.6m over its seven-part run on Sky One earlier this year.

Sky One is planning to make an 18-hour UK version of Temptation Island for the autumn, which will be repeated on Channel 4.

webTitle: Slave ship alert leaves W Africa in confusion

fields.headline: Slave ship alert leaves W Africa in confusion
fields.trailText: An outcry turned into a mystery about the fate of dozens of children reported to be in a suspected slave ship in west African waters when the vessel docked in Cotonou, Benin, yesterday, with none of the suspected victims on board.
fields.body:
An outcry turned into a mystery about the fate of dozens of children reported to be in a suspected slave ship in west African waters when the vessel docked in Cotonou, Benin, yesterday, with none of the suspected victims on board.

Although the region has an extensive trade in child slaves, there was growing uncertainty whether in this case they existed.

The government of Benin and UN officials had claimed that about 180 children destined to work as slaves on plantations in Gabon were in the Nigerian-registered MV Etireno. Benin issued an international arrest warrant for the captain and called on other countries to help track down the vessel when it went missing for several days.

Cabinet ministers, the police and UN workers were waiting to board when it finally docked in Cotonou on Monday night. They had expected to find a horde of sick and malnourished children, based on police reports from Cameroon, where it was last seen.

But only 43 minors were on board, about half of them 13 or younger. Social workers and foreign aid groups were trying to discover whether any of them were travelling against their will.

The captain of the Etireno, Lawrence Onome, denied that there had been slave children on board. "I have not committed any offence that will warrant my arrest," he said.

"I am not into child slavery, they cannot prove it. It is one thing to say and one thing to prove."

UN officials in Cotonou speculated that the other children might have been put ashore elsewhere after the publicity about the ship and its cargo or, at worst, dumped at sea.

But no evidence has emerged to support either theory and the Benin government says it mistakenly identified the Etireno because it was in the same area as another ship carrying the children, it alleges, had been regularly involving in carrying child slaves in the past five years.

But the authorities in Benin have been unable to name the second ship or say where it is now. To add to the confusion, there were reports of a ship carrying a large number of children trying to dock in Equatorial Guinea, but it is unclear whether that was the MV Etireno during the days it was unaccounted for or another ship.

What neither the government officials nor the aid workers are conceding at the moment is that the reports were wholly wrong from the beginning.

The Unicef office in Libreville, Gabon, said the transport ministry there had confirmed that it turned away a second ship carrying about 250 Nigerian children a few days before the Etireno arrived. It said the fate of that vessel was unknown.

The Unicef representative in Benin insisted that its initial alarm call was well founded. "Our sources were the police in Benin as well as the port police at Douala [Cameroon]. With the two of them combined we have good reason to believe these children were destined for plantations in Gabon."

fields.headline: Westwood leads Cosmo Brides up the aisle
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: The Sun's fashion editor, Catherine Westwood, is to edit new Cosmopolitan magazine Cosmo Brides, writes Jessica Hodgson.

28.03.2001: NatMags relaunches Bride & Groom
fields.body:
The Sun's fashion editor, Catherine Westwood, is leaving to join the National Magazine Company, where she will edit the new Cosmopolitan magazine, Cosmo Brides.

Ms Westwood, who has edited the Sun's fashion section since mid-2000, will spearhead the launch of the NatMags Cosmo spin-off, which is a rebranding of an existing magazine, Bride and Groom.

NatMags bought Bride and Groom, along with a clutch of other publications, from AIM last year.

The news of the appointment suggests that NatMags's strategy of diversifying magazines from the Cosmpolitan brand is alive and well.

Earlier in the year it emerged that Cosmo Girl, targeted at the teenage market, was to be put on ice until the autumn.

Related story

fields.headline: 'Bloodshed and desperation' in Israel
fields.standfirst:
The Arab-language papers of the Middle East are filled with violent anti-Israeli rhetoric, while the English language versions opt the bland, official line, says Derek Brown

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Arab-language papers of the Middle East are filled with violent anti-Israeli rhetoric, while the English language versions opt the bland, official line, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The Arab-language papers of the Middle East are filled with violent anti-Israeli rhetoric, reflecting a public mood inflamed by images of Palestinian suffering. You would never guess it, from the staid, bland reporting of the English language versions, which strive to reflect the official line rather than popular feeling.

In Dubai, for example, the Khaleej Times solemnly reports a predictable condemnation of Israel by a United Arab Emirates 'foreign ministry source': "The UAE, he said, also called upon the international community to step up efforts to put an end to Israel's aggressions and to force it to implement UN security council resolutions 242, 338 and 425, which call on Israel to completely withdraw from all occupied Arab territories.

"The source also denounced Israeli ground and air raids on Gaza Strip and other Palestinian towns as a deliberate and systematic aggression against the Palestinians who are struggling for their legitimate rights."

The paper's editorial column plays safe, focusing on marine pollution in the Gulf, and the US economic downturn. The leader column in the Jordan Times is a little bolder, featuring a stinging attack on Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, and on the international community for failing to intervene:

"What is most appalling is that, while Israel is contravening each piece of paper it ever signed and the simplest principles of international law, annihilating and massacring an entire nation, the US administration is sending an envoy to the region to discuss the Iraqi situation. Talk about getting your priorities right...

"Amid all this bloodshed and desperation, is not Europe wondering what will happen to all the billions that it spent for the development of Palestinian infrastructure, economy and institutions? Or is European tax-payers' money that cheap, that it can be scattered to the winds by a few shots of Israeli tanks?"

In the latest edition of the Cairo-based al-Ahram weekly, columnist Ibrahim Nafie also has a vitriolic attack on the Sharon government, quoting the extremist views of several prominent Israeli ministers.

He goes on: "It is absurd to think that such a government could seriously explore viable options to realise a lasting peace. Moreover, not only is there a disturbing consistency in the attitudes of its constituent members, it has derived considerable reassurance from the new Republican administration in the US, which is reluctant to intervene to halt the current deterioration."

Mr Nafie predictably praises the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, for his diplomatic efforts to prise the US away from its hitherto slavishly pro-Israel stance.

However, in the stridently hawkish Jersusalem Post, columnist Barry Rubin offers a different view, in a long polemic on Egypt's alleged failure to provide coherent leadership in the Arab world:

"The one thing Egypt does continue to produce is anti-Israel rhetoric. Having met with intellectuals, scholars and analysts from virtually every Middle East country, I can attest that the Egyptians are, generally speaking, at the lowest level of competence and are the most obsessed with scoring points by inaccurate and nasty attacks on Israel. Aside from the obvious reasons for this behaviour, it might be suggested that they - in tune with Egyptian policy - have little or nothing else to offer."

The liberal daily Ha'aretz has lost all patience with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, whom its leader writer accuses of deliberately stepping up attacks on Israel:

"It is clear the Palestinian intention was to push Israel to take harsh military steps. Presumably, Yasser Arafat continues to hope Israeli military action will reawaken international opinion from its apathy and encourage foreign intervention in the conflict, finally bringing the Palestinians a political achievement to justify their six months of suffering."

webTitle: Liverpool and Parma battle for Guardiola

fields.headline: Liverpool and Parma battle for Guardiola
fields.trailText: Liverpool manager Gerald Houllier has expressed an interest in Pep Guardiola today - but it already looks like he could lose out to Serie A side Parma in the race for the Spaniard's signature.
fields.body:
Liverpool manager Gerald Houllier has expressed an interest in Pep Guardiola today - but it already looks like he could lose out to Serie A side Parma in the race for the Spaniard's signature.

According to reports in today's Gazzetta dello Sport, Guardiola has signed a provisional agreement to join Parma next season, worth 4.5 billion lire (£1.5 m) a year over four seasons.

However, there are two conditions. The first is that Guardiola would only join Parma, currently fourth in Serie A, if they qualify for one of Italy's four Champions League berths. The second is that he would be able to reject the deal if a more lucrative offer arrived from an English premier league club.

Parma, who were linked to Guardiola in the summer of 1997 when a transfer deal with the Spaniard fell through, declined to comment on Gazzetta's report. "We don't comment on transfer speculation - either on Guardiola or any other player," a club spokesman said.

Earlier, Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier had confirmed his interest in the 30-year-old. "He is a player I respect and admire," said Houllier on the eve of his side's Uefa Cup match against Barcelona.

"We are interested in any good player who becomes available if they can strengthen our squad, and you can write that," he told a news conference.

Guardiola has already attracted interest from Newcastle United, managed by his former coach at Barcelona, Bobby Robson.

webTitle: Renewed violence as Israel leaves Gaza

fields.headline: Renewed violence as Israel leaves Gaza
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Fighting between Palestinians and Israelis was continuing today after the Israeli army's hasty overnight exit from a small section of the Gaza Strip that it had occupied yesterday.
fields.body:
Fighting between Palestinians and Israelis was continuing today after the Israeli army's hasty overnight exit from a small section of the Gaza Strip that it had occupied yesterday.

Palestinian security officials said that Israeli tanks and army bulldozers entered a Palestinian-controlled area of the Gaza Strip near the Egyptian border. Israel confirmed a brief 'pinpoint operation' to demolish a Palestinian police station and said it was over.

An Israeli army spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the operation confirmed that two bulldozers, a tank, and another armoured vehicle had entered Palestinian territory to demolish what had been the source of gunfire earlier in the day.

Six Palestinians were wounded this morning, one of them seriously, when Israeli tanks shelled two neighbourhoods in Hebron and exchanged fire with Palestinian gunmen, according to witnesses. The Israeli army said Palestinian gunmen opened fire from Abu Sneineh and Harat al-Sheikh on Jewish settlements in central Hebron late yesterday. It said its tanks shelled the areas in response and exchanges of fire followed.

Hospital sources in the divided city said six people from one Palestinian family were injured, including a 40-year-old woman who was seriously injured in the face and chest.

Witnesses said a small missile hit the government's Alia hospital in Hebron, smashing windows and damaging walls. Palestinian police fanned out throughout the city, which has been a flashpoint of violence during the nearly seven-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation.

The renewed violence follows a confirmation by Israel today that it had completed a pullout from the Palestinian-controlled slice of the Gaza Strip it had seized just a day earlier. The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, denied the about-face was a result of heavy US pressure.

The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, had called the takeover - which was triggered by a by mortar fire on an Israeli town - "excessive and disproportionate".

Raanan Gissin, an aide to Mr Sharon, said today that the decision to withdraw was already made yesterday morning, before Mr Powell issued his statement.

Yesterday, several hours after Israel tanks had rolled into the orange groves and fields north-east of the Palestinian town of Beit Hanoun, the Israeli army commander of the area, Brigadier General Yair Naveh, said his men would remain for "days, weeks or months" - as long as it took to quell Palestinian mortar fire from the area.

But today the army said Gen Naveh had exceeded his authority when he spoke of the possible duration of the operation.

Early today, Palestinian policemen returned to the area briefly held by Israeli troops, inspecting the ruins of one of six police positions razed by bulldozers. Officers checked for booby traps and searched the rubble for files and documents.

Since the current wave of violence erupted in September, 475 people have been killed, including 392 Palestinians, 64 Israeli Jews and 19 others.

webTitle: C4 has moved on, says Jackson

fields.headline: C4 has moved on, says Jackson
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Channel 4 should be seen as a 'media company' and not just the TV station for minorities he launched 18 years ago, chief executive Michael Jackson said today in a liveonline chat on MediaGuardian.co.uk.
What he said about Tour de France
On the Big Breakfast
On North Square and West Wing
On the BBC's digital channels
Click here for full discussion
fields.body:
Michael Jackson has declared that Channel 4 should now be seen as a "media company", and not just the TV station for minorities that he helped found more than 18 years ago.

The broadcaster's chief executive told MediaGuardian.co.uk today that a radical overhaul of Channel 4's image had been necessary to meet the demands of an increasingly competitive world.

"We've tried to move over the past three years to thinking of Channel 4 as more of a media company than a single terrestrial TV channel.," said Mr Jackson.

"The fact is that we are moving into a multichannel, multiplatform universe and as a forward-looking channel we have to move with the times."

However, the man who helped launch Channel 4 as a ground-breaking and irreverent TV station in November1982 said the company will not consider privatisation to fund its expansion.

"I actually think the private/public model of public ownership and private funding has given Channel 4 a sense of entrepreneurial purpose which has helped us stay ahead," he said.

Mr Jackson added that Channel 4's extensive internet investments would have landed the company in hot water had it been a listed company.

"Our investment in the internet would now be deemed a mistake by shareholders were we to be a FTSE company. So I think there are real advantages to our status and for the foreseeable future it will stand us in good stead," he said.

He said senior executives had "campaigned energetically" against privatisation and had no interest in holding share options in the company.

Mr Jackson admitted the channel was still vulnerable to the depressed advertising environment that has hammered ITV in particular, and warned the problems faced by Granada and Carlton may not be confined to one network.

"You've got to be concerned. There is definitely a downturn coming and advertisers are pulling in their horns," he said.

Following its acquisition of the controversial reality show, Temptation Island, Mr Jackson defended Channel 4's plans to launch interactive betting as part of the Go Racing consortium.

"Yes, we hope this will make money, maybe a lot of it," he said. "If it does, all of the profits will go back to its partners - of which Channel 4 is one third - and we will reinvest this in new programmes and services."

Mr Jackson added that Channel 4's extensive internet investments would have landed the company in hot water had it been a listed company. "Our investment in the internet would now be deemed a mistake by shareholders were we to be a FTSE company. So I think there are real advantages to our status and for the foreseeable future it will stand us in good stead," he said. He said senior executives had "campaigned energetically" against privatisation and had no interest in holding share options in the company. Mr Jackson admitted the channel was still vulnerable to the depressed advertising environment that has hammered ITV in particular, and warned the problems faced by Granada and Carlton may not be confined to one network. "You've got to be concerned. There is definitely a downturn coming and advertisers are pulling in their horns," he said. Following its acquisition of the controversial reality show, Temptation Island, Mr Jackson defended Channel 4's plans to launch interactive betting as part of the Go Racing consortium. "Yes, we hope this will make money, maybe a lot of it," he said. "If it does, all of the profits will go back to its partners - of which Channel 4 is one third - and we will reinvest this in new programmes and services." webTitle: Better health behind bars is a necessity

fields.headline: Better health behind bars is a necessity
fields.standfirst: Depriving prisoners of access to adequate healthcare services is an infringement of their basic human rights, argues Dr Patrick Keavney
fields.trailText: Depriving prisoners of access to adequate healthcare services is an infringement of their basic human rights, argues Dr Patrick Keavney.
fields.body:
Approximately 65,000 people in England and Wales are admitted to our penal institutions in an average year. The average length of stay is only six months, six weeks in our young offenders' institutions.

Around 70% of them will have significant health problems, primarily mental health.

Drug and alcohol misuse, self-harm and suicide, personality disorders and genuine psychotic illness dominate the clinical picture. There are, of course, the usual range of physical problems for prisoners, who lead more unhealthy lives compared with their peer group.

More than 90% will come from our more deprived communities. The vast majority of male prisoners will not have used the NHS when at liberty to do so.

Prison, therefore, is probably the primary area where such health problems can be addressed and some opportunity afforded to integrate them into NHS services on their release. The consequence for the rest of society in not doing so is only too obvious.

Surely the way we treat our citizens incarcerated in the penal system is a measure of whether we consider ourselves a humane society. Deprivation of liberty as a punishment for criminal activity is one issue - deprivation of an adequate healthcare services is an infringement of a basic human right.

One of this government's first priorities was the issue of equity and equitable services in the NHS for all UK citizens. To some extent they have addressed this by setting up a joint policy and task force unit between the Home Office and the Department of Health.

In doing so it abolished the previous directorate of health care within the prison service, including its support mechanisms for healthcare departments in all prisons.

At the same time it made all governing governors responsible for clinical governance. This has been a difficult enough task within the NHS for clinical managers - it has become a nightmare task for governing governors and the clinical staff they are supposed to support.

Governing governors have had little training in such issues. They are used to working to a prison standards audit which is very much process driven and has little connection with clinical audit, which requires active consideration by clinicians and is based much more on clinical outcomes.

This is putting governing governors on a direct conflict path with clinicians, preventing adequate working environments to allow clinicians to work to their professional regulatory requirements. Add to this the poor funding of prison healthcare, which has resulted in poor capital assets and inadequate resource funding.

Traditionally, the prison service has remained responsible for the funding of primary healthcare within its own institutions, with the NHS only becoming involved when there is a need for secondary care. But primary care within the prison service has not kept pace with the development in the NHS.

Consequently, the employment policy has put clinical staff in a precarious position. Staff are continuing to be employed who are just not competent for the clinical tasks required.

Nursing staff in primary care within the NHS are expected to work on their own initiative. They are expected to provide much of the health maintenance programs within primary healthcare teams, with their medical colleagues concentrating more on diagnostics and clinical problem solving.

All staff work together to provide an integrated service to patients while at the same recognising that the doctor must retain the clinical responsibility for their patients.

Nurses are, of course, equally responsible for the clinical activities that they are competent to perform. This is far from the truth in the prison service. Too few staff are being employed to carry on the clinical service that is patently needed to deal with the extent and range of clinical problems that are being thrust upon them.

What with poor salary scales, poor terms and conditions of service, poor understanding of their clinical roles and responsibilities, poor relationships with prison management, and poor working relationships that fail to address the questions of clinical management, professional management and resource management, is it any wonder there is a crisis in the recruitment and retention of medical officers within the prison service?

Without motivated, appropriately resourced and well-compensated clinical teams within the prison service there will be no advancement in meeting the genuine clinical needs of the patients that are admitted to our prisons by the criminal justice system.

This is an opportunity lost for meeting those clinical needs, which in all truth should be part of an integrated healthcare system that specifically addresses the issues, especially those that derive from our deprived communities.

 Dr Patrick Keavney is chairman of the BMA's civil service committee and author of Prison Medicine: A Crisis Waiting to Break.

fields.headline: What he said about BBC1, BBC3, and BBC4
fields.trailText: Channel 4's chief executive, Michael Jackson, has given his backing to the BBC's proposed new digital channels.
fields.body:
Channel 4's chief executive, Michael Jackson, has given his backing to the BBC's proposed new digital channels, but called for a continuing commitment to arts programming on BBC1.

"I support their plans for BBC3 and 4, which in effect recognise that the TV market is becoming more like radio, with thematic rather than general channels," said Mr Jackson.

"BBC1 does look more competitive, but I guess you have to see this in the context of the potentiality of a four channel BBC stretching from BBC1 to BBC4.

"However, even if BBC1 no longer broadcasts Omnibus, I still think it should be running bold arts programming as specials and events throughout the year. Let's see if they do this."

fields.headline: Chelsea admit interest in Carbone
fields.trailText: Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri could move for Benito Carbone if Gianluca Zola leaves Stamford Bridge at the end of the season.
fields.body:
Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri could move for Benito Carbone if Gianluca Zola leaves Stamford Bridge at the end of the season.

Speaking on Italian TV, Ranieri admitted that Zola is yet to decide whether to move back to Serie A or see out the remaining year on his contract. If Zola leaves, Chelsea will speak to Carbone about a move to London.

"Zola is a fantastic player. He would still have a role to play for me if he decides to stay, and we are constantly talking about the subject," Ranieri admitted.

"However I must also be aware that if he does decide to go, then I must have a replacement ready to come in," he added. "Finding someone to take over will be hard, but we already have some players in mind, and Carbone certainly would be a player we would consider.

"It looks like his current team Bradford will struggle to stay up this season, and I believe that if he was to be offered the chance then he would like to stay in the Premiership."

fields.headline: What he said about the Big Breakfast
fields.trailText: The Channel 4 chief has revealed the Big Breakfast will not be axed, declaring: 'There's life in the old dog yet.'
fields.body:
Michael Jackson, the Channel 4 chief executive, has declared the Big Breakfast will not be axed just because ratings have fallen to record lows.

"There is life in the old dog yet," he said.

The show, which has been threatened ever since presenter Johnny Vaughan quit in January, has been struggling to maintain audiences and is now lucky to count 300,000 fans.

It has also struggled to maintain staff - producer Richard Hopkins was fired and replaced by Ben Rigden, who has been given nine months to salvage the show.

Mr Jackson said he has faith in the programme because it still brings in younger viewers.

"The Big Breakfast is a very important show for us, it is also a unique show.

"Over its relatively long life it has had its ups and downs as presenters have come and gone," said Mr Jackson.

He added: "The intrinsic idea is a good one and we and the production team are working hard to make it as good as it can possibly be.

"So I suppose we think there's life in the old dog yet - it still does pretty well among 16- to 24-year-olds."

Mr Jackson also said he would welcome Chris Evans back to the channel any time.

His TFI Friday show was axed last year because it was felt it had become "tired".

Mr Jackson said: "I think TFI Friday had had its turn. You have to say Chris's TV record - three games played, three won - is pretty good and I'd back him above many other people."

fields.headline: Schmeichel joins queue behind Fergie
fields.trailText: Peter Schmeichel has added his name to the list of Alex Ferguson's potential successors at Old Trafford by declaring he'd like to become the manager of Manchester United.
fields.body:
Peter Schmeichel has added his name to the list of Alex Ferguson's potential successors at Old Trafford by declaring he'd like to become the manager of Manchester United.

"I would like to have that job," said the 37-year-old Danish international, who will make his 129th and final appearance for his country in a friendly against Slovenia next week.

"I would like to go into management at a later stage in my life and obviously I have always set myself targets. That is the biggest job in football so that is the one I am going to go after."

But before Martin Edwards is tempted to call up the former United keeper and check on his availability come the end of next season, when Ferguson is set to retire, Schmeichel doesn't want the job just yet.

"I wouldn't like to be anywhere near that job for the first 10 or 15 years," he told BBC radio, unveiling his management master plan.

"It takes a very, very special character to manage Manchester United and to follow Sir Alex Ferguson takes an even more special character. Eric Cantona could be that character but I am not sure if he wants it."

Currently with Sporting Lisbon in Portugal, Schmeichel spent nine years at Manchester United, playing his final match in their 2-1 win over Bayern Munich in the 1999 Champions League final.

fields.headline: What he said about North Square and West Wing
fields.trailText: Channel 4 legal drama North Square was axed because it didn't have 'freshness of tone', Michael Jackson revealed today.
fields.body:
Channel 4's legal drama, North Square, was axed because it didn't have "freshness of tone", Michael Jackson, revealed today.

In an online chat with MediaGuardian.co.uk, the station's chief executive said he was a big fan of the award-winning show, but said he felt the current drama series, Teachers, was better.

"We were proud of North Square and we did actually commission 10 episodes as part of a decision to try to build a long running Channel 4 serial," he said.

"The second of these is Teachers and next year there should be at least one more. I guess we felt that although North Square was very good it didn't have the freshness of tone and attitude that Teachers has so far exhibited. "The whole idea here is to find something we can continue with for several years in the spirit of an ER on NYPD Blue."

North Square was axed last year after ratings failed to live up to expectatations - it started off with about 1.7m fans but audiences fell away to around 0.9m - a meagre 4% share of the audience.

Mr Jackson was also criticised for moving the broadcast time of the award-winning American series, West Wing, starring Martin Sheen as the US president, Josiah Bartlet.

Today he said: "I like West Wing too. I guess its scheduling is all about balancing the different needs of different programmes in the schedule. The first episode had a great critical response and a very good audience, which then unfortunately fell off pretty dramatically, to about 1.2m.

"By putting it at 11pm we've been able to keep the audience around the million mark, whilst finding a space for other programmes at 10pm. Fans of West Wing are still finding it at 11pm and others are videoing it. "
