fields.headline: Blair considers cull of ministers
fields.standfirst: With the Commons in its Easter recess, it's time to catch up on the latest cabinet reshuffle speculation. Political correspondent Matthew Tempest reads the runes
fields.trailText: With the Commons in its Easter recess, it's time to catch up on the latest cabinet reshuffle speculation. Political correspondent Matthew Tempest reads the runes.
fields.body:
For Westminster's chattering classes, the yet-to-be-called general election is already a bore. The Islington dinner party set decided more than six months ago that Mr Blair would win with a reduced, but still three figure, majority, William Hague would be culled along with the nation's cattle, Michael Portillo would finally decide he wanted to be leader - even if it was only of the opposition - and Charles Kennedy would stare into the abyss as the Lib Dems lost half their 1997 seats as tactical voting evaporated.

Instead, the new game among political anoraks, and political journalists with little to report on, is The Great Tony Blair Second Term Reshuffle. This is based, if it is based on anything at all, on:
 the assumption of a large Labour majority
 the assumption that Tony Blair will want a "honeymoon cull" of his least favourite cabinet performers
 the need for middle-ranking ministers and ambitious
backbenchers to drop lobby journalists helpful hints about how and where their own talents could be best utilised.

This spring's speculation has been given seasonal spice by the foot and mouth outbreak. Now knives are being sharpened not just for agriculture secretary Nick Brown, but for the entire Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. The anachronistic department is just one piece of the Whitehall jigsaw on the agenda for Labour's forces of modernisation.

So here is the full run-down on the latest insider knowledge/informed gossip/pure speculation doing the rounds:

Those not going anywhere:

 the prime minister, Tony Blair - unless the lure of little Leo proves too much for our family-friendly PM

 the chancellor, Gordon Brown - there's only one post he's interested in, and it's not up for grabs

 the foreign secretary, Robin Cook - with his only real rival spending more time in Hartlepool, and a steady pro at the wheel as President Bush sends jitters around the globe, Mr Blair sees no need for change at the most plum job

 the health secretary, Alan Milburn - with his 10-year NHS plan recently set in motion, it would appear a loss of confidence to switch the pugnacious Geordie who has yet to put a foot wrong

 the overseas development secretary, Clare Short - she loves the job, no Cabinet minister wants it, no backbencher would dare punt for it.

 the Northern Ireland secretary John Reid - there's never a good time to lose a NI secretary, but for the prime minister to dump two within five months would look careless. In any case, he's doing a good job

 the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon - has impressed Mr Blair in filling the Nato chief George Robertson's old post.

Those on the move:

 the deputy prime minister John Prescott has told "friends" he is willing to relinquish the strain of yoking together environment, transport and the regions for a beefed-up cabinet office role

 the home secretary Jack Straw - the man dubbed "minister for the interior" by libertarian critics is keen to move across the cabinet table and take on education, especially with the emphasis on secondary schools in a Blair second term

 the education secretary, David Blunkett - so powerful within cabinet he has already held an unofficial "leaving" do at the Department of Education and is champing at the bit to impose his thrifty working-class values at the Home Office. At the weekend, Mr Blunkett said: "I have been in the job, in opposition as well , for six and a half years. That's a long time. I think the prime minister probably wants to reshuffle the cabinet"

 the trade and industry, secretary Stephen Byers - could head up the new Department for Work, merging social security and employment

 the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine - definitely on the way out, Trevor Kavanagh, political editor of the Sun says so. Spent too much of Blair's goodwill on £300 rolls of wallpaper and embarrassing Labour-supporting lawyers into giving money to the cause

 the Welsh secretary Paul Murphy - the job will disappear beneath him as role is subsumed into a ministry for the constitution

 the Scottish secretary Helen Liddell - ditto, although she may grab the constitution post

 the minister at environment, transport and regions, Lord MacDonald - the friend of the motorist is expected to land any new transport minister job. He is so highly thought of by Mr Blair that he could take over as leader of the Lords to smooth out reform of the upper chamber. Quelling the toffs would be quite a prize for the former shipyard organiser.

 the agriculture secretary, Nick Brown - after a calm start to the foot and mouth episode seen to have faltered in the final hurdles as Maff dithered. Could be returned to a behind the scenes role as chief whip.

 Charles Clarke - the former Kinnock adviser is now No 3 at the Home Office. A charming bruiser, could do any cabinet job left over.

Backbenchers hoping for a phone call from No 10:

 Oona King - a telegenic loyalist with a keen interest in the developing world, could fit smoothly into junior foreign office post.

 Chris Leslie - Brownite baby of the house [at least until David Lammy was elected], as a keen advocate of air traffic privatisation and PPS to Lord Falconer he could go far if he can hold his formerly Tory seat.

Departments expected to be rejigged:

 the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food - agriculture and fisheries to be merged into trade and industry, food safety to environment and the new food standards agency, if the recent institute for public policy research thinktank report finds agreement with the PM
 the Department of Social Security - could join employment as the new ministry for work

 the Welsh and Scottish offices - merged into a new body, the ministry for the constitutional affairs, which would also oversee any English regional assemblies.

fields.headline: Subscribers help AOL through slump
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: AOL Time Warner has brushed off the slump in the media sector thanks to a surge in subscriber numbers, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet and cable giant AOL Time Warner has brushed off the slump in the media sector thanks to a surge in subscriber numbers.

The world's largest media company, formed by last year's merger of America Online and Time Warner, said revenues for the first three months of the year had risen 9% to £5.6bn, with subscriptions making up nearly half of the total.

AOL Time Warner said its subscriber base has grown 16% to 133m, with AOL's customer figures climbing to 29m.

The group also bucked the trend of falling advertising revenues in the media sector by reporting a 10% rise in advertising and commerce income to £2.2bn.

John Levin, chief executive of AOL Time Warner, said the results underlined the "unique promise" of the £130bn company, which contains prime assets such as the CNN news network, Time magazine and Warner Music.

"We are aggressively rolling out next-generation products and services that will fuel continued growth momentum in our subscription and advertising and commerce businesses," said Mr Levin.

The figures were in line with analysts' expectations, but there was no mention of the looming actors' and writers' strikes in the US, which will affect revenues at the group's Warner films and television divisions.

AOL Time Warner is a preferred stock for many analysts, because its lack of exposure to the advertising market gives it better protection against the downturn in the US economy.

The company has outperformed the S&P 500 US stock market index over the past 12 months, despite a downturn which has forced its rivals to revise earnings estimates and cut jobs.

However, industry observers will be itching for the group to deliver on its promises of integrating products across its internet and cable distribution platforms.

The main barrier to fulfilling this promise is the slow roll-out of broadband internet services in the US, and the fact that advertisers remain wary of the internet across the Atlantic.

webTitle: Israel forced to pull out of Gaza after outcry

fields.headline: Israel forced to pull out of Gaza after outcry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, was last night forced to order out his tanks from territory recaptured from the Palestinians in Gaza, in the face of unprecedented international condemnation.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg and agencies in Beit Hanoun, Gaza Strip
fields.body:
Israel's hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, was last night forced to order out his tanks from territory recaptured from the Palestinians in Gaza, in the face of unprecedented international condemnation.

Only hours after a senior Israeli army general promised that the military occupation could last for weeks or even months, news agencies reported that the withdrawal had started.

Mr Sharon's spokesman, Raanan Gissin, claimed that this was according to plan: "We always said that it will happen when the military operation ends," he said.

The apparent about-turn followed an unusually out spoken intervention by the American secretary of state, Colin Powell, who accused the Israeli army of an "excessive and disproportionate" response to Palestinian mortar attacks.

Mr Powell said that Israel was failing to uphold its commitment under the Oslo accords of 1993 which awarded Palestinians control of designated areas of Gaza.

"The situation is threatening to escalate further, posing the risk of a broader conflict," he said.

The operation to reoccupy the Palestinian-controlled territory around the town of Beit Hanoun - in northern Gaza - had commenced before dawn yesterday when Israeli tanks began shelling outlying Palestinian border posts north and east of the town.

A Palestinian border guard was killed by a direct hit from a rocket, and 36 people were hurt.

Later in the day, two Palestinian youths, aged 10 and 14, were killed in separate shooting incidents in Gaza involving Israeli soldiers.

At Beit Hanoun, Palestinian officials said Israeli troops thrust a kilometre inside Palestinian territory, bulldozing or rocketing four police posts.

They razed houses and citrus trees in the most fertile part of a pitifully overcrowded and parched territory, and dug a trench to seal off the northern hinterland from the town centre.

The move was met by instant outrage. The Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, said peace efforts were dead. "I don't see any possibility of success this way," he said.

"What happened was an unforgiveable crime," Mr Arafat said, arriving in the West Bank city of Ramallah from Jordan. "These raids are not just an escalation but they are dirty and are intended to bring our people to their knees."

Israel's stated justification for the action was to protect Israeli citizens from mortar fire from inside Gaza.

Brigadier General Yair Naveh - the commander of the army's Gaza brigade who predicted the occupation could last months - said it was a defensive operation. "Its aim is to create and stabilise a line that will enable our citizens, in Sderot and other communities in the area, to sleep peacefully," he said.

On Monday night, five mortar shells had landed on the edges of Sderot, a development town inside the borders of Israel which lies just up the road from the farm belonging to Mr Sharon. Israel said the mortars were fired from Beit Hanoun.

From yesterday's events, it had appeared the army was intent on widening its security perimeter inside the borders of the Gaza Strip.

Under the Oslo accords, Palestinian security forces cannot patrol within 500 metres of Gaza's borders with the Jewish state without Israeli army permission. But that security cordon does not provide protection from long-range mortars.

The Islamist militant group Hamas claimed the attack on Sderot but Gen Naveh, echoing previous Israeli charges, said the strike bore the "fingerprints of the Palestinian Authority".

The attack, the latest in a spate of mortar strikes, caused no damage or injuries, but Israel said the targeting of a town within the borders of the Jewish state was unacceptable.

"This is unjustified and crosses the line," the foreign minister, Shimon Peres, told Israel radio. "There's a limit to everything."

Israel had threatened repeatedly in recent weeks that it would retake some Palestinian-controlled areas if the escalation in violence continued. Israeli troops entered Palestinian-ruled areas in Gaza three times during the last week, and its bulldozers regularly razed farm land and houses.

It has shelled Palestinian police posts - as it did in Beit Hanoun yesterday morning, and in Gaza City overnight on Monday, where eight security installations were hit.

For the last six years, the people of Beit Hanoun have lived under the Oslo agreement and under autonomous Palestinian control. They have had virtually no contact with Israel, or its army, unless they tried to leave the territory. For several hours yesterday they were back under occupation - indefinitely as it then seemed.

As the troop withdrawal began last night, it was still unclear whether the Israeli army would quit other strategic parts of Gaza that it had captured yesterday.

Soldiers sealed off the road at two junctions, effectively slicing the territory into three pieces and cutting off Gaza City from its hinterland. They also closed the Rafah border crossing to Egypt.

"The Israeli soldiers are trying to get as close as they can to the Palestinians, and to cut off as much of their movement as they can, without putting themselves at risk," a foreign diplomat said.

"They do not want to go back to the first intifada in the 1980s when they were holding on to densely populated Palestinian towns."

fields.headline: PR Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 13
fields.trailText: April 13: The Central Office of Information is to overhaul its PR roster.
fields.body:
The Central Office of Information is to overhaul its PR roster, putting around £35m worth of business up for grabs.

The beleagured staff of R-JH are in limbo this week as they await the outcome of a review of royal business affairs.

Transport for London has appointed Colin Douglas as its first communications director.

GE Capital has created the role of communications director for Europe in a bid to make the sprawling organisation better understood.

The Marbles PR agency has been appointed by South West Tourism to help save the region's £6bn tourist industry from foot and mouth ruin.

LD Publicity has been appointed to handle PR for this year's Smash Hits Poll Winners' Party without a competitive pitch.

Energis is reviewing its communications needs following the appointment of Ross Sampson as group-wide marketing and communications chief.

fields.headline: Will Jospin run against Chirac?
fields.standfirst: The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, still hasn't made it clear whether or not he will be a candidate in next year's presidential elections, writes Jon Henley
fields.trailText: The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, still hasn't made it clear whether or not he will be a candidate in next year's presidential elections, writes Jon Henley.
fields.body:
So, will he stand, or won't he? The Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, in his first major television appearance in six months, again left voters in doubt last night as to whether or not he plans to run against Jacques Chirac in next year's French presidential elections.

"I could be a candidate, but I don't need to be, either as a man or as a politician," Mr Jospin insisted in a lengthy interview aimed at reviving his flagging fortunes - and those of his leftist coalition government - with an increasingly disillusioned French electorate.

"The presidential election is not today's problem," he said. "I am sure that its outcome will be decided over the course of a few weeks, on the basis of a few key questions that are not yet clear today. I will be a candidate if those around me want it, if the French people want it, and if it makes sense. But I do not need to be."

His message amounted to a thinly disguised threat: with his popularity dented by labour unrest, natural disasters, mass corporate redundancies and a poor showing by his party in last month's local elections, Mr Jospin, by far the left's best hope for the next president of the Republic, will not stand unless he feels wanted.

He went to great lengths to underline his government's achievements, noting that it had cut unemployment by more than one million people and put the economy on a strong growth footing.

Since his election in 1997, he said, "can anyone really say these have been bad years for France? Honestly, I don't think so."

However, problems have nonetheless piled up on France's grey-haired, professorial PM in the past four weeks since the left unexpectedly lost substantial ground in the provinces to its conservative opposition during local elections across France.

A series of damaging public sector strikes, including stoppages by public transport workers and midwives, have combined to sour the public mood, with high-profile protests against mass private-sector layoffs by the likes of the French multinational food group Danone and British retailer Marks and Spencer.

Matters have not been helped by the weather, with continued heavy rain and flooding in northern France prompting thousands of residents of the stricken town of Abbeville to openly jeer the welly-shod PM last week following rumours that the government had diverted floodwaters from the river Seine to spare Paris.

In a determined counter-offensive, Mr Jospin, 63, has since announced a £20m aid package for the drenched north, and hinted yesterday at the possibility of penalties for profitable companies that sack employees.

But the impression persists that the prime minister, a straight-talking and irreproachably decent former economics teacher, is somehow losing his image as a calm, competent and in-control manager of the country.

Polls after the Socialists' poor local election showing put his personal popularity rating some seven to eight points below Mr Chirac's, the widest gap for a very long time.

Even Mr Jospin's own allies are unhappy. His Green environment minister, Dominique Voynet, last week advised him to take some time off after the prime minister spectacularly lost his temper on a recent trip to Brazil, blasting two French journalists for what he said was their unfair coverage of his speeches.

Today, the opposition inevitably derided his performance of last night, arguing that he was in dire need of a few good new ideas and had said nothing concrete about "the real hopes and fears of French people".

But the opposition's views will worry the prime minister less than the stubborn problem of how to convince the French people that he deserves some reward - and, why not, even a little bit of affection - for his achievements.

Unfortunately for Mr Jospin, the French currently seem to prefer the backslapping, jovial and largely ineffectual bonhomie of their current corruption-tainted president to the stern, straight-A accomplishments of their prime minister.

fields.headline: RSPCA bites back at watchdogs' ruling
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Advertising watchdogs have angered the RSPCA by saying it cannot claim most people support a ban on fox hunting. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The RSPCA has reacted furiously to an advertising watchdog's decision that it cannot claim most people would favour a ban on fox hunting.

The charity said it would challenge the Advertising Standards Authority's ruling that it should not use the claim in its advertising.

The ASA based its decision on an NOP poll that showed most people would not support a ban.

The advert, which appeared in the national press last December, carried the image of a dead fox and encouraged readers to write to their MPs calling for a ban on hunting.

It stated that independent polls had shown most people in the country agreed with a ban.

"We are shocked by the ASA's decision," said a spokeswoman for the RSPCA. "We have a wealth of evidence to support our claim. The NOP poll was not phrased in a sufficiently neutral manner."

The RSPCA's objections will now be sent to the independent reviewer of ASA adjudications.

fields.headline: Bad Girls come good for ITV
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: ITV's prison drama locked out Carole Smillie and Changing Rooms for another week, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ITV's prison drama, Bad Girls, yesterday continued its dominance of Tuesday evenings after seeing off Changing Rooms for another week.

The hard-hitting series pulled in 8.2m viewers and a 34% share at 9pm, while the Carol Smillie's crew bettered last week's performance with 6.4m and a 26% share.

BBC2's moving documentary on fallen snooker legend Alex Higgins pocketed 3.5m and a 15% share for the same timeslot, with Channel 4 and Channel 5 tied on 1.9m viewers for the Body Story and Paul Newman film Cool Hand Luke.

ITV also cleaned up after the 10pm bulletins thanks to its Champions League highlights, with 4.2m fans tuning in at 10.20pm to follow the fortunes of Arsenal and Leeds United in the quarter-finals, winning the network a 27% share.

BBC1's Life after Life documentary, which charted the rehabilitation of a man wrongfully convicted of murder, drew 2.4m and an 18% share at 10.35pm.

The return of Channel 4's identity-swapping Faking It series was greeted by 2.2m people and a 12% share at 10pm.

Earlier in the day, Anne Robinson increased her grip on both sides of the Atlantic by registering 4.6m quiz fanatics for The Weakest Link and a dominant 31% share at 5.15pm on BBC2.

fields.headline: Russia's gas giant
fields.standfirst: Gazprom is rumoured to be Kremlin-controlled, but many in Russia think that even the government struggles to penetrate this labyrinthine, highly influential gas company, writes Amelia Gentleman for Guardian Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gazprom is rumoured to be Kremlin-controlled, but many in Russia think that even the government struggles to penetrate this labyrinthine, highly influential gas company, writes Amelia Gentleman for Guardian Unlimited.
fields.body:
The entrance to the glass skyscraper headquarters of Gazprom in southern Moscow seems as heavily guarded as the gateway to the Kremlin. Gazprom, the world's largest gas company, does not encourage visitors.

The facade of the 36-storey building is made of glass - presenting a veneer of openness - but the blue tint to its windows makes it difficult to peer in. The tower block's physical impenetrability reflects the opaque nature of its inner workings.

Shielded behind these walls is the power centre of a company which holds the key to Russia's whole economy. If Gazprom were to stop operating, lights would go out across Russia from Kaliningrad to Vladivostok, businesses would be forced to shut down and apartments would be left without heat and hot water.

Gazprom has been forced into the public eye in recent weeks because of the work of its subsidiary Gazprom Media in taking over outlets owned by Vladimir Gusinsky, the exiled media magnate whose businesses are heavily in debt to the gas monopoly.

Journalists at NTV - Russia's only national independent television network, seized by Gazprom Media officials in a pre-dawn raid last Saturday - insist that they were the victims of Kremlin oppression, exercised through Gazprom, 38% owned by the state. The government's influence on the gas company was stepped up last summer when Dmitri Medvedev, a senior Kremlin aide and personal confidant of the president, was appointed non-executive chairman.

But not all Moscow's business analysts are convinced that Gazprom is the simply the pliant Kremlin flunkey that Mr Gusinsky's Media-Most outlets portray it as. "The NTV journalists, presenting themselves as martyrs of a repressive state, insist that Gazprom is a mere tool of the Kremlin. Investors in Russian equities know better. Gazprom is a state within a state," Christopher Granville, from United Financial Group, said.

Gazprom's size and power has for years given it such political clout that successive Russian governments have been forced to turn a blind eye to alleged management abuses. Moscow market sources to claim that colossal sums of money leak annually from the business into unknown hands, but the Kremlin has done little to stop the flow.

After more than a year in his post, it was only last week that Vladimir Putin finally steeled himself to take on this massive enterprise. He demanded greater "transparency and efficiency in the company" and insisted that efforts to achieve this end should be injected with new dynamism.

The need for Gazprom reform and restructuring has become something of a cliché in Russian politics after successive attempts have collapsed in failure. But there is a sense of hope amongst investors that Mr Putin may have the determination to penetrate the murky interior of Russia's largest and most influential business.

The task that faces him is as massive as the business itself - and the scale of the company is gargantuan. Gazprom has an annual operating cash flow of $5.3bn (£3.7m). Its vast operation accounts for around 7% of Russia's GDP and represents 25% of government revenues; it controls about 20% of the world's proven gas reserves and is Russia's single biggest hard currency earner. Gazprom controls about 50% of the fuel used for power generation in Russia.

There are some 300,000 Gazprom employees labouring to maintain a pipeline network which run between the Arctic north and the hot plains of the south. Gazprom officials control 95% of the gas extraction which takes place on Russian territory and all of the gas transportation.

They are also responsible for an unusual stable of subsidiary companies: farms, dairies, meat-packing plants, health resorts, yacht clubs, private clinics and several banks - not to mention the collection of national and regional newspapers and television stations.

By supplying cheap, subsidised gas to domestic consumers, Gazprom is also supporting a huge proportion of the Russian economy as well as helping to keep the population warm through the long winters. Its chairman, Rem Vyakhirev, is fond of commenting: "We heat and feed all Russia." He also likes to say: "Without Gazprom there is no Russia."

Moscow's more fanciful business analysts resort to creeping sea-creature analogies when they struggle to describe the company. Gazprom is portrayed as a giant octopus-like sea monster, its tentacles stretched across Russia, sucking gas out from the country's reserves, pumping it through its organs and depositing it in other reaches of Russia and Europe.

The company's scale has made it very difficult for outsiders to penetrate its defences to understand its internal mysteries. One of its most enduring riddles is how a business with such enviable assets has failed to develop into the cash cow for the Russian government that it ought to have become.

The choice of Gazprom's partners has caused much suspicion. Its decision to hand over all its gas supply contracts with former Soviet Union states to a Florida-based company called Itera has triggered suspicion among shareholders and accusations that Itera is being given special treatment because it is in fact partly owned by Gazprom. There is constant concern about covert asset-stripping.

Gazprom denies the allegations and argues that the reason why profits are low is that the company is saddled with a duty to provide cheap gas to the domestic market - selling gas at home for $15 per 1,000 cubic metres which could be sold on the international market for $110 per 1,000 cubic metres.

The massive gas monopoly may have performed a convenient task for the Kremlin in removing some of the media outlets most aggressive in their criticism of Mr Putin's regime, but Moscow's business community is convinced that the president has a much tougher job on his hands in imposing order within Gazprom's own empire.

fields.headline: Vaccination
fields.standfirst:
The government is considering a limited vaccination programme in Cumbria and Devon to combat foot and mouth, but faces opposition from the NFU. Derek Brown and Mark Tran explain

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government is considering a limited vaccination programme in Cumbria and Devon to combat foot and mouth, but faces opposition from the NFU. Derek Brown and Mark Tran explain.
fields.body:
Why vaccinate?
To contain the spread of foot and mouth. Those in favour of vaccination, including the Soil Association, the National Trust, the RSPB and the Wildlife Trusts, say that the present policy of mass slaughter is not working - there are simply too many animals (568,000) to be killed.

Does vaccination work?
Not always. Pigs are particularly unpredictable and vaccination does not work if the animal is already infected. Farmers argue that it is not 100% effective.

Would all animals have to be vaccinated?
That would be impossible, given that there are 60m cattle, sheep and pigs in Britain, not to mention a million deer and countless other wild animals which can contract or carry the disease. The pro-vaccine camp wants a programme of "ring" vaccination around infected farms and abattoirs. Animals within the cordon sanitaire would be vaccinated, and slaughtered later if necessary, when the disease is under control.

What are the disadvantages of vaccination?
It is expensive. Scientists have suggested that initially 180,000 animals, in Devon and Cumbria, should be vaccinated against the disease. The cost of vaccination is £5 a shot, which means the initial cost of the mooted programme would be £900,000.

Treatment also needs to be repeated every six months, and given to each new generation of animals. The adoption of vaccination as a policy is a tacit admission that foot and mouth has not been eradicated.

Why do many farmers with healthy animals to protect still resist vaccination?
Their main argument is that it is impossible to distinguish between vaccinated animals and those with the disease. That could mean the loss of Britain's disease-free status and the destruction of the £1bn-plus meat export trade. However, according to EU rules, a limited vaccination programme would mean a 12-month ban on exports, not a permanent one.

Has the export trade not gone already?
There is a total ban on export of meat and live animals, so long as the disease persists. That is why most farmers favour drastic action to end the crisis as quickly as possible.

Are farmers not also worried about consumer reaction?
They are concerned about consumer resistance to meat and milk that come from vaccinated animals. Although Sainsbury's and Tesco have said that they would agree to sell food and milk from vaccinated products, consumers may shun them, leading to a "two-tier" market.

Is there any public health risk from vaccinated animals?
The food standards agency says that vaccinating animals against foot and mouth poses no risk to public safety so any food and milk sold from vaccinated animals will not carry warning labels. But with the BSE scare still fresh in people's minds, the public may take some convincing.

How does the government plan to overcome consumer resistance?
With strict conditions. Milk from vaccinated animals can only continue to be sold if it is pasteurised and there will be a ban on selling raw milk from such animals. Meat will have to be heated to a temperature that kills the virus but does not cook the meat.

webTitle: Scottish crofter fails in cull prevention bid

fields.headline: Scottish crofter fails in cull prevention bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The crofter at the centre of the foot and mouth scare in the Scottish Highlands has failed in an 11th hour bid to prevent his animals from being slaughtered, it was disclosed today.
fields.body:
The crofter at the centre of the foot and mouth scare in the Scottish Highlands has failed in an 11th hour bid to prevent his animals from being slaughtered, it was disclosed today.

Lawyers acting on behalf of Chris Shepherd of Strathtongue, Sutherland, lodged papers at the court of session in Edinburgh at 11.30pm yesterday, said the Scottish executive.

The legal documents called on the court to grant an interim interdict preventing the cull pending a full judicial review of the Scottish executive's decision.

But an executive spokesman today said the application was rejected by Lord Carloway at 1.30am today and that the cull of around 350 sheep and 75 cattle on Mr Shepherd's land would go ahead today.

The spokesman said: "The case was heard at 11.30pm and the judge ruled at 1.30am against the interim interdict. The cull of Mr Shepherd's stock will proceed during the course of today."

Mr Shepherd's lawyer, Ruben Murdanaigum of Lochgilphead, was not available for comment today.

The cull was ordered after it became known the Mr Shepherd, who runs six crofts at Strathnaver and Strathtongue, had visited his brother in an infected area in Cumbria.

His actions were condemned by Jim Walker, president of the National Farmers' Union of Scotland, who branded Mr Shepherd "stupid" and said his decision to visit Cumbria "beggared belief".

It also emerged last night that Mr Shepherd was charged several days ago in connection with a separate matter involving allegations that he had allowed his sheep to stray.

webTitle: £50,000? He's not much good without an autocue

fields.headline: £50,000? He's not much good without an autocue
fields.trailText:
Angus Deayton has secured a £50,000 contract for one night's work at the Bafta television awards, writes Matt Wells.
10.04.2001: Dyke clamps down on awards liggers
fields.body:
If there was a Bafta for brass neck, then Angus Deayton would be favourite to take it. In a gift to his Have I Got News for You colleagues, the presenter has secured a £50,000 contract for one night's work at the television industry's annual love-in.

Deayton's lucrative package to host the Bafta television awards for the BBC next month is one of the biggest deals of its kind. The broadcaster had originally set aside £20,000 to pay for the ceremony's host. The deal, which includes Deayton's fee, his own scriptwriters, and a tailor-made suit, was sanctioned by the BBC's director of drama and entertainment, Alan Yentob.

It has caused some disquiet at the corporation: some insiders believe that Deayton's fee outweighs his profile. Davina McCall was paid around £15,000 to front the Brit awards for ITV last year, while Ant and Dec commanded a similar deal for this year's show.

But the deal is an indication of the success with which showbusiness agents are able to trade on the increasing demand for TV presenters, with the proliferation of awards ceremonies, game shows, discussion programmes and other personality-led formats.

The BBC cast around for a number of presenters before settling on Deayton. It is thought that Graham Norton turned down an offer because of other commitments; the former footballer Ian Wright, who has just signed an exclusive £1m deal with the corporation, was also mentioned.

Deayton was finally chosen because he is a "BBC face". But one BBC programme-maker said that the presenter, who is nominated for best entertainment performance at the Baftas, was overrated. "He's not much good without a script and an autocue," the source said. It is thought that Deayton was able to secure such a high fee because the BBC was beginning to worry about whether it could secure a big enough name in time.

Deayton's star is in the ascendancy: all the performers in Have I Got News for You are reported to have received a hefty hike in their fees when the show transferred from BBC2 to BBC1. He also has a lucrative deal fronting the Barclaycard advertising campaign.

The BBC is prepared to play an increasingly commercial game to secure key talent. The signing of Wright indicated that the BBC1 controller, Lorraine Heggessey, was determined to nurture a new generation of presenters who would be readily associated with her channel.

One commercial television executive said of the Baftas deal: "I just cannot under stand why the BBC thought that he was worth this amount of money. For some reason, Deayton is one of those people who can command vast fees for whatever he does."

A BBC spokeswoman said: "We can't discuss the figures, but we think Angus is a highly talented presenter and we are delighted to have secured his services."

 Angus Deayton is the odd one out: Paul Merton, Ian Hislop and, as far as we know, the lard have never earned £50,000 and a free suit for a couple of hours work.

fields.headline: Wednesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are about as amusing as Dom Joly
fields.trailText: Southampton will ask Brighton for permission to interview Micky Adams for their vacant managerial post. According to the Sun, the Southampton board is split between offering the job to Keven Keegan or a younger man like Adams, an ex-Saints left-back who saw the Seagulls promoted from the Third Division this week.
fields.body:
Southampton will ask Brighton for permission to interview Micky Adams for their vacant managerial post. According to the Sun, the Southampton board is split between offering the job to Keven Keegan or a younger man like Adams, an ex-Saints left-back who saw the Seagulls promoted from the Third Division this week.

The Mirror says combative Leicester midfielder Robbie Savage has been approached by Real Betis about joining them in the summer if they get promoted to the Primera Division.

Meanwhile, Tottenham is keen to bolster his squad by luring ageing stars Stefan Effenberg and Teddy Sheringham to White Hart Lane. The Star says Glenn Hoddle will make his approaches soon.

Fulham are trying to make Paris St-Germain's £7m-rated right winger Laurent Robert his next major signing, according to the Mirror. Newcastle are also after the 25-year-old, but Jean Tigana stole a march by speaking to his agent last Saturday.

The Express claims Fulham are stepping up efforts to make another big-money signing, Monaco defender Martin Djetou for £8m. They have offered Djetou, 26, a four-year deal, and are also interested in his defensive team-mate Philippe Christanval. Norweigan Under-21 left back Erland Hanstveit is another target. The 19-year-old will cost about £1m from SK Brann. The only gossip from the lower leagues comes courtesy of the Star, which says Gillingham midfielder Nicky Southall is a target for Sheffield Wednesday.

fields.headline: Trouble lures teens with text message game
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Trouble TV is launching a text message game to promote its content on different media, writes Julia Day.
28.03.2001: Vodafone texts youth
fields.body:
Flextech-owned teen channel Trouble TV is launching an interactive text message promotion as part of a push to deliver content across different channels.

The promotion takes the form of a game and is the first in a series of text services lined up for Flextech's channels.

The game, called Text God, aims to get teenagers signed up to the TV channel's membership club, which is run through its website.

Every afternoon, Trouble viewers who spot the "Text God" icon on their TV screens will be encouraged to text in code words on their phones to compete for prizes.

Throughout the day, TV presenters will show viewers how to play and how to become members of the Trouble club.

The promotion was put together by the wireless marketing agency, Aerodeon.

"This innovative deal underpins our commitment to integrate our content across digital platforms and we look forward to demonstrating the value of mobile-phone marketing to our client base," said James Wildman, the director of commercial development at Flextech.

According to the Childwise Monitor Report carried out in 2000, 90% of 15 to 17-year-olds use text messaging instead of voice calls and 68% of 11 to 16-year-olds have their own mobile phone.

webTitle: Government to back foot and mouth vaccination

fields.headline: Government to back foot and mouth vaccination
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Government advisers were today expected to set out the scientific case for a limited foot and mouth vaccination programme in a bid to win the support of sceptical farmers.
fields.body:
Government advisers were today expected to set out the scientific case for a limited foot and mouth vaccination programme in a bid to win the support of sceptical farmers.

Ministers believe the jabs are now needed in Cumbria, where the disease has struck hardest, and possibly in Devon, which is also severely hit.

However, farmers' leaders are resisting the move, arguing there are still unanswered questions over whether it will work and what the possible economic fallout might be.

The attempt to convince farmers was expected to come as the prime minister, Tony Blair, was expected to make a further effort to boost the stricken tourist industry.

Downing Street has said the government "accepts in principle" arguments for limited vaccination from the chief vet, Jim Scudamore, and the chief scientist, Professor David King.

Jabs were "justified as a means of protecting those animals", a spokesperson said last night. However, officials are stressing that the programme could not be expected to work without "substantial support" from farmers.

With the National Farmers' Union (NFU) currently blocking the move, it was anticipated that Professor King and Mr Scudamore would set out their reasoning at a briefing this morning. It was hoped that by clearly stating the scientific case they might win over the NFU leadership.

The government's agricultural development and advisory service has already placed advertisements in job centres in Cumbria and Devon for people to carry out the programme.

But the extent of farmers' suspicion of the proposed programme was underlined by NFU president Ben Gill.

Mr Gill said: "We have put forward a list of questions that we required to be answered, on trade related issues, on consumer related issues, and on veterinary and epidemiological issues.

"We have had some answers, but regrettably those answers have spawned even more questions. Not because we want to be bloodyminded, but because before we make such a far-reaching jump into the future, my members have a right to know that they are not actually doing anything more than putting a ball on a roulette wheel that might come up trumps, but has a far greater chance of being a long-term denigration to our industry."

The total number of confirmed cases in Great Britain reached 1,365 as of 7pm yesterday - an increase of 22 over the day before.

The prime minister chaired a series of meetings in Downing Street yesterday on foot and mouth, discussing latest developments with the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, other ministers, Mr Scudamore and Professor King.

After around two hours of discussions, a No 10 spokesman said that the scientists firmly advocated a limited vaccination programme for cattle in Cumbria and Devon. Vaccination, the spokesman stressed, would be a "supplement" to the current culling policy.

webTitle: Matt Seaton meets Harry Potter creator JK Rowling

fields.headline: 'If I could talk to my mum again I'd tell her I'd tell her I had a daughter - and I wrote some books and guess what happened?'
fields.trailText: The author of the phenomenally successful Harry Potter books talks about how she went from being a struggling single parent to a multi-millionaire novelist
fields.body:
"There was a point where I really felt I had 'penniless divorcee lone parent' tattooed on my head," remarks JK Rowling sardonically. "You couldn't read about Harry Potter without seeing that somewhere in the piece.

"So I thought, 'Fine, let's take that and use it.' "

"Using it" meant sacrificing the relative anonymity that Jo Rowling still enjoyed before she decided last year to lend her support to the National Council for One-Parent Families. The origin of "JK" goes back to the advice from her publisher Bloomsbury that the adventures of an 11-year-old boy who goes to wizard school would not appeal to 11-year-old boys if written too identifiably by a woman.

Ironically, the initials provided a kind of anonymity and mystique, behind which Rowling was able to guard her privacy. Beyond the fact that she was a young-ish single mother who had written parts of the first book sitting in a cafe in Edinburgh because her flat was unheated, relatively little was known. Only when the third book (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban) was published did the media's curiosity force her hand: "So I decided that I would give interviews - when I had something to say."

She has plenty to say about the way single parents get blamed for everything from falling morals to rising crime: "It's this universal human desire we have through history: if we demonise them, we don't have to help them. It's much easier for certain sections of society to say, 'You've brought this on yourself by your fecklessness; you sort it out,' than to say, 'You've been a victim of circumstances,' or 'Hey, marriages break up ... but how are we going to help you help yourself?'

"I never set out to be a lone parent - and there I was," she says. "It's undeniable: there's a stigma attached. But I was the most unashamed lone parent you were ever going to meet. I was, like, 'And what is your problem? I'm doing a great job.' I'm very impatient with the idea that any of us should be ashamed about it."

Rowling became a single parent when her marriage to Portuguese television journalist Jorge Arantes fell apart shortly after the birth of her daughter Jessica. "It was my Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee moment," she jokes. "It is the most humiliating thing, actually: you're supposed to have your relationship disaster in your teens, aren't you - and then wise up?"

Rowling left Portugal in early 1994 and came to Edinburgh, planning to stay with her sister Di for a few weeks until she found her feet. She never left. "Edinburgh is beautiful," she explains, "has good public transport and did have, then, free museums, and I thought, 'I'll have a much better life here on a low income with my daughter.' I could just see that broke single-parenthood here would be easier."

"Poverty is the issue," she continues. "I do say that partly out of my own experience, but I am acutely aware when I talk about single parents being poor that, for me, it was a temporary state and it was always likely to be. We were never going to be rich if I had been a teacher, but we were never going to be dirt poor. And I had middle-class friends who could lend me a tenner."

Rowling's success as an author - the four Harry Potter books to date have sold more than 90m copies worldwide and been translated into 42 languages - has clearly removed that problem. The days of sitting in a cafe, snatching a few hours to write while Jessica slept in her pushchair, are long gone. Jessica, now seven, goes to school, and has a nanny who picks her up two days a week, while Rowling looks after her the other three.

"She's embarrassingly precocious and gloats about the places she's been," she says. "I heard her saying: 'I went to the Space Needle in Seattle, but Mummy couldn't go; Mummy was in a bookshop.' I'm like: 'Yeah, cheers, I know.' "

So does money solve all the problems of being a single parent? "No, but it sure as hell helps. The worst of being a single parent is constantly thinking, 'I can't give you what I want to give you.' "

Rowling named her daughter after Jessica Mitford, sister of Nancy, author and avowed communist, whose autobiography Rowling read as a teenager. "Basically, [Mitford] had every single possible component you could want as a 13-year-old leftwinger."

Rowling looks an unlikely rebel. She was head girl of her comprehensive school in Chepstow - but she was the sort, she says, who got "caught smoking at bus stops with boys in leather jackets". Now 35, she is slim and chic in fitted black rollneck and charcoal hipster pants that flare from the knee. She shakes her head now and then to clear the blonde fringe from her vision - a mannerism that gives her an air of diffidence. But when she fixes you with her blue-grey eyes, you don't doubt that here is a person with some steel.

"It's a funny thing," she muses, "but I doubt very much there would have been a Jessie if mum hadn't died when she did. I only went abroad nine months after she died: I really needed to get away. A lot of bad stuff had happened, and I needed to sort myself out a bit. And obviously, I met my ex-husband and Jessica was the result, so life does go on.

"It was doing a big rebound job, really," she adds. "That's when you're most vulnerable."

Her mother Anne had died in 1990 from multiple sclerosis at the age of 45. With just 20 years between them, Jo and her mother had been very close. "Because I was the older child, to me she was almost like an older sister. I was never in any doubt that she was my mum, but that kind of relationship was there. I could talk to her a lot more freely than some of my friends spoke to their mothers."

Anne Rowling had been 35 when first diagnosed with the illness - "the same age as me now, which is a bit of a facer, isn't it?" Because of the experience of losing her mother, Rowling has recently embraced the MS Society in Scotland and will be helping to publicise MS awareness week shortly. Anne had been a wheelchair user since Jo graduated from Exeter University, but the end, when it came, still seemed sudden.

"The last time I saw her before she died, I went back for Christmas," she recalls, haltingly. "I can't believe in retrospect that I didn't really realise what was about to happen because she was so ill. Her mobility was very limited; she looked ill, very ill - which I'd never really seen before. She was absolutely exhausted.

"She died at home, of respiratory failure. Dad went upstairs and found her dead."

Part of the appeal of the Harry Potter stories is the way Rowling's fiction engages with the dark stuff. Rowling began work on the first book just six months before her mother died. It is one of those well-known facts that the idea of Harry's world first came to Rowling on a train journey to King's Cross; but it was also on a train from that station that her mother and father first met. "That's obviously why it looms large in my psyche," she comments wryly.

Her mother's death, she says, made the fact that Harry is an orphan and the theme of death and loss "immeasurably more important", and she alludes to the now famous episode in chapter 12 of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, when Harry sees his dead parents in the Mirror of Erised (Desire backwards). What, I wonder, would Rowling see in the mirror?

"It would be my mother," she says without hesitation. "You'd want five minutes to say, 'I have a daughter, and she's called Jessica, and she looks like this and she likes this, and I wrote some books - and Mum, guess what happened?'

"I'd gabble on and at the end of five minutes I'd realise I hadn't asked what it's like to be dead. It's the selfishness of the child, isn't it? - at least I'm aware of that. But it couldn't be long enough. That was all in that mirror episode, I think: recognising that it's just not healthy, not good for you to dwell and dwell and dwell.

"It's not about forgetting, but you have got to move on."

 This is an edited version of an article that appears in the May issue of In Style, on sale from Friday.

Rowling's success as an author - the four Harry Potter books to date have sold more than 90m copies worldwide and been translated into 42 languages - has clearly removed that problem. The days of sitting in a cafe, snatching a few hours to write while Jessica slept in her pushchair, are long gone. Jessica, now seven, goes to school, and has a nanny who picks her up two days a week, while Rowling looks after her the other three. "She's embarrassingly precocious and gloats about the places she's been," she says. "I heard her saying: 'I went to the Space Needle in Seattle, but Mummy couldn't go; Mummy was in a bookshop.' I'm like: 'Yeah, cheers, I know.' " So does money solve all the problems of being a single parent? "No, but it sure as hell helps. The worst of being a single parent is constantly thinking, 'I can't give you what I want to give you.' " Rowling named her daughter after Jessica Mitford, sister of Nancy, author and avowed communist, whose autobiography Rowling read as a teenager. "Basically, [Mitford] had every single possible component you could want as a 13-year-old leftwinger." Rowling looks an unlikely rebel. She was head girl of her comprehensive school in Chepstow - but she was the sort, she says, who got "caught smoking at bus stops with boys in leather jackets". Now 35, she is slim and chic in fitted black rollneck and charcoal hipster pants that flare from the knee. She shakes her head now and then to clear the blonde fringe from her vision - a mannerism that gives her an air of diffidence. But when she fixes you with her blue-grey eyes, you don't doubt that here is a person with some steel. "It's a funny thing," she muses, "but I doubt very much there would have been a Jessie if mum hadn't died when she did. I only went abroad nine months after she died: I really needed to get away. A lot of bad stuff had happened, and I needed to sort myself out a bit. And obviously, I met my ex-husband and Jessica was the result, so life does go on. "It was doing a big rebound job, really," she adds. "That's when you're most vulnerable." Her mother Anne had died in 1990 from multiple sclerosis at the age of 45. With just 20 years between them, Jo and her mother had been very close. "Because I was the older child, to me she was almost like an older sister. I was never in any doubt that she was my mum, but that kind of relationship was there. I could talk to her a lot more freely than some of my friends spoke to their mothers." Anne Rowling had been 35 when first diagnosed with the illness - "the same age as me now, which is a bit of a facer, isn't it?" Because of the experience of losing her mother, Rowling has recently embraced the MS Society in Scotland and will be helping to publicise MS awareness week shortly. Anne had been a wheelchair user since Jo graduated from Exeter University, but the end, when it came, still seemed sudden. "The last time I saw her before she died, I went back for Christmas," she recalls, haltingly. "I can't believe in retrospect that I didn't really realise what was about to happen because she was so ill. Her mobility was very limited; she looked ill, very ill - which I'd never really seen before. She was absolutely exhausted. "She died at home, of respiratory failure. Dad went upstairs and found her dead." Part of the appeal of the Harry Potter stories is the way Rowling's fiction engages with the dark stuff. Rowling began work on the first book just six months before her mother died. It is one of those well-known facts that the idea of Harry's world first came to Rowling on a train journey to King's Cross; but it was also on a train from that station that her mother and father first met. "That's obviously why it looms large in my psyche," she comments wryly. Her mother's death, she says, made the fact that Harry is an orphan and the theme of death and loss "immeasurably more important", and she alludes to the now famous episode in chapter 12 of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, when Harry sees his dead parents in the Mirror of Erised (Desire backwards). What, I wonder, would Rowling see in the mirror? "It would be my mother," she says without hesitation. "You'd want five minutes to say, 'I have a daughter, and she's called Jessica, and she looks like this and she likes this, and I wrote some books - and Mum, guess what happened?' "I'd gabble on and at the end of five minutes I'd realise I hadn't asked what it's like to be dead. It's the selfishness of the child, isn't it? - at least I'm aware of that. But it couldn't be long enough. That was all in that mirror episode, I think: recognising that it's just not healthy, not good for you to dwell and dwell and dwell. "It's not about forgetting, but you have got to move on."  This is an edited version of an article that appears in the May issue of In Style, on sale from Friday.

fields.headline: Morris rebukes teachers over 35-hour week
fields.standfirst: Minister tells union it is 'unprofessional' to campaign for cut in hours but delegates expected to back call for hours limit
fields.trailText: Minister tells union it is 'unprofessional' to campaign for cut in hours but delegates expected to back call for hours limit.
fields.body:
The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, yesterday accused the teaching unions of being unprofessional in their pursuit of a 35-hour week.

Revealing that talks between ministers and union leaders on a reduced workload could begin as early as next week, Ms Morris put the government's view that a strict limit on hours was inappropriate for a profession.

She told the annual conference of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers in Jersey: "I will be honest; I am not in favour of a 35-hour week, but I am in favour of reviewing workload. This is one of the most important professions, and I don't think it is the mark of a profession to campaign for a 35-hour working week."

The government this month offered an independent inquiry into teachers' work, provided the two largest unions - the National Union of Teachers and the NASUWT - called off their industrial action in refusing to cover for teacher vacancies or illness of more than three days - which they did.

Responding to Ms Morris's charge of unprofessionalism, Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of NASUWT, said: "It is quite common for other professions, such as the medical and legal professions, to charge by the hour. The crucial thing is that we end the open-ended contracts which trigger extra workload for teachers."

His union is expected today to back, by a huge majority, a joint motion calling for the weekly hours limit - in line with a deal already offered to Scottish teachers. The NUT backed the motion at its conference this week, as did the Association of Teachers and Lecturers at its conference.

In a parallel move, the NUT yesterday threatened to boycott the government's scheme for appraising staff performance, unless ministers dropped plans to link it to pay rises.

In a defeat for the union's leadership on the last day of its annual conference in Cardiff, delegates demanded a ballot on a boycott of the performance management system.

Members are furious that the government proposes to use the results of that appraisal, carried out by headteachers, in decisions on whether teachers should receive performance-related pay.

The motion called for a ballot on the boycott in the autumn, but the leadership wants to delay.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary, said he would first press the government to include performance management in the promised review of teachers' workload. He also wants a delay until the report next spring of the school teachers' review body, which decides on pay.

But he added that unless the government ended the link between performance management and pay, the union would eventually take industrial action.

Delegates backed the ballot call by 112,203 to 87,879. A source close to David Blunkett, education secretary, said the conference had made "a particularly silly decision", as performance management had already delivered £2,000 rises to more than 150,000 experienced classroom teachers at the top of their pay scale.

On other key issues the conference had backed the leadership.

In his speech to close the five-day meeting, Mr McAvoy told delegates they had to accept some system of performance management, even if they opposed the government's scheme. "We are not free agents, how can we ever argue that headteachers should be ignorant of the strengths and weaknesses of teaching in their schools?"

He told them to "cheer up" and acknowledge some of the gains the union had achieved for teachers. It had "stopped the cover-up" on teacher shortages, forced the general teaching council to cut its fee for teachers, won members the right of appeal against being denied performance related pay and helped to persuade Ofsted to reform the school inspection system.

Mr McAvoy rounded on leftwingers for opposing the terms of a motion calling for the union to work towards the merger of the main classroom unions.

Most members back the idea in principle, but many are concerned that it will lead to watered down NUT policy.

He told delegates: "We have an opportunity to progress towards professional unity, an opportunity that will be lost if we fail to show discipline and understanding in our joint campaigns. Let us strive for the biggest prize."

The joint motion on teachers' hours calls for a maximum 35-hour week with no more than 22.5 hours of teaching, in line with recommendations of the independent McCrone inquiry in Scotland.

The talks on reducing workload, involving ministers, unions and employers, are likely to focus on the scope of an inquiry, which the government has insisted will not include pay.

fields.headline: Report blasts healthcare in jails
fields.trailText: Medical services in jails are in crisis, with prisoners denied effective medicines and governors interfering in doctors' clinical judgments, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
Medical services in jails are in crisis, with prisoners denied effective medicines and governors interfering in doctors' clinical judgments, according to a report published today.

Experienced prison doctors are deserting the service and the profession is experiencing recruitment problems because of low morale and poor resources, the British Medical Association study found.

The crisis will rebound on the general public because prisoners with serious problems such as mental illness and HIV are simply being returned to the community without support or treatment, the BMA says.

As doctors called for extra cash to fund healthcare in jails, the government unveiled details of a £60m investment programme to improve health services in prisons in England and Wales.

The report was written by Dr Patrick Keavney, chairman of the BMA's civil service committee, and covered prison services in England and Wales.

There are just 230 prison doctors, of whom 135 are directly employed by prisons, while the rest are GPs contracted to work part-time from the health service.

Dr Keavney said even though prisoners have much higher rates of mental illness, drug and alcohol problems, doctors working in the service have less support and fewer resources.

Prison governors are too concerned with bureaucratic processes and cost-cutting rather than focusing on the medical needs of prisoners, he claims.

His report says: "Much of the difficult working environment for prison healthcare staff stems from the lack of co-operation, and in some cases active opposition, of prison administrators, particularly certain prison governors.

"Many of the complaints made to the BMA from its own members who are prison doctors concern unacceptable interference by prison governors in their doctors' clinical judgment about the needs of their patients.

"Structural changes in the service in the 1990s also increased the status of governors relative to prison doctors and further undermined clinical independence."

Prisoners are denied effective drugs such as migraine medicines that are available in the NHS as a whole because of cost-cutting in jails, the report says. That was leading to more ill-health in jails and undermining trust between doctors and prisoners, who realise they are being denied effective drugs.

Prison doctors are also being excluded from decision making among jail bosses on which medicines and therapies should be available.

The lack of other staff such as psychiatrists, health workers and substance abuse counsellors is also contributing to the problem. The report says: "Failure to support prison doctors will inevitably affect both prisoners' health and the wider public health in the long run.

"People who come out of prison after serving their term, if they are still suffering from inadequately diagnosed or insufficiently treated conditions, will inevitably affect the wider public health.

"Many prisoners also contract HIV or other communicable diseases while in prison, which could be treated much more quickly and effectively in prison."

The government's £60m cash boost will be used to repair or replace prison healthcare centres, improve staff training, tackle infectious diseases and set up new drug programmes.

More than half of the total, £35m, will be for healthcare centres including the building of new ones at Pentonville and Chelmsford prisons.

Another £10.5m will be spent on building and running drug units. which will cope with 4,000 prisoners a year on top of the 18,000 already going through detoxification annually.

Around £14m will be spent on staff training and fighting infectious diseases, including offering vaccination against Hepatitis B to all prisoners when they first enter the prison system.

Prisons minister Paul Boateng said: "Historically, healthcare provision in prison has fallen short of the service provided by the NHS and on too many occasions has fallen short of basic decency."

Health minister Lord Hunt also announced details of new NHS teams to support specialist mental health services in prisons.

The NHS-funded mental health scheme, which aims to have 300 new staff by 2004, will be piloted in prisons at Birmingham, Brixton, Chelmsford, Eastwood Park, Holloway, Feltham, Leeds, Leicester, Pentonville, Wandsworth, Winchester and Wormwood Scrubs.

webTitle: Sharon Maguire to make 'modern Pride and Prejudice'

fields.headline: Sharon Maguire to make 'modern Pride and Prejudice'
fields.trailText: Sharon Maguire, who made her directorial debut with Bridget Jones's Diary, is to direct a modern-day Jane Austen-style comedy
fields.body:
Sharon Maguire, who made her directorial debut with Bridget Jones's Diary, is to direct a modern-day Jane Austen-style comedy.

Screen Daily reports that Maguire, whose friendship with Helen Fielding nabbed her her first director's role, is to make the film in Boston for FilmFour.

The movie is apparently inspired by Austen's Pride and Prejudice and has a script written by American playwright Wendy Wasserstein. Wasserstein won a Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award for her play The Heidi Chronicles. She also adapted The Object of My Affection, starring Jennifer Aniston.

"At the end of the day, what I really want to get is a good story," Maguire told Screendaily. "That's what makes you get up every morning."

Talk is also heating up about a sequel to Bridget Jones, based on Fielding's own sequel, the best-selling, Bridget Jones: Edge of Reason. After the huge opening weekend for the first film - the best ever for a British movie - demand is growing for a follow-up. The book has already been optioned by Working Title.

fields.headline: C4 gets Passengers back on board
fields.trailText:
11.30am: C4 is resurrecting late night youth TV show Passengers on its pay-TV entertainment channel E4, reports Jason Deans.
C4 chief Michael Jackson live online
fields.body:
Channel 4 is resurrecting its advertiser-funded, late-night youth TV show, Passengers, on pay-TV entertainment channel E4.

Passengers, which was funded by Pepsi in its previous mid-1990s Channel 4 incarnation, will now be backed by Sony Playstation 2 on its E4 return.

Eight 30-minute episodes of the show, which uses video diaries to explore different aspects of international youth culture, have been commissioned for E4 from producer Rapido TV.

The original version of Passengers featured video diaries from then unknowns including actor Ewan McGregor and drum'n'bass pioneer Goldie, as well as now deceased rapper Notorious B.I.G.

"It will have a real international feel and be shot around the world," said Peter Stuart, managing director of Rapido, which is responsible for programmes including Eurotrash, the Girlie Show and Baadasss TV.

"We will be exploring and embracing youth culture around the world, but not in an insular Ibiza Uncovered way. Not just Englishmen abroad."


Talk about it with C4 boss Michael Jackson

webTitle: Wanted: director with a taste for adventure

fields.headline: Wanted: director with a taste for adventure
fields.trailText: Trevor Nunn's supporters can point to obvious achievements during his term of office. The National has won a fistful of awards. It created, for a brief period, a magical ensemble. Nunn's own productions, most especially of Troilus and Cressida, The Merchant of Venice and The Cherry Orchard, have been outstanding.
fields.body:
Trevor Nunn's supporters can point to obvious achievements during his term of office. The National has won a fistful of awards. It created, for a brief period, a magical ensemble. Nunn's own productions, most especially of Troilus and Cressida, The Merchant of Venice and The Cherry Orchard, have been outstanding. And, whatever one thinks of the propriety of the National doing straight runs of commercial musicals, both Oklahoma! and My Fair Lady have drawn new audiences into the building.

But, within the theatrical profession and even inside the National itself, there has been criticism of Nunn's policy. His unwillingness, or inability, to appoint a team of associate directors has led to accusations of presidential-style government. The growing disparity between his own work and that of freelance directors was highlighted last year by a string of box-office failures in the Olivier with The Villains' Opera, Romeo and Juliet and Peer Gynt. And the choice of new plays, with the obvious exceptions of Michael Frayn's Copenhagen and Joe Penhall's Blue/Orange, has been at best erratic and at worst woeful.

The National has to be seen as an adventurous theatrical flagship to justify a £13.3m subsidy. The real charge is one of artistic caution. Under Nunn, the National has seemed an all-too-apt metaphor for the nation: nervous, insular, obsessed with public-private partnerships and faintly Europhobic.

Paradoxically, within the next 15 months there are signs of a more expansive approach. We are promised new plays from Tom Stoppard, Patrick Marber, Mark Ravenhill and Charlotte Jones as well as Tartuffe with Martin Clunes, A Streetcar Named Desire with Glenn Close and a Peter Hall production of The Bacchae. But this should be the rule rather than the exception. In recent weeks, the main drama emanating from the National has been whether or not Martine McCutcheon will sing as Eliza. You feel there has to be more to a great national enterprise than that.

fields.headline: One2One signs Oldman for new campaign
fields.trailText: 11.30am: One2One is ditching its 'Welcome to your world' tagline after less than two years, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
One2One is quietly dropping its "Welcome to your world" tagline after less than two years for a new campaign that focuses on the important conversations in people's lives.

The telecoms giant is shooting a new commercial with actor Gary Oldman, which it says will "celebrate the pivotal One2Ones in everyone's lives".

Details of the commercial are being kept under wraps, but it is not expected to include the "Welcome to your world" line introduced in December 1999 in an advert starring football hard man Vinnie Jones.

The advertising replaced the long-running "Who would you like to have a One2One with?" campaign, in which celebrities including Kate Moss and Chris Evans described dream conversations with their heroes.

The new tagline was designed to promote the whole range of services offered by One2One, rather than just showing someone talking on a mobile.

The old line is being dropped because the company wanted its brand name to become more central to its advertising.

It is the first time Oldman, who appeared in Hannibal and Air Force One, has appeared in a TV commercial.

"One2One's award-winning and inspirational advertising heritage allows us to attract major celebrities to star in our commercials," said Tim Yates, marketing director for One2One.

"Gary Oldman is the perfect choice to star in the forthcoming interwoven story that, I'm sure, will delight and intrigue viewers over the coming months."

The new campaign was created by Bartle Bogle Hegarty and will appear on TV screens in May.

fields.headline: Northern Ireland faces heavy cost of foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland's reliance on agriculture and tourism would make the further spread of foot and mouth a national disaster, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's reliance on agriculture and tourism would make the further spread of foot and mouth a national disaster, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The uncontrolled spread of foot and mouth in Northern Ireland would be an unmitigated disaster. The economy is heavily reliant on agriculture and rural tourism, both likely to lose millions even if there is not a single new case.

The restrictions on farmers are even more severe than in the rest of the UK, with a complete ban on all animal movements ordered by the province's agriculture minister, Brid Rodgers.

The loss of income and the consequent extra costs for feeding and housing livestock will be crippling to many smaller farmers.

Agriculture accounts for 6% of the Northern Ireland economy - four times more than in mainland Britain. Though farming is no longer a major source of employment, the crisis could quickly add to joblessness in the province, through its effect on the tourist trade.

The savage irony of the current outbreak is that tourism in Northern Ireland was beginning to emerge from 30 years of recession caused by conflict and political upheaval.

The province has much to offer visitors - not least its compactness. From the glorious North Antrim coastline, with its famous Giant's Causeway to the fabulous lakes of Fermanagh, its landscapes are made for rest and recreation.

Now, as the funeral pyres blaze in at least two of the six counties, those attractions are beginning to look remote once more. The Easter holiday trade was reportedly brisk, but it was confined for the most part to towns and main roads, with the more bucolic areas all but deserted.

Some of Northern Ireland's most justly famed attractions are closed completely, like the bathing beach at Cushendun, County Antrim, and the Tollymore Forest Park in County Down. Other parts, until so recently poised to take off as tourist attractions, have once again been plunged into gloom.

Hoteliers and caterers in Fermanagh have reported that trade is down by as much as 60%, and are gloomily forecasting that the summer season will bring little improvement.

fields.headline: What he said about Tour de France
fields.trailText: Channel 4's chief executive, Michael Jackson, has no regrets about dumping Tour de France cycling after 15 years.
fields.body:
Channel 4's chief executive, Michael Jackson, said he had no regrets about dumping Tour de France cycling after 15 years, despite protests from up to 1m fans.

In an online chat today with MediaGuardian.co.uk, he said the station simply had to "move on" and tempt viewers with other sports such as cricket.

"Channel 4 has always broadcast a range of sports, but the fact is that if we are to innovate we have to move on," said Mr Jackson.

"So just as the channel started with American sport, particularly American football - which worked particularly well when football was in its 80s doldrums - but then moved on, so the same is true for the Tour de France.

"We've added cricket to the mix, pretty successfully, and next year we start our coverage of the World Rally Championship to which we hope to bring the same sense of innovation and commitment.

"I do recognise there are many Tour de France viewers who are losing out but we felt we were going to be messing them around this summer because of the clashes between the tour and the Ashes. "We are looking to find another broadcaster to take it on," he said.

When asked "if innovation is about 'moving on' why don't you dump Brookside?", the Channel 4 boss replied: "We're still covering minority sports such as windsurfing, snowboarding, Formula Three, and in December the World Extreme Games. To answer your point about Brookside, I think you can 'move on' within a soap, introducing new characters and storylines."
