webTitle: National Theatre director to step down

fields.headline: Exit Nunn, pursued by critics
fields.standfirst: National Theatre director to step down after controversial regime dominated by safe, commercial productions
fields.trailText: National Theatre director to step down after controversial regime dominated by safe, commercial productions.
fields.body:
Trevor Nunn, the multi-millionaire artistic director of the Royal National Theatre - whose regime has been criticised for its timidity and unashamed commercialism - is to step down. Nunn, 61, who has long insisted that he would not be hounded out of one of the toughest jobs in theatre and would outlast his critics, could go by September next year.

In a low-key statement slipped out over Easter, the National's board announced that Nunn was "not seeking reappointment".

The statement continued: "Even so, he has generously agreed to stay in post until a successor is ready to take over ... He has, by his leadership and example, enhanced the reputation of the National Theatre and upheld the standards established by his predecessors, Laurence Olivier, Peter Hall and Richard Eyre." Nunn refused to comment.

His four-year tenure of the National's brutalist bunker on the South Bank has been attacked for its "drift and muddle" and has been characterised by what one critic called a "saturation diet of musicals".

Major achievements such as the amazing ensemble of actors he has put together, and greatly increased touring, have been obscured by the flak Nunn has attracted for eschewing the radical new work many believe the National was set up to perform in favour of such "safe" bets as his revival of Oklahoma!.

Anti-Nunn opinion was further inflamed by the cut he took from the musical's lucrative transfer to the West End. Unlike his predecessor, Sir Richard Eyre, whose fee from transferred productions such as Guys and Dolls was capped at a low level, Nunn's is not limited, although he cannot earn more than the National itself.

The precise nature of his contract with the theatre, however, is confidential. His bank balance will be further enhanced by a planned Broadway run of Oklahoma! and Nunn is also likely to make up to £1m when his sell-out production of My Fair Lady moves to the Theatre Royal in Drury Lane in July in another of the tie-ups with the impresario Cameron Mackintosh which has so angered some of his peers.

Joint ventures

Two years ago Nunn was estimated to be worth more than £43m by the Sunday Times rich list, mainly from his joint ventures with Andrew Lloyd Webber on the musicals Cats and Les Miserables.

His personal fortune has risen sharply since then, though his National salary brings in a comparatively modest £120,000 a year.

Sir Christopher Hogg, the National's chairman, however, had no such qualms about dallying with the commercial sector and claimed that even with its £13m grant, subsidy covered only 36% of their overheads as against more than 60% in the past.

"One should be so lucky to have a public-private partnership in which you enlist well below market cost the services of someone of the class of Trevor."

He also pointed to the success of such outwardly uncommercial plays as Michael Frayn's Copenhagen - about the ethics of scientists building nuclear weapons - and Joe Penhall's Blue/Orange - about schizophrenia - during Nunn's reign

After two gilded decades at the Royal Shakespeare Company, Nunn felt he was "doing the National a favour" by taking over from Sir Richard Eyre when no suitable replacement for him could be found in 1997.

He has made no secret of the fact that his wife, the actor Imogen Stubbs, was not happy he had taken on "the nightmare" that comes with having to fill 2,500 seats in three different auditoriums every night.

Worn down eventually by the constant sniping, Nunn is believed to have made the decision to bow to the inevitable at the end of last year and since then Sir Christopher has been lunching a long line of likely candidates including Nicholas Hytner, another director with an impressive commercial pedigree.

With no heirs apparent waiting in the wings - another of the many accusations levelled at Nunn was that he acted like a "one-man band" - the race for his replacement is probably the most open in the National's history.

Although his Oscar-nomination for his debut film Billy Elliot has brought Hollywood to his door, Stephen Daldry, the mercurial former director of the Royal Court, now in the final stages of filming his second film, The Hours, is seen by many as the best chance of the reviving the institution's radical spirit.

At 39, and with an impressive track record of combining edgier new writing and canny, yet politically relevant West End hits like An Inspector Calls, he has been playing his cards close to his chest. When asked by the Guardian recently if he would take the job, the normally forthright Daldry demurred.

"Ask me anything but that. It's more than my life's worth to say anything about that," was his reply.

Dream team

A dream team of Daldry and Sam Mendes, the Oscar-winning director of American Beauty, who runs the Donmar Warehouse, has long been mooted, though with both now combining theatre and film, it looks highly unlikely.

A strong head of steam, however, has been building up behind Jude Kelly, the artistic director of West Yorkshire Playhouse, who is believed to have the vocal backing on the National's board from Booker Prize-winning novelist Ben Okri, whose play she will soon stage, and the black academic Lola Young.

As well as her proven track record, Kelly would have the added appeal of being the first ever woman to run the National Theatre.

Whatever he does after his "retirement", Nunn will not be short of a few bob. For his final year at the National he is directing another musical, South Pacific, A Streetcar Named Desire starring Glenn Close and a new trilogy of plays by Tom Stoppard.

All have a huge potential for commercial transfer, which he stands poised to benefit from.

webTitle: Vieira: a season to be forgotten

fields.headline: Vieira: a season to be forgotten
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira has claimed that Arsenal "made a mistake" in selling Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars. And, in the wake of their Champions League defeat last night, he has also admitted that the Arsenal's season is best "forgotten".
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira has claimed that Arsenal "made a mistake" in selling Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars. And, in the wake of their Champions League defeat last night, he has also admitted that the Arsenal's season is best "forgotten".

In an interview with French newspaper Le Parisien, Vieira said: "I feel very disappointed to have gone out to Valencia because I believe we have looked a better team than them.

"But we do need more players in the squad," he went on. "I feel it was a mistake at the club not to keep Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars to their contracts when they went to Barcelona in the summer. We miss them.

"I know it was good business for the club and that Marc was keen to join Barcelona but for me it was a big disappointment to see them go."

Vieira also admitted that even finishing second in the Premiership and winning the FA Cup would only be an "average" season for the Arsenal.

"We have to finish second in the Premiership to secure our place in the Champions League next season," Vieira said. "We also have to win the Cup. That is the minimum to so when you wear the Arsenal shirt.

"But I have to be honest, even if we manage to reach these two objectives, I would qualify our season as average," he added. "In the championship we are 15 or 20 points adrift Manchester United, so for me it's really a season to be forgotten."

Vieira insists he is still committed to Arsenal but his plain speaking on the strength of the squad will make Arsene Wenger wonder if a more expansive buying policy is needed.

Vieira, who is just 24 and the man Wenger wants to one day take over the Arsenal captaincy, said: "I'm under contract until 2004 but I always say that you never know in football. Anything can happen."

webTitle: Global English: A Guardian Weekly debate

fields.headline: Global English: The European Lessons
fields.standfirst: A debate about the role of English to be held on:
fields.trailText: A debate about the role of English.
fields.body:
Europe is one of the world's largest English-speaking regions, yet how much do we know about the language that is its prime lingua franca or the impact English is having on Europe's linguistic diversity and identity.

In 2001, the European Year of Languages, Macmillan Heinemann ELT and the Guardian Weekly will bring together a distinguished panel of experts to explore Europe's lingua franca, its role in the region and the implications for English language teaching in Europe and beyond.

Chaired by Will Hutton Chief Executive of The Industrial Society.

To be held on Wednesday April 18 2001 at the International Association of English Language Teachers annual conference, Brighton Conference Centre, Brighton, UK.

Speakers' biographies

Will Hutton
Will Hutton is one of Britain's leading commentators on European economic affairs, formerly Editor in Chief of the Observer newspaper and author of The State We're In, the influential analysis of British political and economic governance in the 1990s.

Robert Phillipson
Robert Phillipson, is currently Research Professor at the Department of English, Copenhagen Business School.

He is the author of Linguistic Imperialism, (OUP, 1992), and his latest publication, as editor, Rights To Language: Equity, Power And Education, (editor, Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, 2000) highlights his concern with language rights, globalisation and English, and language policy in the European Union.

He has lectured world-wide and is a board member of the Danish Centre for Human Rights. He is British.

Juliane House
Juliane House was educated at the Universities of Heidelberg and Toronto. She is professor of Applied Linguistics and head of the English language programme at the University of Hamburg. Her main research interests are in the areas of contrastive and interlanguage pragmatics, translation theory and intercultural communication and misunderstanding.

She is currently researching the nature of interactions in English as a lingua franca, and the influence English may have on discourse norms in other European languages via translation and multilingual text production.

John Walsh
John Walsh is Editor of Eurolang, the Brussels-based news agency dealing with minority language issues. He studied Celtic languages at University College Dublin before working for six years as a journalist with RTE, the Irish state Broadcaster, and the Irish language television channel, TG4.

He currently carrying out research work at Dublin City University where is undertaking a Ph.D in minority languages and socio-economic development. He speaks Irish, English, Welsh, French and Dutch.

Barbara Seidlhofer
Barbara Seidlhofer is Associate Professor at the English Department of Vienna University. Her principal interest is in applied linguistics for language teacher education, especially the relationship between language description and pedagogic practice.

Her publications include Pronunciation (with C. Dalton, OUP 1994), Principle and Practice in Applied Linguistics (co-edited with G. Cook, OUP 1995), and Language Policy and Language Education in Emerging Nations (co-editor, Ablex 1998). She is currently working on a book on the description and pedagogy of English as a lingua franca.

Jennifer Jenkins
Dr Jennifer Jenkins is co-ordinator of Teacher Education and Applied Linguistics in the English Language Centre, King's College London.

She has carried out extensive research on English pronunciation within an international framework, her latest and most controversial publication being The Phonology Of English As An International Language (OUP, 2000).

Event schedule
9am Arrival: Registration and coffee. Doors are open from 8am for registration
9.30am: Ticket holders will be able to choose to attend 2/3 morning seminars arranged by IATEFL.
14.00: Welcome t/c
14.15: Introduction by Will Hutton
14.30: Presentations:

1. Principles and policies for a multilingual Europe
Robert Phillipson will analyse what determines European language policy, and assess strategies for appropriating English without being victimised by it.

2. English as a lingua franca for Europe
Juliane House will present the case for promoting English as Europe's lingua franca by drawing the distinction between a "language for communication" and a "language for identification".

3. Can minority languages survive?
John Walsh will illustrate the link between language, identity and self-esteem, and the changing definition of Europe's language minorities.

4. Teaching English as a lingua franca for Europe
Barbara Seidlhofer will explore what the latest corpus research - the analysis of vast amounts of electronically stored written and spoken text - tells us about English as a lingua franca and the radical changes curricula and methodology may undergo in the near future.

5. Euro-English as it is spoken
Jennifer Jenkins will consider the emergence of a hybrid European accent and illustrate her "pronunciation core" of English when it is spoken internationally.

16.00: Summary Questions from the floor
16.30: Tea
16.45: Open debate
17.45: Close
18.30: Drinks at the t/c

fields.headline: Agency set to promote UK worldwide
fields.trailText:
8.30am: GCI has won the PR account for the British Tourist Authority's push to promote the UK, reports Julia Day.
10.04.2001: Agencies line up to say 'UK is OK'
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
GCI has won the public relations account for the British Tourist Authority's push to promote the UK as a safe tourist destination in the face of the foot and mouth crisis.

The agency pitched against Hill & Knowlton and Weber Shandwick to spearhead the huge PR campaign.

GCI will co-ordinate a PR campaign to run across 10 countries including the US, Canada, Germany, Australia and New Zealand.

Rhodri Harris, the GCI's director, is leading the agency's team handling the account in London and they will liaise with GCI's offices in each market.

The campaign will aim to send out a message that the UK is safe for holidaymakers to visit.

"We are certainly confident that we can get the message across in the short term to bring tourism back to Britain," said Mr Harris.

He added that the length of the PR contract is still being negotiated.

The appointment of a creative advertising agency to work on selling the UK as a holiday destination will not be made until the foot and mouth crisis abates.

fields.headline: Government launches cyber-crime unit
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The government will today launch a £25m internet policing group devoted to stamping out paedophile gangs and cyber-criminals.
fields.body:
The government will today launch a £25m internet policing group devoted to stamping out paedophile gangs and cyber-criminals.

Law enforcement agencies and members of the IT industry will make up the group, dubbed the national hi-tech crime unit (NHTCU), which will concentrate on trapping members of paedophile gangs, such as the Wonderland Club. A coordinated police effort on the Wonderland case resulted in seven of the group's members being jailed earlier this year for their part in the world's largest paedophile ring.

The NHTCU's 80-strong group of officers will also crack down on people using the internet for fraud and other crimes.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said the group will include experts from the national crime squad, the national criminal intelligence service, HM customs and excise, police forces and the IT industry.

The director general of the National Crime Squad, Bill Hughes, said the group would also be focusing on financial crime on the internet.

"Looking to the future the equation is simple - money is going electronic and where money goes, so will organised crime," he said. "Therefore, as we have learnt from our colleagues in the US, the only way to tackle this type of crime is by using a joined-up approach."

Mr Straw said: "The government is committed to ensuring a safe and secure online environment for internet users in the UK, by tackling hi-tech crime and ensuring our law enforcers have the tools to deal effectively with online crime.

"New technologies bring enormous benefits to the legitimate user, but also offer opportunities for criminals, from those involved in financial fraud to paedophiles. We are determined that the UK will be the best and safest place in the world to conduct and engage in e-commerce, and that our children receive the full protection they deserve online so they can surf the Net in safety," he added.

Civil liberties groups have expressed concerns that increased policing of the internet could compromise people's privacy if the government does not produce stronger legislation to protect personal information held on computers.

Yaman Akdeniz, head of Cyber Rights and Cyber Liberties, said the NHTCU will need to be "open, accountable and transparent" to allay fears that police will spy on citizens online.

He said: "You have to ask what the real problem is that the government is trying to address. The most pessimistic view is that this is the beginning of an Orwellian initiative from the government now that they have such wide powers under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act.

"But it is good that law enforcement agencies are getting organised in the field of cybercrimes. That coordination on a national and international level is important," he added.

fields.headline: Sunday Times journalist may lose sight
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The award-winning foreign correspondent, Marie Colvin, may lose the sight in her left eye, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Doctors fear the award-winning Sunday Times foreign correspondent, Marie Colvin, could lose the sight in her left eye after she was hit by shrapnel.

Ms Colvin was caught in cross-fire in Sri Lanka on Monday while reporting on the conflict between the government and the Tamil Tiger guerillas.

Doctors are performing exploratory surgery to assess the damage to her eye.

Ms Colvin, who was named best foreign correspondent at last month's British Press Awards, has reported from many of the world's toughest troublespots, including Kosovo, Libya and Eritrea.

The Sunday Times is hoping to fly Ms Colvin to the US for surgery in the next few days.

webTitle: £7m Bridget Jones keeps up with blockbuster hits

fields.headline: £7m Bridget Jones keeps up with blockbuster hits
fields.trailText: Bridget Jones's Diary, the most hyped and eagerly anticipated British film for years, broke all cinema box office records for a domestic film on its opening weekend
fields.body:
The world is full of thirtysomething single women pining for love, chocolate and a cheap and painless cure for cellulite. Bridget Jones had a word for them - competition. This weekend there were nearly half a million fewer on the singles scene: they were flocking to see their heroine make her big screen debut.

And so it came to pass that Bridget Jones's Diary, the most hyped and eagerly anticipated British film for years, broke all cinema box office records for a domestic film on its opening weekend. Good reviews, the hilarious pony club English accent of the American star, Renée Zellweger, and a massive marketing push helped push it close to the £7m mark.

Even if you subtract the takings from preview screenings (included in the £7m) - a nifty piece of cosmetic surgery used to make movies seem more successful than they really are - the film version of Helen Fielding's cult paean to the consoling qualities of cigarettes and Chardonnay did v.v.g. Its three day box office of £5.72m easily surpassed the first three days' takings of Notting Hill, and Four Weddings and a Funeral, both penned by Fielding's ex, Richard Curtis.

Such a performance puts it in the same league as Titanic, Men in Black, and Independence Day, an unheard of achievement for what industry insiders call a "chick flick". Although its £7.8m gross only managed to get it to number three in the American chart behind Spy Kids, and Morgan Freeman's Along Came the Spider, its takings per screen bettered both.

Robert Mitchell, of Screen International magazine, said it was another triumph for the London production firm Working Title, run by Eric Fellner and Tim Bevan, who, he said, could "teach the Americans a thing or two about making mainstream hits".

According to the entertainment site People News about 60% of the audiences were said to be women and rather frighteningly, were said to have been flocking to the cinemas in packs. Furthermore, the film's distributors said that the audiences were made up of a large age sweep, ranging from 18 to early 50s.

The film's distributors, Miramax, who initially decided to launch the film on only 1,600 screens (half the number of some of the big American blockbusters) have added another 400 cinemas to their distribution list in the wake of the film's phenomenal success.

 Guardian review by Peter Bradshaw
 Observer review by Philip French

fields.headline: Will LA vote Latino?
fields.standfirst: The emergence of Antonio Villaraigosa as the leading candidate in the Los Angeles mayoral elections has put the spotlight on the agendas of the city's ethnic groups, writes Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: The emergence of Antonio Villaraigosa as the leading candidate in the Los Angeles mayoral elections has put the spotlight on the agendas of the city's ethnic groups, writes Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
Union Station in downtown Los Angeles is one of the most beautiful buildings in the United States and certainly one of the world's most stunning railway stations. Built in 1939, it has deservedly appeared in countless films since. So what better place to have a party to celebrate the political arrival of the man who could be the first Latino mayor since 1872 when the city had 5,000 inhabitants and no one had invented rollerblading?

This was where Antonio Villaraigosa chose to throw his celebration party, complete with Latin band and Mexican and Korean snacks, as the votes came in last Tuesday in the first round of voting for the LA mayoralty. Old political hands at the event said they had not seen anything like it for decades.

Villaraigosa took 30% of the vote, 5% ahead of the city attorney, James Hahn, whom he will now face in a run-off on June 5 as none of the candidates took more than half the votes polled. This week the two men, both Democrats on the liberal wing of the party, have been actively courting all those undecided voters.

What makes this particular election so important is what it will tell us about the sometimes delicate relations between the different ethnic communities in a city often described as the most diverse on earth. The mayoral race has long been seen as a social barometer. Back in 1969 the white incumbent Sam Yorty was opposed by a black former police officer and city councillor called Tom Bradley.

Yorty ran campaign ads with pictures of Bradley and the slogan "Will your city be safe with this man?", using the newspapers in the traditionally conservative San Fernando Valley to press home his message. He even hinted that, with Bradley as mayor, the city could face another Watts riot and - absurdly - that the former police lieutenant had links with the Black Panthers. Yorty won.

Four years later, Bradley fought again and this time the voters were not scared off, electing him as the first black mayor of the city, so popular that he was re-elected and re-elected and re-elected. One of the terminals at LA airport is now named after him.

This time the focus is different. The chants as Villaraigosa arrived with Governor Gray Davis at the Union Station party were "si, se puede" (yes, we can), the old slogan of the United Farm Workers Union and one that was adopted by the janitors in LA during their recent strike. It has become a symbolic chant for Latino empowerment.

James Hahn is white but much of his support has come from the African-American community. His father was a much loved local politician who had a particular rapport with the black community and Hahn the Younger is benefitting from the name. Both of the final two candidates have been at pains to say that they want to represent the whole city but Villaraigosa is seen very much as the Latino candidate, a working-class boy who made good, paid his dues as a union organiser and civil rights activist and has now been adopted by liberal LA as the man to bring a new deal to the city.

Not everyone in LA is happy at the growing power of Latinos over the last decade and they could choose Hahn purely for this reason. Equally, some black politcians are dismayed at the way that the Latino vote has now become the one to court as the Latinos become the largest minority in California. They, too, may back Hahn for that reason.

To confuse matters further, the Morongo Indians, who run one of the state's largest casinos, threw nearly $250,000 into campaign ads against Villaraigosa, citing his plea for clemency on behalf of a drug trafficker pardoned in Bill Clinton's final amnesty; the suggestion being that Villaraigosa is soft on crime and the sub-text being that he is opposed to the expansion of gambling in the state.

What happens over the next few weeks of campaigning, as each side takes their message to the various constituencies - Korean and Vietnamese, Jewish andRoman Catholic, liberal and conservative, suburban and inner city - will determine the result on June 5. And Villaraigosa's supporters are counting on an even better party and anticipating that their man's train will be the one that arrives at the platform.

fields.headline: Red carpet rolled out for foreign travel chiefs
fields.standfirst:
Misty glen is change from TV shots of smoking pyres
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Britain yesterday began its campaign to rebuild a foreign tourist market dented by the foot and mouth crisis. Over the next few days, representatives from the UK's top 10 overseas markets will be wooed with the message that Britain is open.
fields.body:
The mist, this time, was a welcome sight - not a dense screen of smoke from funeral pyres, but the romantic drape of a rainy spring in the Highlands.

It was finally an image of Britain to entice not deter foreign tourists. And that, of course, was the point.

As the peak period of summer travel looms, Britain yesterday began its campaign to rebuild a foreign tourist market dented by the foot and mouth crisis. Over the next few days - on private jets, chartered boats and air-conditioned coaches - representatives from the UK's top 10 overseas markets will be wooed with the message that Britain is open. Winning them over is the first step in preventing the collapse of an industry worth seven times more to the economy than farming.

The campaign began yesterday on the shores of Loch Ness as the first group of tourist chiefs sailed down the loch to the ruins of Urquhart castle.

The image was classically Scottish, but it had other, more contemporary, pictures with which to contend. News footage of Britain's burning pyres, soldiers burying corpses, and JCBs gathering carcasses have been beamed around the world for months now.

American viewers, in particular, have been shocked by what they have watched. "We are getting an image of thousands of animals being slaughtered on our screens, and of men in flak jackets, like military commandos, with huge machines burying carcasses," said Richard Copland, president of the American Society of Travel Agents.

The British tourism authority estimates that overseas visitors contribute £13bn to the UK economy each year. Cancellations due to foot and mouth are expected to cost £2.5bn this year.

Already, thousands of Americans have cancelled their trips. Brian Stack, vice chairman of the US Tour Operators Association, estimated that 100,000 of the 4m Americans who would normally visit the UK would cancel their holidays this year - many through a misconception.

"Their attention span is not huge, and all they know is there's a problem: they see lines of burning animals on the TV, and are simply afraid to come," said Mr Stack.

Like their American counterparts, many Japanese have cancelled their UK trips because they have confused foot and mouth with BSE. They mistakenly believe they can become infected with a brain wasting condition by eating meat from animals infected by foot and mouth.

Koji Shinmachi, managing director of the Japan Association of Travel Agents, estimated that at least 20% of the 600,000 Japanese who visited Britain every year would cancel because of foot and mouth.

"Some in Japan are very concerned about this, because they think that foot and mouth is the same as mad cow disease," said Mr Shinmachi.

The campaign to win back overseas visitors will be difficult, but one in four jobs created in the UK in the past 10 years is in tourism and related fields, and no expense has been spared in courting the delegates. From the shores of Drumnadrochit to the moors of Dartmoor their business will be solicited by everyone from hotel keepers to Prince Philip and Tony Blair.

"At the end of this trip these people will, in effect, become tourism ambassadors for Britain," said Jeff Hamblin, chief executive of the British tourist authority.

fields.trailText: Reebok's global marketing chief, Angel Martinez, has stepped down after 21 years, citing family reasons for his departure.
fields.body:
Reebok's global marketing chief, Angel Martinez, has stepped down after 21 years, citing family reasons for his departure.

Lucozade Energy is to be temporarily rebranded Larazade next month to promote the summer release if the Tomb Raider film.

IPC Media has scrapped one of its longest running weekly titles, Woman's Realm, and is launching a women's weekly called Your Life.

Utility company npower will launch an insurance service this month, the first product in its financial services package.

Homeless charity Crisis is set to lose its deputy chief executive marketer, Neil Churchill, to Age Concern.

Dell Computer Corp has awarded its £60m global branding account to DDB Worldwide , ending the company's three-year relationship with BBDO Worldwide.

Coltas has been appointed handle a £5m press campaign for the launch of Tiny Computers' Takami digital entertainment system.

Premier International Foods is poised to review the media accounts for all its brands, including Typhoo Tea, Cadbury's Highlights and Toppers, and HP Beans.

Time Magazine has appointed Carat International Global Media's account director, James Griffiths, as the first marketing director of its European edition.

webTitle: Labour tax rises increase poverty gap

fields.headline: Labour tax rises increase poverty gap
fields.trailText: Higher taxes on cigarettes and alcohol have increased the gap in spending power between rich and poor households since Labour came to power, government figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Higher taxes on cigarettes and alcohol have increased the gap in spending power between rich and poor households since Labour came to power, government figures revealed yesterday.

Despite the chancellor's initiatives to boost the incomes of the poorest households, inequality in post-tax income has risen to its highest level for 10 years, according to the office for national statistics.

The main reason appears to be changes to the indirect tax regime. The ONS figures show that inequality in disposable income - what people have to spend after direct taxes - has risen only slightly.

Indirect taxes such as excise duties and VAT hit the wallets of poorer households harder because they spend more of their income. While VAT rates have remained unchanged, excise duty on petrol, alcohol and cigarettes has risen sharply under Labour.

After falling for the first half of the 1990s, inequality in post-tax income started to rise in 1995, according to the ONS figures. It flattened out briefly then began rising again in 1997, reaching its highest level since 1990 last year.

The changes over the past three years are small by comparison with the rapid rise in inequality before and after tax which Britain experienced in the 1980s.

Wage inequality rose dramatically between 1979 and 1989. It fell slightly under John Major's government and has been largely stable since the mid 1990s.

Measures of income inequality after taxes are taken into account also rose steeply in the 1980s, particularly in the last half of the decade, when the then chancellor, Nigel Lawson, slashed the tax bills of top earners.

After-tax inequality fell under the Major government then resumed a rising trend under Labour.

fields.headline: Earnings inequality widens under Labour
fields.trailText: The income gap between rich and poor is continuing to widen under Labour and last year outstripped even the highest inequality mark under the Conservatives, according to government figures.
fields.body:
The income gap between rich and poor is continuing to widen under Labour and last year outstripped even the highest inequality mark under the Conservatives, according to government figures.

Data from the office for national statistics, published yesterday, shows that the standard measure of inequality increased in 1999/2000 beyond its previous high water mark under John Major's administration in 1991.

In a further blow to the government's claims to be tackling poverty, the figures, from the annual Family Expenditure survey, also reveal that the poorest households are paying a higher proportion of income in tax than the richest.

The government last night faced strong criticism from the Liberal Democrats, who accused ministers of hitting the poor hardest by raising indirect taxes rather than direct taxation.

Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman Ed Davey said: "By copying Conservative policies of raising indirect taxes whilst cutting fair taxes like income tax, Labour have hit society's poorest.

"Liberal Democrats recognise that schools, hospitals and police need more investment, but we believe that the burden should be paid for in fair taxation."

Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo claimed that the statistics showed poorer people were taking the brunt of Labour "stealth taxes".

"These figures confirm that Gordon Brown has hit the poorest hardest," said Mr Portillo.

"Labour chancellors used to boast of taxing the rich, but Gordon Brown has increased the taxes that everyone has to pay. His stealth taxes on petrol, mortgages, marriage and cigarettes have hit the least well off.

"Labour's stealth taxes mean that the least well off are seeing the largest share of their income being taken by the taxman.

"Conservatives disagree with Labour's view that every pound spent by the government is spent wisely and morally, while the same pound spent by an individual is spent selfishly and immorally.

"We have a positive alternative for a more prosperous society, that involves cutting taxes and leaving people with more of their own money, allowing them to be more independent and enjoy more self-esteem."

Tobacco duty is cited by the office for national statistics as one of the indirect taxes which disproportionately hits those on lowest incomes. It represents 4.9% of disposable income of the poorest fifth of households, and just 0.5% for the top fifth.

According to the office's figures, the Gini coefficient - a complicated mathematical formula used to measure inequality - shows that the gap in incomes after tax between rich and poor has increased to 40, on a scale where zero represents universal equality of income.

In 1998/9, that figure was 39 - itself a new peak since 1991 - and 38 in 1997/98, Labour's first year in office.

The office says one reason for the trend is the growth in the importance of income from self-employment, which is much more unequal than earnings among employees.

The statistics also show that somebody in the poorest fifth of households typically pays 41.4% of their overall income in tax compared with 36.5% for the richest fifth.

In a trend which exposes the government further to Tory and Liberal Democrat accusations of relying on stealth taxes rather than direct taxation, the proportion of income paid in tax has risen for the bottom 80% of households since 1997/8 and fallen for the richest fifth of households.

The share of all UK household income received by the poor has steadily decreased since 1981 - when data was first gathered on the current basis, with a fresh fall under Labour after a seven year plateau, the figures show.

The poorest fifth of households had 6% of national income after tax, while the share held by the top fifth has risen under Labour from 44% to 45%.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Ominous events continue to plague the Times. The Microwave Mystery - you will recall the vanishing fuses and plugs - is mutating into something more sinister.
fields.body:
 Ominous events continue to plague the Times. The Microwave Mystery - you will recall the vanishing fuses and plugs - is mutating into something more sinister. The two original suspects - both since cleared of all charges - are targeted, apparently deliberately. Countryside editor Val Elliot is repeatedly rung at 2am by someone playing the Godfather theme down the phone. Although she has yet to find an equine presence in her bed (so far as we know), a worrying twist saw her "fall" into a canal. We cannot check whether this was in Wales, where she has a cottage, or in London since, as she told her news desk, her mobile was ruined in the plunge.

Meanwhile, the man falsely accused of planting a snipped-off plug in Val's drawers is himself a victim. The wheelie bin outside political writer Andrew Pierce's elegant east London home has vanished at the hands of person or persons unknown. These are deep waters - deeper, certainly, than the canal - and my colleague Marina Hyde wishes to discuss the escalating crisis with tank-top-wearing managing editor George Brock asap.

 Signs that Millbank has moved to a full war footing, with news that the aptly named Jackie Stasi has instituted a clear-desk policy. The local government unit reports the loss of several important documents already. There is no word yet on whether New Labour staffers will be allowed to eat at their clear desks this time round. Last time, of course, they were not - a privation that led directly to the legendary soup quote fiasco, when Oofy Wegg-Prosser failed to make his "no thank you" to our offer of a bowl of chicken soup retroactively off the record.  Speaking of Oofers, his splendid political website (Guardian Unlimited Politics) interviews Boris the Jackal Johnson, who seems unclear if he will yield the Spectator editorship after the election. "Well, I'm not even going to get into that. I'm not interested in a successor," says the soon to be MP for Henley, "and neither are you." Questioned over when he will step down, he replies, "I don't know", and although he offers a simple "yes" when June 8 is put to him, this sounds more like a diversionary tactic than an honest answer. What a slippery fish he is. The decision on whether a Diary candidate will also contest Henley will be taken very soon.

 One already confirmed comedy candidate is Neil Hamilton, who says he'll stand against my squash partner Keith Vaz in Leicester East. Good for Neil. Since Neil, who owes about £3m from his failed libel case against Mohamed Al Fayed, routinely claims not to have the price of a cup of cha, perhaps he'd let us know who is putting up the deposit. And - assuming this is one of those chumpin' arses like top pipe smoker Lord Harris of High Cross and Taki-George, who bankrolled the case - why the cash isn't being directed towards Neil's creditors?

 On the US debut of The Weakest Link, Richard Littlejohn has words for Anne Robinson. The Sun writer doesn't rate her and loathes a show he describes as a "one-trick pony". While Anne has become such a star, Richard's TV career - which began with Michael Winner delighting the audience by calling him "an arsehole" during his LWT debut - has gone downhill. Now he seems to have no network presence at all. What a relief, then, that he can still think about the medium not only profoundly but without the faintest trace of bitterness.

 Can nothing be done for Patsy Prescott? News that he won't be allowed to berate the US government over Kyoto, as he boasted in advance, confirms that he has all the authority of a Maff accounts clerk. So wouldn't it be fairer on the poor sap to settle him down in a Whitehall office with some building bricks and a lovely jigsaw, and leave him be until June 8?

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Digital TV must cast off its shell suit

fields.headline: Digital TV must cast off its shell suit and try to be posh
fields.standfirst:
Hundreds of channels, but still very little for the discerning viewer

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Hundreds of channels, but still very little for the discerning viewer. By Polly Toynbee.
fields.body:
Digital television gets another kickstart this week with the government announcing a pilot to test how a universal switch-over could work. A thousand households will get free digital boxes with internet access. Every viewing moment will be monitored to find out what people watch, whether they buy extra paid-for channels, how much they use the internet and email, whether they shop on the box and if they like what they see.

The government has a high-flown line about keeping Britain in the vanguard of the communications revolution (which it is), and the importance of plugging every household into the internet (why not?). But the urgent reason is the fat plum of up to £20bn that waits to be plucked by whichever government is in power when the old analogue system is turned off and sold. The earliest date officially mooted is 2006. But sooner would be better if people can be urged or paid to switch, so that this money cascades into Labour-controlled coffers. Can it be done?

So far a quarter of households have gone digital. Media analysts expect 65% will go digital by 2006. But that still leaves 35% who say they won't. They don't want more channels, they don't understand interactive or email and they don't want to shop on television. Half of those aged over 49 are in this refusenik group. How can they be pushed? Eventually many of the poor and the obstinate will be given free digital equipment, a price worth paying given the handsome reward the government will reap, but naturally the government hopes to seduce as many as possible to switch over of their own accord.

The trouble is that digital boxes and dishes have a downmarket, shell-suit image. Young, brash, vulgar, sports-pub, Sun-reading, Murdoch-tainted, digital TV just does not have class. Those in the burgeoning middle classes who are not sports fans have too little reason to switch. Their children may demand it but otherwise, says Mathew Horsman, a media analyst, "My granny in Bournemouth just won't." They don't want to pay and they are not yet enticed by the free channels, despite the excellence of some such as BBC News 24. (Digital sellers deliberately avoid promoting the option to buy only free channels.) Unfortunately it is the plethora of awful free channels that gives digital its low reputation - those timeless zones of wall-to-wall cookery or quizzes from the 1970s drifting through the digital universe like space litter: try Breeze Men and Motors or Granada Plus for a taste of the eye-achingly terrible.

This is where hopes are now pinned on the BBC. Can it change the image of digital with high-quality channels to tempt the refuseniks? It has put in a bid to Chris Smith to launch four new free services - two daytime children's channels, one for the very young, one for older children, BBC3 for young people and BBC4 for arts, ideas and culture. BBC4 is the crucial channel. Its prospectus promises it will be "the home of culture, the arts, ideas and serious debate", with live performances (the whole of the Proms, for example), world cinema, "thought-provoking documentaries" and "in-depth debate around the key issues of the day", exploring "the thinkers, performers and writers driving today's cultural society".

But do they mean it? Will it be allowed to have a small audience? Will it escape the curse of having to make everything difficult "accessible"? It will test whether the BBC still has enough nerve to declare its own standards and stick to them. BBC1 and 2 are almost entirely populist and ratings-chasing now. That doesn't mean many of its programmes aren't very good, but they are only allowed to exist if they aim to pull off the magic trick of being both good and widely popular. Some subjects simply can't be both. The original promise of the digital future was that it could provide niche channels for every taste and enthusiasm. So far in a sea of cheap and cheerless channels, bar a few gems, that hasn't happened.

BBC4 needs the cultural weight to capture the same kind of devoted adherence as Radio 3 and 4: just consider how these very small radio listenerships fill the air and letters pages with protest at any minor change to the schedules. BBC4 needs to raise the tone and reputation of digital television to such a high-brow pitch that the sort of people who like to boast smugly "we never watch the box" start boasting loudly about last night's viewing. Posh TV is what will drive the digital future. In a world where one in three young people are graduates, the future is up-market.

But BBC3 is another story: it looks like a turkey before it even gets off the page. The word is that Chris Smith may refuse it and he would be right. Its prospectus threatens: "The service would be targeted at the younger viewer and would reflect the lifestyles and attitudes at the young heart of today's multicultural UK." It promises "gripping entertainment, new comedy and compelling drama". But what for? If there is money to spare for "gripping drama" then spend it on BBC1 and 2. A bit more cultural bravery would have saved those channels from recent disasters such as the insipid Love in a Cold Climate, Adrian Mole, Take a Girl Like You - all supposedly popular and "safe" ideas that deserved to bomb. There is no shortage of stuff for the young. "Young", like "accessible", is mainly code for dumb, (to the rage of the young who are not dumb). Saga TV is a better bet for getting older refuseniks to switch. Or a specialist channel for enthusiasms and peculiarities uncatered for elsewhere.

However, the BBC children's channels will convert many households: half of those with children have already switched, and high-quality BBC children's programmes with no advertising or cartoons will be a winner. The part-Murdoch-owned Nickelodeon children's channel has put in a strong objection, on the usual Murdoch grounds that the BBC should never offer popular services competing with commercial television. Most observers think Smith will approve these channels, but he hesitates interminably. The plans have been out to consultation, but still he sits on them. There will probably be no decision before the election (the government may not wish to upset Murdoch just now). If Smith is moved after the election, a new arts minister might want to make their own decision, taking yet longer. It then has to go to Europe for approval as a state-aided enterprise, and that takes another three months. So the hope of launching new channels with a blaze of publicity in the autumn has died.

This will be a sharp test for the BBC and Greg Dyke. So far his reign has been characterised by ratings wars, pressure to turn science and history into entertainment, the serious squeezed out in favour of frivolity wherever there is a choice, the news more strident and less analytical. Now BBC4 has to dare to be what it promises - a new Olympian benchmark.

webTitle: Mowlam steps up war against narco-guerrillas

fields.headline: Mowlam steps up war against narco-guerrillas
fields.trailText: Two British generals and the former head of security at the Northern Ireland Office have been sent to help train Colombian government forces.
fields.byline: Owen Bowcott, and Martin Hodgson  in Bogota
fields.body:
Two British generals and the former head of security at the Northern Ireland Office have been sent to help train Colombian government forces in the past six months as Britain becomes increasingly involved in combating drugs trafficking and bolstering Colombia's precarious peace process.

Convinced of the need to commit more resources to resolving the civil war which has been raging for the past 37 years, the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, has travelled to Bogota three times since last June. She is trying to promote alternative crops to the coca bushes from which cocaine is refined.

The former Northern Ireland Secretary, who is now in charge of the government's drugs programme, has recently visited the cocaine-producing state of Putumayo on the lawless Ecuadorian border. After the US, Britain is the biggest investor in Colombia.

Three-quarters of the cocaine and much of the heroin smuggled into Europe comes from Colombia. The leftwing rebels and militias supporting the government both fund their campaigns by charging drugs cartels "war-taxes" for protecting narcotics plantations.

As well as advising the Colombian army, Britain has made £100,000 available to the UN drug control programme to monitor the effects of chemical defoliant sprayed on coca plants. Fields of plantain, cassava and maize have been inadvertently destroyed by herbicides.

The US is spending $1.3bn (£900m) to support Plan Colombia, a strategy which the President Andres Pastrana believes will devastate the drugs trade and promote peace.

President Bill Clinton approved the expenditure last year, despite concern about the Colombian army's human rights record and warnings that the aid - which, among other things, will pay for 60 combat helicopters - will add to the violence.

Britain too believes that the Colombian army needs help, chiefly advice on preventing collusion between soldiers and rightwing paramilitaries.

Ms Mowlam revealed the extent of British involvement in Colombia last week. General Sir Roger Wheeler, former chief of the general staff of the British army, General Sir Michael Rose, former UN commander in Bosnia, and the former head of security in Northern Ireland John Steele, have been sent out since last November.

"They talked to the [Colombian] police and army about what they can do to make them more effective," Ms Mowlam said. "You couldn't tackle drugs without offering assistance with the peace talks and in [reducing] violence. You have to strengthen the military and police, but also teach them human rights. You are not going to get progress unless you have a military that can take on the [rebels] and the paramilitaries."

Ms Mowlam has "some problems" with US crop-spraying. Dousing smallholders' fields in chemicals could alienate farmers, she warned. Herbicides should be used to destroy only large coca-growing operations; campesinos - peasant farmers - should be encouraged to grow different crops.

Last June the British ambassador, Jeremy Thorp, flew to an enclave controlled by the Revolutionary Armed forces of Colombia (Farc) to discuss human rights and alternatives to drug production. The embassy has been working with a group called Women Waging Peace to organise a visit by women involved in the Northern Irish peace talks.

While the US is channelling aid to the Colombian army, the EU, which has pledged $100m (£70m), is directing its efforts towards civilian reforms.

Interviewed by the Guardian, Ms Mowlam agreed that the west had to reduce the demand for illegal drugs, but declined to contemplate a future of either legalisation or decriminalisation."We are trying to reduce demand; we are beginning to make progress," she insisted.

Amnesty International has opposed Plan Colombia, saying there is "conclusive evidence that paramilitary groups continue to operate with tacit or active support of the Colombian armed forces".

It added: "Evidence has emerged that Colombian army personnel, trained by US special forces, have been implicated by action or omission in serious human rights violations, including the massacre of civilians."

webTitle: A farmer's diary during foot and mouth

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Our diarist has a plan to help devastated farmers re-stock - but only if her flock survives

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Our diarist has a plan to help devastated farmers re-stock - but only if her flock survives.
fields.body:
The Independent on Sunday receives the prize for this week's most insensitive front page - a photograph of part of Hadrian's Wall, Crag Lough. Unfortunately the paper had not bothered to find out that the animals from this part of the wall were destroyed over Easter.

The wall remains off limits to the public in a desperate effort to save the remaining livestock. And anger is growing - although the weekend's gruesome work was carried out speedily, the majority of the livestock would still be there if the action had been faster earlier. And without the sheep grazing around the ancient stones, the landscape will quickly begin to look different, once the spring grass and weeds start to grow and take hold.

Some of our Blackface flock came from one of the farms culled at the weekend. Years of work and selective breeding have gone into the Sewingshields' Scottish Blackface flock and other well-known flocks along the wall. All gone now.

Peter and I have hatched a tentative plan, but we know we may never be able to carry it through. If our flock is lucky enough to survive then we might be able to offer Angus at Sewingshields the chance of taking back a dozen Blackie ewes. It's not a lot, and the lambs we buy from him almost every year are not quite as good as the ones he has lost, but it might offer him a start with the re-stocking.

I have thought this idea over for a few weeks now: that the farmers who survive this epidemic should be encouraged to help with the re-stocking of empty farms by releasing some of their healthy stock to the affected farmers. But I do not know when this would be possible, owing to movement restrictions and the time limit on re-stocking, or how the financial side would be arranged. However, it must be in the industry's best interests for us to work together on the rebuilding of whatever is left.

We are all confused over vaccination. Is the science any different now to what it was at the start? I understand the concerns about turning cattle out of the shed and on to the summer pastures. We will have to turn ours out at some point in May. But there are issues which I am uneasy about. Is the potential change in vaccination policy for cattle an admission that the slaughter policy hasn't worked because it was not carried out quickly enough? And is it going fast enough now?

How will vaccination stop the disease spreading when rogue cases can suddenly pop up miles from an already infected area? And what about the issue of vaccinated animals continuing to shed the virus? What will be the effect on the UK's whole livestock industry which, apart from any meat products, exports genetically superior semen and other high value goods? Will the farmers in Cumbria and Devon be sidelined in a second-tier marketing system because their cows are vaccinated? Will this affect all animal movements in these areas for a further 12 months, and will re-vaccinating be necessary after six months?

And what about the national sheep flock? I am led to believe that the possible vaccination strategy is just for cattle. fields.bodyText: The Independent on Sunday receives the prize for this week's most insensitive front page - a photograph of part of Hadrian's Wall, Crag Lough. Unfortunately the paper had not bothered to find out that the animals from this part of the wall were destroyed over Easter. The wall remains off limits to the public in a desperate effort to save the remaining livestock. And anger is growing - although the weekend's gruesome work was carried out speedily, the majority of the livestock would still be there if the action had been faster earlier. And without the sheep grazing around the ancient stones, the landscape will quickly begin to look different, once the spring grass and weeds start to grow and take hold. Some of our Blackface flock came from one of the farms culled at the weekend. Years of work and selective breeding have gone into the Sewingshields' Scottish Blackface flock and other well-known flocks along the wall. All gone now. Peter and I have hatched a tentative plan, but we know we may never be able to carry it through. If our flock is lucky enough to survive then we might be able to offer Angus at Sewingshields the chance of taking back a dozen Blackie ewes. It's not a lot, and the lambs we buy from him almost every year are not quite as good as the ones he has lost, but it might offer him a start with the re-stocking. I have thought this idea over for a few weeks now: that the farmers who survive this epidemic should be encouraged to help with the re-stocking of empty farms by releasing some of their healthy stock to the affected farmers. But I do not know when this would be possible, owing to movement restrictions and the time limit on re-stocking, or how the financial side would be arranged. However, it must be in the industry's best interests for us to work together on the rebuilding of whatever is left. We are all confused over vaccination. Is the science any different now to what it was at the start? I understand the concerns about turning cattle out of the shed and on to the summer pastures. webTitle: Jabs decision favoured three weeks ago but delayed to win debate

fields.headline: Jabs decision favoured three weeks ago but delayed to win debate
fields.standfirst:
Time factor: change of tack inevitable as feed for cattle runs out
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government is locked in a race against time over vaccination as farmers, running out of cattle feed, start putting cows into the fields, potentially doubling the risk of foot and mouth spiralling.
fields.body:
The government is locked in a race against time over vaccination as farmers, running out of cattle feed, start putting cows into the fields, potentially doubling the risk of foot and mouth spiralling.

Throughout the crisis vaccination has been at the centre of a shifting debate within the government and among veterinary surgeons. The first sign of a shift in the no-vaccination policy came when Jim Scudamore, the government chief vet, disappeared from public view "to take more hands on control of the epidemic". His role of expert adviser to the politicians was taken by the chief scientist, David King, and the government's views on vaccination began to alter.

Professor King was frank on Monday about the time pressures. "A decision about vaccination is imminent for the simple reason that cattle will soon be let out to pasture. The decision needs to be made very soon as some cattle have already been let out."

He denied, however, talk of a u-turn, saying: "We have been considering the policy from the very beginning and left it to this point so we can evaluate up to the last moment."

Tony Blair also knows that the government does not have the resources to meet its target of animals slaughtered within 24 hours of detection of the illness. In all the scientific models a 24-hour policy is regarded as essential to slowing the epidemic. A vaccination policy in Cumbria would ease the pressure on the slaughter.

At the same time, Mr Blair needs incontrovertible signs that the disease is coming under control before he triggers a June 7 general election in a month's time. Yesterday he said he would not impose a vaccination policy against the wishes of farmers. There have also been doubts about the legality of an enforced jabs programme, even if sanctioned by the EU.

But, for three weeks or more, the prime minister has been convinced of the inevitability of a limited vaccination programme. Behind the scenes he has been preparing a strategy to persuade farmers' leaders to change their minds. His aides, though, are increasingly sceptical about whether the NFU is representing the majority of farmers' views; there has been no meeting of the NFU council for weeks, and more than 50,000 farmers are not even in the union.

A survey by the Penrith and Borders Tory MP, David Maclean, last week showed that 80% of 240 local farmers backed a one-off jab. Michael Hart, chairman of the Small and Family Farms Alliance, yesterday called on Mr Blair to ignore the NFU.

Patrick Holden, the director of the Soil Association, was more blunt, claiming three scientists and two or three farmers' leaders had got Mr Blair in an arm lock.

Yet the NFU is genuinely sceptical, retaining its faith in the scientists who claim the cull is slowly working. The number of new cases has fallen to about 20 a day.

The government had failed to keep up with the policy of killing infected animals within 24 hours and those nearby within 48 hours. But the biggest problem was finding disposal sites; despite increasing numbers of vets and more than 1,600 soldiers involved, the problem of unburied carcasses continued to grow.

In a fresh attempt to stall vaccination the NFU has now put 40 questions on vaccination to the government, covering the scientific and economic wisdom of the policy.

Financial self-interest lies at the heart of these questions. Farmers fear that vaccination would mean the loss of Britain's disease-free status, barring, for at least 12 months, exports worth £1.3bn a year. But supporters of vaccination argue that these markets are lost anyway, as consumer confidence has evaporated.

Cumbrian farmers fear the public will not buy meat and pasteurised milk from vaccinated stock, and that a two-tier market will develop for milk from vaccinated and non-vaccinated animals. The NFU wants compensation for any farmer who loses markets through vaccination. But the Treasury, fearing another open ended commitment, will not make this concession.

Mr Blair is now running out of options. It could take 10 to 14 days to inoculate all animals affected in north Cumbria, and all cattle within 3km of infected farms would need jabs.

Yesterday Martin Howarth, the policy director of the NFU, said: "We are still not satisfied that we have all the facts to make an informed decision."

webTitle: Farmers sinking in despair grab the latest lifebelt

fields.headline: Farmers sinking in despair grab the latest lifebelt
fields.standfirst:
With 'backs against a barn wall' some accept policy
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Miles of empty fields line the proposed vaccination zone in north Cumbria. The sheep are dead and the cattle are locked in barns. Farmers say the number of new foot and mouth cases is only decreasing there, simply because there are hardly any animals left. Epidemiologists predict that 85% of north Cumbria's livestock will be wiped out in the cull.
fields.body:
Miles of empty fields line the proposed vaccination zone in north Cumbria. The sheep are dead and the cattle are locked in barns. Farmers say the number of new foot and mouth cases is only decreasing there, simply because there are hardly any animals left. Epidemiologists predict that 85% of north Cumbria's livestock will be wiped out in the cull.

Plans to vaccinate come at a time when farmers say they have their "backs to the barn wall". They risk dented sales of vaccinated beef and milk, or seeing every animal culled.

Last night, Cumbrian farmers were divided on vaccination. Cattle were locked in barns, costing around £1,000 a week of uninfected Scottish silage and hay feed, when cattle would normally be outside grazing free at this time of year.

The government's chief scientific advisor, David King, said vaccination would protect cattle due to be turned out of barns this week and increase the number of animals left in Cumbria. But local farmers call it the "experiment", saying Cumbria is "guinea pig land".

Local NFU leaders said half the farmers were for vaccination and half were against. Pedigree cattle specialists were largely anti-vaccination and those most in favour wanted a promise of government compensation if sales were affected in the future.

Peter Vasey, 54, a breeder of pedigree Charolais cattle, had spent the last two months on his farm with his wife, scared if he left he would bring back the disease and infect his 120 cattle. He said his experience contradicted Prof King's reasoning for vaccination: that cattle ran twice the risk if allowed on to fields.

Mr Vasey farms in an infected zone. A neighbour has foot and mouth and in a field adjacent to Mr Vasey's property sheep have been slaughtered and carcasses left on the ground for 10 days.

Yet Mr Vasey's pedigree breeding cattle have been out in fields since winter and have not contracted the disease. "I do not believe it when they say cattle outside are at more risk from foot and mouth," he said.

"I am very much against vaccination. It is going to make foot and mouth endemic here. We are never going to get rid of the disease. If my cattle were vaccinated, the only option I would have would be slaughter because I would have no way of selling them."

Mr Vasey's breeding bulls would sell for around £6,000. Customers have told him they will not buy vaccinated stock.

Harold Armstrong, a dairy farmer from Bromfield, was one of the many who yesterday changed his mind to take a positive attitude to vaccination. He has 400 dairy cows in an infected zone.

There have been three outbreaks on nearby farms in the last two days - the nearest was two miles away. He has already voluntarily surrendered his healthy sheep to the precautionary cull.

"I have come round to thinking it is maybe our only option. But we must have promises about the sale of the milk and meat. My milk goes to make powder for export. We are already having problems getting it out of the country.

"I wouldn't like to think vaccination would stop my neighbours restocking. And we want guarantees that vaccinated cattle are tested and don't all have to be slaughtered in a year."

In the north Lake District, Will Cockbain, a pedigree sheep and beef farmer and deputy county chairman of the NFU, suggested farmers had been left to form opinions on vaccination without information.

"People haven't been aware of all the facts until now. There is a lot of scepticism, but vaccination is a step in the right direction. If the facts are made available, I think the majority of farmers would go with it."

Farmers agreed on one thing: the desperation that shapes their attitude to any new policy at this stage. As one said: "If you are on a sinking ship and some- one throws you a life jacket, you are going to put it on."

webTitle: Blair fails to get NFU backing for vaccination

fields.headline: Blair fails to get NFU backing for vaccination
fields.standfirst:
Policy shift: prime minister now sees inoculation as option in Cumbria and Devon, but fails to convince 'deeply divided' farmers
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The prime minister has failed to convince the National Farmers' Union that vaccination is a sensible way of tackling the foot and mouth epidemic and is considering whether he should force the issue.
fields.body:
The prime minister has failed to convince the National Farmers' Union that vaccination is a sensible way of tackling the foot and mouth epidemic and is considering whether he should force the issue.

The government is embarrassed as it loses ground in the battle to dispose of carcasses and slaughter animals which might have been in contact with the disease.

There are 431,000 carcasses remaining unburied and 568,000 animals still to be killed.

With the number of new cases still running at more than 20 a day, and the total number of outbreaks reaching 1,365 yesterday, vaccination was becoming an increasingly attractive option for Tony Blair.

Last night a statement from Downing Street confirmed that the chief scientist, David King, and the chief vet, Jim Scudamore, supported limited vaccination of cattle in Cumbria and Devon, but said the government would not begin without the consent of "deeply divided" farmers.

A Downing Street spokesman said vaccination would be a "supplement" to the current culling policy.

But he said the experts had cautioned ministers that vaccination would only be effective if it had "very substantial" support from farmers. There were also some "very difficult consumer issues to be addressed".

"It is quite clear from the discussions so far that the support from farmers is not currently there, and that the farming community as a whole is deeply divided on the issue," he said.

The government has the power to kill animals to contain the disease, but not to vaccinate compulsorily. Consent is required from every farmer, and unless there is blanket vaccination of cattle in Cumbria and Devon the policy is unlikely to be effective.

The government would need legislation to force farmers to comply.

Last night the NFU remained unconvinced that the government had answers to its questions about vaccination. Its main query is whether inoculation would prolong the epidemic and delay the resumption of exports. The union still favours the government's original eradication policy.

The farmers also want compensation if they are unable to sell meat and milk from vaccinated animals, saying assurance that there is no public health risk is not enough.

Martin Howarth, the NFU's policy director, said: "It seems to us an ineffective strategy, we remain to be convinced by the scientific evidence that vaccination will make a difference to the course of the epidemic."

The government ran into more flak yesterday from Dirk Hazell, chief executive of the environmental services association, charged with burying carcasses of culled cattle up to six years old, which might be contaminated with BSE.

Although the government denies there is any danger to the public it refuses to indemnify the landfill site owners if in the future people contract BSE as a result of this emergency dumping measure.

Mr Hazell said: "Until this crisis it was against the law to dump carcasses over 30 months, now suddenly there is no danger. If that is the case then indemnify us. So far we have no guarantee and we are not happy."

Sir John Krebs, chairman of the food standards agency, last night said he had advised Maff that meat and dairy products from vaccinated livestock could safely enter the food chain with no harmful effect on humans.

He said there were already 33 vaccines commonly used in Britain to prevent livestock contracting common conditions as diverse as digestive diseases and fevers.

"Our message on vaccination is that milk or meat from vaccinated animals would not constitute a food safety risk," said Sir John.

webTitle: Firms split over deal in cheap drugs lawsuit

fields.headline: Firms split over deal in cheap drugs lawsuit
fields.standfirst: Big companies break ranks in bid to reach South African settlement
fields.trailText: A split emerged last night between the world's big pharmaceutical companies over whether to proceed today with a patent rights lawsuit against the South African government that has turned into an international public relations disaster.
fields.body:
A split emerged last night between the world's big pharmaceutical companies over whether to proceed today with a patent rights lawsuit against the South African government that has turned into an international public relations disaster.

Three of the world's largest pharmaceutical firms - Britain's GlaxoSmithKline, and Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb in the US - broke ranks with 36 other companies who are party to the attempt to overturn a South African law that permits the government to import generic and other cheaper drugs to deal with health emergencies or where patented medicines are too expensive.

Last night the firms were negotiating with the South African government to reach a settlement before the Pretoria high court hearing resumes today after a six-week adjournment.

At the weekend, Nelson Mandela joined widespread international condemnation of the pharmaceutical companies' lawsuit by denouncing it as "a gross error".

"They are exploiting the situation in the developing world, because they charge exorbitant prices," he said. "This is completely wrong and must be condemned."

But Mr Mandela also said that the case could be settled through negotiation and said the South African government must "take responsibility for not doing sufficient work".

Sources close to the case said the breakaway drug companies were keen to withdraw from the lawsuit but were unable to see a way out without making concessions they are concerned could influence other countries following South Africa's lead.

The firms are particularly worried that a legal precedent might be established, allowing governments to declare individual drugs as too expensive and patents to be overridden worldwide.

If an agreement can be reached between South Africa and the three drugs manufacturers, it would exert enormous pressure on the other firms to pull out of the lawsuit and prove an important moral and legal victory for campaigners for wider access to anti-Aids drugs.

But the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (PMA), in whose name the legal challenge was filed, said it would continue the action even if only a handful of drug companies wanted to do so.

None of the parties was willing to discuss the talks publicly, but an industry source said that Merck in particular had been deeply uncomfortable about the legal action for some time and was urgently looking for a way out. Last month, amid rising international criticism of the lawsuit against South Africa, the company said it would sell two anti-Aids drugs in the developing world without profit.

GlaxoSmithKline distanced itself by using its South African subsidiary as a representative in the lawsuit and has also offered cheaper life-saving drugs to the developing world. Bristol-Myers Squib said it would not oppose generic production of its drugs in Africa, and offered to sell its anti-retrovirals for $1 each.

Last night, the head of the PMA, Mirryena Deeb, said she could not discuss the legal case. The South African government is divided on the issue. While Thabo Mbeki and some of his ministers have portrayed the case as a legal crusade by the developing world against the exploitation of multinationals, there has been concern within the administration that it will deter foreign investors.

But a health department spokeswoman, Jo-Anne Collinge, said the government would not abandon its central claim to the right to import generic and other cheaper drugs to deal with health emergencies or where prices are defined as unaffordable. "Whatever the outcome, we expect to be able to implement this legislation," she said.

fields.headline: $5bn losses push PSINet closer to bankruptcy
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: PSINet, the US internet service provider, stepped closer to bankruptcy yesterday after reporting net losses for 2000 of $5.03bn.
fields.body:
PSINet, the US internet service provider, stepped closer to bankruptcy yesterday after reporting net losses for 2000 of $5.03bn (£3.5bn) - up from $433m the previous year.

The company, which has warned that it could go out of business as its cash position worsens, lost $3.2bn in the final quarter compared with $223.5m at the same time in 1999 and said it had defaulted on some equipment leases.

The company, which provides web hosting services to run larger corporations' internet sites, reported revenues of $996m for the year, almost double the $534m it had in 1999, with a sharp rise in the fourth quarter.

PSINet, which is based in Virginia, said these indicators of growth were more than offset by "rapidly changing circumstances that are negatively impacting the company".

It is expected to reorganise under US bankruptcy laws although the auditors questioned its ability to survive or "continue as a going concern".

This prospect hastened when PSINet disclosed an estimated loss of $1.13bn on the disposal of discontinued operations and a charge of $2.59bn for the write-down of assets, following the decrease in the valuation of e-services companies.

The company said it had approximately $520m in cash, cash equivalents, short-term investments and marketable securities on April 10. It had $4.3bn in debt or lease obligations at the end of last year.

This reserve, even when combined with the cash it expects from asset sales, is unlikely to be enough to meet its cash needs.

PSINet has hired Goldman Sachs to help it weigh up a series of financial and strategic options and has enlisted Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein to explore ways to pay its creditors.

However, the company said: "Even if we implement successfully one or more of such alternatives, we cannot assure you that we will not run out of cash."

The company's reorganisation under bankruptcy laws would probably result in the stock having no value.

A pioneer business in providing internet access services to companies, PSINet is said by analysts to have foundered because it took on too many companies too quickly in non-internet areas.

Trading in its shares , which have lost 99% of their value, were halted on April 3 at a price of $3/16.
