fields.headline: Mississippi to keep rebel flag
fields.trailText: Mississippi has voted by a two-to-one margin to keep the Confederate emblem on the US state's flag, officials confirmed today.
fields.body:
Mississippi has voted by a two-to-one margin to keep the Confederate emblem on the US state's flag, officials confirmed today.

Voters rejected suggestions from the US state's governor and business leaders that a new flag would help the southern state escape its segregationist past.

With all ballots from yesterday's poll counted, 488,630 voters, or 65%, favoured keeping the old flag and 267,812 voters, or 35%, wanted to replace it.

Mississippi is the last state to prominently display the emblem on its flag.

Governor Ronnie Musgrove said Mississippi should accept the results. "We must put aside our differences as we continue to create a state that provides a good quality of life for our people," he said.

In a state where William Faulkner said the past is never dead, the flag debate, while largely peaceful, polarised voters along racial lines.

In DeSoto County, a predominantly white county in the Memphis suburbs, the old flag led by a six-to-one margin. In Hinds County, the majority-black county that includes Jackson, two out of three people backed the new flag.

Voters had two choices: keep the current 1894 flag with the Confederate emblem of 13 white stars on a blue X, or adopt a new flag with 20 white stars on a blue square, denoting Mississippi's role as the 20th state.

Farmer Terry Galey voted to keep the old banner. "I've had things on my farm that have been working for 20 years and if they're still working, why change them?" he said yesterday.

Former state senator Robert Crook said he hopes people accept the election results without boycotts or other pressure. He said there were few complains about the flag until former governor William Winter made it an issue.

"I don't think black people were upset with the flag. There was no hue and cry, no boycotts," Mr Crook said.

Mississippi's only black congressman, Democrat Bennie Thompson, has refused to fly the flag in his Washington office. "We will now have the sole distinction of having a Confederate battle symbol on a flag that can only further divide a diverse population," he said.

Some white people said they support the old flag because it represents their heritage and was the banner they saluted as children.

Many black people see the emblem as a symbol of past injustices, including beatings and lynchings by the Ku Klux Klan.

The state, with 2.8m people, is 61% white and 36% black.

Mr Musgrove and many business leaders supported the new flag, saying it would help move the state forward economically and socially.

The debate arose after the Mississippi supreme court ruled last May that the state technically has no flag, because the 1894 design was left out when the state code was updated in 1906. The legislature decided to let the voters choose.

The vote is part of a larger debate across the south about dealing with past racism and facing the future.

In neighbouring Alabama, jury selection is under way in the trial of a white man accused in one of the civil rights era's most notorious crimes, the 1963 bombing of Birmingham's Sixteenth Street Baptist Church. The bombing killed four black girls.

In recent years, prosecutors in Mississippi and other states also have dusted off files on old civil rights cases.

In 1994, a jury convicted Byron de la Beckwith of assassinating National Association for the Advancement of Colored People leader Medgar Evers in Jackson in 1963. The Mississippi attorney general Mike Moore said he was also pursuing leads in a case against those accused of killing three civil rights workers in 1964.

Other southern states have also wrestled with symbols of the Confederacy. South Carolina politicians, under economic pressure from the NAACP, last year removed a Confederate flag from atop the Statehouse dome. In January, Georgia legislators shrank the Confederate symbol that had dominated that state's flag since 1956.

Many Alabama cities and counties have stopped flying the state's flag - a red X over a white background, adopted in 1895 - because some say it looks too much like the Confederate banner.

webTitle: Doctor guilty of NHS fraud may have taken £4m

fields.headline: Doctor guilty of NHS fraud may have taken £4m
fields.trailText: A doctor believed to have swindled £4m from hospitals was yesterday convicted of the biggest one-man fraud of the NHS.
fields.body:
A doctor believed to have swindled £4m from hospitals was yesterday convicted of the biggest one-man fraud of the NHS.

Dimitri Padelis, 45, of South Norwood in south London, ran a company placing locum medical staff at hospitals and defrauded the health service by billing hospitals twice, inflating the number of hours doctors had worked and submitting bogus expenses.

Among the hardest hit was the Great Ormond Street children's hospital in London, which lost more than £12,000.

Padelis was convicted of two counts of fraudulent trading and three of false accounting between 1991 and 1995, at Southwark crown court in London yesterday.

The case was adjourned until May 25 for pre-sentence reports and Padelis was released on bail.

Anthony Leonard QC, prosecuting, told the jury it had been a subtle and widespread fraud.

"At its heart was the notion that so long as he kept the overcharging to an insignificant level on each invoice or in respect of each trust - a philosophy of a little bit here and a little bit there - the fraud would go unnoticed.

"But for a chance discovery, goodness knows how long it could have run."

Prosecution counsel said it was impossible to be certain about how much money had been lost to the NHS.

Although the case was conducted on the basis that Padelis had stolen at least £340,000, an investigating accountant who studied his pattern of offending estimated that he had pocketed as much as £2m, and later warned it was possible that the amount could be twice that.

One investigator said: "We have no doubt this man was responsible for one of the biggest frauds on the NHS and almost certainly the largest committed by a single individual.

"He was a secret cancer infecting just about every hospital he dealt with.

"No one will ever know just how much unnecessary suffering he was responsible for."

Alarm bells began to ring when an audit manager checked the 1994-95 accounts for Gwynedd hospital trust in north Wales and noticed that a series of payments for the same amount of money had been paid to the same company, Allcare.

Police were alerted and a mass of incriminating documents were found at Padelis's home and office.

All 458 NHS trusts in Britain were asked if they had dealt with Padelis's agency - detectives were surprised when thousands of documents flooded in.

webTitle: NHS agency will try to cut errors

fields.headline: NHS agency will try to cut errors
fields.trailText: Hospitals in England are to be forced to report medical errors to a new NHS agency to help cut the thousands of instances of clinical negligence and "near misses" that each year cost £2bn in hospital stays.
fields.body:
Hospitals in England are to be forced to report medical errors to a new NHS agency to help cut the thousands of instances of clinical negligence and "near misses" that each year cost £2bn in hospital stays.

The national patient safety agency, to be set up in July, will consider all "adverse effects" and issue guidance on avoiding such mistakes. The new body will have a separate chairman and chief executive, like the present food standards agency, and will report to the Department of Health.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, said the annual level of 850,000 incidents and errors was unacceptable. "While it is an inescapable fact of life that people make mistakes, there is much we can do to reduce their impact and so reduce risks for patients."

The agency will "be the way in which one patient's bad experience will help hundreds of others", he added.

The system, modelled on procedures used in the airline industry, will encourage staff to report errors under a "no blame" culture and will also offer protection to those who feel threatened by colleagues, through guaranteed whistle-blowing channels. It is designed to replace internal and external inquiries commissioned by government and professional bodies - which can often cover the same ground and be seen as insufficiently independent or open.

Conservatives and the Patients' Association were yesterday holding fire until more details emerged, but the British Medical Association welcomed the move.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultants' committee, said: "Modern health care is highly complex and many accidents or near misses are the result of a chain of events which combine to produce a systems failure. Problems are all the more likely because of the relentless pace at which we all work."

A huge change of working culture was necessary. But he added: "Unless we have some degree of confidentiality and protection for the individual clinician, it will be difficult to succeed in creating a climate in which we can all, genuinely, learn from experience."

The NHS pays out about £400m a year in settlements of clinical negligence claims. Infections acquired in hospitals affect about 100,000 patients, of whom 5,000 die.

fields.headline: Loudcloud targets corporate sector
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Loudcloud yesterday announced partnership agreements with Accenture and iFormation in an effort to expand into the corporate marketplace. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Loudcloud, the web-hosting firm set up by Netscape founder Marc Andreessen, yesterday announced partnership agreements with Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting, and iFormation in an effort to expand into the corporate marketplace.

The company, which made its debut on the US stockmarket early last month, will be able to provide internet infrastructure to Accenture clients.

Its internet outsourcing service will also be available to iFormation - a joint venture of Boston Consulting, Goldman Sachs and General Atlantic Partners - and its partner companies.

"They are offering our services to their customers," said Ben Horowitz, chief executive officer and co-founder of Loudcloud.

Mr Horowitz would not comment on the financial details other than to say: "Money is changing hands.

"These deals enable us to go into the corporate market place which expands our potential customer audience ten-fold. We are aggressively moving into this market."

Loudcloud, which is based in Silicon Valley and aims to be a one-stop shop for internet infrastructure, recently raised $150m for research and development and sales and marketing through its flotation. The IPO was initially priced at between $160m and $180m.

The loss-making company, which aims to be profitable in 2003, announced in February it had been chosen by the Post Office to run its internet operation. The firm, which has more than 40 customers, provides the internet infrastructure used by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

The company also launched yesterday its Opsware 2i technology, which allows customers to use Loudcloud products within their own data centres, and its Smart Cloud integration service.

Loudcloud was co-founded by Mr Andreessen in 1999. He led the dot.com boom when he earned £120m from the initial public offering of Netscape, the web browser business. Netscape was bought by America Online in 1998.

webTitle: Conservative candidate charged with firearm offence

fields.headline: Conservative candidate charged with firearm offence
fields.trailText: The 33-year-old Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate in the Tories' most winnable seat was yesterday charged with possession of a firearm after allegedly threatening vandals with an airgun.
fields.body:
The 33-year-old Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate in the Tories' most winnable seat was yesterday charged with possession of a firearm after allegedly threatening vandals with an airgun.

Christian Sweeting, a property developer and amateur magician chosen by the Tories to fight the marginal Torbay seat, will appear before Torbay magistrates tomorrow in connection with the incident on Easter Monday.

He is alleged to have reacted after suspecting that his car was being vandalised in the early hours.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, who personally endorsed his candidature, is visiting Torbay today, but may now not meet Mr Sweeting.

The Devon seat is held by Liberal Democrat Adrian Sanders by just 12 votes, and is top of the Tories' list of target seats to regain at the coming general election.

Mr Sweeting, from Torquay, was arrested by Devon and Cornwall police on Monday and was charged yesterday.

A police spokesman said: "A 33-year-old Torquay man has been charged with the possession of a firearm, with the intent to cause another person to believe that unlawful violence would be used against him or another."

Conservative central office declined to comment further, saying the affair was "a matter for the courts".

Mr Sweeting was chosen by the local party in December 1999 to replace defeated candidate Rupert Allason, the spy writer better known as Nigel West, who lost his seat in May 1997.

At the time of his selection he received the personal backing of Miss Widdecombe, who commented later that she had cracked open a bottle of brandy to celebrate his victory over two rivals.

Mr Sweeting is a chartered surveyor who runs his own property business in London.

His website lists his interests as badminton, table tennis, tennis, skiing, walking and amateur magic.

webTitle: Liberal titles hit in Russian media purge

fields.headline: Liberal titles hit in Russian media purge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The battle for control of Russia's opposition media continued yesterday with the closure of a prominent independent daily newspaper, writes Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
The battle for control of Russia's opposition media continued yesterday with the closure of a prominent independent daily newspaper and the apparent dismissal of the editorial staff of an influential weekly political magazine.

Both publications were partly owned by the exiled media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, whose Media-Most empire is gradually crumbling under pressure from the state gas monopoly, Gazprom.

The staff of the magazine Itogi arrived at work yesterday to find their newsroom barred by a row of private security guards: a scene reminiscent of Saturday's Gazprom takeover of Russia's only big independent television network, NTV.

The editor, Sergei Parkhomenko, was sacked by the publishing house, Sem Dnei (Seven Days), and the rest of the editorial staff were forced to resign. The management of Sem Dnei recently stopped supporting Mr Gusinsky and allied itself with Gazprom Media, the division which orchestrated the takeover of NTV, establishing a controlling stake in the publications.

The magazine's sister daily, Sevodnya, was absent from the newsstands yesterday for the first time in its eight-year history. Sem Dnei closed it on Monday night, 40 minutes before Tuesday's edition was due to go to press. The staff were ordered to take two months' paid leave and the editor-in-chief was sacked.

Sevodnya and Itogi are among Russia's best-respected publications, although Mr Gusinsky has in the past used them to voice his opinions. Both have been aggressive in their criticism of President Vladimir Putin's government.

Vladimir Biryukov, director and part-owner of Sem Dnei, said their political stance had nothing to do with the editorial changes. The decision to sack the editor of Sevodnya and suspend publication was made purely as a result of the paper's annual losses of $3m (£2.1m), he said.

"As the director of the company I am concerned first of all about cash flow and profitability. I have always thought that unless we make the publication profitable it will have to go."

The sacked Sevodnya editor, Mikhail Berger, said very few Russian broadsheets made money, because of the weak advertising market, and the only way serious newspapers could survive was by being adopted by publishing stables like Sem Dnei, which relied on profitable publications to subsidise their higher-profile papers.

He said Mr Biryukov had "performed a great service to the Kremlin by eliminating a critical paper", and insisted that his dismissal was directly connected with a government-backed campaign to castrate NTV and seize control of opposition media.

"It is hard to say how directly Mr Putin has been involved in all these events, but I think it is clear that he feels a personal dislike for Mr Gusinsky, stemming from his belief that nobody has a right to criticise the president personally," he said.

Mr Berger said that although freedom of the press remained alive, the crisis at Media-Most set a sobering example to other media groups. "These events have served as a warning to news organisations, who have begun to adopt careful self-censorship, making sure they stick to the Kremlin mainstream view."

Gazprom insists that it has stepped in simply to resolve the troubled finances at the heart of Media-Most.

Sem Dnei plans to continue publishing Itogi, using an entirely new editorial team.

Mr Parkhomenko, its sacked editor, said: "Next week you will see a publication with the name Itogi printed on it, but the magazine will be produced by different people, according to different principles, and I suspect with different aims. The Itogi that has existed for the past five years no longer exists."

Defiant NTV journalists who are refusing to work for the new management continued to broadcast a rebel version of the news yesterday from the studios of TNT, another of Mr Gusinsky's channels.

webTitle: Q&A: regulating care standards in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: Q&A: regulating care standards in Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
Why does the system need reforming?
The Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety (DHSSPS) is concerned that there are "unacceptable variations in the quality of care and treatment". It believes efforts to improve services are hindered by guidelines and standards emanating from a variety of sources.
fields.body:
Why does the system need reforming?
The Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety (DHSSPS) is concerned that there are "unacceptable variations in the quality of care and treatment". It believes efforts to improve services are hindered by guidelines and standards emanating from a variety of sources.

The Department of Health has already introduced national measures to clear up this confusion in England and Wales. These include the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), which ensures the best treatments are made widely available, and the Commission for Health Improvement (Chi), which reviews the quality of healthcare provided by the NHS through an inspection programme.

What reforms are proposed?
A consultation document, Best Practice - Best Care, published last week, sets out a framework for setting standards, strengthening accountability for the services delivered, and improving monitoring and regulation.

How would standards be improved?
First, the department proposes to introduce service development frameworks. These would cover the whole system of care for a particular service (for example, mental health) and provide a holistic approach to planning, delivery and monitoring of services. The frameworks would spell out where care is best provided, e.g. primary care, hospital or a specialist service; set the standard of care that patients should receive, and establish performance measures that would be used to check the quality of service provided.

Second, a single source for the production and dissemination of guidelines and standards would be set up. In England, this "source" is Nice. Its remit is to remove clinically ineffective, non-cost effective, or unsafe treatments from the NHS, while making sure the best treatments are made widely available and fairly to patients, thus ending the postcode lottery where access to treatment varies between health authorities. A similar body for social services, the Social Care Institute for Excellence (Scie), will be established later this year.

Most guidelines from Nice or Scie are expected to be applicable to Northern Ireland, so the DHSSPS would prefer to use them rather than create its own specific similar organisations. A standards board would be set up to decide which standards were applicable, and produce or commission specific guidelines where appropriate.

How would the delivery of services be improved?
A system of clinical and social governance, underpinned by a statutory duty of quality, would ensure health and social care organisations are accountable for continuously improving standards.

Clinical and social care governance would rectify poor practice through education, training and research, risk and complaints management, evidence-based practice and continuing professional development.

The duty of quality would place a statutory requirement on health and social services boards, health and social services trusts and special agencies, such as the Northern Ireland Blood Transfusion Service, to put and keep in place arrangements to improve and monitor the quality of care they provide to individuals.

How would monitoring and regulation be improved?
A health services improvement authority would be established to independently monitor social services in a similar way to which Chi assesses standards of healthcare in England and Wales. Chi plans to inspect every NHS trust, health authority through a programme of clinical governance reviews. These reviews inspect each body for quality of patient care; whether clinical staff are up to date in their professional practice, and whether safeguards are in place to prevent clinical errors.

The Northern Ireland Commission for Care Services would take over the work presently carried out by the registration and inspection units within the four health and social services boards. It would register and inspect a wider range of care services including the private and voluntary sector; investigate complaints; where necessary enforce action to ensure standards are improved; serve improvement notices; prosecute and where necessary de-register services; monitor employment practices, and work with other bodies including the health and social services improvement authority.

When will these reforms take place?
The document is out for consultation until July 18. However, the DHSSPS has produced several policy documents that have made little progress through the Northern Ireland assembly. Department of Health sources claim the proposals stand little chance of coming into effect because of the ongoing political deadlock in the province. It is also thought that Sinn Fein members would prefer to have closer ties with the Republic of Ireland's health service.

webTitle: Local papers counter US fall in dot.com ads

fields.headline: Local papers counter US fall in dot.com ads
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Regional publisher Newsquest yesterday said advertising revenues were 'still holding up' despite a slide in the performance of US parent Gannett. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Newsquest, the second largest publisher of regional newspapers in Britain, yesterday said advertising revenues were "still holding up" despite a slide in the performance of US parent Gannett.

Jim Brown, executive chairman of Newsquest, said the foot and mouth epidemic had begun to make an impact on revenues in agricultural and tourist areas but maintained the effect was still small. "We keep looking at the softening market in the US and wondering if it will wash over us but we've had a good first quarter. The recruitment advertising market is still holding up strongly and April is also looking good."

Recruitment advertising was 25% higher for Newsquest during the first quarter while property advertising also showed double-digit growth. The US group said it was "feeling very good about the UK".

Gannett, which owns US newspapers including USA Today and a number of television stations, reported a fall in comparable revenues of 3% in the first quarter and warned the second quarter would also be down on last year.

The group does not break out figures by country but blamed the like-for-like fall in revenues on a slide in the US advertising market. Gannett highlighted a fall in recruitment spend in its domestic newspapers while USA Today had taken a particular hit from the fall in dot.com advertising.

USA Today advertising revenues fell 20% in the first quarter. The newspaper recorded 1,332 advertising pages in the quarter compared with 1,684 in the same period of 2000.

On Monday, the New York Times group reported a 7% drop in advertising revenues for the first quarter to $544m and warned that revenues for the year would be flat at best.

Operating revenues from continuing businesses at Gannett were 19% up at $1.6bn while pretax profits for the first quarter fell 14% to $288m.

Newsquest has been one of the main players in the consolidation of the regional newspaper market in Britain and owns more than 300 titles. It said yesterday Paul Davidson would move up from group managing director to chief executive.

Gannett, which owns US newspapers including USA Today and a number of television stations, reported a fall in comparable revenues of 3% in the first quarter and warned the second quarter would also be down on last year. The group does not break out figures by country but blamed the like-for-like fall in revenues on a slide in the US advertising market. Gannett highlighted a fall in recruitment spend in its domestic newspapers while USA Today had taken a particular hit from the fall in dot.com advertising. USA Today advertising revenues fell 20% in the first quarter. The newspaper recorded 1,332 advertising pages in the quarter compared with 1,684 in the same period of 2000. On Monday, the New York Times group reported a 7% drop in advertising revenues for the first quarter to $544m and warned that revenues for the year would be flat at best. Operating revenues from continuing businesses at Gannett were 19% up at $1.6bn while pretax profits for the first quarter fell 14% to $288m. Newsquest has been one of the main players in the consolidation of the regional newspaper market in Britain and owns more than 300 titles. It said yesterday Paul Davidson would move up from group managing director to chief executive.

webTitle: Lib Dems may capitalise on Tory weak link

fields.headline: Lib Dems may capitalise on Tory weak link
fields.standfirst: In the final part of our series on tactical voting in key constituencies the Guardian visits Romsey, scene of a byelection turnaround
fields.trailText: With her cropped red hair, glasses and long-jacketed trouser suits, Sandra Gidley, Liberal Democrat MP for Romsey, has prompted teasing comparisons among party colleagues with acerbic quiz show hostess Anne Robinson.
fields.body:
With her cropped red hair, glasses and long-jacketed trouser suits, Sandra Gidley, Liberal Democrat MP for Romsey, has prompted teasing comparisons among party colleagues with acerbic quiz show hostess Anne Robinson.

Preparing to defend the Hampshire seat she wrested from the Conservatives in a byelection shock a year ago, she warns her rival Tory candidate: "My campaign slogan will be: 'Paul Raynes, you are the weakest link. Goodbye.'"

The Lib Dems hope to be waving farewell on election night to Mr Raynes, a former Treasury high flyer and policy adviser to William Hague, as they did last May to the old Etonian farmer Tim Palmer.

In a byelection prompted by the death in a house fire of the Conservative incumbent Michael Colvin, Romsey pharmacist Mrs Gidley was catapulted to Westminster on an astonishing swing of 12.6%, overturning a Tory majority of over 8,500.

The victory, which followed an intensive Lib Dem campaign and a chaotic Tory effort, helped the new Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy repel accusations of failure to make an impact, and caused severe tremors at Conservative central office.

At the coming general election, expected on June 7, the Lib Dems are desperate to consolidate an unexpected gain, while the Tories will be in deep trouble if they fail to recover a sprawling shire seat, stretching almost from Andover down to the Southampton fringes, that was previously regarded as natural Conservative heartland.

Some Conservatives regard the seat as a touchstone for Mr Hague's leadership - if it falls again the vultures may begin to circle. Labour's Stephen Roberts meanwhile will tacitly encourage supporters to cast tactical Lib Dem votes to keep out a Tory, while aiming not to go as far as his byelection predecessor and lose his deposit.

Tory postmortems have, correctly, concluded that the party picked the wrong candidate last time, having controversially rejected a local woman, Liz Perry, whom many feel would have comfortably held the seat. Barbour-clad Mr Palmer, who lived across the border in Dorset, came across badly.

But, despite the Tories' insistence that their problems were organisational rather than political, the party's policies - including tough talk on asylum and the usual emphasis on saving the pound - also played badly compared with conventional Lib Dem local fare, focusing on rural post office closures and hospital waiting lists.

A rain soaked rally in Romsey's pretty market square last April saw Mr Hague and the shadow chancellor Michael Portillo play to a damp crowd of supporters largely bussed in from other constituencies.

Mr Raynes, a key author of the Conservatives' Common Sense Revolution policy document, has common sense enough to stress that regaining the seat will not be easy: "The electorate has grown up, and no one is prepared to be taken for granted any longer."

Though the admission sounds astonishing in a constituency in classic Tory territory, the former mandarin is right that many natural Conservatives felt piqued that they had not been wooed but were merely expected to turn out.

Significant numbers stayed at home, contributing to the Conservative demise. "We recognise we could have tried harder when it came to turnout," Mr Raynes said. "There was a certain element of taking people, our own voters, for granted."

This time, he insisted, "the whole pace has gone up. Everybody is working".

Mr Raynes, 33, a sharp-brained high flyer with a personable doorstep manner and just a touch of the student politician about his orange jeans and University Challenge haircut, said he was determined to fight a positive campaign on "issues which matter" such as tax, bobbies on the beat and Labour's failure to deliver on public services.

"The Liberals will spend their time in Romsey demonising the Tories and demonising me," he said. "I'm going to run a resolutely positive campaign about making lives better for people by doing the things that they value."

Despite his protestations that his party would run a positive campaign, Mr Raynes was not above saying that Mrs Gidley was "immensely unpopular with an enormous number of people on both sides", adding: "She's not local, she's from Wales."

The MP was born in Monmouthshire but has lived for years in Romsey, while Mr Raynes, whose selection prompted the resignation of the Tory branch chairman who backed a local candidate, grew up in Surrey before living in London and Paris.

Welsh connections or not, Mrs Gidley enters an uphill election battle with the advantage of incumbency. Unlike Ms Robinson, she boasts an approachable manner. Her first year as MP has been spent in earnest Lib Dem backbencher fashion - she has made a solid Commons start while focusing on creating a strong constituency presence, popping up at parish council meetings, schools, hospitals and church services.

The Lib Dems will again use the two horse race ploy, urging Labour supporters to vote tactically for Mrs Gidley and dismissing Tory claims that last year's surprise was down to Conservative stay-at-homes.

Labour's Mr Roberts, a 40-year-old property businessman and supporter of voting reform, said helpfully: "Sandra is very popular with Labour voters, which makes my job more difficult."

For Romsey, as for much of the UK, Labour and the Lib Dems cannot calculate how big a role tactical voting will play in the next election. Both hope that, as the byelection appeared to signal, an anti-Tory vote still exists, with some voters even more prepared to think tactically now they know the strategy can have a real effect.

Some Tory votes may also be lost to the anti-EU United Kingdom Independence party, whose candidate Anthony McCabe, will hope to better the surprisingly low 901 votes the party took after an enthusiastic campaign last year.

A Tory-supporting antiques dealer a stone's throw from Romsey's ancient abbey, was among those questioning whether the Tories could really win the seat back. The youthful Mr Raynes, he suggested, was again not quite the right candidate for a seat desperate for a mature, genuinely local figure. "We hear nothing but Sandra Gidley this, Sandra Gidley that - we're sick of it, but at least she's getting about."

Mrs Gidley, pointing out that her suits are brown unlike Ms Robinson's stern black, travels the constituency wearing a green bracelet - the kind known as Buddha beads - bought for her by her daughter last year and said to represent success. "I hope it doesn't snap before the election," she said. Her link with Westminster may prove stronger than the Conservatives hope.

webTitle: First black PM 'will be a Tory'

fields.headline: First black PM 'will be a Tory'
fields.standfirst: Backbencher names contenders for No 10 job
fields.trailText: The first black prime minister will be a Conservative and probably enter the Commons at the next election, Peter Bottomley, the Tory backbencher predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
The first black prime minister will be a Conservative and probably enter the Commons at the next election, Peter Bottomley, the Tory backbencher predicted yesterday.

His forecast was a response to renewed claims that some local Tory parties are publishing racist literature in the run-up to the election, despite a directive from party chairman Michael Ancram.

Mr Bottomley's prediction amounts to a suggestion that Mohammed Riaz, Tory candidate for Bradford West, or Shailesh Vara, the candidate for Northampton South, will become Britain's first black prime minister. No other Tory ethnic minority candidate has a chance since they are standing in hopeless seats, albeit with large ethnic minority electorates.

Mr Bottomley pointed out that the Conservatives were the first to elect a Jew and the first to elect a woman as leader. The party had appointed Nirj Dirva to represent the party as MEP in Surrey, he added.

He described Mr Vara as an excellent candidate. A solicitor and Ugandan Asian, 40-year-old Mr Vara was personal adviser to Oliver Letwin, the shadow chief secretary and himself one of the most intelligent Conservative MPs.

Mr Vara was chosen to speak at the last Tory conference and needs a 1.7% swing to defeat Tony Clarke, the Labour incumbent. He has toiled in lesser Tory positions for 20 years, and believes his party is not racist. He supports detention centres for asylum seekers as well as corporal punishment.

Mr Clarke stirred controversy when he told the YouGov.com website that racist voters would help him retain the marginal seat. As a result he expected to "outperform" the national swing for or against Labour by about 4%. "Although the seat is 80% urban," Mr Clarke said, "the 20% rural have shown themselves in the past to be quite racist in terms of their voting patterns."

Mr Bottomley's second suggestion - Mr Riaz - was appointed ethnic minorities adviser to William Hague last month. A 50-year-old Bradford businessman, Mr Riaz fought Bradford West in 1997 and was one of two Tory candidates to take votes from Labour.

According to Operation Black Vote, one of the main reasons for Mr Riaz's progress was that "much of the city's non-white population is concentrated in Bradford West, where 37% of the non-white community is of Muslim origin. However, the Labour party candidate was Marsha Singh, who is of Sikh origin."

The seat includes the Asian population of Bradford as well as some of the poorest parts of Yorkshire and also some of the most middle class, residential areas of Bradford.

Mr Riaz, who runs nursing homes, said his party was trying to address the fact that each time a white member of the party mentioned asylum or immigration, it was interpreted as racist. The Asian grassroots community, as opposed to its "learned leftwing leaders", were opposed to Labour's political correctness, he said.

Mr Ancram's letter pleading for tolerance was sent out in response to the call from the commission on racial equality to all parties not to pander to racism. Aides said he could have been criticised had he not passed on the CRE agreement to local parties.

The letter was sent before John Townend, the Tory MP in Bridlington, warned that Anglo-Saxon society was under threat. Mr Townend's successor, Greg Knight, has refused to disown the remarks.

fields.headline: Website offers Lib-Lab vote swap
fields.trailText: Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters in marginal seats are being invited to trade votes in the general election to keep out Tory candidates, in the first organised tactical voting drive to be seen in a British election.
fields.body:
Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters in marginal seats are being invited to trade votes in the general election to keep out Tory candidates, in the first organised tactical voting drive to be seen in a British election.

A new website will pair up Labour and Lib Dem voters around the country in a vote swapping system based on the so-called Nader trading agreements between Democrats and Greens in the American presidential race.

Labour supporters in Tory-Lib Dem marginals will pledge to vote Lib Dem, provided Lib Dem tactical voters in close Tory-Labour seats agree to vote Labour.

The system, which matches voters by email, is intended to allow supporters to avoid casting a "wasted vote", while keeping their conscience clear that their party's national vote share will not be affected by their tactical manoeuvres.

The site, supporting the centre left but not affiliated to any party - and judged by the Electoral Reform Society to be "just on the right side of the law" - is aimed at building on the kind of informal tactical voting that is widely believed to have lost the Conservatives seats at the 1997 election.

Founders of the vote trading website www.tacticalvoter.net and other new sites encouraging tactical voting within constituencies argue that the power of the internet and email can make tactical voting more effective than ever.

Jason Buckley, the businessman who created the site and is a supporter of voting reform, said: "Tactical voting was just crying out for the technology to make it happen, and the internet can do that by linking people up."

People would still want to avoid wasting their votes in single party strongholds, he predicted, suggesting that the site could potentially affect results in some 15 marginals, such as Torbay and Winchester, which are narrowly held by Lib Dems and which the Tories aim to recapture.

Tacticalvoter.net is funded by the Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust and by the voter education campaign New Politics Network.

Another site, stophague.com, encourages tactical voting to retain the Lib Dem and Labour MPs Ed Davey and Roger Casale in, respectively, Kingston and Surbiton, and Wimbledon, both formerly Tory.

webTitle: The strain that mental health problems put on friendship networks

fields.headline: Stigma ties
fields.standfirst: Would you tell friends if you had a mental health problem? Would they help? Could they help? By  Mike George
fields.trailText: Would you tell friends if you had a mental health problem? Would they help? Could they help? By Mike George
fields.body:
Losing a close friend is painful enough, but imagine how distressing it would be to lose all your friends because you had developed a mental health problem. Research published yesterday, as part of mental health action week, shows that this can happen, even though friendships and social networks are known to be valued and needed by most mental health service users.

The research, by the Mental Health Foundation charity, found that four in 10 service users were worried about telling friends about their problems. One in three felt friendships had become strained, or lost, because of their mental distress.

On the other side of the coin, one in four people discovered that their friend was having problems only when he or she was admitted to hospital. Most poignantly, one in 20 became aware only when their friend attempted suicide.

The research was carried out among 543 people, both service users and their friends. While a small minority of the former - often younger people with serious mental illness - maintain that meaningful social relations matter little, most say that friends can provide crucial emotional and practical support. As one service user told researchers, friends were important just for "being there when I am lousy company".

About half the service users surveyed said that all or most of their friends did try to understand what was happening and offered help. And where friendships were maintained, the majority of respondents found the quality of the relations enhanced by the experience.

However, 34% said they could tell none, or very few, of their friends about their mental distress because they would not understand, or were likely to react negatively. And 39% were worried about doing so. Only 28% said they felt they could tell most of their friends. This was the case even though most said that what they wanted from their friends was just for them to keep in touch and accept them as they were - not necessarily to become carers.

Many of those surveyed blamed all this on the continuing stigma attached to mental illness, a view echoed by mental health organisations. But Tom Harrison, a consultant psychiatrist in rehabilitation at South Birmingham mental health trust, who speaks for the Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCP) on these issues, cautions against people attributing all friendship losses to stigmatisation. "I think that people with psychoses in particular, but also some with bi-polar affective disorder and severe depression, go through such traumatic change in their lives that their whole perception of the world is altered," he says. "They can then find it difficult to relate to people who haven't been there. They may lack everyday social skills, and so are likely to lose previous friendships."

It may be unrealistic to expect "old" friendships to survive, Harrison says, and service users may need to develop new friendships with others who have some shared experience. There may be parallels with those who have had the experience as prisoners of war, he suggests. "Nevertheless, as part of our assertive outreach work, we do try to encourage service users to meet up with old friends, if they agree to this."

For most people who have mental health problems, old friendships are usually highly valued. The foundation's survey found that the majority of friends provided some form of support - though large numbers reported shock, fright, helplessness or powerlessness. Les Sharpe, who chairs the British Association of Social Workers' mental health special interest group, believes that friends have a significant role to play in care in the community, especially "in that difficult period, the first three months following hospital discharge, where they can support, informally supervise and rehabilitate service users".

Sharpe acknowledges, however, that friends often face tough emotional challenges and many practical problems. They commonly feel there are few, if any, professionals or others to whom they can turn to get information and advice. One says: "I would have liked someone to have explained my friend's illness to me, because I was always worried about whether I was doing the right thing. I asked the GP that we both saw and he said that he couldn't discuss it with me. And though he did lend me some books on depressive illnesses, everything was in medical language, so that didn't help. I needed something understandable."

In effect, she says, she was left to look after her friend's children and provide other support for more than two years, without receiving any advice or being able to contribute in any other way. She is still upset about the "dismissive" attitude shown to her when she asked her friend's counsellor what she should do to help.

Monica Endersby, from Northampton, had "a major breakdown" and was subsequently diagnosed as having a dissociative identity disorder. In effect, she lost all memory of friends and family. "I would see all these people coming up to me smiling, but I didn't know who they were," she says. "I tried to explain that I'd lost all my memories, but I could see the uncertainty and embarrassment in their faces. My friends said they'd keep in touch, but they didn't - and still don't."

Consequently, Enderby says she feels embarrassed about her illness, "though I keep asking myself why, because I didn't hurt anyone; if anything I've been the one who's been hurt". And she is trenchant about the need to educate the public about mental health. "One of the biggest problems was that while people often want to help you, they're frightened of doing the wrong thing. I feel it would be helpful if there was some sort of modest guide with some basic dos and don'ts in it, or some other way in which they could get some straightforward advice."

Larry Culliford, a consultant psychiatrist at South Downs NHS trust, and another of the RCP's experts, recognises the problems faced by friends. "What happens when people see someone else suffering is that it can resonate fears and confusions within themselves, and lead them into an emotional and intellectual maze," he says. "So if friends want to help, they need to sit back and consider their own initial reactions - particularly in the case of people with problems like a personality disorder - to make sure that they don't get hurt. Then they could approach the various mental health charities and other organisations, to seek advice, and always try to keep in some form of contact with the person - but not too intrusively."

The Department of Health's national service framework for mental health acknowledges the important role of informal carers and urges health and social care agencies to provide them with more support. But it makes no specific reference to friends. Current discussions about reform of the Mental Health Act include consideration of friends as "the nearest relative" - in other words, the main contact person for the service user - so things may be about to change. The foundation's research suggests that change is long overdue.

"Nevertheless, as part of our assertive outreach work, we do try to encourage service users to meet up with old friends, if they agree to this." For most people who have mental health problems, old friendships are usually highly valued. The foundation's survey found that the majority of friends provided some form of support - though large numbers reported shock, fright, helplessness or powerlessness. Les Sharpe, who chairs the British Association of Social Workers' mental health special interest group, believes that friends have a significant role to play in care in the community, especially "in that difficult period, the first three months following hospital discharge, where they can support, informally supervise and rehabilitate service users". Sharpe acknowledges, however, that friends often face tough emotional challenges and many practical problems. They commonly feel there are few, if any, professionals or others to whom they can turn to get information and advice. One says: "I would have liked someone to have explained my friend's illness to me, because I was always worried about whether I was doing the right thing. I asked the GP that we both saw and he said that he couldn't discuss it with me. And though he did lend me some books on depressive illnesses, everything was in medical language, so that didn't help. I needed something understandable." In effect, she says, she was left to look after her friend's children and provide other support for more than two years, without receiving any advice or being able to contribute in any other way. She is still upset about the "dismissive" attitude shown to her when she asked her friend's counsellor what she should do to help. Monica Endersby, from Northampton, had "a major breakdown" and was subsequently diagnosed as having a dissociative identity disorder. In effect, she lost all memory of friends and family. "I would see all these people coming up to me smiling, but I didn't know who they were," she says. "I tried to explain that I'd lost all my memories, but I could see the uncertainty and embarrassment in their faces. My friends said they'd keep in touch, but they didn't - and still don't." Consequently, Enderby says she feels embarrassed about her illness, "though I keep asking myself why, because I didn't hurt anyone; if anything I've been the one who's been hurt". And she is trenchant about the need to educate the public about mental health. "One of the biggest problems was that while people often want to help you, they're frightened of doing the wrong thing. I feel it would be helpful if there was some sort of modest guide with some basic dos and don'ts in it, or some other way in which they could get some straightforward advice." Larry Culliford, a consultant psychiatrist at South Downs NHS trust, and another of the RCP's experts, recognises the problems faced by friends. "What happens when people see someone else suffering is that it can resonate fears and confusions within themselves, and lead them into an emotional and intellectual maze," he says. "So if friends want to help, they need to sit back and consider their own initial reactions - particularly in the case of people with problems like a personality disorder - to make sure that they don't get hurt. Then they could approach the various mental health charities and other organisations, to seek advice, and always try to keep in some form of contact with the person - but not too intrusively." The Department of Health's national service framework for mental health acknowledges the important role of informal carers and urges health and social care agencies to provide them with more support. But it makes no specific reference to friends. Current discussions about reform of the Mental Health Act include consideration of friends as "the nearest relative" - in other words, the main contact person for the service user - so things may be about to change. The foundation's research suggests that change is long overdue. The whole-life approach to mental illness www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare/

fields.headline: Millbank curbs PR volunteers
fields.trailText: Labour is to reduce the number of lobbyists asked to help out at the party's Millbank HQ during the election, to avoid any possible "help for access" scandal.
fields.body:
Labour is to reduce the number of lobbyists asked to help out at the party's Millbank HQ during the election, to avoid any possible "help for access" scandal.

Margaret McDonagh, the party's general secretary, has decreed that only a few supporters of the party who are employed in public affairs or public relations should be given formal campaign roles.

One party official estimated "around a dozen" lobbyists would be given desks in Millbank this time, compared with "dozens and dozens" in 1997. The ruling reflects nervousness within the party's leadership that it could be accused of trading assistance for the possibility of future influence by allowing lobbyists to work unpaid with MPs and ministers.

Mike Craven, head of his own lobbying firm, Lexington, and a former adviser to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has scrapped plans to advise his old boss. The lobbyist Neal Lawson, who wrote daily reports for the party hierarchy four years ago, has told associates he would play no role this year.

With the possible exception of the former Labour communications director, David Hill, due to return unpaid to his former beat from a PR job with Good Relations, other potentially controversial volunteers will be required to adopt a low profile. The former Labour spokesman Colin Byrne, man aging director of the lobbying firm Wever Shandwick, is to work behind the scenes seeking corporate endorsement in Millbank's business unit.

Most big public affairs and PR companies allow staff to be seconded to both the main parties, and often the Liberal Democrats.

Spending caps to be imposed by the electoral commission mean salaries must be counted by parties against the total allowed, requiring many sympathisers to work unpaid.

One of the most high-profile Conservative volunteers is expected to be Lord Bell, Lady Thatcher's favourite public relations adviser. He is head of Chime Communications, which owns Good Relations, Mr Hill's employer.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst: How the old 'new economy' is fighting back
fields.trailText: April 18: How the old 'new economy' is fighting back. By Stefano Hatfield.
fields.body:
Pain is relative. Two stunned pink-slippers were drowning their sorrows in Le Colonial, a swanky French-Vietnamese restaurant in the affluent heart of San Francisco. One, a dot.commer, had got his pink slip (the American equivalent of the P45) that very day; the other, an incubator or some such (it was difficult catching the exact details from the next table) had had a few weeks to digest his bad news.

"I never thought it would be me. I never thought it would be me," repeated the former like a mantra, whilst gulping down his Zinfandel. His friend nodded, but wasn't listening. "Dude (yes, he really did say "dude"), I'm outta here. I'm heading back east to Boston. The house is on the market, we'll get something great for the money there."

The talk soon turned to mutual acquaintances who had also been laid off. How many others in the same room were sharing similar tales? It was, after all, Monday night. And Monday is the day American human resources directors have designated lay-off day, because before the weekend is deemed more cruel. Everyday stories from the dot.bomb economy.

West Coast advertising agencies have inevitably shared in the fallout. San Francisco's Goodby Silverstein and Portland, Oregon's Wieden & Kennedy, the two agencies that vie for the title of America's hottest, have both made recent lay-offs - the first in Goodby's history. Britain's Leagas Delaney recently axed half its San Francisco staff in a move that casts a shadow over its proposed sale. Almost all agencies have suffered.

But there is a fascinating sub-plot going on starring some of the biggest names of the first silicon valley gold rush. One of the few advertising categories where marketeers are either maintaining their spend, or at the very least committing huge budgets to high-profile campaigns, is computer hardware. So, IBM, Apple, Sony Vaio (OK, not quite Silicon Valley), Hewlett Packard, Compaq and Gateway have all either launched major new campaigns or switched agencies in preparation.

This past week Dell, one of the standard-bearer success stories of the past 20 years, joined that list appointing not a West Coast agency, but DDB Chicago, the people that brought you the "Whassup!" phenomenon. The $200m global budget represents the largest chunk of creative business to switch agencies this year, and it neatly fills the hole at DDB created by the loss of Compaq last year.

The eponymous founder Michael Dell famously cut out the retailer to sell direct to home, growing Dell to be number three in the PC market (behind (IBM and Compaq). However, although few details have as yet emerged as to what tack Dell will be taking, it is unlikely they will focus on sales to the domestic consumer. Already the client has talked of "honing in on the enterprise arena" - in other words going after big corporations.

In a market where overall sales of PCs have levelled off, marketeers know they cannot simply sell product attributes when many consumers have limited use for those higher specs.

IBM, for example, is targeting businesses with an intelligent and ubiquitous campaign "that's when it's time to call IBM". It depicts a variety of situations where executives get very excited about their future plans until they realise no one in their organisation has the ability to implement the necessary IT systems.

Apple is selling its iMac and iBook products on little more than color and their all-run fun personalities (there is nothing particularly outstanding about the product spec). Sony, having almost given up on the PC market, came up with the Vaio, which it sells on its futuristic looks and small size.

All these and more are spending big advertising dollars while certain other categories are being decimated. It is clear that not all brands in this sector will survive the downturn, and it appears that marketeers within these silicon giants have embraced the old advertising adage that a downturn is a time to increase your share of voice.

Their agencies will be very grateful for such confidence in their craft. It may save many advertising employees from their own pink-slips.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global

fields.headline: Emillionaire shows he's able
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The winner of C4's Emillionaire show is finally launching his website, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The winner of Channel 4's Emillionaire show last summer is finally launching his website, nine months after he picked up the £1m prize.

Joe Rajko, one of the two winners, will launch Youreable.com at the end of this month.

The other winner, Colin Robinson, also awarded £1m, has yet to get his business off the ground.

Mr Robinson was thwarted after he tried to sell the business, Schoolsforschools.com, to a rival online education business BiblioTech. He was set to quadruple his prize money, but the deal collapsed and Mr Robinson had to start again from scratch.

Mr Robinson now insists he still has something in the pipeline, and that it will happen within weeks.

Mr Rajko on the other hand, has built up what he says is a sustainable business for an, as yet, completely untapped market of 8m people.

Already the website has generated £400,000 in sponsorship and advertising revenue from the likes of Ford, Barclays and Fish4.

Targeted at disabled people and their friends and families, Youreable.com will provide goods and services which are vital to the disabled community but are difficult to source.

"We aim to be successful, and expect to be profitable in early 2002," said Mr Rajko, who looks back on this past year as an "electric year".

With a staff of 12, Youreable.com says it's "the largest social venture since the Big Issue".

Asked what was the hardest part of being an emillionaire, Mr Rajko said it was pulling together the right team. But once the right people were in place, he said that it took around four months to pull the website together.

Youreable rose to fame last year when Channel 4 and investors Accenture, Oxygen Holdings, Bright Station, Skillcapital and BM Investments voted it the best internet idea from more than 7,000 applications to the Emillionaire Show last April.

A high profile advertising campaign invited anybody with an original dot.com idea to come forward and chance their luck at the internet millionaires game. The two winners received £1m apiece, although half of this money was given in internet services.

The judges included Trinny Woodhall from Ready2, Michael Grade, Matthew Freud and Bright Station's Dan Wagner, among others.

fields.headline: Weakest Link tops US ratings
fields.trailText: On its first night showing on American television, The Weakest Link attracted more than 11m viewers for NBC - more than to any other channel.
fields.body:
On its first night showing on American television, The Weakest Link attracted more than 11m viewers for NBC - more than to any other channel.

Although the figure might not appear to be high for a country with more than 100m households, Anne Robinson beat tough competition from a new comedy, King of Queens, on CBS which was seen in 7.9m homes. Fox TV came third with 7.5m for its second episode of a gritty schools drama Boston Public.

NBC ran an extra edition of the BBC game show last night, and intends to air another today to give it as much initial exposure as possible.

Britain's other big game show export, Who Wants to be a Millionaire, continues to perform well in the ratings with an estimated 10m viewers.

fields.headline: New rules for squabbling companies
fields.trailText: 8.30am: New guidelines for arch-rivals Dyson and Hoover are being drawn up by advertising watchdogs, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
New guidelines for arch-rivals Dyson and Hoover are being drawn up by advertising watchdogs after being forced to referee in an increasingly bitter disputes between rival companies.

The Advertising Standards Authority says it is having to deal with more and more industry-to-industry complaints, with manufacturers of vacuum cleaners emerging as some of the worst culprits.

It is hoping clearer guidelines about what manufacturers can and can't say will alleviate the problem.

Dyson alone has made 12 complaints about campaigns from rival manufacturers including Hoover and Electrolux, while Sebo, Oreck and Miele have also submitted objections.

The ASA has to investigate all industry-to-industry complaints it receives and says the process is becoming increasingly time consuming.

This week the ASA threw out an objection from Dyson to an advert for a Hoover vacuum cleaner. Dyson said Hoover's claim that the product was the "most powerful bag-less upright cleaner" was false.

The news will fuel concerns that the ASA, an advertising watchdog set up primarily to address consumer concerns about advertising campaigns, is being hijacked by companies seeking to steal a march on their rivals.

Almost 10% of all complaints handled by the ASA are now industry-to-industry.

In a recent speech Lord Borrie QC, the chairman of the ASA, called on advertisers to act more responsibly.

He said industry-to-industry complaints take up much more than 10% of the ASA's resources because these complaints are the most likely to require outside experts to evaluate evidence.

fields.headline: Top Banana: Simon Soffe
fields.standfirst: Top Banana is a new must-read awards section courtesy of MediaGuardian.co.uk.  Every week you can nominate your heroes - those men or women who have impressed you most with their media performance. The accolade can be bestowed upon a person, team, campaign or stunt for turning a potential PR disaster into triumph or for positive spin beyond their client's wildest imagination. This week, step forward and collect your coveted Top Banana trophy... Simon Soffe, nominated by Eugen Beer of Beer Davies PR.
fields.trailText: 8.30am: In a brand new section, MediaGuardian.co.uk awards its first Top Banana to the PR brain behind the Tesco v Levi's battle.
fields.body:
Winner: Simon Soffe
Position: press manager
Company: Tesco
Age: 28

Top Banana 1
Simon has been the PR brain behind the Tesco v Levi's spat - a three-year legal crusade for the right to sell cut-price jeans.

Top Banana 2
He also speedily turned a leak about a top-secret trial of home delivery by unmarked Land Rovers to posh people into a winning national story.

Result
Mr Soffe's spin has boosted Tesco's reputation as the consumer champion, to two opposing sets of consumers. All this at a time when the supermarket has just reported its highest-ever profits, of £1bn.

Effect
Levi's is now viewed by Tesco customers as money-grabbing and snobbish for not wanting its products sold where they shop. Meanwhile wealthy customers, who previously turned up their nose at a chain once known for selling tinned beans out of boxes, appreciate a supermarket sensitive to its country-set standards.

How did he do that? 1
Since Mr Soffe joined Tesco three years ago from Hill & Knowlton he has worked tirelessly on translating a complicated legal wrangle - to allow Tesco to sell cut-price Levi's from outside the EU - into a battle cry for bargain-hunters nationwide.

A recent European court of justice legal opinion upheld Tesco's right to sell the grey-market jeans and paves the way for other retailers to sell cut-price designer gear.

Simon says: "It is essentially a very dull part of law, but consumers are very interested because of its ramifications. When I went to the stores two weeks ago after the legal opinion was given, it was fantastic, all the shoppers knew exactly what had been going on."

How did he do that? 2
Regional agency Anglia Press got hold of all the details of Tesco's trial Land Rover home delivery service, scuppering carefully laid launch plans. Mr Soffe was parachuted into Norwich, co-operated fully with the press agency, even supplied pictures, and ended up doing 28 radio interviews. Simon says: "This was a bit of a disaster on the face of it. It was supposed to be a secret trial. But all credit to Anglia Press - they did a tremendous job in getting all the details - so we rolled with it instead of trying to shut it down. We laid on the photos and it became a national story."

 Do you deserve a Top Banana, or do you know someone that does? Email Julia Day with your nominations at julia.day@theguardian.com

webTitle: Portrait of TV comedian Dom Joly

fields.headline: Don't trust this man
fields.standfirst:
An officious park-keeper, dogs beating each other up and an obnoxious mobile phone user - it's an unlikely recipe for a hit show. But it works. Maxton Walker meets Dom Joly, the man behind Trigger Happy TV

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: An officious park-keeper, dogs beating each other up and an obnoxious mobile phone user - it's an unlikely recipe for a hit show. But it works. Maxton Walker meets Dom Joly, the man behind Trigger Happy TV.
fields.body:
My goodness: there it is. Perched on the top shelf of Dom Joly's office, the infamous three-foot mobile phone. It's rather battered and scratched, having been hauled around London for the last two years; the numbers on the giant keypad are almost illegible. Joly, slumped in an armchair, gestures at it half-heartedly.

"It came from a display outside a mobile phone shop. We nicked it, actually. I'd quite like to get rid of it, though. It's a bit annoying that it's become so popular. Everybody, even if they don't watch Trigger Happy, knows about it. 'Hello!' has become my catchphrase."

The phone is, however, an appropriate gimmick for Joly, a man who has earned his fame by, as he puts it, "being able to bullshit on demand". The first series of Trigger Happy last year, a candid camera for the MTV generation, was one of Channel 4's biggest hits. Now Joly's creations - the obnoxious mobile man, dogs beating the crap out of each other in the street, the officious park keeper accusing pensioners of playing football - are already threatening to become part of our national consciousness.

Trigger Happy TV, Joly is at pains to point out, is hard work to make; it took him and his sidekick, Sam Cadman, a year to shoot each series. "It looks like it's made by two drunk students in a week. But for the first series we shot two hours of footage for every minute we used. That's more than they did on Apocalypse Now. We got that down to an hour for the second series. But by the end we're emotionally knackered - and we don't make any money because we've used so much pop music on the soundtrack."

Quite what has motivated Joly to spend two years of his life churning out this stuff isn't immediately clear from his background. He was born in Switzerland, spent his childhood in Lebanon and was educated in Britain and America. He became a runner for MTV before landing an internship as a trainee diplomat ("It taught me how to lie in a suit"). After a year in Prague, a coincidental witness to the velvet revolution, he changed tack and became a political producer for ITN, before moving to the Paramount comedy channel to make short Trigger Happy-style fillers between programmes. Channel 4 spotted him and offered him the first series of the show that made his name.

Joly has a businesslike - even serious - manner, perhaps a legacy of his "proper" jobs. He certainly doesn't have the demeanour of some tiresome office prankster. But does he worry that - aged 33 and married with a daughter - he makes his living this way? Surely at times, for example, when he was sitting in Zermatt prison dressed as a yeti, he must have wondered whether this is a job for a grown man. He shrugs: "It clearly isn't," he admits. "But unfortunately they don't let children do it. The fact is, it's more enjoyable than any job I've ever done, so in fact it's rather a weird paradox."

Its real roots arguably lie in the Dadaists' attempts to bring surrealism to public attention. And this shows through in Trigger Happy; the pleasure comes as much from watching bystanders reacting to Joly's antics as the stunts themselves.

More tellingly - a legacy of his childhood in a French colony - he admits to being a fan of Jacques Tati's amiable buffoon Mr Hulot. And there is more than a hint of Hulot in Joly's bungling spies, forever trying to foist unlikely code words and manilla envelopes on passers-by. That perhaps best explains why Trigger Happy's whimsy is so appealing: it exists in its own childish world where violence is always cartoonish; leavened with enough surrealism to negate any sense of threat.

He's also refreshingly down-to-earth about his "c-list" celebrity status ("c-plus on a good day"): "It's partly because all this happened to me when I was 31 - if this had happened when I was 23 I'd be a nightmare. If go into a shop, everybody dives down thinking I'm going to pull out a phone. Even if I go to the gym, everybody thinks I've got a camera in the showers. People assume I'm pulling pranks 24 hours a day and that I'm really wacky. I'm so far from wacky. "

He says, that - apart from any one-off specials - this second series is the last. He'd rather end it before people tire of it. He's currently preparing a series of pilots for Channel 4, including a subversive fly-on-the-wall documentary, using all the invites to things like the openings of provincial nightclubs he gets sent. A kind of real-life Alan Partridge, he says.

At the end of the interview, I can't resist asking for a go on the mobile phone. He grabs a camera and takes a picture. "I'll send it to you," he says, as he escorts me to the lifts. But he can't resist a Trigger Happyesque parting shot as he walks away: "If you stitch me up, I'll draw a moustache on it first."

fields.headline: Brown warned over petrol hikes
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: As Britain braces itself for another round of fuel price increases, campaigners today warned the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that allowing pump prices to rise would be "political suicide" in the run up to the general election.
fields.body:
As Britain braces itself for another round of fuel price increases, campaigners today warned the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that allowing pump prices to rise would be "political suicide" in the run up to the general election.

The major companies and supermarkets were remaining tight-lipped today about their plans after oil giant Shell put up the price of petrol by a penny a litre.

Garry Russell, of the Dump the Pump campaign, described the situation as "horrendous".

He said: "This is going to bring the whole issue to the forefront again and it is going to highlight just how fragile things are.

"Obviously the government are going to use this and say it is the oil companies. But the level of taxation that is piled on top is a major issue. The government is making huge revenues and they are unlikely to do anything about it."

Brynle Williams, the fuel duty campaigner and north Wales farmer, said: "If Gordon Brown allows prices to go up it will be political suicide. Fuel is going to be very high on the agenda during the general election.

"I won't be leading the next fuel protest - the general public themselves will be," he added.

In announcing its price rise, Shell blamed the jump in the cost of crude oil for the increase which is being introduced in 800 of its 1,100 UK forecourts to bring them in line with the remaining 300 which saw a similar rise last week.

The move comes as the Petrol Retailers' Association warned that prices could rise by up to two pence a litre in the next few days.

Jonathan Akerman, a spokesman for the PRA, said: "What we are likely to see is a price rise of between one and two pence over the next three days, but before the general election it is unlikely that there will be further substantial price rises.

"Even if there are further rises, they will be small - of one or two pence again."

The Shell price rise has come after speculation that Monday's explosion at the Conoco plant near Immingham, north Lincolnshire, could add to the upwards pressure on petrol prices in the UK over the next month.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, announced a cut in the price of ultra low sulphur petrol (ULSP) of 2p a litre in the Budget last month.

With ULSP not yet available nationwide, the 2p cut was extended to unleaded petrol until June 14. Ultra low sulphur diesel was to come down by 3p a litre, it was announced.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union said: "The time has come for ministers to call the bluff of the oil barons. If the huge price increases that have been reported do materialise, they should immediately seize profits by slapping a windfall tax on the oil companies. The fuel guzzlers' greed has gone far enough."

The RAC foundation called on the chancellor to stabilise UK fuel prices by introducing a sliding scale of fuel duty which would fluctuate according to world prices.
