webTitle: Jonathan Watts on Japan's imperial heir

fields.headline: Rejoice! Rejoice!
fields.standfirst:
TV shows have been interrupted for urgent bulletins, newspapers are printing special editions and the prime minister is urging calm. What's the fuss? Japan's favourite princess is pregnant, and at last a gloomy nation has something to celebrate, reports Jonathan Watts

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: TV shows have been interrupted for urgent bulletins, newspapers are printing special editions and the prime minister is urging calm. What's the fuss? Japan's favourite princess is pregnant, and at last a gloomy nation has something to celebrate, reports Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
It is less than an inch long, weighs a mere 10th of an ounce and news of its existence - or its possible existence rather - was sprung on the world only two days ago. But Japan's imperial embryo already bears the hopes of a nation of 126m people, not to mention a 2,600-year-old dynasty.

Japan has been in a frenzy of excitement since Monday, when the imperial household agency - the Japanese equivalent of Buckingham Palace - made the long-awaited announcement that after eight childless years of marriage and a widely publicised miscarriage, crown princess Masako is "showing signs of pregnancy".

The palace and the prime minister are calling for calm: no confirmation will be made until ultrasound and other tests are made later this month. But this official caution has failed to contain an explosion of joy in a nation that has had little to celebrate during more than a decade of economic stagnation and political drift. Regular programmes have been interrupted for special pregnancy bulletins, newspapers have printed special editions and everyone from the man and woman in the street to retired imperial retainers and the princess' old school teachers has been interviewed for comment. Despite the pleas for quiet and respect, more than 100 journalists have staked out the home of Masako's parents, while television stations have broadcast images of a six to seven-week embryo.

That this is still considered relatively low-key coverage underlines just how much is riding on the production of an heir to the Chrysanthemum throne by the 37-year-old Masako and her 41-year-old husband, crown prince Naruhito. Japan's imperial family boasts the world's oldest unbroken royal line. According to the government, the current emperor, Akihito, is the 125th holder of a throne that stretches back to the Emperor Jimmu in 550BC. Ancient myths, which were taught as fact until just 50 years ago, trace his lineage to the sun goddess Amaterasu in the dawn of creation.

And, divine or not, this line is in danger of dying out. Under modern Japanese law, only a man can inherit the throne, but no boys have been born into the family since the birth of Naruhito's brother in 1965. This succession crisis has cast a darkening shadow over the lives of Naruhito and Masako since their marriage in 1993.

A popular match, it was initially hoped that Masako would not only produce an heir, but, like Diana, the late princess of Wales, help to modernise an institution that was seen as out of touch and out of date. The multilingual Oxford and Harvard-educated former diplomat was seen as an independent and internationally minded career woman who could complement the traditional role of her husband, who spent his time at Oxford studying 18th-century commodity transport on the Thames. Initially, the subject of babies was fended off with jokes. "I know the crown prince likes classical music," said Masako at a press conference to announce their engagement, "but I hope he won't expect me to produce an orchestra."

By stealing the limelight from her partner, however - an unforgivable act according to the male-orientated Confucian traditions of the imperial family - this witticism reportedly earned the princess-to-be a rebuke from palace retainers. After that, Masako deferred to her husband, almost never appeared in public alone, dressed more soberly and always walked demurely three steps behind him.

The couple's humorous rebuttals about children also became more strained. "The stork may be scared off by all the attention," Naruhito told reporters after the pressures of a childless first year of marriage began to tell.

Strict control of court reporting by the imperial household agency meant that questions on this touchy subject have almost never been voiced by the mainstream media since. It is clearly a matter of national pride. Earlier this year, the Japanese ambassador to Germany complained when the Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper published a picture of Naruhito with the caption "dead trousers" to suggest he was impotent.

But that has not stopped speculation by gossip magazines, which have splashed erroneous royal pregnancy headlines every time Masako has missed an appointment, put on a little weight or switched to flat-soled shoes.

There was no mistake, however, about a scoop by the Asahi newspaper in November 1999, which broke the news that Masako was expecting, just four weeks into the pregnancy. This led to a month-long media scrummage, the low point of which saw television crews in helicopters buzzing over a car carrying Masako to the gynaecologist. Her miscarriage a month later was partly blamed on the frenzy.

Similar fears have been expressed this time. "This is happy news," said the prime minister. Yoshiro Mori. "But I hope everyone will observe it quietly." Masako's father, Hisashi Owada, was equally cautious. "I am pleased, but also very worried," he said.

The Japanese media has acknowledged it was at fault before, but it remains to be seen how restrained it can be, given the immense public interest in the pregnancy.

"We take the criticism. However, we must say the coverage showed how strongly Japanese people wished for a baby," the conservative Sankei newspaper said in an editorial. "The birth of their baby will lighten up people's hearts amid depressing news ranging from economic recession to political uncertainty."

Expectations already appear to be outstripping reality. Although it is too early to be sure the pregnancy will go to term, speculation has already begun about whether the baby will be a boy or a girl, and the impact it will have on the economy and Japan's low birthrate.

The former question is of particular interest to feminists, who want to see a change in Japan's laws of succession to allow a woman to inherit the throne. There have been several precedents. Before the current rules were introduced in the last century, Japan had been ruled by 10 empresses, the last being Go-Sakuramachi, who abdicated in 1771. Last April, the imperial household agency considered the possibility of reverting to such a system in a study paper that assessed the options if no boys are born in future.

Of more immediate concern to the politicians and businessmen is the effect that an imperial baby might have on the birthrate. The average Japanese woman has just 1.34 children in her lifetime - one of the lowest rates in the world - which has raised fears about the nation's ability to maintain production and sustain its pension and health systems.

"I hope this will trigger a baby boom," said Junichiro Koizumi, one of the favourites to replace the outgoing Mori. "The Baby Boom of the Century," screamed a headline in the tabloid Sports Nippon newspaper.

On the day of the announcement, similar expectations pushed up shares in companies selling nappies and baby clothes by up to 50% on the Tokyo stock exchange. The yen also rose on the currency markets on forecasts that a feelgood factor generated by the royal birth would add 0.1 percentage points to the country's economy.

Forty years ago, such hopes might have been justified as the majority of the nation then had been brought up in the pre-war education system which taught that the imperial family were living gods. Today, however, that aura has largely worn off. It is far less likely that young women in Tokyo or Osaka will believe there is any good fortune to be had in having a child in the same year as a princess.

"I'm pleased for Masako after all she's been through, but it's no big deal to me personally," says Eriko Wada, a 23-year-old university student. "The imperial family don't really have anything to do with my life."

fields.headline: Bunker-busting US 'mini-nukes' alarm scientists
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Pentagon is examining the feasibility of producing a low-yield nuclear warhead capable of hitting deep fortified targets such as Saddam Hussein's underground bunkers.
fields.body:
The Pentagon is examining the feasibility of producing a low-yield nuclear warhead capable of hitting deep fortified targets such as Saddam Hussein's underground bunkers. But US scientists warned yesterday that "mini-nukes" would lower the threshold of nuclear war.

The Pentagon is due to report to the Senate in July in response to a Republican request to it and the energy department to find a way of destroying "hardened and deeply buried targets".

But a Pentagon spokesman insisted yesterday that work on mini-nukes had not yet begun.

"The 2001 defence authorisation bill authorises us to review the requirements for a weapon to use against hardened and deeply buried targets," Lieutenant-Colonel Steve Campbell said.

"There has been no research and development."

A 1994 law prohibits the US developing a nuclear warhead of less than 5 kilotonnes, lest "low-yield nuclear weapons blur the distinction between nuclear and conventional war".

The request by two Republican hawks, Senators John Warner and Wayne Allard, to find a way of destroying targets such as underground bunkers directly challenges that law. Testing a mini-nuke would breach the 1996 comprehensive test ban treaty, too.

There is thought to be support for developing such a weapon in the energy department's nuclear research laboratories and the Pentagon. An adviser to the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, told the Washington Post this week that President Saddam would not be deterred by any of the nuclear warheads in the US arsenal, "because he knows a US president would not drop a 100-kilotonne bomb on Baghdad".

In theory a mini-nuke missile released by a plane would point towards its target and fire its rocket motors, driving it deep underground. The weak nuclear charge would be exploded after a time-delay and the blast, supporters say, would be contained in the hole dug by the missile.

But a report by the Federation of American Scientists argues that the Earth-penetrating bombs now being tested have only penetrated 6 metres (20ft) below the surface. A nuclear blast at that depth, the report says, "will simply blow out a huge crater of radioactive material, creating a lethal gamma-radiation field over a large area".

Robert Sherman, head of the federation's nuclear security project, said: "We have gone 56 years without a nuclear weapon being used anywhere. There is universal recognition that once you use the first nuclear weapon it becomes a great deal easier for someone to use the second.

"Its incredibly stupid to think you can use a small nuclear weapon, cross the nuclear firebreak and get away from it.

"Trying to sell it on the rationale that it can be used without collateral damage and that will be the end of it ... is incredibly irresponsible."

webTitle: Art Malik on the Gujarat earthquake

fields.headline: After the quake
fields.standfirst:
It is three months since a massive earthquake hit western India, killing thousands. The actor Art Malik visited the region and was inspired by what he saw

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: It is three months since a massive earthquake hit western India, killing thousands. The actor Art Malik visited the region and was inspired by what he saw.
fields.body:
I was in the middle of deciding between two possible scripts, one for a play at the Donmar Warehouse, the other a major Hollywood movie with Joel Schumacher, when Jessica, my eldest daughter, handed me the fax. "Well," she said, "Now you can do something positive." The fax was from the British Red Cross asking me to travel to India to report on how people were coping in the wake of the massive earthquake that rocked the Kutch region of Gujarat on January 26.

I have only been in an earthquake once. I was filming True Lies when an earthquake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale struck Los Angeles in 1994. I felt the tremors hundreds of miles away in Las Vegas and a few days later, back in the city, I found myself standing in a doorway caught in an aftershock. It lasted perhaps 10 seconds but it was a terrifying experience. Despite causing an estimated $40bn in damage, someone arriving in the city soon after would never have known that the earthquake had hit.

But India isn't America and Bhuj certainly isn't LA. The earthquake that hit Gujarat measured 7.9 on the Richter scale, it left an estimated 30,000 dead, more than 150,000 injured and up to 1m people homeless.

What shocked me immediately when I arrived was to be surrounded, 360 degrees, by the destruction. Hollywood set designers would pay millions to achieve this look. The scale of the disaster was overwhelming.

We drove to the Red Cross camp from Bhuj's military airport. There were piles of rubble everywhere. Huge cracks snaked across walls of the buildings still standing, broken masonry balanced precariously and some structures were leaning at alarming angles. Bulldozers tore away at unstable buildings. Tents had been pitched on the edges of the debris, many by people whose homes were at least partially intact but who were too scared to sleep inside.

Walking through the maze of Bhuj's old streets I could see the remains of brilliant architecture. There was the ruins of a house with furniture and personal belongings still inside. A calendar hung from what could have once been a kitchen, still open at the January page. The streets were quiet, no one lived in this old part of the city any more and the shutters were firmly down on businesses that will never reopen. I had to remember to walk in the middle of the narrow streets to avoid being hit by any falling stonework.

Bhuj's hospital was razed to the ground by the earthquake. In its absence, a 350-bed field hospital set up by the Finnish and Norwegian Red Cross has become the city's general hospital. Nearly 500 operations had taken place and more than 150 babies born. The 32 separate tents that hold 15 wards, a maternity unit, an operating theatre, labs and x-ray facilities were an impressive sight.

When the earthquake struck, a school that should have been empty in Tapur, a small village outside Bhuj, was filled with 151 people as they celebrated Republic Day, an Indian national holiday. If I'd lost my family I don't know if I could stay in the area, I don't know if I could rebuild my home or walk past the site where they'd died.

On my last day I visited where it all began: the epicentre of the earthquake, about 30km north of Bhuj. I met an eyewitness, Ismail ali Mohammed, who told me that he was driving his truck delivering sugar cane vegetation when the earthquake struck. Suddenly, just yards away, there was a huge geyser of water shooting 50ft in the air; dust was everywhere and it became very dark. He thought it was the end of the world. Now the epicentre is marked by a large hole, still filled with salt water and still gently bubbling in the middle of a barren, dusty plain. It wasn't what I was expecting, there were no great angry fissures streaking off to wreak their deadly havoc.

It was heartening to see how much India has achieved in such a short period of time. But the test for everyone will be the next stage - the rehabilitation and rebuilding of hundreds of thousands of homes, schools and hospitals. It will take at least four to five years. And it is not just the bricks and mortar that need to be fixed. The Red Cross will be implementing a programme offering emotional support and crisis counselling for people struggling to cope with the psychological impact of the disaster.

When I left London to travel to India, Britain was gripped by crises. Foot and mouth disease, a predicted recession, bad weather and a train crash combined to create a sense of national gloom. But in Gujarat there was no such collective mood of despair. I didn't meet anyone who thought of themselves as a victim. Maybe it's cultural, maybe it's religious, maybe it's just the way it is, the people have no choice but to get on with things as best they can. But whatever it is that's inside them, fatalism or the belief that their lives are in the hands of a higher spirit, it seems that even if you take everything away, there's still something left: their belief in themselves.

fields.headline: Corporate rule
fields.standfirst:
Democracy is in hock to an idea of economic and technical progress that ignores people's true concerns

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Democracy is in hock to an idea of economic and technical progress that ignores people's true concerns.
fields.body:
On the big issues of the day, three virtually identical political parties will be competing at the forthcoming general election. There are, of course, differences between them. But we live in an age of dangerous consensus, in which every mainstream party supports the same model of deregulated corporate economics that renders their differences virtually irrelevant.

All, for instance, regard attracting "foreign direct investment" as a prime economic goal, and it is through flirting with big business that they hope to achieve it. Yet just 100 companies control more than a third of all such investments, with the result that we are experiencing a global "race to the bottom" - a lowering of every conceivable standard in an international contest for corporate affections. What we are seeing, in fact, is the hijacking of democracy by business - and one result is the death of choice for us all.

Such globalisation centralises power in the hands of vast multinational companies which increasingly dominate politics. It is this system which homogenises cultures and places, kills off local businesses, leads to increased traffic and pollution as its goods are transported across the world, destroys local democracy, and ravages the environment.

Yet nowhere in the electoral debates will we see discussion or even acknowledgement of the biggest problems that confront us today. The future of the environment, for example, will merit barely a whisper. Climate change, pollution, the cancer epidemic, the centralisation of economic power by fewer and fewer corporations, the death of the high street: these are issues that confront ordinary people every day, yet politicians rarely mention them.

Why? Probably because to do so would necessitate an examination of the root causes - the global economic system that all parties unquestioningly support.

Last weekend the Guardian released some of the results of a sweeping opinion poll commissioned by the Ecologist magazine. Combined, the results are astonishing, and will shock our political leaders. A striking pattern emerged. For one only had to wonder how each of the main political parties would respond to the questions asked to understand how very wide has the gulf between politicians and the public become. The people have spotted this - and they are way ahead of the politicians.

Most people (87%), for instance, would like to see measures applied which would protect small producers from corporate predators - a practice that is currently illegal under the rules of the World Trade Organisation, which all three parties endorse.

A huge majority of respondents (89%) would prefer to buy British food if it were available - which is at odds with the political consensus that increased international trade is our nation's primary objective.

Almost half of all respondents (49%) believe advances in science and technology will harm more than they will benefit society - a view at odds with the government's massive investment in biotechnology and obsession with technological "progress".

On other issues, too, the public want action taken that no major party seems prepared to deliver. For instance, 77% believe there is a clear link between the devastating floods last year and climate change. To that end, 61% believe our money should be spent on alternatives to roads, and 72% believe the rail networks should be renationalised.

Yet this, too, fails to match up to the policies of either Labour or the Conservatives, the former having pledged to invest less into renewable energies than it recently invested into a single giant incinerator.

Asked if the government should spend more on researching organic agriculture than it spends on biotechnology, 66% agreed. Only 7% felt biotechnology should receive more. As things stand today, organic food research is allocated a mere 2% of the total budget, while biotechnology receives 30%. Furthermore, nearly half (45%) of those questioned want a complete ban on the import, testing and sale of all genetically modified products.

What is also clear from these results is the astonishing lack of trust with which people view their leaders. More than half (54%) would like to see an end to the corporate purchase of our political system. Still more (72%) do not believe the government when it assures the public that something is safe. And 73% would like to remove big decision-making from government altogether, with the use of national referendums.

This is not the picture of a people satisfied with the manner in which their taxes are being spent and their futures dictated, but rather a public with a healthy scepticism towards politicians, corporations and even the current definition of "progress". Rather, it is a picture of a public that cares a lot about issues that don't even appear on the radar screens of most politicians - and a public that wants something done about them.

 Zac Goldsmith is editor of the Ecologist magazine

webTitle: Fate of flag stirs Mississippi voters to have their say

fields.headline: Fate of flag stirs Mississippi voters to have their say
fields.standfirst: Business groups drive campaign to ditch 'symbol of racism'
fields.trailText: Voters in Mississippi seem likely to have kept the "southern cross" battle emblem of the Confederacy flying on their state flag despite a drive by local businesses and black groups to replace it with a less divisive symbol.
fields.body:
Voters in Mississippi seem likely to have kept the "southern cross" battle emblem of the Confederacy flying on their state flag despite a drive by local businesses and black groups to replace it with a less divisive symbol.

The turnout in a referendum yesterday was reported to be heavy as up to 2m voters decided whether to remain the only one of the 50 US states to give a prominent place to the civil war "rebel" flag or follow other southern states in consigning the emblem to history.

"It's really heavy here this morning," said Barbara Dunn an election official in Hinds county, north of the state capital, Jackson.

"Some of my people tell me they've had to wait in line, and one person said that when he left his precinct a little after 7am there were a hundred people lined up to vote."

Supporters of a new state flag want the southern cross, which has occupied the top lefthand quarter of the flag since 1894, replaced by a circular design of 20 stars, marking Mississippi's position as the 20th state to join the union in 1817.

The governor, Ronnie Musgrove, voted for the new flag in Jackson.

The referendum was "an opportunity to remove any obstacle that would stand in the way of bringing good jobs to our state", he told reporters.

But opinion polls suggested that a clear majority of voters wanted to keep the old flag. An Associated Press poll at the beginning of April showed three-to-one support for the present design.

White voters, who make up two-thirds of the state's population, were opposed to change by four to one, the poll found.

Black voters favoured change by more than two to one, but a significant minority supported the old emblem.

The campaign was marked by an unusual alliance in favour of the new flag between mainly white business leaders and local and national black groups.

Local black churches made a major last-minute effort in the final week to overcome voter apathy.

Black civil rights groups such as the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People ran dozens of adverts on local black radio stations in the final days of the campaign.

But the biggest pressure for change came from business interests anxious to send a signal around the US and beyond that their state is ready and willing to enter the global economy.

They invested more than $750,000 (£520,000) in the campaign for the new flag, outspending the defenders of the old flag by more than five to one.

Groups such as the Mississippi Economic Council - the local equivalent of a chamber of commerce - led the campaign for the new flag, along with bankers and property development interests.

The former president of the Netscape internet browser corporation, Jim Barksdale, a native of Mississippi, played a prominent role financing the change campaign.

Advocates of change say that the southern cross is a symbol of racism and segregation and a standing insult to black Americans in Mississippi and beyond.

But supporters say the old flag is a statement of "southern heritage" and ancestral pride which should remain in place.

In the past year state legislatures in Georgia and South Carolina have taken action to reduce the profile of the southern cross Confederate emblem on state flags and buildings.

The Mississippi legislature decided against taking a similar decision itself, preferring to leave the issue to the voters.

fields.headline: Crackdown on abuse by priests
fields.standfirst:
Every Roman Catholic parish may get child protection coordinator

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church was told yesterday that it must appoint child protection representatives in every parish in England and Wales to head off the wave of criticism that has broken over the church after a series of high-profile abuse cases involving clergy.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church was told yesterday that it must appoint child protection representatives in every parish in England and Wales to head off the wave of criticism that has broken over the church after a series of high-profile abuse cases involving clergy.

Even closed religious orders will be required to select protection coordinators as part of a 50-point strategy recommended by an independent committee headed by Lord Nolan, the man who laid down standards for parliament. Everyone working in the church - staff, volunteers and clergy - will be subject to police checks and all applicants will be asked to disclose details of any criminal offences against children and young people.

The 35-page report represents an all but unprecedented, wide-ranging secular assault on the practices of a church where bishops and clergy have traditionally had unquestioned authority.

Lord Nolan told a press conference in London: "The care of children is at the forefront of the teachings of Christ. We believe that the Catholic church in England and Wales should become an example of best practice in the prevention of child abuse and in responding to it.

"Our overriding aim has been to create a secure environment for children. We also want to ensure a consistent and effective approach across the church to allegations of child abuse."

The review is intended to supersede guidelines in place since 1994, which proved ineffective. They were brought into question last year when Archbishop John Ward of Cardiff was seen to have ignored warnings from a fellow bishop in ordaining a priest, Father Joe Jordan, who was subsequently jailed for eight years for indecent assaults against children.

It remained unclear how far the new recommendations would be accepted, although Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, leader of the church in England and Wales, has pledged that they will be adopted when bishops meet in London next week.

Yesterday he said cautiously that the "extremely constructive and helpful" report would form a main item for discussion. "We are committed to ensuring that the Catholic church becomes the safest of places for children and I am sure this report ... will help us to achieve this."

The cardinal came under attack last year for his action as bishop of Arundel and Brighton in the 1980s in moving Father Michael Hill, a priest accused of sexual abuse, from one parish to another and eventually to a chaplaincy at Gatwick airport, where he assaulted a child with learning disabilities. Hill was jailed for five years in 1997 after being convicted of assaults over a 19-year period. He is now free.

The review was set up last autumn to head off criticisms that the church had tolerated abuse by priests and had too often appeared more concerned to protect its clergy than those they were abusing.

Between 1995 and 1999, 21 Catholic priests were convicted of sexual offences against children, two were tried but acquitted, 10 charged but subsequently had the charges dropped, 63 investigated but never charged and six given a police caution.

The review recommends that a national database be set up on all candidates for ordination, that allegations be responded to swiftly, and that cautioned or convicted abusers should not hold any position bringing them into contact with children. It also proposes more pastoral provision to help victims and support parishes.

The report says priests must not give away confidences heard at confession. All new confessionals will have to be constructed so that both priest and parishioner remain visible, if not audible, to those outside.

Even closed religious orders will be required to select protection coordinators as part of a 50-point strategy recommended by an independent committee headed by Lord Nolan, the man who laid down standards for parliament. Everyone working in the church - staff, volunteers and clergy - will be subject to police checks and all applicants will be asked to disclose details of any criminal offences against children and young people. We believe that the Catholic church in England and Wales should become an example of best practice in the prevention of child abuse and in responding to it. "Our overriding aim has been to create a secure environment for children. We also want to ensure a consistent and effective approach across the church to allegations of child abuse." The review is intended to supersede guidelines in place since 1994, which proved ineffective. They were brought into question last year when Archbishop John Ward of Cardiff was seen to have ignored warnings from a fellow bishop in ordaining a priest, Father Joe Jordan, who was subsequently jailed for eight years for indecent assaults against children. It remained unclear how far the new recommendations would be accepted, although Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, leader of the church in England and Wales, has pledged that they will be adopted when bishops meet in London next week. Yesterday he said cautiously that the "extremely constructive and helpful" report would form a main item for discussion. fields.headline: Therapeutic hideaway for wayward priests
fields.standfirst:
Discreet clinic treats gays, paedophiles and alcoholics
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Our Lady of Victory near Stroud, Gloucestershire, is one institution where errant Roman Catholic priests have long been sent for rehabilitation. Built on a terrace in a picturesque valley with lawns sloping down to woods, it has the appearance more of a Cotswold manor house than a clinic.
fields.body:
Our Lady of Victory near Stroud, Gloucestershire, is one institution where errant Roman Catholic priests have long been sent for rehabilitation. Built on a terrace in a picturesque valley with lawns sloping down to woods, it has the appearance more of a Cotswold manor house than a clinic.

But in the lecture hall and consulting rooms, alcoholic, gay and paedophile clergymen are offered counselling and support.

These are problems acknowledged quietly by some Catholic priests to be exacerbated by the solitary, often lonely, and celibate life of the priesthood.

Celibacy is a discipline imposed by the church, rather than by a theological imperative, and therefore one that might one day be changed, if the shortage of priests becomes sufficiently pressing.

In Britain the church accepted more than 100 married Anglican priests for ordination some years ago when they fell out with the Church of England over its decision to ordain women.

Of more concern to some in the Catholic church is the fear that increasing numbers of priests are gay. A book by an American theologian last year estimated that as many as 50% of young US ordinands were homosexual.

Being gay is still viewed as a scandal and a sin and hence a suitable reason for treatment and rehabilitation at centres such as Stroud.

But when it comes to child abuse, the church has for many years been in denial - that the problem exists and is intractable in sufferers, and that it is something that requires firm action. This has inhibited the church from tackling it, rather than just reacting to individual cases and occasionally buying off complainants.

Even though it has had guidelines in place since 1994, some clergy have been slow to acknowledge or accept them. In a deeply hierarchical church, there is a limit to what outside agencies can do.

When Archbishop John Ward of Cardiff was found last year to have ignored the guidelines - and even a warning from a fellow bishop - in ordaining a priest subsequently convicted of child abuse, there was nothing the church could do to censure him, other than calling him in for a carpeting by the papal nuncio in London.

The recommendations of the Nolan review will at least focus the hierarchy's attention on the principle that the needs of children are paramount, rather than protecting the good name of the church. But there are still unanswered questions about how priests can be disciplined - or protected from bogus allegations.

The clinic, often referred to as Stroud, is run by an American order, the Servants of the Paraclete, established in New Mexico in the 1940s. The order opened Our Lady of Victory, its only British centre, in the 1960s. The clinic offers "therapy in a spiritual context".

It is believed that up to 30 residents stay there, usually for a year to 18 months. They tend to be referred by their bishops or other senior clergy.

Michael Hill, the priest jailed for five years in 1997 for indecent assaults on children, was once there but left after three months. He was appointed chaplain at Gatwick in the 1980s by Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, now Archbishop of Westminster but then bishop of Arundel and Brighton, despite complaints that he had been a risk to children.

The centre has attracted criticism. An assistant priest who spent a week there after it was discovered that he was a practising homosexual compared it to "purgatory" complaining of the "gross invasion of privacy, the lack of freedom of movement and the oppressive, claustrophobic atmosphere".

It hit the headlines in 1993 when Father Sean Seddon, 38, was sent there after a six-year affair with a teacher. On learning his lover had lost their baby, he threw himself under a train.

Institutions such as Our Lady of Victory are apparently becoming less popular. The tendency is for priests to be treated in secular organisations.

Yesterday nobody at the centre was available for comment.

Sex attacks

Between 1995 and 1999, 21 Catholic priests were convicted of sexual offences against children. Reported sex cases include:

 1996: Durham priest Adrian McLeish jailed for six years after admitting 12 charges of child abuse

 1997: Michael Hill, a former Gatwick chaplain, jailed for five years for indecent assault and gross indecency over a 19-year period

 1998: Eric Taylor jailed for seven years for abusing boys in his care at the Father Hudson Society's home in Warwickshire, between 1957 and 1965

 1998: John Lloyd , press officer to the Archbishop of Cardiff, jailed for eight years for indecent assaults against children

 2000: Joe Jordan , a Cardiff priest, jailed for eight years for sexually abusing boys

 2000: Investigation at a leading Catholic school, the London Oratory . Pupils alleged they were abused by David Martin , a priest who died of a suspected Aids-related illness in 1998

 2000: Robert Deadman , a Cistercian monk who offered spiritual healing to women, convicted of indecently assaulting four women. The jury heard he carried out attacks in the confessional

 2001: Allegations of torture, beatings and sexual molestation at St Ninian's school in Stirlingshire

webTitle: Report of £1m offer per Concorde victim

fields.headline: Report of £1m offer per Concorde victim
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Faced with the threat of legal action in the United States over last year's Concorde disaster, Air France has made a record-breaking compensation offer, a lawyer for the victims' relatives claimed yesterday.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
Faced with the threat of legal action in the United States over last year's Concorde disaster, Air France has made a record-breaking compensation offer, a lawyer for the victims' relatives claimed yesterday.

Ninety-six of the 113 people who died in the crash were Germans going to New York to join a Caribbean cruise when the jet crashed shortly after take-off from Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris.

The German newspaper Die Welt yesterday reported that the airline had given the families until the end of this week to accept or reject an offer of DM300m, roughly equivalent to £1m for each victim.

Such a figure - more than double previous estimates - would make it the biggest compensation payment ever made in Germany.

A spokesman for Réunion Aérienne, the insurers for Air France, confirmed that, "A serious offer was made about a week ago." But the spokesman added: "Neither the deadline nor the sum mentioned by Die Welt are correct."

Ronald Schmid of the Berlin law firm representing most of the victims' relatives was reported as telling Die Welt: "It is already certain that it will be a compensation payment such as has never been paid out in Germany."

Professor Schmid and his partners had warned Air France that they would take their claim to the US courts if a satisfactory offer were not made. Settlements of this kind are normally much higher in the US than in Europe.

Lawyers for Réunion Aérienne said last week that the families of four victims might not be included in a compensation deal because they have already started legal action against Air France in the US.

No Air France or British Airways Concorde has returned to commercial service since the crash on July 25.

fields.headline: Illuminator raiders write off start-ups
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Illuminator, set up as incubator fund for new technology firms by corporate raiders Julian Treger and Brian Myerson, has written off all its investments in dot.coms as a result of turmoil in the sector.
fields.body:
Illuminator, set up as incubator fund for new technology firms by corporate raiders Julian Treger and Brian Myerson, has written off all its investments in dot.coms as a result of turmoil in the sector.

The write-offs amount to £270,000 - which, according to Mr Treger, might be a conservative estimate but means Illuminator has "got off very lightly".

The decision, announced yesterday as Illuminator reported a £15m operating loss, leaves the company with £10.6m of investments in Clear Technology, Trademet Limited and an investment in a fund known as Puma II.

The group defended its decision to "keep money in the bank" by highlighting some of the spectacular collapses of dot.com start-ups in recent months. It described its £9m cash balance as "strong".

Started in 1999 with a view to nurturing new technology firms, Illuminator is in the process of setting up a new fund to take stakes, or completely take over, companies feeling the strain of the dot.com downturn.

Mr Treger said the so-called TechRescue Fund hoped to attract £25m to invest during its first round of fund raising, some £5m of which will come from Illuminator.

"The TechRescue fund aims to take advantage of the market anomalies and negative investor sentiment towards the internet and technology sectors," Mr Treger said.

He is better known, along with Mr Myerson, for their company Active Value, which has shaken up a number of "old economy" companies including Liberty.

Illuminator's £15m operating loss was largely due to the accounting methods used when it merged with MultiMedia last year with the intention of setting up the TechRescue fund. That ultimately aims to raise as much £100m for investors.

Mr Treger said he disliked being regarded as a "raider". Rather, he said, in the "old and new economies you fund undervalued situations".

webTitle: Connex threat to misery lines deal

fields.headline: Connex threat to misery lines deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Government plans to relieve the misery for thousands of rail passengers who travel into London each day by transferring Connex's franchise were under threat last night.
fields.body:
Government plans to relieve the misery for thousands of rail passengers who travel into London each day by transferring Connex's franchise were under threat last night.

The troubled French controlled rail operator disclosed that it could pull out of a planned deal with a competitor designed to improve travelling conditions for commuters.

Olivier Brousse, Connex's managing director said it might back out of a promise to hand over its seven-year franchise to Govia, appointed by the government's strategic rail authority.

Mr Brousse told the Guardian: "We have been in intense negotiations with Govia for several months, but have made little progress. Unless the negotiations are finalised by June, we will continue to run the franchise until it expires in 2003."

Mr Brousse said there would be no point in handing over the franchise after June because Connex would be involved in pay negotiations and had to take a decision on buying winter uniforms for thousands of staff. "These are expensive items, but the most important consideration must be the well-being of our employees, who are enduring a period of much uncertainty."

The big sticking point between the companies is compensation. Connex wants millions of pounds for giving up its franchise two years early, but Govia has not been prepared to meet Connex's demands, explained a Connex source. "It falls far short of what we are looking for."

Neither company was prepared to discuss the figure in volved. Govia said: "These are sensitive commercial negotiations, although we are still hopeful of reaching a sensible agreement."

Govia was awarded a new 20-year franchise by the SRA after widespread public criticism of Connex's performance. Its trains were often late and dirty and pressure mounted on the SRA to act.

Connex, which is owned by the French multi-national Vivendi, has promised not to run down its services but to hand over to Govia in an orderly manner.

Govia is 35% owned by a subsidiary of the French state railway, SNCF, and by transport company Go Ahead, with a 65% stake.

The collapse of the deal would pose a big problem for the government and the SRA. It highlights the difficulties of the re-franchising process when the price is not right and companies are reluctant to hand over control. In these circumstances, the government is powerless to act.

Connex is anxious to maintain its position as one of Britain's largest train operators. The franchise covers the south central commuter belt stretching from London to Brighton, taking in most of Surrey and parts of Sussex.

The company also holds the southeast franchise stretching from central London to the Kent coast. This runs out in 2011. The company's performance is often criticised for lack of punctuality, in common with the south central franchise. In spite of its setbacks, Connex is bidding for the important trans-Pennine franchise linking Sheffield with Manchester and Manchester airport, regarded in the industry as potentially one of the fastest growing lines.

fields.headline: Silencing Russia's media
fields.standfirst:
Mr Blair should not keep quiet

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: First went the TV station. On Monday the newspaper closed and yesterday the best of Russia's independent news magazines lost its staff.
fields.body:
First went the TV station. On Monday the newspaper closed and yesterday the best of Russia's independent news magazines lost its staff. Three strikes and Vladimir Gusinsky, the man who created NTV, Segodnya and Itogi, is out. The blow to critical journalism in Russia is immense. The impression that Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, is even more prickly than his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, is hard to avoid.

Mr Gusinsky, it is true, is not a man of the highest principle. Like most Russian oligarchs, he made his money opaquely and by knowing the right people in power. During the flawed 1996 presidential election, he used his media empire for blatant pro-Kremlin propaganda. But he was never as slavishly subservient as other tycoons and he allowed his TV channel to probe Kremlin scandals, as well as raise uncomfortable questions about the two Chechen wars.

His company fell into debt, allowing his partner, the pro-government monopoly Gazprom, to exert control and install new management. In sacking staff, the new team claims it is only motivated by commercial considerations. But contrast the treatment of Mr Gusinsky, who is in Spain fighting Russian efforts to have him indicted on corruption charges, with that of Pavel Borodin, the former Kremlin property chief, who is facing similar charges in Switzerland. While Mr Gusinsky is eagerly sought by Moscow's state-appointed prosecutors, the Russian government is happy to find bail to get Mr Borodin free.

It would be naive to think that in this crisis Tony Blair would rush to defend press freedom in Russia. On his last visit to Moscow he refused to be interviewed on Ekho Moskvy, the Gusinsky-owned radio station, for fear of upsetting President Putin. But executive spin in Russia has a far grimmer history than in Britain, and even as controlling a personality as Mr Blair should be worried about what is going on there, and say so.

webTitle: Millennium Dome dancers form circus company

fields.headline: One fantastic gamble
fields.standfirst:
The survivors of the Millennium Dome's glossy live show have formed their own circus company. Lyn Gardner reports

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The survivors of the Millennium Dome's glossy live show have formed their own circus company. Lyn Gardner reports.
fields.body:
Once rubbish was burned here to generate energy. I am at the building that served as the combustion chamber for the old Shoreditch Electricity Company. Over the entrance is the legend: "From dust comes light." So it may prove next week when a new British circus outfit, the Generating Company, performs its first show, Storm, in the 180ft-high building.

It will be up to this company, which hopes to develop a show to rival the success of circuses such as Cirque de Soleil and Circus Oz, to prove that good things can indeed come out of trash. Almost everyone involved in the project was also involved in the Millennium Dome's central attraction, a lowest-common-denominator crowd-pleaser. With its death-defying bungee jumps, it owed more to Don't Try This at Home than to theatre.

The Dome Show may have been pap, but that is not to say that those involved don't have talent. If the Dome has any lasting legacy, it is the 80 or so young performers who were trained to perform in it. Storm includes 20 of them as performers and artistic directors. They hope to silence those critics of the Dome training project who argued that once the attraction closed most of the young performers would find themselves in the dole queue.

As Paul Cockle, former production manager of the Dome Show and now the producer for Storm, says: "There has been a lot of paranoia in the circus industry. A lot of people have been saying that there are already too many performers and we must stop training. But I think that if there isn't the work to go round, we simply have to create it."

Getting this show together hasn't been easy. Cockle and his team, which includes Pierrot Bidon, who has worked with Archaos, and rock concert designer Mark Fisher, originally had plans for a big stadium show. Cockle would have liked to open at Wembley Arena, or better still the Albert Hall, where Cirque de Soleil performed for a number of years.

Cockle seems much enamoured of this bland Canadian company, which has created a brand and turned over millions. But to stage a show in the Albert Hall Cockle reckoned he would need £1.5m. Perhaps unsurprisingly, no independent producer could be convinced to give that kind of money to a company with no track record. Instead, Storm is being mounted on a budget of around £100,000, the bulk of which comes from an investment grant from the National Endowment Fund for Science, Technology and the Arts.

This small budget may prove to be the show's salvation. Everyone involved with the mounting of the Dome Show signed a confidentiality agreement that prevents them from disclosing how much it cost, but at a conference last year one member of the team let slip that you could have bought "15 villas in Notting Hill" for the same money. If that is correct, the Dome Show probably cost far more than The Lion King, which, at £10m, is the most expensive stage musical ever mounted.

Without piles of money, the Generating Company will be forced to come up with artistic solutions rather than rely on spectacle. The suggestion is that the largely aerial-based piece will have all the skill of some of the big international circuses, but also intimacy and a sense of character. Former actor Sean Kempton, a Generating Company performer and artistic director, says that the company approaches the trapeze in the way an actor approaches a piece of text. "Just as an actor you try to find the relationship between your character and the script, here we try to find the same relationship between the character and the equipment. With the Dome Show we did spectacle for a year; now we want to connect with an audience. Storm has always been more of a theatrical proposition than a circus proposition. We are trying to get away from the idea of the circus act."

If this proves to be the case, Storm could be a breakthrough for British circus, which, with rare exceptions, is still struggling to throw off its sawdust image and embrace character, narrative and metaphor. But the real difficulty facing the Generating Company is that the great circus-based companies, such as Circus Oz and De La Guarda, were involved in theatre before they turned to the circus. Each grew organically, developing their identity and dynamic over a period of years. Unlike them, the Generating Company will have just one chance to prove itself. Unless Storm succeeds at the box office the company simply won't be able to do another show. The economics of British circus allow for no safety nets.

 Storm is at the Combustion Chamber at the Circus Space, London N1 (020-7316 4740), until May 12, then tours to Manchester, Glasgow, Newcastle, Henley and York.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: On the contents page of Weekend Guardian, April 14, the photographs of John Atkinson and Thomas Rees were unfortunately transposed. It was Thomas Rees who joined the horse race on the steppes, page 32; John Atkinson was featured in the piece on self-advocacy pressure groups for those with learning difficulties, page 20, and has, sadly, died since the article was commissioned.
fields.body:
On the contents page of Weekend Guardian, April 14, the photographs of John Atkinson and Thomas Rees were unfortunately transposed. It was Thomas Rees who joined the horse race on the steppes, page 32; John Atkinson was featured in the piece on self-advocacy pressure groups for those with learning difficulties, page 20, and has, sadly, died since the article was commissioned.

The former Tory prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, was wrongly credited with the privatisation of our railways, Public rebuffs Blair on food safety, page 1, April 14. In fact it was John Major's government that did the deed, despite some backbenchers warning that it would be a "poll tax on wheels". A white paper was published in May 1992, Railtrack was floated on the stock exchange in May 1996, and the process was completed a few weeks before the general election in 1997.

In our report of the weekend's disturbances, Pubs and cars wrecked in Bradford riot, page 4, April 17, we said that violence had escalated after a group of white and Afro-Caribbean youths had "turned over a bus". In fact, the fighting in the neighbourhood began as a result of them being turned off the bus. The misinterpretation is entirely ours.

In Hollywood rushes movies to beat deadline for strike, page 15, April 17, we said "the studios have stockpiled enough movies to see them through 2002 and possibly into 2203". It couldn't happen, not even in Hollywood.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: GSK directors share £13.9m
fields.body:
GSK directors share £13.9m

GlaxoSmithKline's 28-strong team of top executives took home a total of £13.9m last year, according to the newly merged drugs company's first annual report.

Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier received £2.54m, including £461,000 from exercising share options. His promotion to the top job brought a 40% rise in his basic salary to £820,000.

Sir Richard Sykes, who stood back to take a non-executive role at the end of the year, received a £708,000 bonus in a total pay package of £2.21m.

There were seven-figure payoffs for three directors who lost their jobs in the merger: James Cochrane and Jeremy Strachan of Glaxo Wellcome, and Andrew Bonfield of SmithKline Beecham.

Corus rejects rescue plan

Steel union leaders yesterday expressed dismay after their plan to save hundreds of jobs at a plant earmarked for closure was rejected.

Workers at the Lackenby plate mill on Teesside will hold a mass meeting on Friday to decide their next move. The Iron and Steel Trades Confederation said its proposals were rejected by steel firm Corus after the latest in a series of meetings.

ISTC official Tony Poynter said: "We are absolutely gutted. We have talked seriously about alternatives to closure but we feel we have been strung along by the company. They are simply not listening to their workforce."

The Lackenby jobs are part of the 6,000 being shed by Corus at plants across the country. Talks will be held with the company on Thursday about union plans to save jobs at Llanwern in south Wales.

Marconi moves medical unit

Telecoms equipment maker Marconi is moving its medical systems business into a division that has included companies earmarked for disposal.

Marconi would not comment on a report that it planned to raise up to £1.5bn by selling the business, which makes imaging equipment and healthcare data systems. Marconi Medical Systems will become part of Marconi Capital, a spokeswoman told Reuters.

Edison writes off $2.5bn

Edison International, parent of California utility Southern California Edison, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $2.55bn, including an after-tax charge of $2.5bn.

The write-off relates to costs incurred buying power for customers which it may be unable to recoup under California's much-criticised electricity market deregulation laws. The company announced in late March it might take an after-tax charge of as much as $2.7bn.

This month the utility announced it had reached an agreement with California governor Gray Davis which it hopes will keep it out of bankruptcy.

Pru calls off US legal action

Prudential confirmed yesterday that it no longer needed to press ahead with its attempts to pursue AIG in a Texan court over its rival bid for American General because AIG had filed the necessary documentation with American regulators.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • What a delight to read the musings of Adair Turner, former director general of the CBI, who - adopting a tone of of gleeful superiority that only hindsight can inspire - launches a savage attack in this month's Prospect magazine on New Labour's fascination with the "new" economy. "It is the hankering for a non-political politics which made the e-economy such a beguiling theme," Mr Turner explains, "an opportunity to escape difficult physical and distributional issues, focusing instead on the delusion of a conflict-free modernity." Perceptive analysis which will, no doubt, strike a chord with Mr Turner's successor at the CBI, Digby Jones. Next month Mr Jones is to host a conference entitled Doing the Unthinkable (the weak of heart should avoid searching for this one on the web) at which business leaders will be addressed by such "visionaries and mavericks" of the dot.com world as Lastminute.com chairman Allan Leighton and Julie Meyer, co-founder of networking club First Tuesday. Isn't it wonderful to see the CBI anticipating the needs of its members so well?
fields.body:
 What a delight to read the musings of Adair Turner, former director general of the CBI, who - adopting a tone of of gleeful superiority that only hindsight can inspire - launches a savage attack in this month's Prospect magazine on New Labour's fascination with the "new" economy. "It is the hankering for a non-political politics which made the e-economy such a beguiling theme," Mr Turner explains, "an opportunity to escape difficult physical and distributional issues, focusing instead on the delusion of a conflict-free modernity." Perceptive analysis which will, no doubt, strike a chord with Mr Turner's successor at the CBI, Digby Jones. Next month Mr Jones is to host a conference entitled Doing the Unthinkable (the weak of heart should avoid searching for this one on the web) at which business leaders will be addressed by such "visionaries and mavericks" of the dot.com world as Lastminute.com chairman Allan Leighton and Julie Meyer, co-founder of networking club First Tuesday. Isn't it wonderful to see the CBI anticipating the needs of its members so well?

 Hats off to Vodafone! We were delighted to read that the world's largest wireless company chose the Thames Valley across which to conduct its first live 3G telephone conversation - a year before the company expects to roll out the technology to the rest of Britain. (Vodafone's press release does not reveal the content of this landmark communication but it is understood a short verse was penned in preparation, titled I'm On The Train). Meanwhile, from Newbury, where Vodafone's headquarters are located, the Diary hears an allegation that staff are having trouble with reception signals on their mobile phones. A call to Vodafone's help desk confirms that, while the company claims 99% coverage of Britain, there are weaknesses in some suburbs of the town. Problems in the town centre "could be to do with building structures, and nothing to do with coverage provided by Vodafone". The investigation continues.

 A letter that landed in our in-tray over the Easter break causes much excitement. "Only an elite corps of top managers gets a chance to subscribe to Harvard Business Review," it reminds us. "And with this letter I am pleased to extend the invitation to you." At last, we are to take our place among an elite corps of "business achievers". "In HBR," the letter promises, "you will learn to hone your leadership skills; to motivate people; set agendas; shape management practice; and stimulate innovation ... You owe yourself a look." Indeed we do - and so, of course, do our readers. We telephone HBR to take up the subscription offer and are assured our first copy of this intriguing journal - sure to be a regular point of reference for this column - is on its way. Among highlights of April's issue, we understand, are a thoughtful commentary on "The real boundaries of the 'boundaryless' organisation, and an essay on "How Nike designs emotion into its shoes". More from the HBR soon.

 Our attention is drawn to an unconventional attempt to heal diplomatic relations between the US and its most-favoured trading nation, China, after the crew of the American spy plane returned home last week. A number of apparently over-enthusiastic US patriots have besieged a website set up to commemorate Wang Wei, the Chinese pilot who lost his life in the fateful collision. "Mess with the best and die like the rest," reads one touching message of condolence to the Wang family. "So solly, China boy!" reads another. "You flew Wang Wei. You now numba one fish food." There are many messages in a similar vein and one only hopes the Chinese authorities - well known for their slender appreciation of advanced democracies - comprehend the spirit in which they are sent.

simon.bowers @theguardian.com

webTitle: The only place for physical exertion is the gym

fields.headline: The only place for physical exertion is the gym
fields.trailText: Twenty years ago, guests were lucky to get televisions in their rooms. These days, international hotel chains are falling over themselves to woo customers with exotic luxuries, writes Andrew Clark .
fields.body:
Twenty years ago, guests were lucky to get televisions in their rooms. These days, international hotel chains are falling over themselves to woo customers with exotic luxuries, writes Andrew Clark .

Any business hotel worth its salt offers an internet connection in every room. Duvets have become a must instead of blankets and business travellers apparently like a separate shower unit rather than a shower attached to the bath.

"Turn-down" has become an evening ritual. Housekeeping staff enter every room to put a chocolate on each pillow and fold back the sheets, just in case the strain proves too much for weary guests. In some chains, each guests gets a little bottle of mineral water at turn-down time or a fresh bunch of flowers.

Hilton Group has gone several steps further down the luxury line in four "innovation rooms" at a hotel in Munich. These feature 42-inch plasma screens which rise out of desks, for use as laptop computer screens or televisions.

Hilton's hi-tech rooms have voice-activated systems recognising 20 different languages, allowing guests to draw the curtains, dim the lights or change television channels without moving a limb. Visitors must set their preferred language when they check in, to avoid a muttered curse being mistaken for the Japanese phrase for "open the blinds".

In addition to free soap and shampoo, many hotels have begun to offer scented bath oils and even candles to place around the bath - particularly popular with women, who account for 35% of business travellers.

Whitbread's Marriott hotels have introduced an "at your service" system whereby one employee is assigned to a room, handling inquiries about housekeeping, booking theatre tickets, shoe cleaning or concierge services.

For many chains it is little things that count. Hilton is introducing heat-resistant LED bulbs for its bedside lamps, so guests do not burn themselves if they accidentally touch them. There are even special windows between bathrooms and bedrooms which become opaque on a spoken command - just in case an unexpected visitor arrives.

Martin Hawthornthwaite, Hilton's director of interior design, says: "The guest is getting more and more sophisticated. We need to keep up."

webTitle: Hotels play the global brand game

fields.headline: Hotels play the global brand game
fields.standfirst: Any place, any time, anywhere, the chances are the bathroom will be on the left of your room
fields.trailText: Travellers stepping off long-haul flights receive a carefully tailored welcome at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Sydney. Receptionists have been told to offer refreshments suitable for the time zone which guests have just come from.
fields.body:
Travellers stepping off long-haul flights receive a carefully tailored welcome at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Sydney. Receptionists have been told to offer refreshments suitable for the time zone which guests have just come from.

So it may be early afternoon in Sydney's high summer, but jetlagged British businessmen will be greeted with a breakfast of toast, marmalade and cornflakes.

The hotel chain will even check its worldwide database of guests to anticipate which newspaper each customer will take, in order to offer a "local equivalent". Guardian readers will get a left-leaning daily, while fans of the Times could get Rupert Murdoch's conservative paper, the Australian.

The hotel industry is embracing globalisation with a passion. International chains are encircling the world, swallowing local operators on an almost daily basis.

In Britain, three big players have emerged - Hilton Group, the Hertfordshire-based company which owns the Hilton name outside the US, and two former brewers: Bass and Whitbread.

Bass last week paid £810m for the 79-outlet Posthouse Hotels chain, the middle-market favourite of Britain's travelling sales reps. These will be rebranded as Holiday Inns - one of the group's two global brands, alongside Inter-Continental.

Meanwhile, a £2bn battle for control of Compass' Le Meridien hotels looks set to reach a climax by the end of the month.

These are just the latest in a bewildering series of takeovers that have transformed the landscape of the hospitality industry. Mark Abramson, leisure analyst at Bear Stearns, says: "Everyone's been looking for dance partners. The pressure's been on to find opportunities."

The land-grab began in earnest in early 1998 when Bass bought Inter-Continental Hotels for £1.78bn from Japan's Saison Group. That deal was said to have been clinched by a private meeting between Bass boss Sir Ian Prosser and Emperor Akihito - one of Saison's more prestigious shareholders.

Tom Oliver, chief executive of Bass Hotels and Resorts, says: "Brands are everything - as travel becomes increasingly trans-border, hotels which aren't carrying international brands simply don't deliver the same rate of revenue per room."

Bass was unwittingly pushed into hotels by trade secretary Margaret Beckett, who thwarted the group's ambitions to be come a global brewer by blocking its purchase of Carlsberg-Tetley. Fellow brewer Whitbread realised that it, too, could not go much further in beer, and began building its Travel Inn chain and its British franchise for Marriott Hotels, snapping up Swallow Hotels for £578m in November 1999.

Leisure group Ladbroke joined the rush, switching its focus from gambling to hotels. It bought the 54-strong Stakis chain for £1.1bn in 1999 to add to its 169 Hilton hotels. To reflect its new focus, Ladbroke changed its name to Hilton Group - which did not impress residents of the Warwickshire village of Ladbroke, where the company began. One said: "I think it's a shame. I'm not against change but if it's been a good name for a long time, why change it?"

Hived off hospitality

Then last year Granada, which had wrested control of Forte Hotels in a bitter 1995 takeover battle, decided to concentrate on media. It hived off its hospitality interests to Compass, which immediately put the Posthouse, Heritage and Le Meridien chains up for sale.

Of these three, the only one still to go is Le Meridien, which is being stalked by Marriott International and Nomura, with French chain Accor and Starwood of the US as dark horses.

All these deals have been motivated by a recognition that the market is changing. In the US, 75% of hotels have a well-known brand, compared with just 25% in Europe. Lesley Ashplant, a hotels expert at PricewaterhouseCoopers, says: "Europe is the single largest tourist destination in the world. It has 6m hotel rooms under fragmented ownership. There are clear opportunities in scale, in taking advantage of branding and advanced technology."

Size is becoming important as expectations rise - international business travellers want internet connections, widescreen televisions and push-button blinds in every room, all of which requires investment. They want faxes delivered to their rooms at all hours of the night and the ability to order foie gras at four o'clock in the morning - which means employing more staff than most independent operators can afford.

Hi-tech reservations systems are also emerging as a crucial factor. In an industry where 75% of costs are staff wages, any savings elsewhere are precious. Mr Oliver says: "It doesn't necessarily loom as a big operating expense but when you look at the overall profit and loss account, it's one of those elements which can vary."

Stockbroker Bear Stearns points out that hotels have only a small window of opportunity to increase their margins. Between a third and half of hotels' revenue comes from food and drink, but these only contribute 20% to 30% of profit. Attempts to make hotel restaurants more attractive have generally failed - most still have all the atmosphere of a crematorium in a heating strike.

Much more profitable are the rooms themselves. The main thrust, therefore, for most operators, is on improving occupancy. Loyalty card schemes are becoming increasingly elaborate. They can record guests' preferences for well-cooked steak, ground-floor rooms or feather-free pillows. Hotel operators bombard their loyal customers with advertising bumf to persuade them to make return visits, but they know that having the best geographic reach is the best way to keep their custom.

A clutch of continental chains look likely to be swallowed up next, including Krasnipolski Hotels in the Benelux countries, Scandic in the Nordic region and Swiss Hotels, which has been deemed surplus to requirements by Swissair. British and US operators are bound to cast their eyes over these.

Oops, originality

Even the most ardent advocates of consolidation accept, however, that there will be limits to the creeping internationalisation of European hotels. Mr Abramson says: "The US is a wide-open country - if you want a hotel, you can just build it. In Europe, there's much less opportunity for new-builds, so you get a lot of conversions. They're harder to fit into the specific model of the US chain."

For international chains, the trouble with turning old buildings into hotels is that originality creeps in. The rooms are different shapes and sizes, so the standard "template" does not work.

It is difficult to turn a 17th century Provençal chteau into a Holiday Inn, so some indepent operators still prosper. That is bad news for the ideal guest of a multinational chain, who likes to wake up anywhere in the world in the knowledge that the bathroom is on the left, the blinds are blue and the phone is on the wall, six and a half inches above the bedside table.

webTitle: Notebook: Too soon to say the worst is over

fields.headline: Too soon to say the worst is over
fields.standfirst: Bumpy landings mean casualties
fields.trailText: The American economy is heading for a successful bumpy landing. That was one analyst's view yesterday after new US government figures showed a rebound in manufacturing output and few signs of price pressures.
fields.body:
The American economy is heading for a successful bumpy landing. That was one analyst's view yesterday after new US government figures showed a rebound in manufacturing output and few signs of price pressures. The difference between a hard landing and a bumpy one, presumably, is that in the latter there are no truly gruesome casualties, just a few broken limbs.

But the "worst is over" school of American economic seers have a problem: forward-looking indicators suggest there are going to be casualties aplenty. There was a series of earnings slumps, global sacking schemes and profit warnings yesterday from companies such as Cisco, Kodak, Charles Schwab, Sprint and PSInet, to reinforce the point.

Hopes that the old economy will rescue the new are overdone as well - as a closer look at yesterday's manufacturing figures shows. The rebound in output last month was entirely the result of higher activity in just one sector - the motor industry.

The "worst is yet to come" school points to the large imbalances which have built up in the US economy over the last 10 years. The dot.com-led investment boom has been accompanied by a build-up of debt by corporations and households.

Falling profits are forcing companies to repair their balance sheets and will drive down stock prices again, which may at last persuade American house holds that they cannot keep living on tick. It is hard to see how the economy can escape some collateral damage while these imbalances are being squeezed out of the system.

For a country that has become used to growth of over 4% a year - even if it does avoid recession - the resulting slowdown will be painful. And it is far too soon to declare that the pilot has successfully steered this particular economy back to earth.

Boneld benets

When Andrew Bonfield was appointed finance director of SmithKline Beecham in 1999, at the tender age of 36, he was accorded a breathless fanfare akin to the launch of a new boy band.

A former accountant at Price Waterhouse, Mr Bonfield had risen prodigiously at SmithKline, becoming the youngest person ever to reach the grade of vice-president. On reaching board level, he cheerfully told reporters that the prospect of a merger with Glaxo Wellcome was "dead".

He was dead wrong - negotiations restarted nine months later, and the record-breaking deal was announced in January 2000. Mr Bonfield lost his job in the deal but before the merger was even approved by shareholders, he had secured a new executive bolthole as finance director of BG - on an enhanced salary of £350,000.

The blow, therefore, was somewhat limited - even Mr Bonfield's pride was intact. But SmithKline still felt obliged to pay him four years' salary for two years' work. He received a pay-off of £1.05m, taking the total bill for his brief stint in the job to £2.2m.

That was clearly insufficient, so he was handed a whopping £2.5m of shares and options under an esoteric selection of "reward" schemes explained in impenetrable terms in Glaxo SmithKline's annual report.

Mr Bonfield must surely, therefore, have earned a place in the history books as one of the most expensive finance directors in British corporate history - about £45,000 a week by our reckoning.

He could comfortably afford to put his feet up and spend the rest of his days flicking through audit magazines. It is a credit to the man that the world of gas still holds his attention.

Cavallo caveat

At last! Somebody has finally given the single currency a big tick. Argentina's new economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, has come up with a plan to include the much-derided euro alongside the dollar to stabilise the Argentinine peso.

The peso is pegged one to one against the dollar, but Mr Cavallo reckons that arrangement should be ditched in favour of a euro-dollar average.

On paper it makes sense - the euro zone is the number one destination for Argentina's exports, followed by the US.

But there are justifiable suspicions about his real motives. The greenback's surge on the foreign exchanges has eroded Argentina's competitiveness and put the economy under strain. Meanwhile, Brazilian traders suspect that Mr Cavallo's cunning plan is really a disguised devaluation. He denies that on the grounds that the new plan will not come into effect until the euro hits parity with the dollar.

But if the real goal is devaluation, it is a risky strategy. The history of currency movements is one of overshooting. When the dollar finally loses its gloss, the euro could bolt to well above parity, dragging the peso with it. Exporters will not thank Mr Cavallo for that.
