fields.headline: Who needs a band?
fields.standfirst: Neil Finn tells  Adam Sweeting why he'd rather share a stage with his fans
fields.trailText: Neil Finn tells Adam Sweeting why he'd rather share a stage with his fans.
fields.body:
It's probably the shape of things to come. Singer-songwriter Neil Finn is live online from his recording studio in New Zealand, strumming through a few songs from his new solo album, One Nil, and answering questions in between. The computer image sometimes lapses into jerky freeze-frame or locks up altogether, but it's a glimpse of the way the internet is turning 1960s-style visions of a "global village" into reality. Or virtual reality, at least.

"I'm just starting to explore the possibilities of the net," Finn explains a couple of days later, on the plain old telephone. "Being on the other side of the planet, I'm dead keen on anything I can do to bridge the gap. It saves me having to get on a plane every time I want to do something."

Eager fans also had the chance to catch Finn's live webcast from the St James's Theatre, Auckland on April 6, part of a five-night residency starring Finn alongside a temporary all-star line-up featuring the likes of Radiohead's Ed O'Brien and Phil Selway, Johnny Marr, Pearl Jam's Eddie Vedder, and Lisa Germano. "It started as a whimsical notion, then became a determined effort to become a band in a really short space of time, do five shows and break up," Finn explains. "In a way, it's the ideal trajectory for a band."

The project was evidence of Finn's new-found determination to embrace the full meaning of working as a solo artist, away from the comforting environment of a band. After 20-odd years with Split Enz and then Crowded House, Finn thinks he's seen enough of group dynamics for one lifetime. At 42, he has discovered the joys of taking risks. It's slightly startling behaviour from an old-fashioned musician who tips his hat to vintage singer-songwriters such as Neil Young, Cat Stevens and David Bowie.

"I had a couple of sleepless nights before Johnny Marr and the Radiohead guys turned up, thinking, 'Oh my God! It looks good on paper but this might not work,' " Finn says. "But I wanted to be able to play differently every time. I'm looking for uncertainty because I like that feeling of teetering on the edge. I think people play at their best when there's an element of struggle."

Finn offered a glimpse of his new recklessness at his show at London's Palace theatre in February, when he invited strangers onstage to play songs from his back catalogue. Ironically, they sounded rather better rehearsed than Wendy and Lisa, who collaborated on Finn's new album, and played with him in London. "Everybody who came onstage was as comfortable as I was," he says. "I think a couple of them may do those songs with a tribute band. There was a father and son who were really into it, and they knew the songs better than I did."

The potential for disaster in this policy is obvious, but Finn thinks he knows his audience well enough to take the chance. "With Crowded House, sometimes we'd open it up to the floor and some dickhead would come up and start posturing. But I think I've got better at picking people who are going to make something of it. Also, I've discovered through the internet and from emails that come in that they're mostly a pretty evolved bunch of fans now. There's the odd strange one, but mostly they're just into the music."

The connection with Wendy Melvoin and Lisa Coleman, best known for their work with Prince in the 1980s, was another chance encounter that happened to produce a worthwhile result. While he was working on One Nil in Los Angeles, Finn was introduced to them by his co-producer Tchad Blake. "Then two weeks later I was at Tchad's house and Wendy was there, and we decided to have a play. In the course of that we wrote Secret God, which is on the album."

They ended up writing four songs together, while Coleman teamed up with Finn on the raucous Hole in the Ice. He credits Wendy and Lisa with pushing him down musical avenues he would otherwise not have tried. "They've got a very keen sense of melody and arrangement, and a great appreciation for music as diverse as Vaughan Williams, Stevie Wonder, Led Zeppelin and some Latin influences I really enjoy."

While One Nil doesn't represent the pinnacle of Finn's songwriting, it contains several typically bittersweet observations on life and death. He wrote Anytime after his dog was run over (it survived), prompting him to ponder mortality and the randomness of fate. Rest of the Day Off finds Finn musing over the perpetual tension between the joys of staying at home with his wife and family and the musician's nagging urge to go travelling. "I think the lyrics are a little more direct this time," he suggests.

The album has already gone gold in New Zealand. Is he held up as a role model, alongside fellow Kiwi Russell Crowe? "I knew Russell as Rus le Roc, when he was a pop star in New Zealand," Finn chuckles. "He's having a bloody good time by the sound of it. But I don't set myself up as a role model for anybody other than my kids. Though I hope New Zealanders identify with the music I write, because this is where I'm from and it would be nice if it reminded them of home."

 Neil Finn is at the Waterfront, Belfast (028-9033 4455), on Saturday, the Olympia Theatre, Dublin (00 353 1 677 7744), on Sunday, and the Royal Concert Hall, Glasgow (0141-353 8000), on Monday, then tours.

webTitle: Brian Logan meets playwright David Harrower

fields.headline: 'I'm tired of telling well crafted stories. It's time I started getting my hands dirty'
fields.standfirst: Playwright David Harrower talks to  Brian Logan
fields.trailText: Playwright David Harrower talks to Brian Logan.
fields.body:
We expect debut plays to be angry, like Look Back in Anger or Blasted. Sometimes they're eye-openingly autobiographical: think of Ayub Khan-Din's East is East. Such are the trusted formulae for writers seeking exposure. But one memorable 1990s debut went against the grain. In a decade characterised by onstage buggery and baby-munching, Knives in Hens - first seen in 1995 at Edinburgh's Traverse, then at London's Bush Theatre - was an elliptical, sensual affair, describing how an unfulfilled young woman in a Scottish rural community takes control of her life after a local miller teaches her the words needed to understand it. It heightened the incongruity that the writer was a man, David Harrower, from Glasgow, a city not noted for its rustic airs.

"I don't know where it came from," says Harrower. But he knows why he didn't write about his own life. "I feel quite keenly that I don't have much to draw on. My background is lower-middle class and with no passion about it. That can mean thrashing around for things to write about." Before Knives in Hens, he had been trying to write about land ownership in Scotland. "It was my angry play, but it had taken two years to write and it's exhausting to maintain anger for that long." His breakthrough came when he nixed the rage and concentrated on the characters, asking himself, "How would they respond to each other, and to the land?"

The play's worldwide success - "There's a production in Colombia," smirks its writer - confirmed in Harrower a conviction that it's what the characters, not the writer, want to say that matters. The theory was developed in 1998's Kill the Old, Torture Their Young at the Traverse. Harrower's third major play, Presence, opens at the Royal Court tomorrow, three years after it was commissioned. If the contrast to his prolific countryman David Greig seems pronounced, 34-year-old Harrower would ask that his several adaptations, which include Six Characters in Search of an Author at the Young Vic in February, and Woyzeck at Edinburgh's Lyceum next month, be taken into consideration.

"I think about my sister when I write." he says. "She never comes to the theatre, she's got a job and a kid. I ask myself, what might she come and see with her friends?" His plays may be as wry and inquisitive as the writer himself, but Harrower remains keenly aware that "people don't want to be shouted at or told what to think. People want to be entertained."

fields.headline: Get those kids out of here
fields.standfirst: How the dance world fell in love with old people, by  Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: How the dance world fell in love with old people, by Judith Mackrell.
fields.body:
Catwalk models may be getting younger, pop singers may be pre-pubescent and the images of movie stars may be getting more perfectly airbrushed but, in the world of modern dance, wrinkles seem to be the coming thing.

There have always been starry individuals who have extended their performing lives way beyond pensionable age. Martha Graham ran the gauntlet of arthritis and alcohol to prolong her dance career until she was 74; at 82, Merce Cunningham has only recently given up being the elderly Puck-turned-Prospero of his own dance creations; and the Japanese star of butoh, Kazuo Ohno, continues to perform at 94. What's special about the present trend is that it involves ordinary dancers, rather than box-office names.

A surprising number of recent productions in Britain suggest that choreographers are finding themselves less entranced by the perfect limbs of 20-year-olds than by the dramatic and physical possibilities of bodies that have been lived in. The French choreographer Ea Sola, for instance, made an eloquent case for age when she featured a chorus of women aged between 50 and 76 in her show Secheresse et Pluie. Her choice was obviously prompted by the work's subject - the loss of traditional life stories in postwar Vietnam. Yet the women's faces and bodies were marked by so much character and history that they seemed to be more than elderly witnesses to a specific past. Under the choreographer's skilful direction, they became theatrical personalities in their own right.

In Régine Chopinot's La Danse du Temps, the cast's ages ranged from 20 to 70 and, again, the older dancers did much more than illustrate a theme. By common consent they stole the show, possessing a far surer grasp of Chopinot's slow, looping choreography than the younger dancers.

The truth - frustrating though it may be for dancers - is that while their bodies stiffen, their artistry often matures. Christopher Bannerman, a former principal with London Contemporary Dance Theatre, long ago turned 50 but when he recently performed alongside the exquisite south Asian dancer Mavin Khoo he more than held his own. His poignant-comic solo to Saint Saëns's Dying Swan was an object lesson in how experience can hone technique and expression to a heroic clarity - which is why 53-year-old Mikhail Baryshnikov still garners almost as many superlatives with his modern dance ensemble White Oak as he did when he was a classical prince. Dancers age better than rock stars.

But oldies aren't valued simply for their gravitas. Among the mixed-age, mixed-race cast of Les Ballets C de la B's recent show was a 57-year-old former ballerina who proved as feisty and flighty as anyone else on stage. Diana Payne Myers, star of numerous independent dance shows, appeared in DV8's last production dressed only in a bathing suit. Not only did she cheerfully flaunt all the sags and wrinkles of her tiny 72-year-old body but she also chatted happily about the state of her sex life - which she claimed has never been better, boasting that she had recently had four lovers under 30.

Colin McLean, 66, and Gladys Hillman, 76, aren't required to do anything so raunchy when they appear next week in Rosemary Lee's Passage at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, yet they are crucial to the show. Lee cast both these amateur dancers because they possess a style of energy and stage presence she could never have found in younger performers.

As a choreographer, Lee has always looked for her material in odd places. She presents work in non-theatrical spaces, mixes amateur dancers with professionals, combines film and live performance and frequently employs children and the elderly. Her aim is to see people performing her work rather than straight dance technicians (though the result is never sloppy) and also to communicate with the widest possible audience.

While few serious novelists would admit to writing exclusively about youth, it is standard dance practice to portray humanity only within the twenty/thirtysomething age bracket. Lee feels that when choreographers limit the range of their dancers, they also restrict the range of their audience - older people being less likely to attend shows performed by a much younger generation.

Lee is also very alert to everything that older dancers "carry in their bones". In purely physical terms she thinks they bring "a stillness and an authority" to movement that isn't available to much younger dancers, while she finds them less wary, less closed as performers. Hillman only began dancing at 60, yet Lee says she "has a serenity and an openness on stage that is extraordinary". As for Colin McLean, "he's a complete live wire - I can't stop him moving." She would argue that there's something childlike about McLean's lack of inhibition, except that the real children Lee uses have qualities that are beyond any adult. Apart from their "amazing quickness", she finds in them an "awesome" capacity for intensity.

The point of Passage is to explore the range of energies within a group of disparate people, and certainly Lee's 15-strong cast of professional and amateur dancers includes some extraordinary personalities. When Hillman retired from the civil service she was determined "not to sit and waste my life away" and started dancing with an over-60s group. She was amazed at what her untried body was capable of. "I'm still learning new things," she says. In this, her third show with Lee, she loves the fact that "no one looks down on me as an old person. I'm part of the group."

As a Trappist monk-turned-soldier-turned-Catholic priest, McLean comes from a background unusually bereft of physical expression, which makes him an especially ardent newcomer to dance. He talks about it not only as a "primary form of prayer" but also as the most energising fun (Lee says he's "like a young goat - no one can keep up with him"). And nine-year-old Aella Jordan Edge confirms everything the adults say. Although she has had some dance and modelling experience, working with the peculiarly mixed cast of Passage seems to have opened up new horizons. "I think this is much better than just being with people your own age. With other children you already know who you are. Working with this group I feel as if I'm part of something that's big."

 Passage is at Queen Elizabeth Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242) on April 26, 27 and 28, then tours.

webTitle: Mass kidnapping stokes Colombian oilfield worries

fields.headline: Mass kidnapping stokes Colombian oilfield worries
fields.standfirst: The armed abduction of 100 oil workers is symptomatic of drug-funded civil war which Mo Mowlam says Britain can help bring to an end
fields.trailText: The armed abduction of 100 oil workers is symptomatic of drug-funded civil war which Mo Mowlam says Britain can help bring to an end.
fields.body:
Rebels from Colombia's second largest guerrilla group have seized around 100 employees of a US oil company in one of the country's biggest mass kidnappings.

Armed men stopped a convoy of eight buses carrying maintenance, kitchen, security and cleaning personnel - all of them thought to be Colombian nationals - working for California-based Occidental Petroleum shortly after it left the company's oilfields in the north-eastern state of Arauca.

But a few hours after staging the raid, the armed group released most of the victims. Conflicting reports said that the rebels still held between 19 and 27 hostages. The Colombian army deployed several units to the area to continue the search for them.

"We'd like to get to them before they reach the mountains, the jungles or cross the Venezuelan border," an army spokesman said.

Over 3,500 kidnappings were reported to the government last year, according to Colombia's defence ministry. Leftwing guerrillas, who use ransom money to fund their war against the government, were held responsible for the majority of these kidnappings.

Monday's mass abduction appeared to be the work of the National Liberation Army (ELN), which is known for such high-profile actions. It hijacked a plane carrying 41 passengers and crew in 1999.

The group also kidnapped 160 Colombians from a church in an affluent neighbourhood of Cali the same year. One kidnapped churchgoer died as the rebels fled from the army.

The ELN also fiercely opposes multinational oil companies in Colombia and regularly targets the Cano Limon to Covenas pipeline that carries Occidental's crude oil to the coast for export. Rebels have bombed the pipeline 63 times this year and more than 700 times since 1986.

Occidental's field in Arauca has been under virtual siege since late February because of the attacks.

The ELN is also entangled in a complicated peace process with the government. After promising to demilitarise a 1,500sq mile area in central Colombia to hold talks earlier this year, the two sides have wrangled over the details and ELN leaders have said that the negotiations are in "crisis".

The guerrillas' arch-enemies, the rightwing paramilitaries, have since launched an offensive in the area where the talks were to have been held. Paramilitary commanders say they will not allow negotiations unless the ELN ceases its military activities.

In 1999, the government removed its troops from a 16,000sq mile region in southern Colombia to make room for peace talks with the country's largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc).

But critics of the peace process say that the Farc is using the area to stockpile weapons and drugs and to hold kidnap victims.

Both the ELN and Farc regularly abduct oil workers and attack oil fields. Occidental officials said that employees had been kidnapped in the past.

"It's a huge area with over 70 oil wells," a company spokesman said. "It's very difficult to protect." As many as 800 guerrillas are active in the Arauca region.

Other companies have also been targets. In March, suspected guerrillas bombed the Ocensa pipeline that carries crude from BP's Cusiana-Cupiagua fields in eastern Colombia where it produces 350,000 barrels per day. It was the fifth attack in two years.

Last year, several BP contract employees were abducted by rebels but have since been released.

Guerrillas have also dynamited BP's oil wells, although no incidents have been reported this year.

webTitle: Conductor on trial for cult deaths

fields.headline: Conductor on trial for cult deaths
fields.standfirst: In 1994, 74 died in a mass suicide. But who was responsible?
fields.trailText: The ghosts of 74 men, women and children hovered over the ornate library of Grenoble's fine arts museum yesterday as an orchestral conductor went on trial for his alleged role in the mass ritual killings staged in the 1990s by the macabre Order of the Solar Temple.
fields.body:
The ghosts of 74 men, women and children hovered over the ornate library of Grenoble's fine arts museum yesterday as an orchestral conductor went on trial for his alleged role in the mass ritual killings staged in the 1990s by the macabre Order of the Solar Temple.

Michel Tabachnik, 58, who has denied any responsibility for the five group murder-suicides in France, Switzerland and Canada between 1994 and 1997, is charged with "association with criminals preparatory to crimes and assassinations".

The police believe he incited the doomsday cult's followers to accept that their death would lead to salvation.

The Franco-Swiss conductor faces a sentence of up to 10 years in jail and a £100,000 fine at the end of the two-week trial, held in the museum because the city court is too small for the 250-300 people expected to attend.

"I have come before my judges because I have done absolutely nothing wrong - I am the scapegoat in this affair," he said.

"I suppose the French justice system wants a big showcase trial, and for that it needs a guilty person. It forgets that my first wife died in one of these massacres, and that my career has been destroyed."

Francis Szpiner, one of Mr Tabachnik's lawyers, said the trial was "a pretext for the justice system to show that it is fighting sects".

"Michel Tabachnik is being prosecuted merely for his opinions."

Many of the victims' relatives doubt that the trial will establish the truth about the Order. They say the judge has ignored evidence that sect members who died in France were killed by unknown assailants who fled the scene.

They argue that no effort has been made to explain the millions of pounds channelled through the sect by benefactors, including the late head of the Piaget watchmaking company, Camille Pilet.

One lawyer, Alain Leclerc, says he has proof that the Order was "a massive multinational money-laundering operation" and that the deaths, far from being "collective suicides", were carried out by third parties trying to gain control of its treasure chest.

The trial will concentrate mainly on 16 members, including three children, whose burned bodies were found in a remote clearing known as the Well of Hell in an Alpine forest on December 24 1995.

The investigating magistrate, Luc Fontaine, has concluded that two cult members administered a sedative to the 14 others, killed them with a single shot to the head, and arranged the bodies in a star pattern before setting the corpses and themselves alight.

Another 48 followers died in similar "group suicides" in the Swiss villages of Cheiry and Salvan in October 1994, and a further 10 lost their lives in ritual killings in Canada in September 1994 and March 1997. Investigations there concluded that, as the sect's two leaders were among the dead, no one could be held responsible.

French prosecutors claim that Mr Tabachnik, who has conducted leading orchestras in France and Canada, was number three in the sect's hierarchy, a founder of its precursor and inner sanctum, the Foundation of the Golden Way, and responsible for training senior members.

"He was well aware that death lay at the heart of the cult's doctrine and was the very basis of its teachings," Judge Fontaine said in his indictment.

Mr Tabachnik knew of plans for the mass killings, it says, and encouraged a "homicidal dynamic" among followers in speeches evoking the imminent end of the Order, the "transit to Sirius" and the "return to the Father" - two of the cult's euphemisms for death.

Founded in the early 1990s, the Order is believed to be dormant. Members believe "death voyages" by ritualised suicide lead to rebirth on the star Sirius. They believe they must burn to death to reach the afterworld.

fields.headline: Dispute and denial surround killings of teenagers
fields.standfirst:
Fears over Israeli army shootings

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Seventeen-year-old Bassam Zaharan was suspected of wounding an Israeli soldier with a knife.  But the Palestinian teenager will not be appearing in court or going to prison: Israeli forces shot him dead before he could be put on trial.
fields.body:
Seventeen-year-old Bassam Zaharan was suspected of wounding an Israeli soldier with a knife. If convicted, he could have been jailed for up to 10 years. But the Palestinian teenager will not be appearing in court or going to prison: Israeli forces shot him dead before he could be put on trial.

According to the army, an Israeli soldier "was lightly to moderately wounded from a Palestinian stab" at a West Bank checkpoint near Tulkarm early yesterday.

The army said the attacker - described as a "terrorist" - escaped but was pursued by Israeli forces.

"Forces began searches during which the stabber was found. The force opened fire toward the assailant and killed him," a brief statement said.

Yesterday, human rights organisations on both sides of the Middle East divide questioned whether Israeli troops had followed their own regulations in dealing with the incident.

However, an Israeli army spokesman said that after the teenager was tracked down, he had threatened the soldiers with a knife and they had shot him in self-defence.

The body of Zaharan, who had been visiting the West Bank from Jordan, was handed over to Palestinian police.

Bassim Eid of the Palestine Human Rights Monitoring Group said: "Any Palestinian right now who tries to approach an Israeli checkpoint is regarded with suspicion. Some soldiers just open fire. The Israeli version has not been confirmed yet by any Palestinian sources.

"According to their regulations, if he tried to escape they should shoot in the air and then shoot at his legs. It's better to arrest than to kill."

The penalty for a knife attack would depend on the severity of the injury, but the most serious charge - attempting to kill - would normally result in a seven to 10-year sentence, he added.

The Israeli human rights organisation B'Tselem also said it would be investigating the incident, but that "there are so many cases daily that we can't get to every incident the day it happens". The organisation said that the rules of self-defence authorise soldiers to shoot to kill during an attack, but not if the assailant is running away.

In London, Amnesty International urged the Israeli army to take the soldiers in question off duty in order to investigate thoroughly. "Only if there is an immediate threat to life are security forces permitted to use lethal force," a spokesman added.

According to Amnesty, the Israeli army has investigated very few killings by its soldiers. It did examine the killing of a Palestinian woman, Fatima Jamal Abu Jish, as she returned home from the hospital in Nablus where she worked as a receptionist last January.

After originally saying that the soldiers had been responding to shots fired at their checkpoint, the army later admitted that no shots had been fired.

At the Karni crossing in Gaza yesterday, an Israeli sniper reportedly shot dead another Palestinian, 15-year-old Hamza Obeid, with a bullet through his heart. It was not immediately clear what prompted the killing.

A medical worker stationed at what has become a flashpoint for Israeli-Palestinian violence told Reuters: "He fell dead among his friends. At the time there were no clashes."

In the Rafah area in southern Gaza, witnesses said a boy, aged 10, had been critically wounded in the head by two live rounds fired from an Israeli tank patrolling the border with Egypt.

They said the boy had been shot on the street where he lived as he left home for a private lesson.

The Israeli army said it was checking both reports.

The killings brought the number of dead to at least 379 Palestinians, 71 Israelis and 13 Israeli Arabs since the Palestinian uprising began last September.

fields.headline: Liberal voice that strives to be heard
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli government coalition led by Ariel Sharon was always going to be strained by the presence of Shimon Peres, a liberal and architect of the Oslo peace agreement.
fields.body:
The Israeli government coalition led by Ariel Sharon was always going to be strained by the presence of Shimon Peres, a liberal and architect of the Oslo peace agreement.

The strain began to tell yesterday as the Israeli army occupied Palestinian territory, breaching the agreement signed by Mr Peres, a member of the Labour party.

Mr Peres is the respectable face of the coalition. One of his parliamentary colleagues in the Labour party, who is critical of his presence in the coaltion, said Mr Peres felt he could be a moderating influence: "He thinks he can prevent silly decisions."

But Mr Peres, the foreign minister, does not appear to be having much success.

Two weeks ago Mr Sharon gave the go-ahead for a 700-house expansion of a Jewish settlement in the West Bank just as Mr Peres was boasting that part of the price for going into the coaliton was that there would be no new settlements.

Semantically, Mr Sharon could argue that the expansion of an existing settlement is different from creating a new one: the distinction was lost on the Palestinians.

Yesterday, Mr Peres was forced to defend the Israeli occupation of part of Palestinian-controlled Gaza that goes against the Oslo agreement that is his crowning glory.

Only two weeks ago, in an interview with the Guardian, Mr Peres claimed that part of the price for going into a coalition with Mr Sharon was that the government would respect international agreements. The re-occupation of parts of Gaza would appear to run counter to that.

Mr Peres has been trying to square the circle. He said that in the end there will have to be a diplomatic solution: "Obviously when there's a need to defend, defend. But these problems cannot be solved with force."

webTitle: Sharon's breach of Oslo was step too far

fields.headline: Sharon's breach of Oslo was step too far
fields.standfirst:
Israeli move into Palestinian-controlled area was serious risk

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: "The Israelis crossed a red line today," said Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian who was involved in the peace process. "Oslo is dead."
fields.body:
"The Israelis crossed a red line today," said Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian who was involved in the peace process. "Oslo is dead."

He was commenting after the Israeli army breached the historic Oslo agreement by occupying territory in the Gaza Strip that had been handed over to autonomous Palestinian control - the so-called Area A - and before the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, announced last night that Israel was pulling pull out.

Mr Khatib's pessimism was matched by his counterparts on the Israeli side who helped negotiate the Oslo agreement - signed by the Israelis and Palestinians seven years ago.

But Yossi Beilin, a Labour member of parliament who was part of the Israeli delegation at Oslo did not stop believing that the principles that shaped the agreement were still valid.

"I see the conquering of part of Gaza as a big mistake. It is a deterioration of the situation. It deepens the hatred. The last thing we need to do is win the war. We would be back in all the places we wanted to leave," he said.

He had accused the Israeli prime minister, who decided late last night that the occupation should end quickly, of living in the 1950s, a time when Mr Sharon believed retaliation to be an effective response to Palestinian attacks.

In 1955, Mr Sharon led two paratroop companies into Gaza in an operation codenamed Black Arrow that destroyed the Egyptian army headquarters then based there, killing 37 Egyptian soldiers and wounding 31.

It is not even two months since Mr Sharon became prime minister, but in that short time the crisis in the Middle East has deepened. Attitudes on both sides have hardened, and the threat of a regional war has re-emerged.

Mr Sharon began quietly, the policy of his first few weeks not that different from his predecessor, Ehud Barak. But, facing criticism from the Israeli right for not being tough enough on the Palestinians, who stepped up mortar attacks in the interim, Mr Sharon has opted for tough military action, seemingly in the belief that the Palestinians can be forced to accept a deal.

No longer waiting to respond to Palestinian attacks, Mr Sharon in the last two weeks has gone for "pre-emptive reprisals": rocket and tank attacks on Palestinian areas, accompanied by bulldozers.

And this week Mr Sharon went further, going into Area A in breach of the Oslo peace accord.

In part two of the Oslo agreement, signed in 1995, the West Bank and Gaza were divided into three parts: Area A was to be fully under the control of the Palestinian Authority, which was to be responsible for all civil and security matters; Area B was to be under joint Israeli-Palestinian security control; and Area C was to be under Israeli control.

Both sides blame one another for having breached Oslo. The Israelis say the Palestinians were to blame for failing to maintain the security necessary to prevent attacks on Israeli settlements.

What the Israeli army risked doing with the occupation was make themselves targets in areas that the Palestinians had regarded as sovereign territory.

A Palestinian minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, had warned yesterday that the Palestinian Authority and its people would act in accordance with the reality of the "re-occupation" of Gaza.

This implicit threat backed up the gloomy assessment of Mr Khatib, now a lecturer in political studies at Bir Zeit University in Ramallah, on the West Bank. He was part of the Palestinian delegation that took part in the Madrid summit and subsequent Washington talks that led to the Oslo agreement.

He said he was appalled that the Israeli army had reoccupied a part of Gaza that had been ceded to the Palestinian Authority under the Oslo agreement, and was pessimistic about the chances for peace.

"We have a government in Israel that has policies that go against the legality and philosophy of Oslo. Sharon led the opposition to Oslo and he is now prime minister and has a coalition of people that includes people to the right," he said.

He said the reoccupation had risked "Palestinian reaction and resistance which will fuel the vicious circle of violence".

Ron Pundak, an Israeli who was involved in the secret negotiations that led to Oslo and is now head of an economic foundation based in Tel Aviv, said it was not a single event that was damaging Oslo but different and brutal events coming at different angles. It would require hindsight to see whether the agreement had been killed or not.

He said there was a saying in Israel that "every bastard is king": every member of Hizbullah with a mortar could affect the lives of all Israelis and Palestinians, as could each Israeli soldier who shot at a high-level peace delegation, as happened a fortnight ago.

What was needed was for the two societies and their leaders to understand one another.

Mr Pundak said: "I would judge the situation we are in as one of the lowest ebbs in the process since Oslo and it will not be the lowest we will come to in the next few months or more."

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

C1 Scientists believe that redhead genes come from

(a) A bottle

(b) Didcot

(c) Neanderthals

(d) Mars

C2 Brian Redhead was

(a) A Neanderthal man

(b) A journalist

(c) A Viking

(d) A bricklayer

C3 Which of the following is NOT a famous redhead?

(a) Mick Hucknall

(b) Jessica Rabbit

(c) Cilla Black

(d) Muffin the Mule

C4 Which is the ginger character in the Flintstones?

(a) Barney

(b) Wilma

(c) Dino

(d) All of the above

C5 Redheads legendarily have

(a) Fiery tempers

(b) Dimples

(c) Peggy teeth

(d) Second helpings

 Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday April 25. The winner will be notified by May 4. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at Guardian Unlimited Quiz Room.

fields.headline: No 1861
fields.standfirst: Anne Robinson
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson.
fields.body:
You Brits! You guys are so wacky! What on earth are you talking about?

Well, when you're not burning your cattle or partaking in un-American sexual practices (I've seen Bridget Jones!) you are getting dominated and beaten into submission by your game show hosts! Ah, I see. You must have watched the American premiere of The Weakest Link this week.

Darn right! I was flabbergasted. When it comes to Britain, Americans like to see Dickensian Christmases and upper-class fops. They do not want a scary ginger woman on telly calling them "pathetic", "depressing" and "measly". Oh, poor things! Did mean old Anne Robinson hurt your feelings?

Indeed she did. The New York Post television critic even compared her to Alex and his droogs in A Clockwork Orange as "another British import to make you feel bad". Anne Robinson and Anthony Burgess, eh? Never would have made the connection myself.

The same critic said watching The Weakest Link was "one of the most unpleasant experiences I have ever had in front of the television". Surely an exaggeration. After all, yours is the country which introduced the world to the voyeurism of Temptation Island, the chair-throwing antics of Jerry Springer and the anodyne horror of Friends.

Yes, but people aren't rude on those programmes. They're just intellectually challenged, which, of course, is far more fun to watch. I guess a gameshow host as a ruthless dominatrix doesn't exactly go with the US "have a nice day" mentality.

Not only that, but she's got, like, a totally funny accent, y'know, so it's, like, really hard to understand her, like, y'know? Er, no.

The New York Times took Robinson to task on her semantics, claiming her habit of pronouncing "weak" as "wick" "becomes annoying fast". If it makes you feel any better, Anne Robinson is hated in Wales, too.

Wales? Is that near Scotland? Goodbye!

webTitle: Time to call the editors to account

fields.headline: Time to call the editors to account
fields.trailText: When the News of the World is hauled before the press complaints commission it invariably mounts a public interest defence, implying that free speech would be compromised if Rebekah Wade's disgraceful organ was not allowed to secretly record and film and entrap its victims.
fields.body:
When the News of the World is hauled before the press complaints commission it invariably mounts a public interest defence, implying that free speech would be compromised if Rebekah Wade's disgraceful organ was not allowed to secretly record and film and entrap its victims.

Last week the newspaper was up in front of the commission again, this time defending its actions after secretly videoing a private party held for the stars of Emmerdale. The newspaper's representatives stated that the paper had infiltrated the guest list because wild behaviour had been reported at previous parties.

It is typical of the profoundly dishonest, corrosive regime at the News of The World to make such an insinuation. Even if it had been true - which it palpably wasn't - there was no public interest whatsoever because this was a private occasion.

Under Rebekah Wade, the paper has marked itself out to be the most incorrigible offender in the press. Its hypocritical use of the public interest defence becomes ever more striking, as does its culture of cruelty. In every action it takes - whether the dangerous naming of paedophiles or the callous destruction of Jenny Male - the mother who was exposed by the paper as a prostitute after she appeared in The Weakest Link - the paper is motivated exclusively by its own interest; that is to say sales figures.

These are down by 2.49% over the last year and Wade is under pressure to turn around the paper's performance. In these circumstances, she is unlikely to take the slightest notice of the commission. Besides, the judgment involves the paper in relatively little public embarrassment and she can hide behind the implausible flak catchers who appear for her at the commission.

What the commission needs to do in the worst cases of privacy invasion and abuse of power, such as the Daily Mirror's share dealing scandal, is to summon the relevant editor and ask them to explain their actions in front of a camera. The tape would then be released, together with transcripts, to the media following the commission's adjudication. This power would be backed by statute and include heavy fines against the paper and the editor in question.

Naturally such a measure would be deeply resented by the tabloids, but it really is in the public interest that British newspaper readers are allowed to scrutinise the standards that operate in the press. Editors are less answerable to the public than any other group, and it is time they were made to explain their actions. Of course, if they genuinely have the public interest at heart, then we shall all be the better for hearing their arguments. On their current form, however, I suspect we would be faced with a stream of slippery characters whose evasions and denials will be equally transparent.

For its own sake, the press needs to concentrate on the behaviour of two or three of our tabloids. The press's reputation is important and there are many good and brave reporters out there who are being tarred by the unacceptable behaviour of the News of the World. One thinks of Marie Colvin of The Sunday Times - The News of the World's sister paper - who was injured by shrapnel during an action between government troops and the Tamil Tigers in Sri Lanka on Monday. Colvin, who has a huge number of friends in the trade and is universally admired for her courage and skill, was the first western reporter to visit the Tamil-held area since 1995.

Covering East Timor last year, she was the only journalist to remain in the UN compound while the killing went on around her. Her male colleagues left, but she stayed so that she could bring the news, and maybe offer some measure of protection to the people inside the compound. Compare this to the behaviour of Rebekah Wade, or the bullies who spend their time threatening the likes of Jenny Male and ruining the relationship she had with her children.

The point is that sometimes journalists are called to the front line in the defence of liberty. In Moscow, the reporters, technicians and satirists whose station NTV was taken over by Russia's monopoly gas company on the weekend, have decamped and are managing a skeleton service at a rival station. Their actions are propelled not by sales or salaries, but by truth and a desire for free speech. These are grand words for any journalist to brandish, I agree, but it does make one nauseous to see the News of the World argue that its actions are motivated by instincts similar to those of journalists at NTV or Marie Colvin's.

Not in the ginger genes

The idea that Chris Evans owes his handsome ginger looks to a Neanderthal gene is entertaining but probably wrong. The Oxford scientists who make the claim that the gene passed from apes to early man and arrived at Evans via the Neanderthals, do not address one of the central issues in paleoanthropology. There is virtually no proof that Neanderthal genes survive in modern man.

Three years ago DNA from a Neanderthal was recovered by a German scientist working on his doctorate thesis. The genome was substantially different to ours, different enough for scientists to doubt whether a successful mating could take place between the two species. But even if it occasionally did, we only have to think of the likely dynamics between the two types of early man in Europe to understand that the chances of Neanderthal inheritance are very slim.

When our ancestors moved into Europe 40,000 years ago, they found small groups of Neanderthals puttering along as they had for the previous 250,000 years. We were slighter in build, more gregarious and a great deal smarter. A gradual extinction resulted. During that time there may have conceivably been some kind of exchange between the two groups, but if you think about it for half a second, you realise the mating - in God knows what circumstances - was more likely to have occurred between Homo sapiens males and Neanderthal females, rather than the other way round. For in the competition between two species, it would have been extremely unlikely that many Homo sapiens brides would have opted for the dubious advantages of the Neanderthal groom. So the gene flow, if it occurred, must have been mostly one way, from Homo sapiens groups to Neanderthal groups, which, as we know, became extinct.

If the flow had gone in the other direction Chris Evans would look rather different - he would be shorter, his brow would be heavy, his expression puzzled and he would be far less voluble than he is. Also I doubt whether he would have made £80m from the sale of Virgin Radio.

Tories' negative equity

There is a simple reason why the Tories are performing so disastrously in the polls and face certain defeat at the election. Their predominant message is negative. Whether they're talking about the euro, asylum seekers or public spending, their argument always seems to be for not doing something, rather than doing it. Listening to the Tories at the moment is like meeting one of those gloomy pub bores who complains about everything but offers nothing in the way of hope or innovation. Such people are depressing to be around and we shun their company, which is why most of us have given up paying attention to Hague, Ancram and Widdecombe.

On the other hand, Labour with all its obvious flaws and dissembling, miraculously manages to look a lot more positive and interesting. Until the Tories can think of something constructive to say they don't stand a chance.

 Francis Wheen is away.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Psychology Of Fame | The Reith Lectures 2001 | Tonight At 11
fields.body:
Photographer Richard Young is deeply concerned about The Psychology Of Fame (11.0am, Radio 4). As he explains to Dr Raj Persaud, his livelihood depends on it. Over the past 27 years he has attended 125,000 parties to secure saleable snaps. If he only found unknown wannabes there he wouldn't earn a penny. This week's programme examines the industry which has developed around the fame-hungry. It examines the extraordinary network of intermediaries who ensure not only that hopefuls attend the right events, but that everyone is told they did.

In the third of The Reith Lectures 2001 (8.0pm, Radio 4), Professor Tom Kirkwood muses on why women generally live longer than men. From an evolutionary point of view, humans exist solely to reproduce: they have few uses after that. But while the male body steadily deteriorates with age, the menopause noticeably slows that process in females. The reason is unclear but may be because older women can play a significant role in perpetuating the species.

Natalie Wheen talks to Nick Dodd in Tonight At 11 (11.0pm, Classic FM) about next month's Brighton Festival. He is the man in charge of the three-week event, which this year places special emphasis on Japanese culture. Among its offerings will be Japanese textile sculptures (rarely seen in the West) and traditional music by the Ensemble Tokai.

fields.headline: A fair coppice
fields.standfirst: The Severn Gorge
fields.trailText: The Severn Gorge.
fields.body:
Despite what Shropshire County Council claim, not every public footpath is closed. Down in the Severn Gorge, around Ironbridge, some woodlands managed by the Severn Gorge Countryside Trust are open. Where paths have no contact with sheep or cattle there are signs that actually say "Welcome", instead of threatening fines.

I wander into Lloyds Coppice. This diverse and wonderful stretch of woodland clings tenaciously to the near precipitous north side of the Severn Gorge downstream of Ironbridge. It was once a place of pilgrimage for local people, who came to listen to the nightingales which nested here. But that was a long time ago. No nightingales now, but the wood still has a powerful allure. There are drifts of wood anemone and lesser celandine, and the first of the bluebells are sending up their tiny rocket flowers.

Standing in an old three-trunked oak, coppiced maybe 200 years ago, the ecology of Lloyds Coppice begins to work into my consciousness. The great oak is holding this section of the near-vertical slope together. With other oaks, ash, hazel, yew and holly, the roots defy the downhill pull, and the wild garlic, wood-sedge and bramble hold the soil in place. Very recent slips of creamy red mud show how tenuous a grip the wood has here.

Down slope, wonderful dark pools form between rocks like Japanese gardens; dog violets and golden saxifrage are in flower along muddy tracks. But the real force is not in the wood itself but in the river below. Here the Severn, squeezed between wooded walls of the Gorge, churns relentlessly, eroding an ever deeper channel, and dragging the woods down into it.

fields.headline: You 'orrible little man
fields.trailText: Boot Camp | Faking It
fields.body:
What's all this shouting? We'll have no trouble here. Ah but we will. Just when you thought that reality TV couldn't get any weirder than Celebrity Big Brother, or more dubious than Temptation Island, along comes Boot Camp (Sky One). And it is very shouty indeed.

Imported from America, but actually made by Granada, Boot Camp follows 16 recruits being put through their paces in pursuit of a $500,000 prize. Each week the recruits undertake a number of rigorous activities - this week's included rowing and carrying a dinghy for a long time, getting up at 5am and eating scrambled eggs and an unidentified white gloop for breakfast - after which they vote out one of their number on the rather picturesque Dismissal Hill. The reject is then allowed their revenge by taking another recruit with them. When only two recruits are left, they must compete for 48 hours continuously in what is being called "The Gauntlet". One imagines there is running to be done.

They do all this while being shouted at by the deafening drill instructors, who say things like, "Save the drama for your mama and give me 50 [press-ups]", and "The purpose of our processing is to break them down emotionally and physically." A normal conversation between an instructor and a recruit goes something like this:

Instructor: "What's the theme of Campbell's Soup Company?"

Recruit: "'Mm! Mm! Good!' sir!"

Instructor, looking like he is excreting a handgrenade: "LOUDER!"

Recruit: "'MM! MM! GOOD!' SIR!"

(I have no idea why they are talking about soup but you get the picture.)

Another instructor climbs on a table to shout at one recruit in whose suitcase she finds a teddy. "WHAT IS THIS??", she hollers inches from his face. Spittle must certainly be an issue.

Soon, the male recruits have their heads shaved, the women their hair cut, and they are giving in to authority at every available opportunity. Not long after that, they are referring to themselves in the third person like good psychopaths. Needless to say, it is all quite hilarious.

Boot Camp marks the newest evolution in its genre. It takes the quintessential elements of reality TV - ignominy and discomfort - and turns up the volume. The contestants are made to suffer simply for applying, and one poor woman wimps out after mere hours in the camp. But it is also packaged much more like a drama, with glossy titles, nippy editing and soaring scenery shots from helicopters.

Where Boot Camp falls down is the contestants. None of them are remotely endearing. Naturally, they are all losers and idiots (who else applies to go on these shows?) but there isn't one of them who you'd like to see win. Not he-of-the-teddy, who says, "I'm Dave Thomson, winner", thus making himself sound like a complete dud; not Meyer, the Nasty Nick of the group; not Haar, a pig farmer from Georgia; not Yaney, a professional balloon sculptor; and certainly not Whitlow, who proclaims, "I don't want to win everything, because then I'm a target. I want to do the little things that I can to be part of the team. When the time comes, you'll see me." We want her strung up like in A Man Called Horse.

Too aware of the camera as an active participant in the show, the contestants are all acting (one is actually an actress), and while it's distracting to see Mean Meyer confess to faking his tears to incite sympathy, it soon wears thin. Now that we - and those who apply for it - know the trick of reality TV, the casting that takes place, the editing that's done, it's not so much fun. The naivety and the novelty is gone, so that reality TV is now just as unreal as anything else on the box. Fingers crossed, then, that next week, they have to swim the alligator-infested lake.

It was most apt that Sian Evans had echoes of Martine McCutcheon about her. As the subject of the wonderfully watchable Faking It (Channel 4), she was to be - in a My Fair Lady stylee - transformed from classical cellist to club DJ in a month. From venturing out to a club in a polo-neck jumper to larging it on the decks with some wicked choons, Sian's transformation was a real joy to watch (and an education if you want to pretend to be someone else). At the end of her month, she had to fool some top DJs that she wasn't a novice. And by Jove, she did it. A big up to her.

From venturing out to a club in a polo-neck jumper to larging it on the decks with some wicked choons, Sian's transformation was a real joy to watch (and an education if you want to pretend to be someone else). At the end of her month, she had to fool some top DJs that she wasn't a novice. And by Jove, she did it. A big up to her.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: La Dolce Vita | Bhaji On The Beach | Solomon And Gaenor
fields.body:
Home Alone 2: Lost In New York
(Chris Columbus, 1992)
12.50pm, 6pm, Sky Premier

You'd think, after the events of the first Home Alone, that young Macaulay Culkin's parents would take better care of him, but no, here they go again, flying off to Bermuda and inadvertently leaving him in New York. What are they like? Once again Culkin is the far-too-clever prey of burglars Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern, both a jemmy short of a full tool kit, in a routine but diverting comedy.

Starman
(John Carpenter, 1984)
12noon, 6pm, Sky Cinema

A surprisingly gentle romantic fantasy from Carpenter, more likely to be found helming crunchy action pics. Jeff Bridges is the space visitor who alters his appearance to that of earthling Karen Allen's late husband and creates an intergalactic love affair in the process. Charming, although the snappy bits of conflict show what Carpenter does best.

Popeye
(Robert Altman, 1980)
4.25pm, Sky Premier

Idiosyncratic even by Altman's standards - a musical romance inspired by EC Segar's comic strip. Robin Williams employs all his madcap talents to put flesh on the cartoon character, who is scouring a brilliantly realised Sweethaven for his missing father, and deep in love with Shelley Duvall's Olive Oyl. Bizarre and watchable, despite too few spinach-fuelled punch-ups, too many Harry Nilsson songs.

La Dolce Vita
(Federico Fellini, 1960)
1.30am, FilmFour

One of Fellini's brilliant extravaganzas, which has Marcello Mastroianni as a provincial hack seduced by the more-sour-than-sweet life of Rome's finest. He is fascinated by a film star (Anita Ekberg) and a rich nymphomaniac (Anouk Aimee). The city is evoked throughout by Fellini's flamboyant imagery.

Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid
(Carl Reiner, 1981)
7pm, The Studio

Hilarious homage to film noir, with Steve Martin and Rachel Ward as Gumshoe and Dame-with-the-Boobs out of their depth in a Los Angeles murder case, and calling in Humphrey Bogart's Philip Marlowe to sort it out. Brilliantly edited, with Martin slipping seamlessly into scenes borrowed from the great noirs of the 40s, swapping quips with the likes of Bette Davis, Barbara Stanwyck and Burt Lancaster.

Bhaji On The Beach
(Gurinder Chadra, 1993)
8pm, Filmfour

Spicy stuff from Chadra in her award-winning debut about a group of Asian women on a day-trip to Blackpool. There's battered wife Kim Vithana; bored newsagent Lalita Ahmed, living fantasies from romantic Bombay movies; Sarita Khajuria's pregnant student; and a pair of boy-mad sisters (Renu Kochar and Nisha Nayar): a mixed bunch, all suffering on account of men. Occasionally funny and perceptive, but there's a hard, unforgiving edge.

Solomon And Gaenor
(Paul Morrison, 1999)
11.50pm, FilmFour

A touching tale of love across cultural barriers in pre-first world war Wales. Ioan Gruffudd is Solomon, a door-to-door salesman who hides his Jewish background when he falls for Gaenor (Nia Roberts), daughter of a chapel-going pit family; the two leads give fine, affecting performances.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Rod Liddle's diary

fields.headline: We're out to get you
fields.trailText: There's a man in Twickenham who believes, with some fervour, that all of Britain's many and various ills are a result of what he describes as "the negro phallus".
fields.body:
There's a man in Twickenham who believes, with some fervour, that all of Britain's many and various ills are a result of what he describes as "the negro phallus".

I think Jews and the communists are involved somewhere along the line, too - but definitely in minor roles. The great, looming evil presence is the negro phallus, which is by itself responsible for pretty much everything. Even - and I won't so much as even try to explain the reasoning - extortionate rates of VAT on consumer durables.

This man writes to the Today programme every now and then - presumably directly after vigorous and restorative bursts of ECT - a two-page, tightly typed exposition of his forceful but flawed socio-political analysis. The letters are always - and this is a give-away - cc'd to a vast army of important people: the Pope, George Bush, Javier Solana, Tony Blair, presenters of Watchdog etc.

He's an extreme example of what appears to be a growing band of gibbering conspiracy theorists. Why are there so many of them around at the moment, staring at their computer terminals with spinning eyes, as they tap out another email to some like-minded loon in Nebraska or Dushanbe? One answer is the medium itself, of course; the internet's maxim could be a parody of Lord Reith's. Madman shall speak unto madman. But maybe there's another reason.

Here are a few conspiracies from the Today files for the last six or seven months.

 The foot and mouth epidemic was started by the government in order to scupper the potentially dangerous May Day march by the Countryside Alliance.

 The foot and mouth epidemic was caused by animal rights activists who stole the virus from a government research laboratory.

 The foot and mouth epidemic was started by Saddam Hussein.

 A senior member of the government has a conviction for sexual abuse, but it's all been covered up by the police and the BBC.

 The fuel protests of last Autumn were contrived by the government to deflect attention from the theory above which was "about to break". (Incidentally, they're always "about to break".)

Most of the above come from the dispossessed Right. At least two have made their way into the papers in some modified form. A couple were mentioned to me by politicians. "It's all about to break, you know", they whispered.

I wonder if the government's obsession with "control" isn't, perversely, to blame for the growing propensity of serious-minded people to half-believe some of this guff.

As any psychologist will tell you, paranoia tends to breed paranoia.

 Rod Liddle is editor of the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

fields.headline: Alec Stock
fields.standfirst: Giant-killer with Yeovil Town who brought success to Leyton Orient
fields.trailText: Giant-killer with Yeovil Town who brought success to Leyton Orient.
fields.body:
Alec Stock's football career, first as player, mostly as manager, will be remembered above all for four things. His success with non-League Yeovil Town, which put mighty Sunderland out of the 1949 FA Cup; his fruitful, resourceful years as Leyton Orient's manager; his brief, unhappy interlude as assistant manager of Arsenal; and his almost equally brief spell as AS Roma's manager.

Stock was a miner's son, born in Peasedown St John, in the Somerset coalfield. After the General Strike, his family moved to Dartford, Kent. At school, Alec became a promising Rugby stand-off half-back, playing soccer in the evenings. When he left school, he worked in a bank, which he detested. Soccer, as an amateur centre-forward, was a consolation. As was cricket. Jimmy Seed, Charlton's manager, watched him score a hat trick in a trial at Tottenham and signed him.

The year was 1936. In 1938, without having had a first team game, Stock moved across London to Queens Park Rangers, a club he was destined to manage. An ankle injury hampered his career. When war broke out, he joined an infantry regiment in which he was commissioned. When it became an armoured regiment, he was promoted to captain, commanding a tank, in which he was wounded in the 1944 battle for Caen. He was sent back to Wales to convalesce.

Married in 1943, his ambition was to become a bookmaker. Instead, his wife persuaded him to answer Yeovil Town's advertisement for a manager. A shortage of personnel persuaded him to play again, now as an inside-forward on Yeovil's notorious sloping pitch.

Yeovil's total wage bill then was a mere £80 a week, but early in 1949 they knocked second division Bury out of the Cup on their helpful slope. Then it was Sunderland, with such stars as Len Shackleton. Stock scored the first goal in a remarkable 2-1 win, although he would later say that the 3-1 win over Bury had given him more satisfaction. Reality intervened when Manchester United beat Yeovil, away from that slope, 8-0 in the next round.

The ebullient little East End shoe manufacturer, Harry Zussman, then brought him to Leyton Orient for what was a memorable partnership. Twice Stock left, twice Zussman would get him back.

Stock patiently rebuilt a struggling third-division (south) club. He signed and developed local amateurs such as Vic Groves and Stan Charlton, who were profitably sold to Arsenal. Twice Orient went all the way to the sixth round of the FA Cup, losing in 1952 to Arsenal.

Stock's tactics were pragmatic and intelligent. A policy of 20-yard passes was followed by one of tight defence, no square balls, and reliance on the zip of the inside-forwards.

"I hate yes men," said Stock in 1956, shortly before joining Arsenal. "I love the boy who comes in and tells me he thinks I'm wrong. He's a man." At Highbury, that didn't quite work out.

The idea was that Stock would prop up and perhaps succeed Tom Whittaker, pre-war trainer, post-war manager of the Gunners, whose team had fallen on mediocre times. Perhaps Stock over-compensated, addressing the Arsenal players aggressively, telling them that 20 of them would be sold. At one significant moment, he told a younger player, Danny Clapton, to go over to two seniors, goalkeeper Jack Kelsey and captain Dennis Evans, with an ashtray and tell them to stub out their cigarettes. The players tapped their ash into the ashtray, and went on smoking.

Soon, to Zussman's delight, Stock was back at Orient, but the following year, he was off again. It began when I received a phone call from Sid Robbins, Orient's chief scout: how could Stock get to Italy? I introduced him to Gigi Peronace, the Calabrian football agent who had just brought off the coup of taking John Charles from Leeds United to Juventus. Peronace convinced Roma that Stock was their man. After a tug of war with Zussman, Roma got their way.

But Stock's task in Rome, always so difficult a football city - although another Englishman, Jesse Carver, had recently flourished as the Roma manager - was overshadowed from the first. Roma had appointed as senior executive, Signor Busini, previously a joint selector of the Italian national team, and a notorious intriguer.

Never at ease under pressure - at the worst times, attacks of asthma would plague him - Stock perhaps intentionally signed his own death warrant on the occasion of an away match - he missed the train to Naples. Busini and other officials picked the Roma team on the previous train, presenting Stock when he eventually arrived with a fait accompli. He refused to sit on the managers' bench and was sacked the same evening.

Back he went to Leyton Orient and Zussman. He went on to QPR (1959-68), Luton Town (1968-72), and Fulham (1972-76), who he memorably took to the 1975 FA cup final, where they lost 2-0 to West Ham. At QPR, with whom he won the League Cup in 1967, he worked harmoniously with a talented coach in Bill Dodgin junior - "Bill's got that lovely head of white hair" - although his contribution at training sessions tended to be marginal. "We'd let him take it for a while," said Dodgin. "Then he'd throw down the whistle and go."

But Stock was a man always highly estimated by his fellow managers. His wife Marjorie died in 1986, and he is survived by his two daughters.

 Alec William Alfred Stock, football manager, born March 30 1917; died April 16 2001

fields.headline: Rupert Nurse
fields.standfirst: The first musician to write big band arrangements of calypso
fields.trailText: The first musician to write big band arrangements of calypso.
fields.body:
Many British jazz fans in the 1950s had their first introduction to world music through the calypsos of Lord Kitchener, which appeared on the distinctive mauve-and-yellow Melodisc record label. These slice-of-life snapshots provided witty commentary on the circumstances of the new Caribbean arrivants, and through his inventive musical arrangements for these songs, Rupert Nurse, who has died aged 90, lifted them from their traditional community function and transplanted them into the modern world.

Nurse was the first musician to write big band arrangements for the Trinidadian calypso. A self-taught musician born in Port of Spain, he spent his early years with his family in Venezuela where he learned Spanish. Returning to Trinidad to complete his schooling, he lived in close proximity to the calypso tent and absorbed the tradition.

For four years he worked as a teacher in Tobago, playing piano in his leisure hours and acquiring arranging skills from a mail-order Glenn Miller tutor. Returning home, he worked for an electronics business learnt the saxophone then, with Guyanese saxophonist Wally Stewart, formed the Moderneers, the first Trinidadian ensemble modelled on American big band lines.

In wartime he played with visiting American musicians, entertaining US workers on the island. This gave him the confidence to write jazz arrangements of calypsos and he persevered in the face of purist opposition.

In 1945, Nurse went to Britain, where modern jazz was just beginning. Playing double-bass, he and guitarist Fitzroy Coleman found work at the Antilles, a black club near Leicester Square where young beboppers met. There, sitting-in was the order of the day and he began to make links with local players of the Ronnie Scott generation. With trumpeter Leslie "Jiver" Hutchinson's all-black band he travelled to Czechoslovakia where they recorded, then worked in Holland with entertainer Cab Kaye.

By 1950, the Windrush generation was making its presence felt. As calypso bands sprang up in response to the new craze, colourful shirts became de rigueur on the bandstand and Nurse put jazz on hold while working with compatriots such as the Latin trumpet specialist Peter Joachim and the superb Fitzroy Coleman.

With Joachim, he appeared in a show starring their fellow Trinidadian, pianist Winifred Atwell, then in 1954 was installed as bandleader at the Sunset in Carnaby Street, one of several popular clubs where American GIs and Caribbeans caroused.

He moved upmarket to another such club, the Sugar Hill in St James's, and as resident bassist there met the redoubtable American jazz pianist Mary Lou Williams, then living in London. With Tony Kinsey on drums, he recorded with her in 1953, their combined efforts providing what the Melody Maker called "just the right sort of sprightly spring for her comely piano".

With Nurse as their talent scout and main arranger, Melodisc set about recording dozens of Caribbean and African artists, most notably Lord Kitchener. He wanted the modern sound around him and asked Nurse, a childhood friend, to provide. Nurse augmented a regular Trinidadian team with other Caribbean musicians, including jazz players such as Jamaican alto saxophonist Joe Harriott, who had proved himself at home in the idiom.

Although he enjoyed playing jazz, Nurse switched to electric piano and organ and worked in nightclubs and restaurants, where he made a better living than more purist musicians. He remained in demand as an arranger and teacher and, ever progressive, was using a computer in his 80s to write out arrangements. In a trio with Guyanese pianist "Gervie" Russell and American drummer/singer Danny Wesley, he played electric bass guitar, and when I interviewed him in 1992, was still alternating between this and his keyboard, driving himself to work and hauling equipment up and down stairs as if he were 40 years younger.

He retired to Arima, Trinidad, where Kitchener introduced him to a new generation of calypsonians, and even after settling into a home for the elderly, continued to write arrangements for his old friend's protégé, the Pink Panther.

 Rupert Theophilus Nurse, bassist, saxophonist, pianist, arranger, born December 26 1910; died March 18 2001

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Surgery for war reporter
fields.body:
Surgery for war reporter

The Sunday Times journalist Marie Colvin yesterday underwent surgery in Sri Lanka after being wounded in fighting between Tamil Tiger rebels and government forces.

Ms Colvin, 44, was said to be stable in a hospital in Colombo after suffering shrapnel wounds when she was caught in crossfire on Monday.

Airport delays increase

Passengers were hit by more delays at British airports in 2000, according to civil aviation authority figures released yesterday which showed 69% of scheduled flights were on time from October to December, compared with 72% in the same period in 1999.

Big winner collects

A punter who won more than £136,000 in the biggest individual payout by Jack Brown bookmakers collected his winnings yesterday. The man, who has asked to remain anonymous, put down a stake of £6.30 on six horses on Saturday. He placed 5p multiple bets on six horses at the bookmakers in Pontycymmer, near Bridgend, south Wales, and five of them won.

Layby attack on woman

A woman who stopped her car in a layby because she was feeling unwell was dragged into bushes and stabbed, police said yesterday. The 31-year-old victim from Sussex alerted police on her mobile phone after the attack on the A259, near Seaford, East Sussex, on Saturday night.

Herb 'no cure for depression'

webTitle: Union urges end to expulsion panels

fields.headline: Union urges end to expulsion panels
fields.trailText: Union members yesterday gave a standing ovation to a history teacher from the secondary school where an allegedly disruptive 16-year-old pupil tried to force his teachers to give him lessons.
fields.body:
Union members yesterday gave a standing ovation to a history teacher from the secondary school where an allegedly disruptive 16-year-old pupil tried to force his teachers to give him lessons.

Dave Carver, head of history at Bonus Pastor school in Bromley, south London, was overcome by emotion as he told the annual conference of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers in Jersey how his colleagues had "put their jobs on the line" by refusing to teach the boy. He said the boy was so disruptive he was considered unteachable.

The union last week won a case brought by the boy's mother in the high court. He had been expelled at the end of the last academic year, and was subsequently reinstated by governors against the wishes of the headteacher. NASUWT members at the school refused to teach him.

The boy, due to take GCSEs this spring, has since been taught by supply teachers at an estimated cost of £600 a week. In a landmark ruling, the judge refused to order the pupil back into mainstream classes.

Mr Carver was yesterday among the delegates who spoke in favour of a motion recommending that independent appeals panels - which can order expelled pupils to be taken back to school - should be scrapped. The motion was approved unanimously.

In the first public comments from someone at the school since the court hearing, Mr Carver made no direct reference to the pupil involved. But he told delegates: "I come from what I thought was an inconspicuous school in south London. Unfortunately, it recently became very conspicuous. I'm proud to represent those colleagues at Bonus Pastor who had their jobs and livelihoods on the line for what they felt in their professional judgment was right.

"I didn't lead them into it - in fact, I followed. There was tremendous unity every step of the way, and I have to commend them for their courage and the wisdom.

"Behaviour management is the key to the education process, we have to realise we are holding the line.

"If that line is breached, it's not one student that goes through it, but one after another. Once you start walking backwards you lose the school."

webTitle: Veterans attend exhibition of submarine history

fields.headline: Veterans attend exhibition of submarine history
fields.trailText: Survivors of an era before submarines became hi-tech nuclear leviathans gathered in London yesterday to witness a tribute to their hardiness.
fields.body:
Survivors of an era before submarines became hi-tech nuclear leviathans gathered in London yesterday to witness a tribute to their hardiness.

Among them was Tommy Gould, one of two men still alive who won the Victoria Cross in the cockleshells of Britain's second world war submarine fleet.

Mr Gould, in his 80s, laboured for nearly two hours clearing two enemy bombs from the deck of HMS Thresher off Crete in 1941.

To clear the second he spent more than an hour in a space less than 3ft wide. He had to crawl through a maze of struts, bollards and ventilation pipes. It took 20 minutes to get into the space - and 40 minutes to wriggle out with the live 120lb bomb cradled on his belly "making funny buzzing noises", he said in an interview. Every moment he knew that, if the craft were attacked again, it would have to dive, drowning himself and a colleague. Or, as he put it with understatement, "we would have been swimming".

Mr Gould was a star among 60 guests of honour yesterday for the opening of an exhibition at the Imperial War Museum to mark the 100th anniversary of the Royal Navy's submarine service.

The exhibition introduces younger visitors to the cramped and perilous vessels of the early and mid 20th century.

They can try out a bunk bed, view ships through a periscope, detect underwater sounds with a hydrophone, climb a mock-up of a conning tower, and operate an escape chamber.

And they will hear of the euphemism used by Mr Gould and his contemporaries for the hundreds of colleagues who died beneath the waves: "He's still on patrol."

Mr Gould still has nightmares of cork fillings showering down from deckhead ceilings on Thresher when enemy depth charges exploded; and rats emerging from ducting and staggering about drunkenly, disorientated by the explosions.

The exhibition runs until September 30.

webTitle: BP prepares answers to Tibet protesters' tough questions

fields.headline: BP prepares answers to Tibet protesters' tough questions
fields.trailText: When Sir John Browne, chairman of BP/Amoco and his board of directors, face shareholders tomorrow at the oil giant's annual meeting, they can expect stiff questioning on the company's $568m (£408m) stake in a controversial gas pipeline across Tibet.
fields.body:
When Sir John Browne, chairman of BP/Amoco and his board of directors, face shareholders tomorrow at the oil giant's annual meeting, they can expect stiff questioning on the company's $568m (£408m) stake in a controversial gas pipeline across Tibet.

But the hardest questions could come from BP itself: a leaked document from the firm tries to answer the most embarrassing queries it thinks might be asked by Tibet supporters - expected to disrupt the meeting - who want BP to sell its shares in China's state oil company, Petro China.

The supporters claim the pipeline has human rights consequences and will further Chinese "economic colonisation" of the province. The company denies it.

The questions BP expects range from the easy: "What is your response to the Dalai Lama's demand that you disinvest?" (answer: "The Dalai Lama has never said he wishes us to disinvest"), to the hostile: "How can you invest in Chinese oppression in Tibet?" ("BP does not invest in oppression, without involvement in China there can be no influence").

It has been widely noted that when the company took its 2% stake in Petro China the deal was organised by the US bank Goldman Sachs, whose European director was Sir John Browne. To the question - "Are you claiming that your chairman played no part in the decision?" - the response is, "He did not". BP's inquisitor is not convinced. "How can you claim to support human rights and invest in Chinese oppression in Tibet?" BP's stock answer is: "We support the UN declaration on human rights."

"Throughout this paper BP avoids addressing the politically sensitive status of Tibet," said Steve Kretzman of Free Tibet International.

It also suggests BP is vulnerable; in the paper the firm says it did not lie about taking part in the pipeline. A Tibet supporter said: "But no one ever accused BP of lying. It suggests they have something to hide."

Last night a BP spokesman said of the paper: "It sounds like an old briefing for senior managers on their travels."
