fields.headline: £20 'profit' for muggers who killed woman
fields.standfirst: Hunt goes on for thieves who ran over costume designer after bag snatch at London station
fields.trailText: Hunt goes on for thieves who ran over costume designer after bag snatch at London station.
fields.body:
The woman who was run over and killed by muggers outside Euston station in London had just £20 cash in the handbag she was trying to retrieve, it emerged yesterday.

Police named the dead woman as Liz Sherlock, 42, a costume designer from Chiswick in west London, who was married with no children.

Mrs Sherlock had worked for 15 years as a freelance designer for television, on programmes including Last of the Summer Wine, a royal variety performance and, last month, the Song for Europe competition for the BBC.

She had just finished working on her first feature film, her husband, Peter, said yesterday.

Mrs Sherlock was killed on Monday outside the station, after being run over by the thieves' getaway vehicle.

She had chased a man who snatched her handbag, but was swept onto the bonnet of the car, to which she clung before being shaken off and run over. She died at the Royal London hospital of multiple injuries.

Mr Sherlock, 48, a computer programmer, was being comforted by relatives at the couple's home yesterday. He issued a statement paying tribute to his wife, whom he married in 1995, describing her as a "5ft 2in bundle of energy". "What Liz did yesterday has surprised none of her friends and family," he said. "It was a typical instinctive response from someone who believed in a sense of right and wrong.

He added: "Naturally I am deeply shocked at the events of yesterday. Words cannot express how I am feeling at the moment."

Detective Inspector Martin Lees, from the Metropolitan police serious crime group, said the woman's handbag had contained around £20 in cash, credit cards and "minor personal effects". The black Mulberry bag has not been recovered.

He said details of the incident remained "sketchy", and appealed for witnesses. In particular, it was still unclear whether the woman had leapt on to the bonnet of the car to try to stop it, or whether the thieves had deliberately driven into her.

DI Lees said officers were examining closed-circuit video evidence from the station, which he expected to "assist greatly" in identifying the muggers.

A postmortem examination was being carried out yesterday at St Pancras mortuary.

Police are seeking a man and a woman, both white and in their 20s. The man had long hair, DI Lees said.

Well-wishers were arriving at the couple's home in west London yesterday. Linda Martin, a former colleague of Mrs Sherlock, had brought a bunch of flowers to pay her respects.

She said Mrs Sherlock's actions in chasing the thieves had been typical of her "strong and courageous" friend.

"She never would have let a mugger take her handbag without a fight, she would have fought to the last," she said. "She wouldn't let people take advantage, because it wasn't in her nature."

Kevin Bishop, editor of mainstream light entertainment at the BBC, who worked with Mrs Sherlock on a recent royal variety performance, paid tribute to his "extremely popular" former colleague.

"Liz will be much missed by all those who worked with her," he said.

"She was a tremendous costume designer who worked so well with the large production teams of the entertainment programmes that she made her speciality."

In 1999 Mrs Sherlock, who worked under her maiden name of Nicholls, gave an interview to a newspaper advising aspiring costume designers.

She described her job as a "huge thrill", saying: "Job satisfaction matters much more to me than the pay, although the job does pay pretty well, bearing in mind the long hours.

"If I didn't love it, I couldn't do it. Once you start, you tend to get hooked."

She paid tribute to her "really understanding" husband, whom she married aged 36.

"This is not really the kind of job for anyone with real family commitments," she said. "I don't think I could afford to have a nine-to-five mentality and children.

"I have a really understanding husband and filming on a Yorkshire moor for six weeks is the best contraceptive in the world."

fields.headline: Two-day-old triplet 'killed by wrong injection'
fields.trailText: A senior house officer at a Liverpool hospital negligently killed a two-day-old baby by injecting him with a drug used to treat epilepsy, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A senior house officer at a Liverpool hospital negligently killed a two-day-old baby by injecting him with a drug used to treat epilepsy, a court was told yesterday.

Kosalakumar Karunaratne, who worked at the Liverpool Women's hospital, is accused of the manslaughter of Adam Teare, a triplet who had been born 11 weeks early at the hospital to Nicola and Keith Teare, of Birkenhead.

The doctor has pleaded not guilty to the charge.

The jury at Liverpool crown court heard that on the night of his death in February last year, Adam was in an incubator in intensive care. However, he was breathing on his own and had been given an 80% to 90% chance of survival.

David Steer QC, prosecuting, said that Dr Karunaratne had just started a night shift at the hospital when he administered the drug. The baby had been due to be given an infusion of caffeine to help his breathing but mistakenly had been given phenytoin.

Mr Steer said: "The defendant is a doctor who it is alleged administered a drug to Adam Teare that should never, ever have been administered.

"The administration of that drug by the defendant amounts to an act of gross negligence such as to render him guilty of manslaughter."

He said the doctor had breached his duty of care to his patient and it was that which had caused the baby's death. The prosecution claims that Dr Karunaratne negligently gave the drug, which is normally used in the treatment of epilepsy or fitting, wrongly believing it to be sterile water.

A nurse noticed from the baby's monitor that his heart rate, breathing and oxygen level had rapidly declined.

His condition was compatible with a large overdose of phenytoin, which interferes with the electrical activity of the heart and can slow it to the point where it fails and resists attempts at resuscitation.

A consultant neonatologist became concerned that the baby had been injected with the wrong drug, and took blood samples which revealed the presence of the drug. The prosecution alleged that, when interviewed, Dr Karunaratne did not accept he had mistakenly injected the drug.

Dr Karunaratne, 36, from Shotton in north Wales, qualified as a doctor in 1991 and had worked at three hospitals before arriving in the UK three years ago.

He was a distinguished student in his native Sri Lanka who had received a commendation as best student.

He became a member of the Royal College of Physicians in paediatrics in September 1999.

He began a six-month posting at the Liverpool Women's hospital on February 2 last year as senior house officer in neonatal paediatrics.

The trial continues and is expected to last for three weeks.

webTitle: Pampers makers pay out after employees 'developed asthma'

fields.headline: Pampers makers pay out after employees 'developed asthma'
fields.trailText: Nappy manufacturers Procter and Gamble last night insisted their Pampers line posed no risk to babies' health as they settled claims of £250,000 brought by six employees who claimed to have developed asthma while working on the production line.
fields.body:
Nappy manufacturers Procter and Gamble last night insisted their Pampers line posed no risk to babies' health as they settled claims of £250,000 brought by six employees who claimed to have developed asthma while working on the production line.

The claimants' solicitor said consumers and workers should be warned of the potential dangers and proper handling of absorbent gelling material, developed by the company in the 1980s to help contain moisture within nappies.

Pauline Chandler, of law firm Pannone and Partners, believed the case was the first of its type, involving workers allegedly exposed to "nappy dust" at the Pampers factory at Trafford Park, Manchester, for up to nine years up to the mid-1990s.

Ms Chandler declined to give the exact amounts agreed for each worker. "Procter and Gamble never admitted either that AGM could cause asthma or that the dust levels to which they were exposed were excessive. Most of the research into the long-term effects of AGM exposure has been conducted within the industry itself."

She added that the results of recent studies "were inconclusive and so far the industry does not appear to accept that AGM can cause asthma".

One claimant, John Pickstone, 56, of Swinton, Manchester, said: "I had no idea that I was exposing myself to danger. My health has suffered as a result of poor communication about the risks involved.

Procter and Gamble said: "Nappies containing AGM are safe to use. Millions are used everyday. Our insurers have [settled] because they believed making ex gratia payments without admission of liability was the sensible course as significant legal bills would be saved."

The nappies' safety had been confirmed in more than 450 studies. The plant operated to high standards and dust levels were well within permitted limits, a spokesman said.

The Pampers website aimed at parents says AGM may get on babies, especially if nappies are heavily saturated.

"It can easily be removed by wiping your baby's skin. This material has a long history of safe use in a variety of products and has been in Pampers for more than a decade. Absorbent gelling material is closely related to ingredients widely used in cosmetics, processing and as binders in medicine capsules."

webTitle: Who will take over the running of the Royal National Theatre?

fields.headline: In the spotlight
fields.standfirst: Who will take over?
fields.trailText: Who will take over the running of the Royal National Theatre?
fields.body:
The field is unusually open. Given that Sam Mendes seems happy to combine a Hollywood career with running the Donmar Warehouse, these appear to be the realistic runners and riders:

Nicholas Hytner A brilliant director, whose previous National successes include The Madness of George III, Carousel and The Cripple of Inishmaan. Has never run a big company, though he learned his trade at Manchester's Royal Exchange and is popular at the National where he is directing The Winter's Tale.

Stephen Daldry Combines artistic daring with great charm, had a big hit with An Inspector Calls, was a great success at the Royal Court and helped get the renovated building off the ground. But, after Billy Elliott, will he want to put a thriving film career on hold?

Howard Davies Another top director whose recent portfolio includes All My Sons at the National, The Iceman Cometh and Conversations After A Burial at the Almeida. Earned his spurs directing new plays at the RSC but has since showed a command of large spaces. Highly talented but an essentially private man.

Jude Kelly Put the West Yorkshire Playhouse on the national map, brought Singin' In The Rain into the Olivier and is an excellent politician and communicator. Has strong support on the NT board but some still consider her a better producer than director: at the National, you have to be both.

Michael Grandage A dark horse. fields.headline: Blast inquiry rules out sabotage
fields.trailText: Human error or a leak emerged yesterday as the most likely cause of the Immingham refinery explosion, after three investigation teams ruled out sabotage at the Conoco plant.
fields.body:
Human error or a leak emerged yesterday as the most likely cause of the Immingham refinery explosion, after three investigation teams ruled out sabotage at the Conoco plant.

Production has been halted as a precaution at the 480-acre site, which provides 8% of Britain's petrol and sends out 200 tankers a day to businesses and filling stations.

Most of the trucks were leaving normally yesterday, with the company saying that there were ample stocks available until refining resumes. All 199 staff reported for duty yesterday, including two who were taken to hospital with mild injuries after the blast.

The plant's general man ager, Tom Mueller, said that it was too early to say when production could resume, with extensive blast damage around the scene of the explosion. A 200ft fireball sent blast waves across the Humber river when liquid petroleum gas and petrol ignited at 2.30pm on Monday.

Fears that petrol prices could be affected were downplayed by City analysts who said that the explosion was a "side issue". Clay Smith, an oil specialist at Commerzbank, said that a US$2.50 increase per barrel since the beginning of April followed a more significant explosion at a refinery in Texas last week and speculation of possible shortages in the US.

The health and safety execu tive, which is working awith teams from Conoco and Humberside police at the Immingham refinery said an account of events was emerging.

A spokesman said investigators looking for explanations were considering human failing, hardware or software systems failing, a leak from a vessel or pipeline which led to a flammable mixture being formed in the air and that finding an ignition."

A spokesman for Humberside police said that foul play and sabotage had been ruled out. Engineers are concentrating on the £50m refinery's saturate gas plant, which separates propane and butane gases.

A survey is being carried out of damage to homes in the area.

webTitle: NHS agency will try to cut errors

fields.headline: NHS agency will try to cut errors
fields.trailText: Hospitals in England are to be forced to report medical errors to a new NHS agency to help cut the thousands of instances of clinical negligence and "near misses" that each year cost £2bn in hospital stays.
fields.body:
Hospitals in England are to be forced to report medical errors to a new NHS agency to help cut the thousands of instances of clinical negligence and "near misses" that each year cost £2bn in hospital stays.

The national patient safety agency, to be set up in July, will consider all "adverse effects" and issue guidance on avoiding such mistakes. The new body will have a separate chairman and chief executive, like the present food standards agency, and will report to the Department of Health.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, said the annual level of 850,000 incidents and errors was unacceptable. "While it is an inescapable fact of life that people make mistakes, there is much we can do to reduce their impact and so reduce risks for patients."

The agency will "be the way in which one patient's bad experience will help hundreds of others", he added.

The system, modelled on procedures used in the airline industry, will encourage staff to report errors under a "no blame" culture and will also offer protection to those who feel threatened by colleagues, through guaranteed whistle-blowing channels. It is designed to replace internal and external inquiries commissioned by government and professional bodies - which can often cover the same ground and be seen as insufficiently independent or open.

Conservatives and the Patients' Association were yesterday holding fire until more details emerged, but the British Medical Association welcomed the move.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultants' committee, said: "Modern health care is highly complex and many accidents or near misses are the result of a chain of events which combine to produce a systems failure. Problems are all the more likely because of the relentless pace at which we all work."

A huge change of working culture was necessary. But he added: "Unless we have some degree of confidentiality and protection for the individual clinician, it will be difficult to succeed in creating a climate in which we can all, genuinely, learn from experience."

The NHS pays out about £400m a year in settlements of clinical negligence claims. Infections acquired in hospitals affect about 100,000 patients, of whom 5,000 die.

fields.headline: Aids on the frontline
fields.trailText: As VSO volunteers we see first-hand the devastating impact Aids is having in Africa. Underresourced hospitals struggle to provide medicines and care.
fields.body:
As VSO volunteers we see first-hand the devastating impact Aids is having in Africa. Underresourced hospitals struggle to provide medicines and care. We see patients with HIV returning over and over again with different illnesses and infections. Some basic medicines are available and do help. But there is nothing to offer those with more serious illnesses and they have to be sent away empty-handed.

The scale and breadth of the epidemic would test even the strongest economies and in Africa people and governments are having to cope with the disease on top of extreme poverty. Here, where clean drinking water is in short supply, expensive drugs are beyond ordinary people's reach.

This is why the court case between 39 leading pharmaceutical companies and the South Africa government, which reconvenes today, is so vital for any country trying to tackle HIV/Aids. As three of the 900 VSO volunteers working in Africa, we urge Tony Blair to publicly support the legitimate right of developing countries to access medicines for HIV/Aids as cheaply as possible. We also call on the pharmaceutical industry to use its power and influence to greater good and allow developing countries to get their medicines from the cheapest source.
Gavin Kay
VSO pharmacist, Ghana
Colin Wylie
VSO pharmacist, Cameroon
Andrew Colclough
Aids adviser, Namibia

webTitle: Letters: More critics of census on the cheap

fields.headline: More critics of census on the cheap
fields.trailText: I am a census enumerator. My delivery allocation is 440 households. I am averaging nine deliveries an hour (Letters, April 16).
fields.body:
I am a census enumerator. My delivery allocation is 440 households. I am averaging nine deliveries an hour (Letters, April 16). So far I have had 10 hours of (necessary) study and training, with more to come. Preparation for delivery eats up further time - each form/envelope has to have four separate numerical codes written on it, as well as a name and address. Follow-up duties run on until late May. We are not even provided with pens, and have to pay for our own identity photographs.

The fee for all this is £318. It will probably work out below the hourly national minimum wage. This is supposedly for important work of a sensitive nature. Don't make me laugh. Census? McCensus.
Gordon Wardman
Harlow, Essex

 When I wrote to you in 1991 to complain that the census form omitted to provide space for place of birth, the then registrar-general (PJ Wormald) wrote in your columns that it was "just one of the many topics we could not fit into a reasonably short census form".

The place of birth of ancestors, found in all previous censuses except 1841, is of immense help to family historians. When our descendants have access in 2101 to the present census, which again lacks place of birth, they will not think kindly of the present registrar-general.

I have already inserted my place of birth on the census, as there is plenty of room beneath date of birth. I urge everybody to do the same - unless they were born in Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogery chwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch.
James Thirsk
Tonbridge, Kent

 Ruby Lescott is right to fear that census-derived statistics may be skewed. I was an enumerator in the last census. My patch in Surrey represented the extremes of affluence and poverty. Many houses, particularly the large ones, were vacant. I noted this. My supervisor reprimanded me, saying that the number of empty properties I had reported exceeded the statistical norm. I had assumed my job was to gather statistics, not confirm them. Ten years on, as the bulldozers trundle into the green belt, some of them are still unoccupied.
Vera Lustig
Walton-on-Thames, Surrey

fields.headline: Pay and pray
fields.trailText: Your article (Decline in churchgoing hits CoE hardest, April 14) misses one crucial point: more and more people are coming to church, but they don't come as congregations, they come as visitors.
fields.body:
Your article (Decline in churchgoing hits CoE hardest, April 14) misses one crucial point: more and more people are coming to church, but they don't come as congregations, they come as visitors. Not just the great cathedrals, nor the Church of England: many churches are adjusting to tourists and pilgrims ("tourists pay, pilgrims pray").

In the Methodist church our historic sites large and small attract many thousands of visitors and the evidence we have is that this is often about finding oases of meaning in a busy and sometimes perplexing world. It would be futile to pretend that this is not an authentic expression of faith.
Peter Forsaith
Convener, Methodist church heritage forum
peterforsaith@forsaith-oxon.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: No stake in the pension

fields.headline: No stake in the pension
fields.trailText: Your otherwise excellent leader on stakeholder pensions (April 7) omits a very pertinent reason for the lack of pension take-up by people on low incomes. Quite simply, it may not be worth it.
fields.body:
Your otherwise excellent leader on stakeholder pensions (April 7) omits a very pertinent reason for the lack of pension take-up by people on low incomes. Quite simply, it may not be worth it.

In 1988 I commissioned the health profile of Stoke-on-Trent, which identified parts of the city where retrospective life-expectancy was less than 65 for men and 70 for women. These findings correlated very well with low levels of wealth. Other surveys (Sheffield, Liverpool) have found similar patterns.

Our society is splitting between those able to retire early on good pensions and those who will die before their normal age of retirement. Low and middle-income people who fail to make pension provision may simply be making a rational allocation of resources.

As long as current health inequalities persist, pension provision will be a matter for the upper and middle classes only. Most poor people do not live long enough for it to be a problem. That is the central issue that the chancellor has failed to address.
Norman Rides
Southampton

 The stakeholder pension is clearly a bad investment for those on low or modest incomes for whom it was intended (Pension posers, April 16). Apparently they would still do better to rely on state provision through the minimum income guarantee. However, this will gradually replace the basic pension with a means-tested benefit. Was this part of New Labour's 1997 election manifesto?
Hugh Crawley
Abingdon, Oxfordshire

webTitle: Letters: I put faith in all my voters

fields.headline: I put faith in all my voters
fields.trailText: Faisal Bodi (Muslim voters get awkward, April 17) is a charming man. I should know, he certainly charmed me and was anything but awkward when I called on him as his local MP.
fields.body:
Faisal Bodi (Muslim voters get awkward, April 17) is a charming man. I should know, he certainly charmed me and was anything but awkward when I called on him as his local MP. But he should know that I knock on doors every week in my constituency, not just when "an election is in the air".

He says that I am being targeted because of my "Zionist associations" by "second and third-generation Muslims whose motivation has less to do with class and race than religion". I understand Mr Bodi disapproves of the fact that I helped bring Jews Free School to the area. It is a charge to which I plead guilty. JFS is an outstanding school that will contribute enormously to local educational provision. But he should temper his criticism: upon being elected I campaigned just as vigorously to get the Islamia school recognised as the first Muslim state school. It too is an excellent local school and I am proud that it was recognised under a Labour government.

Mr Bodi's article does highlight a very real issue about attempts to ghettoise politics in the UK. The second and third-generation Muslims of whom he speaks are British-born British citizens who are interested in politics for very different reasons from their grandparents. Their grandparents may well be intimately connected with the politics of Kashmir or Afghanistan, but to these young British Muslims starting a career and a family in London or Blackburn this is and should be foreign affairs. The politics they are concerned about are jobs and education, health and mortgage rates, just like everyone else.

Of course they are rightly concerned about racism and religious discrimination; and in that, I and the Labour party join with them in common cause. But Mr Bodi should be aware that young Muslims have their own issues and will not simply accept an agenda that is driven by what he calls "co-religionists abroad". I will continue to knock on doors to listen to what all my constituents have to say.
Barry Gardiner MP

 Barry Gardiner did not achieve "a result that was in line with the national defection of Tory voters"; he achieved the largest swing to Labour in the country, almost twice the national average. Barry achieved this by appealing to all sections of the community, along with other Labour candidates. In a previous article Mr Bodi attacked the Labour party for its support of equal opportunities for gays and lesbians and now he attacks Mr Gardiner and Mike Gapes for their "Zionist associations". I think we see where he is coming from and his views on these issues might well find an echo in the modern Tory party. Whether he will receive a warm welcome from Mr Townend is another matter.
Rufus Heron
London

 Islamists such as Mr Bodi are engaged in a vigorous campaign against our secular MPs. They are angry because these MPs are not prepared to go along with their sectarian agenda: support for Islamists against other religious minorities in their constituencies.
Randhir Singh Bains
Ilford, Essex

 Faisal Bodi wants Muslims to vote their religion. Does that apply to Catholics, Sikhs, Anglicans, Jews and Methodists? The entire point of democracy is to allow faith to flourish without religious belief determining the political choice of all citizens. Right-wing Americans and their epigones in Europe believe in a "clash of civilisations" setting up the Muslim world as an enemy. Surely British politics should support a "conversation of civilisations", seeking neither to denigrate nor elevate any faith over another?
Denis MacShane MP
MacShaneMP@aol.com

fields.headline: Days off
fields.trailText: Prior to the Bank Holidays Act 1871, there were only two days in the year on which all employers customarily allowed their workers time off: Christmas Day and Good Friday (Leader, April 17).
fields.body:
Prior to the Bank Holidays Act 1871, there were only two days in the year on which all employers customarily allowed their workers time off: Christmas Day and Good Friday (Leader, April 17). A few enterprises also closed on Easter Monday, Whit Monday and Boxing Day, but the army of clerks in banking and commerce remained at their desks. The reason why Bank Holidays were so called is technical: bills falling due on Bank Holidays were made payable on the day after the holiday. It was never suggested that only bank employees should benefit and the act specifically provides that no person could be made to do anything on a Bank Holiday that s(he) could not be made to do on Christmas Day.

Changing the name would be a pointless waste of parliamentary time. There is already a power to create additional Bank Holidays by order in council and a new holiday in July, proposed by the act's author 100 years ago, would go some way to redress the imbalance with Europe.
Eric Lubbock
House of Lords

fields.headline: Jewish charities face ageing problems
fields.trailText: No other minority in Britain has so many volunteers running organisations for the benefit of its members as does the Jewish community, says a study out today. But the groups could be facing severe problems.
fields.body:
No other minority in Britain has so many volunteers running organisations for the benefit of its members as does the Jewish community, says a study out today. But the groups could be facing severe problems.

Although the Jewish population has declined to 250,000, it still sustains 2,000 charitable, educational, religious and welfare bodies with a combined annual income of £500m, according to the first in-depth examination of the community's volunteer leadership.

But the study, for the Institute of Jewish Policy Research (JPR), warns that Jewish organisations face the same difficulties of recruiting and retaining volunteers, from trustees down, as other parts of the charity sector. And, for Jewry, these problems could become more serious.

Typically, Jewish charities are dominated by elderly male trustees. Of 36 organisations interviewed for the study, many reported extreme difficulty finding younger people to take on the work. In spite of clear recognition of the need for a younger age profile, Jewish organisations were found to have made little headway.

Some respondents said this was because members of the younger generation were less selfless than their parents; others pointed out that more women now had careers to pursue. Religious differences between the ultra orthodox and liberal branches of Jewry had added to the problem.

There is, however, a continuing high level of commitment among Jews to philanthropy - "tzedakah". Trustees were found to put in, on average, between seven and nine hours a week; chairpersons were committing up to two days.

Many were long-serving. But even when fresh blood is found, the study suggests, smooth integration is not always easy: almost 60% of the boards of the surveyed organisations had no formal process for inducting new members; only 30% trained them in their new duties.

Some groups had lightened the trustee's load by creating new positions for paid staff. But the study report, Governance in the Jewish Voluntary Sector, notes that the climate is becoming ever more demanding, with government expecting the voluntary sector to meet more social need.

This makes it particularly hard for Jewish charities, it is argued, because the community - largely middle class - is seen as a critical and demanding client group. In addition, intense competition for funds is leading some Jewish donors to give across the wider charity spectrum.

Although the Jewish population has declined to 250,000, it still sustains 2,000 charitable, educational, religious and welfare bodies with a combined annual income of £500m, according to the first in-depth examination of the community's volunteer leadership. webTitle: Market forces cause failing social care projects to close

fields.headline: Shut or bust
fields.standfirst: As market forces bear down on the social care sector, voluntary agencies are having to think the unthinkable - and close failing projects.  Linda Jackson reports
fields.trailText: As market forces bear down on the social care sector, voluntary agencies are having to think the unthinkable - and close failing projects. Linda Jackson reports
fields.body:
For many voluntary organisations, the idea of closing down projects, abandoning long established working practices and relocating staff is a sign of failure. In short, they are reluctant to take tough decisions that would be considered commonplace in the business world. But a supported housing association in the Midlands believes not to do so is a disservice to those it seeks to help.

With market forces now unleashed in the field of social care, voluntary agencies can ill afford old-style working practices based on a philosophy of "if it ain't bust, don't fix it". Yet in the 1990s, Rob Taylor admits, he typified that approach. As operations director of Adullam Homes, he struggled for five years to keep afloat a flagship residential drugs project until he was finally forced to close it down. He describes it as one of the most difficult decisions he has had to make in his 18-year career in the voluntary sector.

That was three years ago. Since then, Taylor, now chief executive of Adullam, has opened and closed other schemes as the Christian-based association has adapted social rehabilitation projects in response to cuts in budgets and the changing needs of users. It now provides housing with support for more than 700 vulnerable people in the Midlands, the north-west, Shropshire and Merseyside. Among them are ex-offenders, drug users, young care-leavers and people with learning disabilities, mental health problems and HIV.

"Too many charities are paying lip service to market forces and are running projects that no longer meet the community's needs," says Taylor, who admits it took Adullam seven years to embrace the corporate culture. "We are in a new reality. Contracts can be won and lost, and the needs of clients change all the time."

He says Adullam's ethos has always been to provide a resident-focused service, with individual support packages designed to minimise the risk of people regressing into former patterns once they have left the scheme. But he adds: "We have learnt that where projects are faced with diffi culties that may undermine the association's standards for housing and support, we are prepared to close a scheme and seek alternatives that will better serve the community."

Such decisions can cause major heartache. Closing the drugs project in Nottingham was particularly difficult, as it had been launched in a blaze of publicity.

The former farm on the outskirts of the city catered for men, women and their families. It was the only project of its kind in the area. Yet it never had enough referrals from the local health authority. Differences in approach to treatment - the health authority favouring the 12-step technique, while Adullam embraced a range of programmes - did not help matters. On top of this, health officials considered the 12-month treatment programme too long.

Cutbacks were made and the project, which was trying to help the most hardened addicts, was scaled down. Instead of offering a 12-month detoxification programme, the unit moved to a six-month course of treatment. However, cuts to grant money - combined with a shortage of staff of the right calibre - eventually led to the project's closure.

Taylor says: "Psychologically, it was very hard closing the project, even though we lost £250,000 in the time it was open.There were lots of emotional ties to it."

Lessons were learned from the closure, which resulted in the setting up of a formal review process for all Adullam projects every two years. At the same time, clients, staff, funders and referring agencies are asked for their views.

Examples of this more ruthless and realistic approach are recent decisions to pull out of projects in Rugby and Wolverhampton. These schemes provided beds for people rejected by other agencies because of their instability and personal difficulties.

National lottery money was used to build the hostel in Rugby, which was to be managed by Adullam. But problems began shortly after opening, when the local authority refused to pay the rent levels needed to staff the unit effectively.

Colin Heath, the association's regional manager, recalls: "The project was only open for two months when we decided to pull out. On the one hand, we had people expecting us to deliver a service; on the other, we had staff stressed out trying to manage it. The council believed it needed staffing between 9am and 5pm. But staff were saying they needed 24-hour cover because the people in the hostel were so vulnerable. If they left the building for any length of time, there was a risk it would be burnt down."

Adullam withdrew from the project and handed it over to the housing corporation. The project remains open, under new management, but it no longer takes people with such challenging behaviour.

Concerns about inadequate staffing levels lay behind last year's closure of a 24-hour direct access project in Wolverhampton. Set up nine years ago, it was targeted at young people aged 16-25 with drug-related problems, ex-offending backgrounds and mental health needs. Staff gave clients practical help in setting up home, getting jobs, handling crises and maintaining physical and mental health.

Over the years, the project was supported by grants from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions and various trusts. However, when these dried up there was an annual shortfall of £60,000. Clients had also become more challenging and the hostel demanded intensive management. As at Rugby two years earlier, understaffing became a problem, exposing workers to unnecessary risk.

"We had staff saying they were working under siege," says Heath. "There weren't enough of them to prevent the frequent damage to the interior, with residents daubing graffiti on the walls, letting off fire extinguishers and kicking in the doors. Windows were being broken by people from the local community who were having a go at people on the pro ject. The stress was such that the project manager had to take three months off sick."

As yet another attempt to find alternative funding failed, it was decided to close the shelter.

This readiness to embrace change and, if necessary, shut down projects that threaten to undermine the association's standards, has made Adullam a leading player in social rehabilitation. Its workforce has grown from 40 to more than 200 over the past three decades and it has won private finance, enabling it to expand further.

Taylor believes the secret is simple, and urges others to remember the croquet game in Alice in Wonderland, where the rules altered all the time. "We have to stay flexible, have more creative manoeuvring and develop closer partnerships with stakeholders than ever before," he says. "Received wisdom has been that, in business, efficiency and innovation cancel each other out. The challenge is to show they can co-exist. It is a lesson the voluntary sector would do well to learn."

Questions of priorities

Adullam's two-yearly reviews of all its projects are carried out against an audit checklist of the association's published standards for housing and support. Even reviews of successful schemes often lead to a refocusing of the work.

This has been the case with AdCare, a Birmingham-based specialist project set up in 1990, providing more than 50 flats, houses and bungalows sensitive to the needs of men, women and children living with HIV.

Changes in drug treatment, with the introduction of new combination therapies, has led to a switch from a counselling-based service, helping people prepare for a dignified death, to one that examines new work opportunities and offers specialist benefits advice. Help is also given to ensure compliance with the new combination drugs which must be taken at the right time in order to be effective.

The changes followed a questionnaire of clients using AdCare. Many said they were no longer in need of a "high care" service, which offered 24-hour support. Instead, they wanted practical advice to help them get on with their lives.

The accommodation built for the project is scattered across the community. Adullam has deliberately avoided installing disability aids, such as bath hoists, for fear it creates a negative image based on an assumption that clients will inevitably become more unwell. Instead, the accommodation can be adapted as necessary.

webTitle: Critics say a historic doss house's conversion into flats will only add to homeless problems

fields.headline: Posh and shove
fields.standfirst: A historic doss house's conversion into flats is good news for some - but not the ever marginalised homeless of London's east end.  Mark Gould  reports
fields.trailText: A historic doss house's conversion into flats is good news for some - but not the ever marginalised homeless of London's east end. Mark Gould reports
fields.body:
Transforming a century-old former doss house into more than 100 flats in an area with a desperate housing shortage would seem, on the face of it, good news. But critics say that the conversion of Tower House - a brooding, 700-room building in Whitechapel, east London - into £200,000 apartments will only add to the problems of an area with some of the highest levels of homelessness in the country.

Property development is booming in the east end. Workers who want to live just two stops on the Dockland Light Railway from Canary Wharf, and 10 minutes' walk from the City of London, are snapping up factory and warehouse conversions. But this popularity puts more pressure on an area of extreme poverty and high levels of immigration from Africa, Asia and now the former Soviet Union and the Balkans. With fewer empty buildings, the homeless are being forced even further towards the margins.

Tower Hamlets council says that more than 8,500 families are living in overcrowded conditions. The council housing sell-offs of the mid-1980s mean that the authority does not have the housing stock to offer transfers, and families cannot afford the £160,000 cost of a three-bedroom, ex-council flat. In the private sector, Victorian terrace houses have reached the £500,000 mark.

More than 5,000 families are stuck in bed and breakfast "hotels" that cost the council £4m last year. And there are 1,130 homeless people - four times the national average - living on the streets, in squats or in derelict buildings like Tower House.

From 6 o'clock every morning, for 105 years, Whitechapel Methodist Mission has been providing food, clean clothes, basic medical care and temporary shelter to the street people of the east end. It helps 120-150 people a day and has a strict "no beer, no glue, no drugs" policy. Director Tony Miller, who has worked for the mission for 18 years, says the new wave of gentrification is adding to inequality and intolerance.

"Thanks to this government, 'homelessness' is now a dirty word. The gap between the rich and poor is widening. Next door, you have 26 luxury flats. Across the road, you have the old brewery - grade II listed - now luxury flats. The two-beds are £270,000. How many east end youngsters can afford that?"

Matters are not helped by confusion over the numbers on the streets. Last year, an official count found just one rough sleeper in Tower Hamlets. "That's because about 30 of them were in Tower House," says Miller. "Or they were standing outside the tube station with a can of beer, so they weren't classed as sleeping."

The count was carried out by Petra Salva, who heads the government-funded homelessness team covering the east end. Her job is to help people off the streets and into long-term accommodation. Outside her office in the crypt of St Botolph's Church, Aldgate, more than 20 homeless men and one woman gather as dusk falls.

She says the criticism is unfair. "The purpose of the count is only to provide a snapshot, to compare to previous counts. We are aware of the real problem, but many homeless people in Tower Hamlets are invisible. They sleep in places like Tower House, so they are off the streets. For health and safety reasons, we are unable to access derelict sites."

The building boom has forced many rough sleepers even further out of sight, Salva admits. "As the area has become more trendy, it has made the rough sleepers more hidden. There are obvious places where you think they would sleep that are dry, but they sleep in damp clumps of bushes under plastic sheets and even in the rubbish bin shafts at the bottom of tower blocks."

Community activist Jil Cove, one of a group fighting the redevelopment of nearby Spitalfields fruit and vegetable market, says that many of the new wealthy migrants are unaware of the problems around them. "This latest wave of regeneration is being done to the exclusion of local people," she says. "A lot of the incomers seem to have so much money they don't know what to do with it. There are places around here for stressed young executives where you can have five people massage you at once. There is a shop that specialises in scuba diving gear and you can't move for four-wheel-drive Jeeps."

In January, a 35-year-old Ukrainian, Max Kukuyuk, was found dying from multiple injuries on the floor of Tower House's cavernous former television hall. Police initially suspected foul play but now think he fell through a skylight while trying to find somewhere to sleep. Under a deal with the council, developer Greenacre Properties plans to landscape the internal courtyard, where Kukuyuk slipped to his death. The basement will be turned into secure car parking and the domed roofs used as distinctive features for penthouses as part of a £10m rebirth of the historic building.

Keith Meehan, of Greenacre, says the deal includes 30 low-cost homes and another 30 flats for homeless people - although they will be off site, in keeping with the "secure environment" image of the project. Meehan denies perpetuating the inequality gap. "The beauty about these places is that everything is mixed up - you are just yards away from a real social and ethnic cultural mix that gives it character," he says.

"We will be building for the people that are staying in Tower House at the moment. We are certainly not just looking for money out of this. We want to provide for homeless persons and low-cost housing."

But John Aldenton, of the Tower Hamlets-based Environment Trust, which has built some 100 affordable homes using shared equity schemes, feels that the building should be turned into a backpackers' hostel. "There is an argument that if you treat young backpackers well, they come back to the area when they have made their fortunes and reinvest - just as the old philanthropists did."

Stalin slept here...

Joseph Stalin spent a fortnight in a sixpence-a-night cubicle in Tower House in 1907, when he attended the Fifth Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party across the road in Whitechapel Road, which consolidated the supremacy of the Bolshevik Party.

Writer Jack London called it the "Monster Doss House" in People of the Abyss, his 1902 journey through the poverty of London. He said it was packed with "life that is degrading and unwholesome".

George Orwell, in Down and Out in Paris and London, published in 1933, described it as the best of all common-lodging houses, with "excellent bathrooms". Orwell's only objections to the shilling-a-night rent were the "no cards, no cooking" rules and harsh discipline. No one was admitted before 7pm.

Tower House was one of six Rowton houses built in London by the philanthropist Montague William Lowry-Corry, the first Lord Rowton, who was Disraeli's private secretary. His aim was to provide cheap and clean accommodation for the tens of thousands of working men who flocked to London and were forced to live in filthy, disease-ridden common lodging houses. He claimed the houses would be "fit for an archbishop".

The only remaining Rowton house still used as a men's hostel is Arlington House in Camden, north London, also known to its largely Irish population as "The Mickey" or "Dracula's Castle".

His aim was to provide cheap and clean accommodation for the tens of thousands of working men who flocked to London and were forced to live in filthy, disease-ridden common lodging houses. He claimed the houses would be "fit for an archbishop". The only remaining Rowton house still used as a men's hostel is Arlington House in Camden, north London, also known to its largely Irish population as "The Mickey" or "Dracula's Castle".

webTitle: Rumours lead to attacks on supported housing scheme

fields.headline: Lies and whispers
fields.standfirst: Rumours lead to attacks on supported housing scheme
fields.trailText: Rumours lead to attacks on supported housing scheme
fields.body:
A model supported housing scheme for people who have had mental health problems has become the target of attacks that have put back its opening. Rumours circulating in the area wrongly suggest that the development is to house paedophiles.

The seven-flat complex with communal facilities in Abbey Wood, south London, is designed for people who want to live independently but with a degree of practical support. The £600,000 scheme has been developed by the Bailey housing association. Residential support worker Andrew Grieve and his partner, Jackie Henery, moved into one of the building's flats in March to prepare for the scheduled arrival this month of the first tenants.

Grieve, who is a coordinator of charity Mind in Bexley, says the building has since come under "repeated attacks" from local young people, with scaffolding, rocks and glass thrown into the garden. Youths have broken in, causing extensive damage to the front door, and run amok inside. Henery has been verbally intimidated when near the building.

Grieve is concerned that local residents are grossly misinformed about the purpose of the building, with rumours that it is for "perverts". He is now working closely with the local Bexley council, residents' associations, local youth groups and the area's Methodist minister, putting out a strong message that the facility is for people who have experienced mental ill-health - including anxiety and depression - and are beginning the process of rehabilitation.

Bailey says it is determined to make the scheme safe and successful. It has increased security at the site, installed a secure front door, and additional closed-circuit security cameras are planned.

Tony Morgan, Bailey's projects manager, believes the problems are linked primarily to certain groups of local youths. He is confident that local residents will be reassured once the tenants arrive and it becomes evident that they present no community threat.

"It's an unfortunate fact that we do get some local resistance to many of the supported housing schemes that we build," says Morgan. "The general community in Abbey Wood has actually been quite supportive and the local social services and housing departments are fully behind the scheme. We are working hard to put right any misconceptions."

Bailey has also agreed, in conjunction with the Bexley authorities, that the tenants will move in on a phased basis, starting now in mid-May, allowing Grieve to give them maximum individual support. Bexley social and mental health services will keep the tenants' original housing vacant for a limited period in case they need to return.

Grieve remains concerned. "However secure the property is made, some residents may still feel unsafe when they set foot outside in that neighbourhood," he says. "It is a sad situation when lack of understanding means the security of the building being upgraded, although it will house members of the public who pose no risk and whose only wish is to settle in to the community and live a normal life.

"It is possible the stigma and discrimination of mental ill health could threaten the building being the final stepping stone it was planned to be for people who deserve a fair chance in life."

fields.headline: Focus on fun
fields.standfirst: The Guardian/Volunteers' week photographic competition
fields.trailText: The Guardian/Volunteers' week photographic competition
fields.body:
Each of the 22m adults who carry out voluntary work is a potential subject for the annual photographic competition run by the National Centre for Volunteering and the Guardian. The 2001 competition, launched today, challenges amateur photographers to submit pictures that show the essence of volunteering in action.

Judges will be looking for pictures that capture both the spirit and, particularly, the diversity of volunteering. The winner will receive two British Airways Club Europe tickets; two runners-up will each get £50 vouchers donated by WH Smith. Winning pictures will be published in the Guardian.

"Volunteering means so many things to different people," says Samantha Sherratt, head of communications at the volunteering centre. "The breadth of what the photos could show is immense. We hope they will challenge the worthy stereotype of volunteering that makes people think: 'It's not for me.' There's a role for everyone which fits their interests, where they are and how much time they've got.

"Pictures should reflect that volunteers often get more out than they put in. We need volunteers to be drawn from a wide pool of people to reflect the different experiences and diversity of customers and service users - and to bring fresh approaches."

The centre is about to launch a website for volunteer organisations, which aims to help them assess the diversity of their teams and address any deficit.

The competition will be judged by the Guardian's picture editor, Eamonn McCabe, British Airways community relations manager Carolyn Smith, and Fiona Shadbolt, head of volunteers' week. The closing date is May 25. The winners will be announced during volunteers' week - June 1 to 7 - which involves about 17,000 organisations each year. The week aims to recognise, reward and recruit volunteers.

The centre has also launched a campaign to encourage MPs and celebrities to volunteer during the week. To date, 90 have signed up. Sherratt hopes the looming general election will encourage others to come forward - especially as political leaders including Tony Blair, William Hague and education secretary David Blunkett have been singing the praises of volunteers.

Rules of entry

 The competition is open only to non-professional photographers. You may enter up to two photographs (black and white or colour).

 Entry forms from: Photographic Competition, National Centre for Volunteering, Regent's Wharf, 8 All Saints Street, London N1 9RL. The forms must be clearly filled in using block capitals and attached to the entry with a paper clip.

 Provide two clear copies of each photo, and send them to the National Centre for Volunteering.

 Closing date is May 25, 2001.

 Entries not accompanied by a signed entry form cannot be included in the competition.

 Photos must clearly show volunteering in action.

 Photos must have been taken in the previous year and not previously published.

 The organisers reserve the right to free reproduction and exhibition of all entries, with acknowledgement of the photographer where possible.

 Photographs cannot be returned.

 A panel of judges will choose the winning and commended entries. This decision is final and no correspondence will be entered into.

 The winner and commended entrants will be notified by June 5, 2001.

 The winning entry and a selection of commended entries will be published in the Guardian on June 6, 2001.

webTitle: The changing face of Britain's network of seafarers' missions

fields.headline: Angels of Mersey
fields.standfirst: Britain's network of seafarers' missions is having to trim its sails in the face of economic pressures. But their chaplains are as determined as ever to provide comfort and aid.  Chris Hulme reports
fields.trailText: Britain's network of seafarers' missions is having to trim its sails in the face of economic pressures. But their chaplains are as determined as ever to provide comfort and aid. Chris Hulme reports
fields.body:
A Russian sailor paces the reception of the Stella Maris seafarers' mission in Liverpool. He looks troubled and a long way from home. The previous night, he was attacked by his captain. The police took the victim to a mission because there was nowhere else to help a stranded mariner.

The world's first seafarers' mission opened in London in 1853. Today, missions are part of maritime culture worldwide. Some offer accommodation; others are more of a social club. But they all act as a base for the chaplains and volunteers who do the unsung work of maritime welfare.

It is a valued service, but it is under threat. Changes in shipping since the mid-1980s have squeezed missions into an awkward position: there has been a drastic decline not only in the number of seafarers but also in the number of days that ships spend in port. At the same time, though, the need for a welfare safety net for those people who work at sea has never been greater.

Shipping has more than its share of companies with industrial relations that leave a lot to be desired; and the fact that 80% of seafarers now come from the developing world has only encouraged exploitation. These days labour is sourced from where it is cheapest - and that means so-called flag of convenience states, such as Panama, where the transport authorities are notoriously lax. Abuses ranging from non-payment of wages to dangerous working conditions are commonplace.

For all that, changes in shipping are making it almost impossible for welfare centres to support themselves financially. The income they derive from selling beer, shampoo, phone cards and other small comforts is drying up. As a result, Britain's network of missions is facing the biggest upheaval in its 150-year history.

"Given the quicker turn-round of ships in ports, one has to ask whether there's a need for large seafarer centres on the waterfront," says Timo Lappa lainen, of the London-based International Transport Federation (ITF), a grouping of trade unions. This year the ITF will donate £600,000 to British missions. It wants better value for its grants and is encouraging the movement to re-evaluate how it operates. In some ports this could mean closing a mission and running mobile ship-visiting services. In others, it might mean pooling resources - which again could mean closures.

"It's very challenging for people because the mission building is a physical symbol of their presence at the port," says Lappalainen. "But the mission need not necessarily be a particular address - it's the work, it's encountering seafarers."

Christian churches operate some 90% of missions worldwide. In this country, the three main providers are the Anglican Missions to Seafarers, which has a network of Flying Angel clubs; the Catholic Apostleship of the Sea, operating Stella Maris centres; and the British and International Sailors Society (Biss), which has clubs representing the Methodist, United Reformed and Scottish churches. At a handful of ports, chaplains from separate denominations have overcome obvious religious differences and started to work together under the same roof. Joint centres have opened at Avonmouth, Felixstowe and South Tees, defeating contentious issues such as whether they should have a condom machine in the toilets.

Liverpool, which still has separate Anglican and Catholic missions, plus a Biss club on the Wirral, is typical of a port that is only just beginning to face change. "We rely heavily on donations," says Roy Paul, 42, assistant chaplain at Liverpool's Anglican mission. "We're surviving by cashing in investments from the sale of a building we used to own in the city centre, but that source will run out."

The Anglican mission amounts to a homely bar, the centrepiece of which is a karaoke machine and a guitar - singing being a popular form of entertainment with Filipino crews, who account for 60% of the seafarers visiting Liverpool. There is also a chapel. As with missions the world over, this is open to people of "all faiths and no faith".

With his bushy black beard, Paul looks like a merchant seaman. He grew up in Immingham, on the Humber, and used to accompany the local reverend on ship visits. He now occupies a role somewhere between entrepreneur, civil rights activist and pastoral carer.

He recently stepped in to help a Filipino boy crushed by a container - persuading the shipping company to fly the boy's family to Britain, and also sorting out legal representation to ensure fair compensation. He describes a run-in with a captain who was trying to leave port: "A member of his crew, a Russian man, had just been taken to hospital with a serious head injury. The hospital asked me to find an interpreter - and quickly." Using a mixture of stubbornness and moral authority, Paul persuaded the captain to stay. It cost the ship's owner some £10,000 in pilot fees and additional port charges.

We visit the Dynamic, a Panama-registered bulk carrier unloading foul-smelling animal feed. Faces light up when we enter the crew's mess. The ratings, all Filipinos, have just made an 18-day transit from New Orleans. The ship is 21 years old and has a Greek captain, with Romanian and Ukrainian officers. The Filipino ratings say the vessel is well maintained, but the interior is as grim as a rundown factory. Apart from the spartan mess, the crew has a room with a pool table - crudely improvised from white laminated wood - and a dartboard.

Paul and his assistant, Sean Draper, work their way around the mess, chatting and answering questions. "Fresh faces are always welcome," says Paul later. "There's only 25 of them and it can be a bit like being in prison - they run out of things to talk about. Some don't even want a lift to the mission - they prefer to walk because they have been in a confined space for such a long time."

The ITF has commissioned a study into the future of shipping in Liverpool. It is thought it may recommend a joint Anglican/Catholic centre.

"As far as seafarers' welfare is concerned, we already work together very closely," says Paul. "The Stella Maris does have accommodation; we don't. If we need a room for someone, we send them over. I don't know what will happen in the future. We are not attached to this building. It's just a tool that allows us to do our job. If we have to move, so be it."

There is a greater emotional investment in the Stella Maris - a purpose-built centre that dates from 1962. It feels cold and sterile but its facilities include a canteen, 35 bedrooms, a chapel and a function suite. As Father Pat Harnett, who has run the mission for nine years, points out, the Stella Maris is a monument to the generosity of locals. "This building was paid for by the pennies of the poor," he says.

"There's a case for pooling resources," says Harnett. "I wouldn't have any objections sharing this building, but I don't think something should be imposed from on high. Leaving to go elsewhere would certainly be a wrench - there's the investment of two generations here. But we have to realistic.

"I want to see as much work at grassroots as possible, so that whatever happens evolves naturally. It doesn't always work when you bring two associations together who have different backgrounds. I think it can depend very much on the chaplains in charge at the time - and there's a weakness in that. We do as much as possible. Liverpool used to be like Belfast. It's much better now, but there is still work to be done."

A haven of help amid disaster

Most of the crew of the Derbyshire, the largest British merchant ship lost at sea, came from the north-west of England. The ship sank off Japan in 1980 with the loss of all 44 people on board. The bereaved families were helped by the British International Sailors Society (Biss), which has a club in Birkenhead. The Biss operation, then and now, really amounts to one man - the Rev Peter McGrath, who drives a battered van and spends his days visiting crews on the Wirral side of the river Mersey.

McGrath supported the Derbyshire families during their 20-year battle to get an investigation into how a ship, which was almost three times the size of the Titanic, could sink so quickly that the crew did not have time to send a distress call. This campaign finally yielded results last year when a high court judge ruled that the crew was blameless - and that the pride of the British merchant fleet was ill-equipped to survive the typhoon seas it encountered.

"He's a remarkable man," says Paul Lambert, of the Derbyshire Families Association, whose brother died in the disaster. "Peter has been a source of strength and comfort since the day we heard they had lost contact with the Derbyshire. I've lost count of the times I've rung him and found he's out visiting some ship at all hours, taking on board books, food, videos, and just being a friendly face for the crew. I know it's his job, but he goes way beyond the call of duty."

webTitle: Care home places falling - but sector is not in a tailspin

fields.headline: Counting the losses
fields.standfirst: Care home places falling - but sector is not in a tailspin
fields.trailText: Care home places falling - but sector is not in a tailspin
fields.body:
Almost 10,000 places in care homes for elderly and disabled people were lost last year, according to figures released today by leading sector analyst Laing & Buisson (L&B). As many as 760 private and voluntary care homes closed during 2000, but the rate of closure did not accelerate - contrary to warnings from the care home sector itself that it was going into a tailspin.

L&B calculates that the independent sector (private and voluntary homes) lost a net 7,300 places, or 1.6% of total capacity. It suggests that the government will "take comfort from the fact that the percentage is not higher than it is".

Care home proprietors have complained that they are struggling to keep going on rates paid by local authority social services departments for state-funded residents. Some homes are said to manage only by cross-subsidising such residents from higher charges levied on people paying their own way.

The new figures, published in L&B's Community Care Market News, show that closures last year amounted to 16,200 places in the independent sector and 2,500 in local authority homes. But 145 new homes opened and 150 repositioned in different markets, leaving a net loss of 9,700 places.

Although the closure rate nationally may have been exaggerated, and the sector may previously have had spare capacity, L&B says there is a growing number of "hot spots" with acute shortages - mainly south of a line from the Severn to the Wash.

Community Care Market News is on 020-7923 5398.

webTitle: Profile:  Steven Tindale, Greenpeace UK's new executive director

fields.headline: Mind over mutter
fields.standfirst: Steven Tindale, Greenpeace UK's new executive director, is a different kind of leader. By  John Vidal
fields.trailText: Profile: Steven Tindale, Greenpeace UK's new executive director, is a different kind of leader. By John Vidal
fields.body:
Lord Melchett he ain't. Unlike his predecessor, Steven Tindale, Greenpeace UK's new executive director, has no hereditary peerage, no acres to till, no experience as a Labour government minister - and he has spent only one night in prison (after a demonstration in Brussels).

Then again, Tindale is no Swampy either. He is a former civil servant and has certainly not lived down a tunnel to stop a road being built.

Tindale, 38, takes over the 200,000-member operation with none of the qualities usually associated with leadership of Britain's most charismatic mainstream environment group. His style is described by colleagues as "passion masked by coolness" and "bright and calm". In more than 15 years, he has moved between the Foreign Office, Friends of the Earth, the Green Alliance, think-tanks, the Labour party and government, quietly building a reputation for rigour, political intelligence and level-headed determination.

His appointment suggests that the organisation, which hangs on to its reputation as the least afraid of upsetting corporate and establishment applecarts, will think a lot, be politically astute and may move into areas that mass membership groups have barely considered for almost a generation. Such as disarmament, an issue he says he has been passionate about since his early days with CND.

"It was my first point of activism. It's essential for us to get more active here," he says. The idea of President Bush's revamped Star Wars nuclear "shield" around the US, with Britain as an essential listening post, appals him on every level. "The UK has a crucial role to play", he says. "We can stop it happening. It would be ludicrously weak for Blair to just give in."

So watch out, Ministry of Defence, watch out Fylingdales listening station, and beware New Labour, because Tindale has an intimate knowledge of how the firm and the civil service thinks and acts. He was author of Labour's 1994 In Trust for Tomorrow, which formed the basis of its environment commitments in the 1997 general election manifesto and helped develop Britain's ambitious climate change strategy, as well as the transport white paper, the right to roam and the green tax proposals which Chancellor Gordon Brown has largely accepted.

More dramatically, Tindale was midwife at the political rebirth of environment minister Michael Meacher. As his adviser from the moment he took office, Tindale was instrumental in his understanding of the complex social, political and scientific issues of GM, climate change and a host of other issues. He has not looked back since.

"Working in government was an important experience," he says. "I know my way round and how it works. But I also understand the limits of polite and rational politics. You can only get so far with them."

He left, he says, because of the "powerful vested interests" that shape government.

But Tindale, a polite and rational man, was briefly a junior diplomat (third secretary, Islamabad) and will not say precisely who pulls the lever of government process. What he will say is that there is "a mindset" in politicians of both major parties and especially the civil service, which accepts that business is always right and that the status quo must be maintained.

There is a limit to logic and rational argument, he suggests. "What I realised after 10 years of working in policy-making was that it was not going to get us very far because of the strength of the status quo and the small mindedness of politicians. The voices that the politicians and civil service hear are those of big business. You have the odd, unusual minister, but the mindset is powerful."

He has been described as a "policy wonk", which is misleading, and he promises that Greenpeace will not give up its confrontations or direct actions, nor its mix - developed under Melchett - of high-profile, carrot-and-stick methods. So the balance between identifying the culprits and offering industry and government solutions will continue. He wants Greenpeace to be fearless and, though he does not say it, seems prepared to lead from the front.

"Greenpeace will never be part of the establishment", he says. "We engage with government as well as business, but it's not an alternative to confrontation and direct action. The remarkable thing about Greenpeace is that ministers and companies feel they need to talk to us, despite being in confrontation with us."

He takes over in the middle of the worst rural crisis in a generation, after the worst floods in years, a fuel and rail crisis, the US shredding the global climate agreement, large-scale GM test trials and unprecedented deforestation, mining and destruction in the developing world. But he remains certain that something can be done.

"This is probably a fairly positive time for environment groups," he says. "But we need to remember that it is nowhere near the top of the political agenda. I don't think it's a cynicism in government, so much as a patronising dismissal of the issues. They just don't see environment as serious politics.

"But it's a self-fulfilling prophecy. The politicians say that they don't think the environment is very important; so the focus groups don't mention it; so the politicians don't talk about it.

"At the same time, there is a sense of fatalism with the public, because the politicians don't act."

Tindale aims to make a mark, but quite how he will change the world remains to be seen.

webTitle: Initiative to stop child behavioural problems escalating

fields.headline: Early warning system
fields.standfirst: Initiative to stop child behavioural problems escalating
fields.trailText: Initiative to stop child behavioural problems escalating
fields.body:
Reece is only eight years old but is already severely depressed. He seems preoccupied with death and is worried his mother might die if he leaves her. Some mornings he throws a tantrum when she drops him off at school.

The frightening thing is that Reece is not alone. Recent figures show that one in 50 children of primary school age is so depressed that they need to see a specialist child psychiatrist.

When Reece told his mother he had tried to kill himself with a can opener, she realised they needed help. The school put her in touch with Leicester's child behaviour intervention initiative (CBII), a pilot scheme bringing together experts from social services, education and health. Their aim is to prevent behavioural difficulties in young children escalating into mental health problems.

"If you get in early, you offer support before problems arise, and the outcomes for children are improved," says Jayne Nash, an educational psychologist working with Reece and his family.

Despite having suicidal thoughts at such an early age, Reece is actually one of the lucky ones. He is among 800 children under age 12 who have been picked up by Leicestershire's early intervention schemes. It is widely acknowledged by mental health professionals that if you catch a problem early, you can sort it out with fewer resources. If you intercept a child at three, you might address it in a few weeks; at eight, it might involve several months. If you do not intervene until 10 or 11, it might be five years of treatment - and in some cases it might already be too late.

Nicola, now 15, received no such early intervention. "I was abused at four, I think the first one was; and if someone had tried to help me then . . . but no one came to help me, you know things just got worse when I was growing up." At 10, Nicola went into foster care. At 13, she started to hear voices and, after threatening to commit suicide, was admitted to Oakham House in Leicester, one of the few residential child psychiatric units in the country.

Within months, Nicola had deteriorated so much that even Oakham House could not manage her violent and abusive behaviour. She ended up in a secure unit, where she spent over a year.

Nicola is now in a care home, and making progress. But she still takes medication three times a day: an anti-depressant, an anti-psychotic and a mood stabiliser. And when she gets angry, anxious or feels out of control, she slashes her arms. "You just want to do something to get rid of all your anger and built-up aggression and tension," she says, "so you just get something and cut away at yourself."

With two in three children in care having an identifiable mental health disorder, Nicola is just one of thousands across the country in desperate need of attention. This rising number of children in crisis is placing a huge strain on an already over-burdened, under-resourced child and adolescent mental health service.

Neil Hemstock, clinical nurse manager at Oakham House, has seen a marked increase in acute admissions to psychiatric facilities since the early 1980s. He says: "A lot of these issues are going unidentified and they go on then to develop into chronic mental health problems, personality disorders and relationship problems which cause kids to come into trouble with the law. If there were systems in place that could identify these problems at an early stage, they could be resolved and these young people could go on to develop in a normal way without having the need for adult mental health services."

One in five children is now reckoned to have some form of mental health disorder and at least 5% of teenagers are seriously depressed. This is forcing early intervention on to the agenda. Yet the Department of Health has just failed to confirm the third year of funding of a ring-fenced three years of core funding for children's mental health, seriously threatening projects like CBII.

So what will this mean for Reece? Will he grow up to become another problem teenager? For Nicola, who is likely to need continued psychiatric treatment throughout her adolescent years, intervention - when it came - was already too late.

Julia Black's film, which includes Reece's story, can be seen on Channel 4 News tonight at 7 pm.
